name: Președintele. –
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the report of Mrs Anna Záborská, on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality on the application of Directive 2006/54/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 July 2006 on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in employment and employment (2014/2160(INI)) (A8-0213/2015).

name: Anna Záborská
text: Rapporteur. – Let me begin by thanking the shadow rapporteurs and members of the Committee on Women's Rights for their cooperation. Although we did not always have the same view of the matter, I felt that we were united by the desire to improve the position of women in the labour market.  Three years ago, this House adopted our colleague Edit Bauer's report on the principle of equal pay for men and women for work of equal value. This report contained a list of specific recommendations to the Commission to improve the position of women in employment. But three years have passed and almost nothing has changed. That is why, in my report, I focused on four things that seem crucial to me. Firstly, to introduce a clear definition of work of equal value in all Member States. Secondly, to improve women's access to justice. Thirdly, the motivation of employers. Fourthly, the call on the Commission to take all these requirements into account in the proposal for a new directive, which would replace the existing one and place higher demands on the Member States. The concept of equal work or work of equal value has so far only been introduced in 12 of the 28 Member States. In most of them, it takes into account skill, effort, responsibility and working conditions. Since the voluntary implementation of this concept has not produced the expected results, I propose that it be compulsory in all Member States, which will also contribute to deepening the freedom of movement of labour in the European Union. These are in particular paragraphs 8, 9, 10 and 11. The definition of work of equal value is complemented by the obligation for employers to define jobs neutrally, i.e. so that they do not overfer both men and women as candidates. Such a requirement may require greater sensitivity, but it certainly does not represent an additional administrative burden. As regards women's access to justice, I propose strengthening anti-discrimination offices or trade unions in the Member States and extending their competences, even so that they can offer women not only legal advice, but also representation before the courts in discriminatory disputes. It is precisely the lack of legal awareness and the financial situation that prevents many women from doing justice. When I talk about the motivation of employers, I am thinking, in particular, of the recommendation in paragraph 37 that companies that fail to fulfil their obligations in the field of equality between men and women should be excluded from public procurement of goods and services financed from the European Union budget. I would like to stress that this is not a sanction, but an incentive. Those who want to apply for European contracts must create a level playing field for both the men and women they employ. Ladies and gentlemen, the duty of equal treatment has been enshrined in the Treaties of the European Union for almost sixty years and it is our responsibility for every employer in the European Union to respect it. We have seen stagnation in recent years. It is time we finally overcame it and moved on.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of my colleague Commissioner Věra Jourová, I am here for this debate. Thank you for this important report and in particular my thanks to Ms Záborská.  Tackling pay discrimination – tackling the gender pay gap – is an important commitment for the Commission. It is a real priority and it has been for a very long time. But, as your report reminds us, we still have work to do. Let me highlight at the outset that this is not only about fairness: it is also an economic issue. Reduction of the gender pay gap is an investment in the future of the Union. There needs to be better use of women’s skills to allow them to contribute more to the economy as a whole. There are clear benefits to this: improved recruitment and retention; reduction of skills mismatches; an increase in motivation and productivity; improvement in a company’s image; and an increased female employment rate.  The gender pay gap has numerous complex causes. Occupational and vertical segregation, and lower rates of female participation in the labour market are all relevant factors. It is also key to encourage a more balanced sharing of family responsibilities between women and men so as to reduce the persistent gender pay and pension gaps. Equal pay legislation is an important part of the solution but the broader mix of law and policy is equally relevant, at both national and EU level. Closing the gender pay gap therefore needs a comprehensive approach with both legislative and non-legislative action. It requires the efforts and commitment of all players – decision makers at EU and national level, as well as stakeholders.  Effective application of the existing EU legal framework on equal pay is crucial for tackling pay inequality. I fully agree with you that this remains one of the biggest challenges. The Commission is therefore monitoring constantly whether EU law on equal pay is being correctly applied, and it supports Member States and other stakeholders with the proper enforcement of the existing rules. Two years ago, the Commission published a report reviewing the application of the Gender Equality Directive (Recast). This demonstrates to stakeholders what is required for more effective application of the existing legislation, with practical guidance on gender-neutral job classification systems so as to assist Member States and employers in bridging the gender pay gap.  Moreover, last year the Commission adopted a Recommendation on Pay Transparency. This provides Member States and stakeholders with a toolkit of concrete measures to tackle pay inequality and the gender pay gap.  Pay transparency and gender-neutral job evaluation, and evaluation systems in companies, are crucial because they reveal gender bias or discrimination in the pay structures of a company or industry. They support employers and social partners in taking concrete action to ensure the effective implementation of the equal pay principle.  By the end of this year, Member States should notify to the Commission the national measures they have taken in accordance with the Recommendation. We will closely assess the situation and we will prepare a report on progress made in implementing the Recommendation. On that basis, we will assess the potential need for additional measures. We will look specifically at measures to tackle pay discrimination, to ensure equality in occupational pension schemes and to strengthen the implementation and enforcement of the legislation. The core task of national equality bodies is to promote equal treatment, and to provide independent assistance to victims of discrimination. Strengthening their role would improve enforcement in general, in particular in relation to equal pay. Effective, proportionate and dissuasive sanctions are crucial to provide a strong incentive for compliance with equal pay rules and to guarantee enforcement. Let us look at the bigger picture. We have also recently announced our plans for a new initiative in the area of work-life balance. We intend to support working parents and carers across the EU – to strike a better work-life balance, and to encourage more equal sharing of care responsibilities between women and men. This initiative will help women to remain and advance in the labour market and thereby to tackle, over the longer term, the gender pay and pension gaps.  As well as legislation, the Commission is also undertaking a number of policy and awareness-raising actions to address the gender pay gap. We are currently funding eight multi-national projects, worth around EUR 2.5 million, which tackle different aspects of the gender pay gap in a concrete and targeted manner.  The Commission will mark European Equal Pay Day on 2 November this year, to make the gender pay gap plain and explicit for all Europeans and to draw attention to the fact that a pay gap still exists between men and women. This is the day when women symbolically stop earning and work for free for the rest of the year.  Honourable Members, again, thank you for this report. The progress we are making is clearly not fast enough. We need to work together to ensure that everyone steps up their efforts on this issue.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – First of all, I would like to stress that the Directive on equal opportunities for women and men at work and on the labour market is indeed difficult to implement in the Member States. Therefore, this directive should be reviewed urgently, because we really must tackle the long-standing problem of unequal pay for women and men for the same work. Because this is the greatest violation and non-compliance with the principle of gender equality. As rapporteur for the opinion in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I therefore call on the Member States to implement the Commission recommendation on strengthening the principle of equal pay for men and women by increasing transparency as effectively and actively as possible. Secondly, I would like to remind you that there is a continuous sectoral breakdown of jobs in the labour market. And women usually work in sectors with lower salaries, illegal jobs, precarious jobs, such as domestic work, nannying, care for sick people. These are very difficult jobs, but are still undervalued and low-paid. Finally, I would like to call on the Commission to declare a European year for combating the gender pay gap.

name: Constance Le Grip
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, it is clear that, despite the efforts made - and the European legislative arsenal on gender equality, in particular equal pay, there has been a good deal in recent years that the reduction of wage inequalities and the fight against wage discrimination against women in the labour market have stagnated. So we can't remain inert. We need to look at being more effective, more credible in order to achieve results. That is what our citizens expect.  I welcome the work of our colleague, Anna Zuborsk, who, in a very honest, precise and comprehensive way, takes stock of the application of the 2006 directive, points to the shortcomings and shortcomings and, above all, proposes concrete and operational action. Again, we need to be precise and come up with concrete solutions. She sketches several tracks.  We must not refrain from thinking about sanctions to make the imperative of reducing wage inequality truly credible in our European companies. We must consider, very seriously, with certainly in-depth studies, to be able to distinguish between, on the one hand, the real cases of discrimination against women, which are absolutely intolerable, unjustifiable and incomprehensible, given the mess that this represents and the female potential which is thus flouted and set aside, and, on the other hand, the too many obstacles, glass ceilings and other obstacles to the progression of women. It is time to act.  We are all waiting for the European Commission to come up with a proposal for a legislative overhaul, which we will support.

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, yes, we are here today, assessing - which I understand to be very important - the report by Mrs Záborská, whom I congratulate on her breadth of view, even though she has had to make a small reservation as regards her vote, because it is necessary to review and develop a new text that improves and modernises the Equal Treatment Directive. employment and wages.  I think it is unacceptable that there is still more than 15% of the gender pay gap in Europe today, which shows that equal pay for the same work is not a reality in our democracies today. That is why we agree and fully support the need to promote – and to do so, I look at the Commissioner and the Commission – non-sexist systems for assessing and classifying jobs, so that through these systems and wage transparency we can develop job assessment methodologies to avoid gender biases that make this pay gap systematized. We are also calling for and supporting the obligation for companies to develop and implement annual strategic plans on gender equality, as well as the right, for both women and men, to the reconciliation of working life with family life, which is also so difficult today.  Finally, it is essential for us that compulsory wage audits are proposed in relation to companies listed on a stock exchange in the Member States, except, of course, small and medium-sized enterprises. We also need for women that the social partners and, in particular, trade unions be supported by all these demands, and we certainly need a radical approach in the next text of the Commission. There are good practices, the Commissioner has told us, in all areas, including at the international level, but, in our view, there is still a gap of more than 15% between the salaries of men and women that is totally unacceptable in our democracy.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The report on updating the Gender Equality Directive in the workplace is most often mentioned by the fact that the rapporteur herself, Mrs Záborská, has to make a separate statement to her. This document, which should be a pragmatic attempt to tackle wage inequality and unequal treatment in the workplace, is full of ideological, subsidiarity-intrusive about the need to include gender issues in vocational education and training or the need for legal recognition of gender reassignment, excessive administrative burdens in the form of audits.  It is bizarre that the report replaces all references to objective biological sex with socio-cultural gender. Motherhood is a social role that is only appropriate for women and it is not surprising that it also affects their careers. Of course, action must be taken to compensate for the pay gap. However, the way to do this is not to impose further information obligations on employers. These key competences are important in the labour market and the european Union's action should not suggest that women are less competent. Unfortunately, the FEMM Committee is not pragmatically able to approach this issue, which is why the ECR Group will vote against.

name: Catherine Bearder
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, equal treatment of men and women is a fundamental value of EU law, and the principle of equal pay has been enshrined in the Treaties since 1957. Despite this long-standing commitment to equality, progress remains far too slow. The gender pay gap and gender pension gap still show significant differences. It is gender that we are talking about, not biological sex. Women are in effect punished because of society’s expectations that they will bear children, regardless of whether they have them or not. Single women without children earn less than their male colleagues. Marriage and children are irrelevant to women’s earning potential. Women earn less whether they have husbands or children or not. As the gender pay gap stands, on average European women work 60 days without pay compared to European men. Employers might think this is good value, but it is shocking that it still happens. The best way to tackle wage inequality is to improve wage transparency but, despite years of various instruments, the problem persists. The time has now come for stronger action. We need mandatory wage transparency and committed action from governments and businesses alike. Large companies listed on the stock exchanges in Member States should be obliged to publish their data so that employees can see for themselves whether they are getting a fair deal. They already have to publish other financial data, so this requirement is not too onerous. On a related point, we have to protect the independence and funding of national equality bodies, which assist in cases of unfair treatment, and we must likewise protect them from political interference. I am also delighted to see language in this report ensuring that trans people are protected under equality legislation. A recent study found that one third of trans people reported discrimination when seeking employment at work. Trans women earn 20% less than their other female colleagues and they are punished doubly for being a woman and for being trans. We need improved trans-inclusive diversity training and legal gender recognition across our Member States, as well as equality for women in the labour market now.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. – Mr President, this report upholds fundamental principles and measures for the creation of equality in the workplace. Some examples: the appreciation of collective bargaining and the criticism of the attack that is made on this day, the appreciation of the role played by trade unions in promoting equal treatment and the concept of equal pay in employment, the defence that professional assessment and classification systems should be based on collective bargaining, the finding that Member States should guarantee maternity-related rights - in particular the impediment to abusive dismissal of workers during pregnancy or when returning to work after maternity leave - the recommendation to Member States that they take steps to ensure the reversal of the burden of proof, ensuring that it is always the employer's place to prove that it does not discriminate.  Now, two things would be important: first, for words to move from paper to practice. In many countries, it is not because there is no legislation that protective women's rights that discrimination takes place; secondly, that the economic measures adopted by this Parliament do not contradict these principles.

name: Karima Delli
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, how many times are we going to have reports and questions about equality in this Parliament, when we have Member States that lack courage? The first observation is dramatic. That is the most glaring, of course, it is the question of wages. On this issue, today, when we look at the figures and the latest data, the salary received by women in EU countries is still on average 16.4% lower in 2013. In 2008, it was 17.3%. At this rate, we'll have to wait 71 years - 71 years! - so that equality between men and women on the issue of wages is put in place. While the very principle in the European Union is equal pay for the same work. That is the basic principle.  As a result, after years of inaction, it is high time that this changed because the issue of salary is just a great symbol, but behind it, there are all the questions concerning retirement, when we know that women receive on average a pension 39% lower than that of men and that the directive adopted in 2013 which asks, among other things, companies to have at least 40% women on boards, is still not applied...  What should be done? In my view, the watchword is punishment. States that do not respect the principles of equality must be punished, and companies must also be punished.

name: Daniela Aiuto
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we recently had the opportunity to deepen the employment framework for women in Europe at a meeting of a delegation from the FEMM Committee in Ireland at eurofound headquarters. What emerges from this is a worrying, not to say alarming, picture.  As far as gender inequality between workers is concerned, the percentage of posting in Europe averages around 10%, with peaks, for example, in Italy, my own country, where this disparity reaches as much as 20% in the 30-40 age group. This means that not enough has been done in recent years either for employment policies or for family welfare systems and for early childhood. It is only by means of more effective funding that this percentage, which is still shamefully high, will be lowered.  As far as gender pay inequality is concerned, we have a guilty 16% difference across the Eu ropean Union. This is where a more cultural discourse comes into play, because it is based on discriminatory practices in all the Member States of the Union and that the 2006 directive, to which the Záborská report refers, aims to combat it.  We therefore welcome the basic content of this dossier, while pointing out our opposition to the introduction of excessively onerous sanctions and bureaucratic practices, which make the administrative burden on companies even greater. It is all very well to work on anti-discrimination policies, but without going too far on employers, who are often blameless.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague Mrs Zuborsk for her extensive work.  I also share her concern to promote women's access to the labour market, especially those who have started a family and have children. I also support the desire to allow mothers working from home, particularly under the status of self-employed entrepreneurs, to benefit from better social protection. I am pleased that the situation of the most vulnerable, especially single mothers, often lives in France but also in all other Member States, below the poverty line, is taken into account. But, unfortunately, the adversaries of the traditional family of a man and a woman and their children have fought your text, Madam, and have drowned your good intentions under a deluge of considerations having nothing to do with the subject of your report, which, I recall, is the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in terms of employment and work. What do, Madam, consider race, ethnicity or religion in this report? What was the need to distinguish lesbian or bisexual women from other women? What does this obsession with sex change do in the report? It mentions no less than six times, I counted them, sex change and transsexualism. I am not convinced, moreover, that the people concerned, who are quite few, also want to be shown this way.  I therefore deeply regret that your report, whose substance is sincerely very commendable, is distorted by an exacerbated LGBT communitarianism and by this desire to destroy the foundations of our society. So I won't be able to vote for it as it is, and I'm sorry.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I would like to quote point (q) of the report, and I have a specific question for the Representative of the Commission here and for Mrs Záborská, our reporter. It says in point (q): "As certain categories of women, including ethnic minority, lesbian, bisexual, transgender ... (pám-pám-pám) women are at risk of cumulative discrimination in employment and work." I cordially ask that mrs. Záborská, who I admire very much, and who is very knowledgeable, who happens to be in the conservative ranks and comes from a Slovak country, i.e. central and eastern Europe, peripheral countries, that you do not think should have mentioned with such weight the discrimination that is found in the fivefold, tenfold pay gap between women working in the countries of the centre and the Periphery and, for example, nurses and nurses doing typical female work. Which then defines their whole lives because they have to leave their country to support their children. I await the reply of the Representative of the Commission and the reporter to this question.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, it is clear that much more needs to be done to ensure equality for women in employment. The principle of equal pay for equal jobs is still not respected in all the Member States. This creates inequality even later when women have lower pensions. Member States should take concrete measures to eliminate the gender pay gap, including addressing the root causes. Commissioner, I welcome your work both on transparency and on evaluation. To have a job and economic independence are key for women’s equality and, in particular now, for the integration of migrant women in our society. We need to create the conditions for all women to access the labour market without discrimination. The selection criteria should be based on competence and skills. It should be easier for women to start a business and to be entrepreneurs. Women’s empowerment is crucial, and – as you said, Commissioner – it is also for the benefit of the European economy and growth.  Women and men should also have the same opportunity to combine family and career. Mothers are not the only parents responsible for taking care of children. Member States should promote shared parental responsibility. Equality at work is also about removing stereotypes and changing mentality. Too many women are still victims of sexual harassment at work. As long as women are considered more for how they look than for how they perform at work, inequality will not be achieved. Our fight for equal treatment should not be ideological and it should not involve imposing a model. It is about women’s individual choice and dignity. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Madam Representative, you have called for action by member states. I would like to give you an example Hungary, where, by the way, textbooks are under state or government control. It is written in a sixth-grade elementary school textbook in Hungary: girls are supposed to learn to read more easily than most boys, but in mathematics boys are more adept. Boys and girls have different physical abilities and mental abilities. This is the case in Hungary in a sixth-grade primary school textbook. The FIDESZ in your party's ranks has been in control of it in a textbook.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I find what my colleague said regrettable. I do not think that there should be any discrimination at school between girls and boys. I am not aware of what you were saying, Mr Szanyi, but schools are a national issue. We do not deal with school texts in Parliament, but we definitely deal with non-discrimination, as I said, and this is very much the policy of the whole EPP Group.

name: Anna Hedh (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Although Mrs Záborská and I do not always share the same political values, I would like to thank her for this report. The labour market situation remains unsustainable, with disastrous differences in equal pay and pensions paid. At the same time, inequality is not exclusive to the labour market, nor is it something that should be talked about in purely economic terms. Inequality in society is based on how we look at and think about women – a usually stale view of women. This view allows company boards to cover only men. It would like women to do unpaid housework, and perhaps above all that it is the role of women. When Záborská and other right-wing politicians talk about this, one of the few solutions seems to be that the work in the household should be in a higher position. I then ask myself: what does it solve? It could certainly generate an increase in economic income, but the real problem remains, namely that women are expected to take double the responsibility. When are we going to tackle the real problem, getting men to take responsibility, men tending to work more as parents of young children and taking responsibility at home? (The speaker agreed to answer a question ("blue card") in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: John Stuart Agnew (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I would just like to ask the speaker this: you used the term ‘housewife’ and you are in the S&D Group – are you aware that this is a politically incorrect term? If I was to use the word ‘housewife’ in Britain I would be branded as a woman hater.

name: Anna Hedh (S&D)
text: answer ("blue card"). "I didn't use the word "housewife" in Swedish. There must be something wrong with the interpretation. I used "work in the household" – and not "housewife", which is an expression that we no longer use in Sweden either.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Today we are talking about the report, which, if you ask me, does not deserve the name; it is too bad. I quote paragraph 16, entitled Surveillance and Data Collection: 'Parliament calls on the Commission and the Member States to take supervisory and control measures and to establish effective monitoring systems to improve the collection of data on sex harassment cases;' – a Europe-wide monitoring system against harassment. Hurray! The second point I would like to highlight is important: 'We reaffirm the need for clear definitions, for example with regard to the gender pay gap'. Very right! We urgently need to define clear terms: what is gender, what is sexual identity – sexual identity – what is gender identity – gender identity? What is it? Let's define that and then talk about it instead of talking about it without knowing what. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – After that speech, which I agree with very much in many parts, I was wondering if you would agree with me how remarkable it is that, every time we speak about equalities in this place, it is never mentioned that the new people who come to this continent, the migrants from other parts of the world, have vastly different ways of looking at equality between men and women. Maybe that should be addressed when people come here: the fact that they come from totally different cultures. That is an area that does not even get discussed: the fact that women are treated far more as inferior in the places they come from.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I believe that it is important that, even against this background, we clearly define what we are actually talking about: the acceptance of gender diversity. That kind of sounds totally great or completely insane. In any case, we should be clear about what this is all about. And then we should explain to the millions of immigrants who are now coming to us from other cultures what that is – the acceptance of gender diversity.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I believe that the pay gap, austerity policies and gender-based violence are the clear example of how little institutions are doing in both States and the European Union to implement these policies of equality and gender prevention which, although often insufficient, exist. I would like to use my speech to ask the Commission: what do you intend to do in practice to eliminate the gender bias that exists when implementing equality policies? What do you plan to do in practice to eliminate gender bias when it comes to combating gender-based violence? What positive action measures do you plan to put in place? Because if we do not make progress on this, we will continue to analyse the situation of women in different areas every year, but we will remain in the same situation.  (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Paul Nuttall (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I am a bit confused because I looked at your Group yesterday and the day before, and there were ‘Refugees welcome’ signs on your front tables. Do you not agree with me that violence against women will increase if we allow more and more people into this continent from countries where the words of a woman are, in some cases, worth only half of those of a man, and which generally treat women in an appalling fashion? Do you not agree with me that if we allow more people to come to this continent from Muslim countries in the Middle East violence against women will naturally increase?

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" response. "It seems to me that this question doesn't make much sense. Gender inequality exists and will continue to exist if we do not take positive action.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I say to the House: the Members all seem in a pretty confused state to me. You do not really know what it is you want. You have now started to contradict yourselves completely – which I know is absolutely nothing new for this place, but now it is so blatant. In paragraph 34, you call for EU gender-neutral job classifications and evaluation systems, yet, in paragraph 13, you demand the introduction of binding gender quotas. So what is it? Jobs based on the gender of a person, or jobs irrespective of the gender? Do you want to fight discrimination or don’t you? In paragraph 37, you call for EU mandatory pay audits for listed companies in order to obtain gender data. You call for the introduction of sanctions at EU level that would exclude companies from procurement of goods and services financed with public subsidies. So are you saying that you want the EU to block companies from using public goods, services and money if there is not an appropriate gender balance? In paragraph 41, you call for a reversal in the burden of proof between employer and employee. Are you aware that this would require a complete alteration in the UK judicial system? Shall we just throw away the concept of innocent until proven guilty? Finally, in paragraph 50, you want the EU to conduct a study on the situations of working mothers, mothers who choose to stay at home and women without children who have made the choice to work. And why? To find out how each affects the labour market. It is almost as if you want to belittle those who do not conform to your view of what the role of a woman should be.  Please do something useful. Let us talk about female genital mutilation; let us talk about forced marriage; let us speak out about abuses of women across the world. But, please, stop wasting all of our time.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, you have been trying for years, you say, to achieve equality at work between the sexes. But have you wondered why all your efforts so far have ended in failure? You fail to realize that your own approach is wrong. Surrendered to an individualistic excitement, you refuse to accept the normal fact that society's cell is a family. You are putting pressure on citizens in pursuit of greater earnings and extreme consumerism. You seek equality at all costs and you cannot understand how you simply cause flattening.  Equality is not the magic solution. The word you're looking for is harmony. Harmony between the sexes, harmony between all members of a society and cooperation of all to promote our social rather than economic level alone. You have even arrived at the sacred task of raising children or caring for the elderly and disabled, trying to value it in financial terms. Equal opportunities for all: this is the only equality that can exist and, at the same time, strengthening in every way the institution of the family, the only institution that can guarantee social cohesion.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to the rapporteur, Anna Zéborska, for her report and for the efforts made on her own-initiative report. We have a situation where a great deal has been done in recent decades in terms of equality and equality in the European Union. But, of course, there is still room for improvement and improvement, particularly on the issue of the wage gap, the pay gap. What do we have to do to get to grips with this problem? I think first of all, analyse the causes: why is there this large pay gap? This is primarily due to the fact that women naturally have a great many breaks in employment and that reconciling work and family life is still difficult to achieve in some countries. Women also tend to choose occupations that are less well paid. These are all the causes. We must ensure that it is possible to stay in the profession and also facilitate re-entry. This is where the parties to the collective bargaining agreement are called upon to do so. I do not think we can do much in this, legislatively. I also reject the passages in the report that interfere with collective bargaining autonomy and reporting obligations, which mean only bureaucracy for companies, but do not achieve anything for the interests of women.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: Mr President, I welcome first of all the rapporteur, Mrs Zuborsk, for her commitment to this issue, which shows the flaws and proposes remedies. In my report voted at the beginning of the year on the evolution of equality, I stressed, as Karima Delli said earlier, that we will have to wait until 2084 to have a pay equality, which is obviously far too long. Enforcement action is needed to address the problem. The choice of 2 November, Commissioner, is symbolic because it means that after 2 November, women work for free. We're at 85% of the year. November 2 is the day of the dead. Also, I hope it will not be conducive to burying this file.  The fight against stereotypes seems to me to be something fundamental. Gender stereotypes, which reproduce inequalities at the time of entry into the workforce, must be combated. Therefore, it is from the world of education and training that action must also be taken to avoid this scourge of gender stereotypes.  Finally, I think we need to improve the compatibility, as has been said, between work and family life. And there, clearly, it is often women who are forced to make the choice to give up their jobs. It needs to be addressed as well.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR).
text: – The report very well rememmes a problem that I personally consider important, namely that of a specific group of parents, mostly mothers, who take care of their children with disabilities with great love on a daily basis. It is a great shame if caring for such children is synonymous with living in poverty and gives rise to a phenomenon that we know as the feminisation of poverty. The Member States must therefore be more involved not only in eduing this work, but also in creating the conditions to promote the creation of jobs for mothers who want to work at least partially, but are rejected by employers in view of children's health problems. It is not enough that we have a ban on discrimination on paper, because reality will only change if we finally stop thinking of these women as being inferior in the labour market. Moreover, motherhood, caring for the sick, the elderly and the disabled must not be a stigma and a condemnation to a low pension, but a value in itself and an equal contribution to life in our society. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed under the Blue Card procedure (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: "blue card" question. – It is very nice what you said, but I will disagree with you on one particular issue: because I am the father of a disabled child, I have a 32-year-old daughter with Down syndrome, child care is not only entrusted to the mother, but to too many families she shares the burden and responsibility on both parents and the father and the mother; do you not agree?

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – You are right there are many families where the father bears this burden or where the father also takes care of a child with a disability. Unfortunately, in my experience, many families where a child with a disability is born are falling apart. And most of the time, it's the mother who stays to look after this baby, and really the financial assessment of such care is at the survival level, not to mention the fact that it then, of course, also has an impact on her pension. So when I talk about the fact that these women, mostly women, are at risk of poverty, it is unfortunately a sad fact.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, equal treatment and non-discrimination between men and women is not only a matter of justice, it is not just a right enshrined in the Treaties of the Union and it is not just a historical debt. It is also a strategic and common-sense issue for Europe's economic and social development, for the sustainability of our societies. The report that brings us together here this morning demonstrates the ineffectiveness of legislation which is not properly implemented in the Member States.  Meanwhile, the wage gap between men and women is 16.4% and the pension gap reaches 39%. Leaving aside more than 50% of the European population does not contribute to prosperity or well-being.  Measures should be put in place that do not allow companies to ensure the management of equality in the labour market, but it is also necessary to implement other measures, to deepen legislatively on other issues, such as ensuring decent rights and working conditions for domestic and care work, exercised mostly by women, and ensuring co-responsibility with compulsory paternity leave , equal and non-transferable.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: Mr President, the European Union is concerned about women's equality in employment. So the perpetrator is worried about his victims. The mockery in all its glory! The Union hides its barbarity, which culminated in the memoranda: the abolition of all rights, the downward equation, the common impoverishment of women and men. In Greece, the three Memorandums of the Union, with SYRIZA, PASOK and New Democracy, effectively abolishes the pension completely, especially for women, increasing the age limits up to 17 years and years of work when unemployment is galloping. Undeclared, intermittent, part-time work, hunger wages rage, particularly on women, as an incentive for competitiveness. The Sunday holiday of rest and family contact is abolished. The EKAS for low-income pensioners, especially women, is abolished. They cut the lower pension from EUR 486 to EUR 392. Pensions-crumbs 200 to 250 euros, until you reach 67. The Union's private pension systems are making the situation worse.  One way left for women and men: conflict with governments, the European Union of memoranda and capitalist barbarism.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: Mr. President, I want to congratulate Mrs. Zaborska on her dedication and consistency. This report supports the fundamental principle of "equal pay for equal work" and I agree that such discrimination can no longer be tolerated, if the data is correct, and I believe it is, that according to some indicators the salary of women is 15% lower, and translated into days this means 60 days of work more than men.  Therefore, the question arises which society wants half of its potential to remain untapped. I don't believe any society, any member state wants that. It also raises the question of how many more times we will have such or similar report, Mrs Zaborska. The fact is that all these years, despite efforts, not enough has been done. However, I would agree that this is nevertheless a cultural or civilizational issue, that Member States must take equal opportunities measures for women and men, we should ensure dignity for women, so I expect the Commission to introduce better oversight, for some kind of review to take place. It's the only way to move forward, Mrs. Zaborska.

name: Andrea Cozzolino ( S&D). –
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if you are a woman who works as much as a man and earns less, the figures are now final, on average we are around 16%, as the report denounces, but there are areas of Europe where this figure, this percentage, reaches really worrying levels: 20-25%.  Let's ask ourselves why. Why do women have a lower level of productivity? Do they have less knowledge and expertise? Do they do less in the workplace? It would be really strange to support some of these arguments. So, if there are no real irrational reasons, the gender pay gap is a gap that needs to be fixed right away. Equal treatment has been in the European legal system since 1957, but the data tell us that we are still totally far from its full implementation. Perhaps we are not working on it in the right spirit and with the right determination.  We are well aware that it is not a directive to break down stereotypes and prejudices, but I support the rapporteur in calling on the Commission for a new directive and greater rigour of application by the Member States.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Indeed, Mrs Záborská has done an extraordinary job and I wanted to congratulate her. It was a much-needed report. Even today women still charge an average of 16% less than men for work of equal value and it is a gap that can be extended to 20% in some Member States. Indeed, the legal framework also exists in the European Union, but Directive 2006/54/EC, which came to group all the above legislation, has not been used by the Member States to be able to seize the opportunity and courageously review national systems so that this discrimination does not occur. That is why the request to the Commission is very clear: a revision of that directive and a new directive where everything that has not worked can be re-eded. Think that the immediate consequence of the pay gap is the retirement gap, which can reach 39%.  And I would like to end by asking for the principle of non-discrimination for the most vulnerable sectors, which would be all sectors of LGBTI, disability, ethnic minorities, sexual orientation, etc. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: blue card question. – Mr President, listening to Mrs Beres say that there are Member States where the pay gap is widening and knowing that since 2011 - and we are not satisfied - it has stabilized in the European Union, how do you value that in Spain, since 2011, the wage gap has increased by 8%? Does it have to do with the government's labour reform in relation to equality policies?

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – After the Socialist Government left us with an incredible unemployment of more than four million people, the labour reform of the Spanish government has enabled us to create, after a major crisis and for the first time, work in Spain and that we can recover from what the Socialist Government left us.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is a pity because the text talks about wage discrimination, which is fundamental for us, for so many women, especially in Italy, but it has been weighed down by the reversal of the burden of proof for the employer, by the mandatory sanctions, by the expulsion of companies in public procurement with regard to European funding.  And then I would like to make the rapporteur think about one point: the text introduces a new legal case, multiple discrimination, and in this way it becomes discriminatory for women, because one woman will have simple discrimination and another sensitive category will have multiple discrimination, which frustrates the legal concept of discrimination. Discrimination is unique, there can be no second-class discrimination and second-class discrimination.  That is why, unfortunately, despite the fundamental concepts that had to be introduced, my vote will be against.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I have indeed made this clear: the pay gap is something that must be raised in the political debate, at the first point of our agenda, because, until it is corrected, there will be no justice and we will continue to fuel discrimination. He said earlier that in the European Union, the pay gap has indeed stabilized. Despite this, a new regulation, a new directive, is needed to finally end it. But it is true that it is more dramatic when in Member States, despite what has been said, labour reforms are made and this discrimination is not taken into account and the world of work is precarious, because the consequence is that women still suffer more discrimination, as is the case in our country: that after a labour reform that precarious the world of work , inequality has increased, the wage gap has increased and is therefore today eight points higher than in 2011. We can't, ladies and gentlemen, look the other way.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in employment and labour matters has so far failed to bear fruit as legal enforcement has not been seriously insisted on.  It grieves me that we are not ready to make a turn and adopt a different approach to this issue, but it is proposed to further intensify efforts in the same direction. By amassing regulations, we can only put additional pressure on European companies, and this will have a negative impact on all workers – both women and men. I guess our goal is to get as many women and men working as possible, not as little as possible.  The proposed drafting of annual business plans on gender equality and staff training on equality and diversity is a simple satisfying form that will change absolutely nothing, except that due to rising costs, a few workers will lose their jobs anyway, and the laws will still not be enforced on their own.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, in order to improve the European labour market, it is important that gender equality policy is implemented not only on paper but also on the share. It is a market necessity for Europe's women to be economically independent, to be rewarded fairly, to rely on work-family balance and to know that they have no ceiling to running companies.  To this we need to add a real sectoral balance sheet. It requires improving women's access to typically male professions and increasing men's access to feminised professions, such as in education.  In Bulgaria, low pay acts as a barrier for young people, and mainly men, to pursue the teaching profession. Opportunities to stimulate gender balance in professions like this are real. And we need to take advantage of them because both sexes contribute differently to the system, education and education of students, including gender equality.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I want to address my colleagues. I, on the whole, say that the report is necessary, but what chance does it have of applying when, Commissioner, you start by saying that it is an important report, and then, amazingly, you say that, in fact, we need to improve women's skills and help them? What do you want to induce, Commissioner, the idea that women are not prepared, that they do not have competence, that we have to help them? How do you explain that, in countries with a majority female population, women's access to leadership positions, whether it is state institutions, political or private, are men's? Who decides, Commissioner, in this case? Men. Do not induce the false idea that, in fact, this is why women are discriminated against and there are disparities: because they are not professionally prepared. That's why I'm leaving skeptical here, if that's your perception. We women don't want positive discrimination. We want you to respect the value; mathematically, it cannot be that, of a large percentage of the female population in a state, there is no close percentage in the decision-making places. And there is another problem: the issue of education, which has been talked about. There can't really be a textbook education where the woman sits in the kitchen and the man's in the car. I think we need oversight of how the legislation is involved.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, for many years, the European Union has been making efforts to stop gender discrimination in terms of pay and employment. Nevertheless, we see that the pay gap against women continues; they are paid at least 16%, lower wages than men. We have over-representation of women in part-time work; we have under-representation of women in full-time jobs and we also have pensions at least 39% lower on average for women than for men.  In particular, now, in the countries affected by the Memorandums, it is women who have been most affected by austerity and fiscal adjustment measures. In Greece, the latest figures from 2015 show that women have an unemployment rate of 30.6%, while men have an unemployment rate of 23.5%. Measures must, as a matter of urgency, be taken to tackle and stop discrimination between the sexes.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: " Mr. President, this home likes to call itself the home of European democracy. This house will today discuss four human rights violations in the world. This House today discusses a topic that was discussed as if we were in the Middle Ages, because here I listen to the arguments of some who will not support this report. They really live in the Middle Ages! If we need to still talk about equality and equality in this house today and if some deliberately don't want to understand it, then they really live in the Middle Ages. And I am sorry that today I listened to some discussions, some arguments against this report and arguments that are not arguments at all, but is an ideology that violates equality and equality and that just wants to go against what equality and equality are.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is not the first time I have spoke in this House on women's rights and gender equality.  I have to say that, despite the existence of European directives, we are too far from achieving the objectives and also from the application of European legislation. I therefore welcome the new directive that the rapporteur wants. As can be seen from the report itself of the European Union's strategy for equality between women and men after 2015 in Europe, women are under-represented in decision-making processes, and this is the case in parliaments, national governments, but also in companies, especially in large companies. In short, progress has been made everywhere in all sectors, but it will still take 81 years to close the gap on employment opportunities between men and women, and on our continent we also have to deal with the 20-25% of women who suffer violence at least once in their lives, including in the workplace.  Europe cannot confine itself to mere denunciation, it must ensure that European legislation on gender equality is actually complyed with. It is right to ensure the same opportunities and rights for men and women, but this must not justify radical drifts that must be combated with energy and determination.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this very rich discussion. After this, I am all the more convinced that closing the gender pay gap needs a comprehensive approach. That means legislative and non-legislative measures and, of course, efforts from all the relevant stakeholders at both EU and national level. The effective application and enforcement of equal pay in Member States are essential to ensure the rights enshrined in the directive. This remains the biggest challenge.  Going forward, the Commission will examine national measures following the Recommendation on Pay Transparency. We will assess the need for any additional measures at EU level. Of course this will include looking at whether we should review the Gender Equality Recast Directive.

name: Anna Záborská
text: Rapporteur. – Thank you for your inspiring discussion. I felt her support for a number of ideas that I have tried to put into the draft of my report, and I am grateful to you for this support. However, I also felt a number of reservations, although several of them did not concern my text at all. Mrs Morway is right about this question for me, but unfortunately this report does not speak of the issue of women's pay in Eastern and Western Europe. There is no response to everything, and then let me react more symbolically. The process of approving an own-initiative report from the committee to the vote in Parliament's plenary sometimes resembles a gala dinner serving freshly baked fish. You managed to bake it exactly the way you wanted it, it has the right color, smell and taste, but you know there will be bones in it.  And sometimes there are so many of them that you can't eat a portion after all. I openly admit that this report also has bones. Some are small and can be swallowed, but others are downright uncomfortable and raise my concerns. I have tried to draw attention to these bottlenecing points for me through the 'split' and 'separate' votes. At the same time, however, I have realised that three such places, three such bones, are indigestible to me, and it is Article 18, Amendment 2 and Article 42. I have repeatedly warned in this plenary and in committee for 11 years that the use of the term 'gender' leads to confusion, because this term is not legally defined. Its content varies depending on its use in the media or ideological pamphlets. This is evidenced by the various translations of the text of my report, which therefore also have different implications. I have devoted a great deal of time to preparing this report, but if the final text, despite my best efforts, is indigestible, I will have to abstain in the vote. Thank you once again for your cooperation, support and understanding.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place today, 8 October 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. – Gender inequality in the field of employment hampers the potential of women to fully use their skills and abilities in contributing to society, and seriously impacts on the living conditions of European families. No mother should be made to choose between earning an income or caring for her child, elderly, disabled or other vulnerable family member. Parents have the exclusive discretion of deciding how to balance their family responsibilities with their employment, and policies must aim at setting up different frameworks within which parents can make a free and informed decision as to what is best for their own family and circumstances. In this regard, the EU needs to offer evidence-based options for family-focused growth and an integrated approach to equality in employment. Policies must also seek to propose measures which, while facilitating work-life balance, do not seriously prejudice SMEs. This must be accompanied by an understanding that an employee who reaches a work-life balance is a better employee. I have voted in favour of quotas and similar measures, as temporary provisions addressing the current situation, which are to be systematically reviewed.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. If you're a woman, you work as hard as a man and you earn less. In the European Union, women earn about 16% less than men. Let's ask ourselves why. Do they have 16% less intelligence? Do they work 16% less? Do they commit 16% less? Do they know 16% less than their male colleagues? It would be strange to put forward such a thesis. So, if there are no real and rational reasons, the gender pay gap is a gap that needs to be fixed right away. Equal treatment has been in the European legal system since 1957, but the data tell us that we are still a long way from its full implementation. Maybe we're not working hard enough on it. We are well aware that it is not a directive that break down stereotypes and prejudices, but I support the rapporteur in calling on the Commission for a new directive and greater rigour of application by the Member States.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. – As is well known, women in Europe, and especially in Central Europe, perform better in achieving tertiary education than men. Nevertheless, this is not reflected in the labour market, but at the same time more and more unskreated men are appearing among the unemployed. The stability of families is also becoming increasingly questionable, while education is increasingly burdened with responsibility and responsibility.  The solution would be to strengthen a more harmonious division of family labour and equality between the parties declared in the institution of marriage, in accordance with Hungary law. The family must remain a fundamental building block of society, as children can be the most important part of a family. Highlighting the work of the reporter, Assemblywoman Zaborska, I would like to confirm that the display of the values of the People's Party in the report was a priority. As far as the selection of female managers is concerned, competence should continue to be the main consideration.  It is essential that the wider public is objectively informed about the qualities of female leaders and their unbalanced, greater responsibilities and disadvantages in relation to child-rearing, due to the current practice of gender division of labour. Unfortunately, this aspect was not explicitly included in the report, nor was the length of service taken into account. Thus, the development of balanced and non-discriminatory evaluation and rating systems has remained controversial.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – According to the available data, women are better educated than men, but this does not translate into their position on the labour market. Statistically, women are less active, earn less by doing the same work and are under-represented in decision-making bodies in different areas of the economy. The data show that if the current trend in increasing female employment in the EU continues at the same level, the europe 2020 employment rate of 75% among women and men aged 20-64 will be delayed by 18 years. Bridging labour market disparities requires coordinated action at European and national level in cooperation with employers and trade unions. In order to increase women's professional activity, we need an effective family-promoting policy aimed at facilitating the reconciling of work and family life m.in. ensuring good quality childcare. In addition, women should be facilitated to return to the labour market through appropriate training and career guidance. We also need greater promotion of women's employment, support for their entrepreneurship and active participation of women in decision-making processes. I also draw attention to the role of education in promoting equal opportunities in the labour market for women and men and in combating stereotypes and gender discrimination.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – In paragraph 13 there is a call for the Women on Boards Directive to be adopted, which includes gender quotas. The EU has absolutely no right to impose gender quotas on UK companies. Quotas are demeaning for women, and recruitment should be based solely on merit, not on gender. You do not fight discrimination with more discrimination. Calls for EU mandatory pay audits and EU sanctions, in paragraph 37, shows once again that the EU is trying to interfere and take more powers where it has no right to them. Paragraph 41 states that you want to see a reversal in the burden of proof between employer and employee. This would rip up the justice system in the UK and do away with the principle of ‘innocent until proven guilty’. UKIP, of course, supports gender equality, equal pay and any steps to fight discrimination based on gender, ethnicity, religion, orientation or any other characteristics. Everyone should have the same protection and the same opportunities to prove what they can do. UKIP cannot, however, support calls for more EU legislation and interference in UK laws and freedoms. Only our elected and accountable Government should be able to decide these things, not unelected EU bureaucrats.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The gender pay gap and gender differences are still far too large. It is essential that the European Union works for greater equality between men and women, especially in the world of work. Thank you.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. – In the Global Gender Differences Index of the World Economic Forum, Portugal, my country, was in 2014 in 39th place. Let's look at some figures: 31% of seats in the National Parliament are held by women, 21% of ministerial positions are held by women and there are only 12% of women on the boards of companies. A man Portuguese earns on average 30% more than a Portuguese woman. For these reasons, I think it is very positive that this report explicitly mentions that Member States should legislate to compel companies to draw up and define annual business plans on gender equality and women's rights and also men who take care of family members, and to ensure a balanced representation of women and men on boards.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D)
text: Writing. Equal pay for men and women should be a matter of course in the 21st century. Nevertheless, equal pay for the same work is still a pipe dream for many women. Even ten years after the principle was enshrineed, the directive has not yet been properly implemented in many Member States. For years, the so-called gender pay gap has averaged 17% in the EU. Without concrete and ambitious measures, this gap will only be closed in 70 years. So 2086! This inequality is taking women into retirement age. There, the difference between men and women is 39%. The Commission should identify the weaknesses in its implementation and come forward with a proposal to remedy them. How about, for example, a mandatory pay review and sanctions in the event of non-compliance with the principle of equal pay? A review of progress in the European Semester would also be a good step. Equality is a fundamental value of the European Union, and this should not just be the case on paper.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. – Equality between men and women is a fundamental principle of European law which applies to all aspects of life in society, including the world of work. However, based on the last available figures from 2012, the average gender pay gap in the EU was approximately 16.4%. Moreover, while female labour participation varies between sectors, some sectors, such as transport, have even fewer women on average. The reasons for that are related to stereotypes of male dominance and lack of attractiveness in a wide sense. We should address the situation by calling for more action by the EU 28 and the individual Member States. We need to start by revising the recast directive in order to reduce differences in pay for men and women. We must also urge Member States to take more action on unequal pay practices and to promote wage transparency. Most divisively, we can request the introduction of mandatory pay audits for companies listed on stock exchanges and the imposition of sanctions on companies failing to meet their responsibilities with regard to gender equality. There is no reason why, in today’s world, we should accept a situation where men are receiving higher pay and preferential treatment in the matter of employment and occupations.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – There is inequality in the employment of women in the Union and around the world, despite some of the positive measures we have taken to address this phenomenon. Likewise, despite our capable, talented and skills, women are not in practice achieving the same pay as men in equal professional positions, and I believe that the European Parliament should promote all those measures that go in the direction of equality and equality between the sexes. Gender inequalities arise from the reconciliation of family and professional life. This is also reflected at a time when they leave the labour market or when they retire and put women in an uneasy position. Women are still traditionally the ones who are more burdened – both mentally and in terms of time organisation, as they usually do informal housework. If there were real equality between men and women in the labour market, we, as a society, could also exploit the many potentials of both sexes – which in turn would result in higher GDP growth of all individual Member States as well as the EU as a whole. That is why we must continue to advocate for the concept of sexual equality and equality in employment, for transparency of wages and for better conditions in reconciling family and professional life. Only in this way will the EU be able to truly apply the principles to which it also undertook itself in the Treaty establishing the Union.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. – Thank you very much, Mrs Záborská, for your report; you've done an excellent job. Equal treatment between men and women in the workplace is a clear objective in all Member States.  This report is much needed to address this situation. Conditions of access to the labour market must be fair, equal and non-discriminatory. Equality in the quality of employment between men and women must be ensured, and we must work on it: equal pay for the same work must be a basic premise. If there is no such equal treatment, in the long run more inequalities will arise, there will be no economic independence of women and they will be economically diminished in the face of retirement. The causes must be addressed and this situation within the European Union to be put to an end and thus avoid creating situations of vulnerability.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question on the implementation of Article 20(2) of the Services Directive and Article 8(3) of the Consumer Rights Directive, addressed to the Commission by Evelyne Gebhardt, on behalf of the S&D Group and Andreas Schwab, on behalf of the PPE Group (O-000083/2015 – 2015/2881(RSP) – B8-0754/2015).

name: Evelyne Gebhardt
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you for being able to ask this question here today. We keep saying that citizens want to shop on the Internet and cannot do so for a variety of reasons – because they have the wrong IP address, have the wrong credit card, have the wrong nationality, live in the wrong country – and therefore cannot make that purchase. The law in the European Union is actually clear: discrimination on grounds of nationality is not allowed, is not okay. That is why it is an aberration that this large internal market that we have, which brings a very great profit for businesses, this large bee market for people, for consumers and for women consumers still does not exist today and that many obstacles arise. That is why it is very important that we take action against this here too. In its Communication on the Digital Single Market Strategy for Europe, the European Commission said it wanted to "address unjustified geo-blocking in the field of e-commerce in 2016, including, where appropriate, by a targeted change to the regulatory framework for e-commerce". I would be very interested now: what do you mean by this change? What kind of change should this change be? What are your purpose? I am also very interested in this: how do you, as the European Commission, intend to ensure that Article 20(2) of the Services Directive and Article 8(3) of the Consumer Directive are finally implemented? Rights that have been in force for a long time, but which are still incomprehensible to citizens. I am very curious to see how you will reply to us.

name: Andreas Schwab
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Today's oral question to the Commission gives us the opportunity to make clear once again what we, on the one hand, and the Consumer Rights Directive, on the other, have made clear. Disadvantages or different treatment of consumers on the basis of their nationality or location are only permissible if there are compelling legal grounds for doing so. In the European Parliament, we are working hard and hard to ensure that the legal conditions for this are created and that, in future, different treatment is no longer permitted. We are aware that, of course, we also need a number of standardisations for this, so that businesses, on the one hand, and consumers, on the other, actually find a uniform regulatory environment. However, what we have seen with some suppliers – I am mentioning the Disneyland case from the summer – is that, although conditions in these areas are harmonised, there is still some abuse of attempts to impose different pricing models in Europe. And that is simply unacceptable. I call on the European Commission to take action here with all the possibilities it has at its disposal. I say this particularly because we know, of course, how difficult it is to achieve uniform conditions. We also have a constant debate about how much uniformity we can afford. There are many Member States that do not want to have harmonisation of certain areas of legal conditions. But if, even in the conditions where we have been brought to unification, at the end of the day, the consumer, the consumer, gets the impression that businesses can, in a sense, snatch the good part of the internal market for themselves, then this meets with our firm resistance. Commissioner, I would ask you to make a clear statement about what you intend to do in these cases.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I'm sorry to barge in during the session, but we have a problem with the Croatian translation, we just don't have a Croatian translation. Now we didn't have it in German, we didn't have it in English before, so be kind, I can understand some languages, but still I can't understand everything so I would ask you to try to see if we can get translations.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of my colleague Commissioner Elżbieta Bieńkowska, I am here to discuss this issue. The issue raised by the honourable Members touches at the heart of what EU citizens can expect of the single market. When shopping cross-border, our consumers are still being discriminated against on the basis of their nationality or place of residence. This is not acceptable. We keep on receiving complaints from citizens against alleged discriminatory practices, through various channels. First, direct complaints; second, complaints to European Consumer Centres; third, information requests to Your Europe Advice; and, fourth and most importantly, parliamentary questions. As democratically elected representatives, you act as a major interface between citizens and EU institutions. I cannot encourage you strongly enough to keep on sending us feedback from your constituents. With the rise of the internet, e-commerce is getting increasingly important, but many questions also concern transactions taking place on commercial premises. Online geo-blocking is one of the most visible and the most often described types of discrimination, with consumers being barred from completing transactions, or being redirected to another website offering the same service but at a higher price. Discrimination also takes place on a daily basis for millions of Europeans travelling abroad as tourists, buying a second home in another country, or just crossing the border. This must stop – and action has been announced in the digital single market strategy. The need for action will be expanded on in the internal market strategy for goods and services, to be adopted at the end of the month. On 24 September 2015, the Commission also launched a public consultation. The consultation will help the Commission prepare a legislative initiative in 2016. We all know examples of discriminatory practices. Last year, we initiated an action with the main car rental companies in Europe, after noticing very substantial price differences for exactly the same service, just depending on the place of residence of the customer. This year, you will have heard of press reports concerning a major amusement park in France, for which some special offers were limited to French residents. We also have examples of people being denied access to car-sharing with a non-national driving licence, or for the need to have a national registration number to buy a service. The current legal framework has not created enough certainty for businesses and consumers. It has not enabled national authorities to enforce the non-discrimination obligation in daily practice. This is what we are planning to address. Contractual freedom is an important principle, which must be preserved, but we must also tackle the voluntary segmentation of the single market by companies, and we must safeguard the rights of consumers. The interests of SMEs must also be protected. We want to encourage companies and consumers to use the single market, not force them to do so if it would be too burdensome or uncertain for them. My colleagues Elżbieta Bieńkowska and Günther Öttinger will be more than happy to discuss those challenges further in order to find solutions that open up the single market for companies and consumers alike.

name: Olga Sehnalová
text: On the basis of the S&D Group. It is therefore essential to clarify the legal framework for non-discrimination in the field of both services and goods. Clarification of the so-called objective criteria is essential. Conditions that are acceptable in exceptional cases to restrict access to goods and services must be clearly defined. It is also important to strengthen the cooperation of supervisory authorities so that they can pay close and coordinated attention to all possible forms of discrimination and make full use of the powers of the Consumer Protection Cooperation Network.  However, let us bear in mind that the elimination of so-called geoblocking is not only one of the biggest challenges in the creation of the digital internal market, but consumers also face discrimination in the offline environment. Let us therefore see differences between the rules applicable to offline and online purchases, which would be contrary to the idea of the internal market. I therefore call on the Commission to take these comments into account in the planned revision of the Consumer Protection Cooperation Regulation.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I am glad the Commission is fighting on this issue. The ALDE Group is looking forward to addressing this in a geo-blocking regulation complementing the services and e-commerce directives. Consumers across Europe face two huge barriers when trying to shop across borders: either they are denied delivery completely or delivery costs are so high that there can be no justifiable reason for them other than to prevent sales. If goods and content cannot cross borders, Europeans will not shop across borders.
