They will forever be locked within their national markets and subject to higher prices due to a lack of full and honest competition. Commissioner, when combined with different prices based on location, there can be no doubt that this is a case of discrimination by companies, based if not on nationality then on place of residence – discrimination if not because I am Czech then because I live in Prague. Some small businesses have said that it is not discrimination, but that they simply cannot handle the problems associated with language and returns. Maybe they are right and we need to do more on those problems, as is provided for in the strategy. But, Commissioner, on what grounds can a giant company justify this denial of service? Normally I am against overregulating businesses. I honestly believe that most businesses want to do right by their customers and thereby attract more customers, but this is clearly a case where we must act to stop this illegal price discrimination and segmenting of the market. This is pure price discrimination and it should not be acceptable in the digital single market.

name: Patrick O’Flynn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, it is all very well for the Commission to highlight the problem of geo-blocking and to pose as a consumer champion, but arguably the Commission itself deserves to be ranked as the Geo-blocker in Chief. Over-regulation by the Commission has made it much more difficult than it need be for SMEs to sell abroad. The recent VAT Mini One-Stop Shop (VAT MOSS) measure is a case in point: SMEs have to pay this tax on e-commerce sales in every single member country that they sell to, and the result has been a mass withdrawal of micro-businesses from export markets and a consequent narrowing of consumer choice. Far too often, the Commission, as well as the EU in general, becomes the problem rather than the solution. I do not doubt that it wishes to do good; I do ask that it opens its eyes to the harm it is doing in practice to the prosperity of what is fast becoming the world’s economically least dynamic continent.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I begin by congratulating the authors of the oral question. I am part of the IMCO Committee and we often discuss this in the committee: it is not enough to have a directive on services, unless we have an accurate monitoring of what is happening in the market. Because, indeed, we want a unified framework and, as my colleague Eveline said, very often you want to move to another country to make an online purchase. Discrimination is not only about price, as my other colleague said, but also about delivery time and many other quality-related things. I think it is important for the Commission to take note of this question, but we would also be waiting for a concrete answer: what can be done to have, indeed, an improvement in the quality of uniform application in the Member States of the Services Directive and, above all, what can be done to stop this discrimination? I think we need to act and preventively, not to be in the case of Volkswagen, to find out when things are too serious.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, we are discussing consumer rights and how the Member States should ensure that they are not discriminated against on the basis of the nationality and place of residence of the addressee. Firstly, Member States must monitor the proper implementation of existing legislation on online services. Often, some consumers from small Member States face several difficulties in the process of receiving the items they want, while in some cases, online providers refuse to deliver the items to consumers. It is therefore necessary for the European Union to put an end to the unjustified exclusion of consumers from the market for any goods or services if this move infringes their basic rights. In addition, in the context of e-commerce, the additional burden on the consumer for transport costs should be stopped if he has not been informed of this in advance. Finally, immediate measures should be taken by the European Union to make a targeted change in the way e-commerce is conducted, without violating consumer rights.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, geoblocking is one of the most perfidous discriminations we face in this day and age of the single market and is one of the biggest obstacles that new technologies offer in creating a Digital Single Market. The European Union was created precisely by the uniqueness of the market and the desire for a single market, and today we face that technologies prevent us from further development.  That is why, and also because of the personal experiences I have had and the experiences my colleagues have had, I would really like to call on the Commission to try to do as much and as soon as possible to prevent this perfidish way of market marketing with various products and services and for Europe to truly develop the Digital Single Market.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the creation of telecommunications networks and digital services that can cross national borders is essential in order to support the digital single market strategy in Europe.  Account must be taken of the primary value of consumer protection, which deserves the highest possible system of protection of both transactions and the usability of the purchased good, without geoblocking. For protective European legislation that exalted growth, transparency of online purchasing processes, uniform application of the legislative framework and the equal conditions for the performance of the service are therefore categorical imperatives. The signals coming from the last Judgment of the Court of Justice of 6 October 2015, which, in declaring the so-called 'safe harbour' regime invalid, have made it clear that the flow of sensitive consumer data must be protected and not used to their detriment, as is the case in geoblocks. I hope that the Commission will take on board the Court's decisum and the complex scenarios it offers, working together to balance the objective of supporting the Digital Single Market Strategy and protecting consumers in their free use of online content and services.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to thank the honourable Members again for their questions and comments on this very important issue of consumer protection and discrimination. This is an issue on which we can all agree that the current situation is not acceptable, when we look at the potential we are promising to our citizens and consumers in the internal market. In the current situation, we are supposed to have access to online and cross-border purchases, yet we cannot be fully guaranteed that because the offer is not available to another country, or because we cannot be sure of getting fair treatment compared to another consumer. The internal market is about offering everyone the chance to access – everywhere on EU territory – the services he or she needs, even from another EU country. I want to be clear: freedoms always have to be balanced against one another and there is not any which is more important than the other. So we need to balance contractual freedom with the right of consumers not to be unfairly discriminated against because of their place of residence. But we also need to recognise that there is no ‘obligation to sell’ or to unify prices throughout the single market. Where this balance lies will depend on the outcome of the consultation and the discussions with the stakeholders and Member States. Article 20 of the Services Directive lays down the basic principles which Member States should implement and apply. If a Member State is in breach of these principles, the Commission can initiate action against the Member State.  It appears that many Member States have not taken sufficient action to put this principle of non-discrimination into practice. Buying online has aggravated the current problems and a more comprehensive, effective and consumer-friendly solution is necessary. Legislative proposals will be made by the Commission as a follow-up to the Digital Single Market Strategy and the forthcoming Internal Market Strategy.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate has been closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. – I applaud the presentation of the Digital Single Market Strategy by the European Commission following the priorities put forward by the Juncker Commission, which responds to the challenges of the digital age. The Digital Single Market should ensure the free movement of goods, persons, services and capital, and citizens and businesses should benefit from unrescanted access to online activities and to carry out such activities under conditions of fair competition and with a high level of protection of consumers and their personal data, regardless of their nationality or place of residence. Although these principles are already enshrined in Article 20(2) of the Services Directive, complemented by Article 8(3) of the Consumer Rights Directive, European consumers are currently faced with major problems in online purchases for territorial reasons, either by denying delivery in another Member State, by price discrimination or by geo-blocking of ip address. This opportunity must be taken to put an end to these unjustified limitations by replacing consumers at the heart of the Digital Market, adapting existing rules to our societal realities and changing the paradigm of justification of the exception to guarantee the benefits of the Internal Market to consumers.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the Central African Republic (2015/2874(RSP)).

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: Author. – Despite the efforts of the international community, the humanitarian and security situation of the CAR remains dramatic and even deteriorating. The European Union's mission, the bridging mission, has been a success, which has also been assessed by SEDE members visiting the Central African Republic, but seems to have lasted too short. The intertieve of unfortunate circumstances surrounding the operation of MINUSCA, the UN mission, meant that it could not effectively fulfil its mandate. I appreciate the commitment of the UN Secretary-General, the Security Council, but it seems that the international community should step up its efforts to support the Central African Republic. This could be an outbreak of really dramatic radicalisation and a deterioration in the security situation.

name: Louis Michel
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, the ceasefire that took place in April 2015, the holding of the Bangui National Forum for Reconciliation last May, the disarmament, demobilisation, reintegration and repatriation agreement finally allow us to rebuild a real political perspective. We must once again thank France for its involvement, we could have hoped, on the part of the European countries, a little more solidarity and commitment. I would also like to take this opportunity to congratulate Mrs Samba-Panza and the transitional authorities on their determination to complete the ongoing process.  On 3 June, they enacted a law establishing the Special Criminal Court, the adoption by the National Transitional Council of the draft constitution, which is due to be put to a referendum shortly.  The main message of my speech is that it is essential that we hold general, free, reliable and transparent elections before the end of the year, that is, that we scrupulously respect the agenda.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in the Central African Republic is yet another situation that is in danger of degenerating into an out-of-control civil war, and this is yet another situation in Africa in which we are faced with a country that is very rich in resources, full of opportunities for growth, but which in reality always remains submissive to a different colonisation, because it is true that the official one is over. , that of the Member States, French, but it is true that the economic market has begun, especially on the wood market. And here we can take the example of our inconsistent policies, because we have concluded several agreements as the European Union, but, even today, there are many NGOs which, around the export of wood, there is the financing of rebels and therefore the cause of these conflicts.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the recent outbreak of violence between the different religious communities of the Central African Republic is very worrying and this deterioration in the situation is a new episode in the crisis that the country has been facing since 2012.  Over the past three years, extremely serious crimes have been committed in the Central African Republic, including war crimes and crimes against humanity. We therefore need to act very clearly, for example we need a functioning and indispensable judicial system to carry out a thorough investigation into all violations of human rights and international humanitarian law. and democratic. We need to work in this direction.

name: Tunne Kelam
text: author. – Mr President, the September wave of new clashes indicates how volatile the situation really is in the Central African Republic. I am really concerned about the threat of a revival of sectarian fighting. Last Saturday, two Christian churches were set ablaze or ransacked. Then a mosque and Muslim radio headquarters were attacked. There was an attempt to murder one of the top Christian leaders there. Therefore, the most important task is to contain the violence and return the country to national reconciliation, the rule of law and regular elections. I think it is important to avoid formally opposing Muslims and Christians, a practice being misused by political and economic groups. For example, the so—called anti—Balaka militia is falsely labelled as Christian, whereas it has animist roots or whatever. Therefore, international pressure and more humanitarian aid are needed and, as I mentioned, regular elections are what we expect next.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: Author. – The conflict in the Central African Republic, together with those in Syria and Sudan, is one of the biggest humanitarian crises now, but that in the Central African Republic is getting a lot less attention. It seems to have been forgotten. The rebels in the Central African Republic are responsible for executions, rapes, kidnappings and mass looting. 2.7 million people, almost half the population, need help, but aid agencies, such as the Red Cross, can no longer even offer their services in the capital Bangui. Patients have to go to the hospital on foot. Yesterday, a blue helmet was killed in a rebel firefight.  These rebel armies pay their people with the trade in diamonds and hardwood. There is a temporary halt to the trade in diamonds, but that ban is both being evaded and stocks are building up. As soon as diamonds can be officially traded again, these diamonds will be on the market. The population will not benefit from this. In fact, it is once again funding rebels. European companies also buy this hardwood and these diamonds from these rebels. Amnesty International has just done a major investigation into this. There are Belgian companies that trade there. I call on European companies to stop doing so now, because the money must go away from the rebels or that conflict will never end.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: Author. Mr President, the Central African Republic is facing the worst humanitarian crisis since independence. The entire population is affected and two and a half million people, or half the population, mainly children, are in need of emergency assistance, including food aid. This is not a simple confrontation between religious communities but an instrumentalization of them. Security disturbances are perpetrated by political-military groups, against a background of grabbing resources, including timber and diamonds, with the complicity of large multinationals.  The European Union should therefore focus its action primarily on a political and non-military resolution of the conflict, addressing its roots, that is, underdevelopment and the fight against corruption.  A transparent and independent investigation into allegations of crimes committed by both the French forces of Sangaris and those of the United Nations is necessary because these acts are intolerable.  We will not vote in favour of this resolution, which welcomes the actions taken. They failed. Unfortunately, the result is there and we have doubts about the possibility of holding elections in good conditions.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Central African Republic is one of the poorest countries in the world and, as many colleagues have said, is facing the biggest humanitarian crisis since independence in 1960. 20% of the population are refugees – internally moved, resettled. It is important that the European Union has increased its support to the CAR not only in the form of humanitarian aid, but also in the areas of health development, job creation and women's economic integration. However, I call for a strengthening of the political message on issues such as peace-building, security and respect for human rights.

name: Gilles Pargneaux
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr President, Commissioner, peace is once again faltering in the Central African Republic: 61 dead, 300 wounded last week in Bangui. I was part of the European Parliament delegation last February, which has provided a number of proposals and actions that remain relevant, Commissioner. First of all, we must quickly, now, hold legislative elections. This political transition, however desired by the President, Catherine Samba-Panza, does not exist and, therefore, we must do everything possible to organize these legislative elections. Our priority is to disarm the militias. We must carry out this action to disarm the militias.  Then, to put an end to violence and instability, we must prepare for the future. I invite all Member States that have not yet done so to participate in the Bêkou fund. This fund has 54 million euros for the long-term development of the country. That is not enough. We must therefore ensure, Commissioner, that you are proactive so that all Member States are part of this fund.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, we know that the plundering of natural resources is the cause of misery and poverty throughout Africa. In the case of the Central African Republic, we know the interest of multinational companies in oil, wood and diamonds. According to different NGOs, the largest gemstone and timber companies would have participated in some way in the financing of armed groups responsible for summary executions, rapes and enforced disappearances. And I wonder: how long are you going to allow this resource expo to continue? When are they going to end intervention policies and military policies that favor the interests of multinationals? And finally, I also wonder what they are going to do to prevent international trade in diamonds stored during the conflict.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the recent outbreak of violence between different religious communities in the Central African Republic is highly alarming, with approximately 50 people killed, 100 injured and 30 000 displaced since 26 September 2015. I therefore strongly support the call for maximising support for stabilisation, peace-building and humanitarian efforts in the Central African Republic. We need the EU and its Member States to do all they can to bring the country back from the brink, ensuring better civilian protection as soon as possible and accelerating the disarmament of militias. Inadequate assistance is likely to lead to further instability and to increased flows of refugees and displaced people. The Government of the Central Africa Republic should address the root causes of the crisis, such as widespread poverty and regional disparities and inequalities, and should reinforce governmental structures in administration, fight corruption and promote an inclusive economic recovery. Only strong action supported by the efforts of the international community can re-establish reconciliation, security and trust in the state institutions.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the Central African Republic is a rich country; He's got diamonds, he's got lumber. And yet, at the moment, it is facing a humanitarian crisis, the worst humanitarian crisis since it gained independence in 1960. All 4.5 million of its population are in trouble, while half of its inhabitants are children. So you understand that the problem is serious. Conflicts which appear to be religious conflicts, in the background, are based on the very exploitation of natural resources and, above all, of resources. That's what these conflicts are about. At the same time, many diamond and gemstone companies are directly related to armed groups, which are responsible for rapes, deaths, looting, etc. The international community must therefore intervene immediately. The European Union must be more determined to stop this situation, to bring about peace in the region and, above all, to exploit gems and diamonds in favour of the people of the Central African Republic themselves.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, the Central African Republic is a country that has undergone various processes in recent years – from reconciliation, from attempts to normalize relations, to the currently evident deterioration of the situation, to the fact that we have come to the situation that peacekeeping missions have been attacked, to having murders, robberies and robberies in recent weeks. The big question is whether the elections will solve the problem. Of course elections are what is most democratic and if everyone respects the results of the elections then we can expect that the elections are likely to solve the problem or at least pave the way for solving the problem.  However, the fact is that there are still various hidden interests that exist when we talk about the great resources that the Central African Republic has, especially when we talk about diamonds and wood, and the big question is whether the elections alone will solve the problem or whether the problem will be solved by our continued engagement in the Central African Republic and in other countries that are of interest to the European Union.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Central African Republic, we are talking about a country where in 2014 there was one child who died a day, in which as many as 10 000 people were drafted in the same year by the various factions in the struggle.  Since 1960, this state has experienced virtually a constant state of instability and civil war, thanks also to ethnic and religious fragmentation, but above all thanks to the so-called economic neo-colonisation that has led to a state in which we have a clear lack of means of transport, often the injured cannot be taken to hospitals, where drinking water covers a ridiculous area of the country. As always, the richer you are with resources, the poorer the citizens.  Mr Corrao mentioned fine wood, the intervention of the European multinationals, could also be extended very well to diamonds, but unfortunately they have not been included in the draft dossier on conflict minerals by this Parliament and the Commission. There must also be a very strong condemnation of the violence perpetrated by the military forces of other countries on peacekeeping missions, and we must therefore make themselves credible in order to disarm them. If we do not put an end to the action of our multinationals, it is very difficult to emerge from the political and humanitarian crisis and we will hardly have credible elections.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we welcome the adoption of Parliament’s urgent resolution on the new outbreak of violence in the Central African Republic (CAR). The European Union condemns in the strongest terms the recent violence, as voiced in the statement from the spokesperson for the High Representative/Vice-President issued on 28 September 2015. Those behind these actions, in and outside the country, should be held accountable.  Deplorably, humanitarian workers have again been targeted, and prevented from doing their work. We also call for the observance of international humanitarian law. I want to express the European Union’s solidarity with the victims of these last few days. The overwhelming majority of citizens of the Central African Republic deserve – for the country’s prospects for peace and recovery – and demand an end to conflict and division between communities. At a time when the country is nearing the end of the transition, recent events demonstrate that elections, reconciliation and security should remain our priorities for the coming months. I want to reiterate the EU’s strong support for the transitional authorities. In particular, I would like to compliment the transition Head of State, Catherine Samba-Panza.  There is no alternative to the transition process. The electoral process must continue. Everything must be done to achieve a level of inclusiveness, transparency and credibility that will lead to an outcome accepted by all: a legitimate, post-transition government with a new constitution endorsed by the majority of the country’s citizens. This needs to go hand in hand with renewed efforts for reconciliation and the restoration of social cohesion. Security remains another priority, not only in view of the elections. The CAR is still too dangerous a place – there should be no tolerance for any party which refuses to abide by the Disarmament and Cessation of Hostilities and Violence agreements. The EU recalls that there can be no reconciliation without justice. Also, let us not lose sight of the still ongoing humanitarian crisis affecting over half of the population. The European Union will continue to provide humanitarian assistance to those in need. Furthermore, it is building bridges between humanitarian aid and longer-term development action. This is the objective of the Bêkou Trust Fund that has mobilised to date EUR 108 million. The European Union remains fully committed, together with its partners on the ground, to assist the people of the Central African Republic in the humanitarian field. To close: the CAR is at a turning point in its history. It can set an example of recovery and stabilisation. It will require goodwill and, above all, determination by the leaders in Bangui and all of the international community. Thus, it is important to keep the CAR on the international agenda at this very critical moment of the transition process. Today’s urgent debate is a concrete contribution to preventing the CAR becoming a forgotten crisis again.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debates.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the situation in Thailand (2015/2875(RSP)).

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: Author. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Thailand is a country known to us Europeans, especially from very pleasant holidays spent in this country, is a tourist destination for many residents of the Member States of the European Union. However, in a political sense Thailand associates less nicely. Of course, these are events that have been going on in this country for two years now, from the great protests of the opposition, to the introduction of martial law in this country. It seems that Thailand, one of those 'tigers' of Southeast Asia at the time when it comes to economic issues, must today hear very clearly from our Parliament, from the European Union, the demand for real democracy, because that is what this nation absolutely deserves. In my opinion, in the opinion of my political group too, it is very necessary not only to monitor the situation in this country very clearly, but also to indicate that our economic cooperation, cooperation between the Union and Thailand will depend on whether human rights are respected in this country or not.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: proposers. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The Thai people are close friends of ours in Europe. Not least in my country, Sweden, there are many, many people who feel that Thailand is their second home. However, friends must also be able to speak honestly with each other. Friends can also withstand criticism. The truth is that developments in Thailand in terms of fundamental human rights and freedoms are very, very deeply worrying. The people of Thailand deserve a life of full freedom – with the right to choose their lives, the right to elect their political representatives and the right to live in a democracy.  I would now call on the Thai authorities to ensure immediately that respect for fundamental human rights and freedoms is restored and that democracy is restored.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I agree with what Mr Czarnecki said about the fact that when we talk about Thailand in our imagination it is often and willingly a beautiful tourist destination for European citizens and that almost no one knows under what political conditions the country is spilling over.  Since the coup d'état, we have seen an escalation of repression, an escalation of violence, a situation in which anyone who opposes the military regime is nevertheless silenced. It is true that relations have eased somewhat between the European Union and Thailand, but it is also true that we, as the European Union, are still able to put pressure on the military junta to set up a process leading to democratisation in the country. And that is what we must try to do through our economic, as well as diplomatic, strength, to try to bring Thailand back into a democratic process, because it is really very important.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Thailand has long been experiencing a serious political and institutional crisis.  It is a country where human rights are not fully safeguarded. We must close with the current phase and there are two points that we want to highlight: firstly, it is important to give the country a new democratic Constitution and set the date for the elections, and to respect this date in order to ensure the transition from the military junta to a democratic government. Secondly, it is essential to focus on the issue of human rights and, in particular, on the rights of workers who are seriously questioned. The UN has described the current situation of fisheries workers as a modern form of slavery, as well as in the Natural Fruit pineapple factory denounced by British activist Andy Hall.  These abuses must be combated and we call on the European Union not to conclude any fisheries agreement unless these problems are tackled and resolved.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thailand is an important partner of the EU in both the political and economic sense. This makes it all the more important that the EU, as thailand's friend and partner, addresses worrying developments in terms of human rights and democracy. Thailand must do all it can to return to a democratic civilian government as soon as possible and to keep to the timetable for the forthcoming elections. The Thai Government can orientate itself on its own constitution and on international obligations with regard to the independence of the judiciary, freedom of expression, freedom of association and assembly. The arbitrary arrests of dissidents must stop. The Regional Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights documented 1 222 arbitrary arrests between May 2014 and August 2015 alone. After the arrest, in many cases, so-called behavioural change sessions take place, which take place in isolation detention on military bases. I welcome the fact that the Thai Government has taken action to combat illegal fishing and trafficking in human beings. Many men work on fishing boats under conditions that can be called slavery. Workers are bought and forced not to leave the ship and sometimes work for years without pay. Migrants from Malaysia and Cambodia and Rohingyas from Myanmar are particularly affected. The Thai Government must also implement the measures and controls that have been taken consistently.

name: Jeroen Lenaers
text: author. – Madam President, this debate on this resolution is a result of our commitment to, and our friendship with, the Thai people. Because of this friendship and commitment there can be only one priority for the EU with regard to Thailand and that is for Thailand to return as soon as possible to a democratic society with an elected civil and representative government. We therefore urge the Thai authorities not only to stick to the presented timeline for a new constitution, with elections in mid-2017, but also to present a constitution that is based on democracy, equality, freedom and fundamental rights. This is something we are concerned about because, if a constitution is to be future-proof, the process needs to be inclusive. It needs to be transparent, and people need to have the opportunity to participate. We have seen increasingly worrying reports of deteriorating human rights in Thailand. We call on the Thai authorities to lift all measures that restrict freedom of assembly and freedom of speech, and to allow for the genuine political involvement of all citizens.

name: Tania González Peñas
text: Author. – Madam President, the European Parliament cannot tolerate widespread human rights abuses by the military government in Thailand, which, in addition to endangering the lives of its people, jeopardizes the momentum towards democratic progress in the region. Equally worrying are the conditions of workers in Thailand and especially those of migrant workers and natural fruit abuses. It is not enough that the European Commission has temporarily suspended trade treaty negotiations with Thailand; under no circumstances should these negotiations be resumed. But, moreover, it is necessary to immediately suspend the system of generalized preferences and strictly apply human rights clauses.  Similarly, it is unacceptable that the export of arms to a country that flagrantly violates human rights will continue.  We urge that a civil and democratic government be reinstated immediately and demand the release of all persons detained for political reasons and imprisoned by the military junta since the coup.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, the political situation in Thailand is at an impasse. We have, on the one hand, a military regime that has taken power by force and wants to maintain itself for as long as possible, and, on the other hand, social tensions which are the result of a tightening of the power in place, particularly in the area of freedom of expression. The European Union has a long and strong political, economic and cultural relationship with Thailand. Our role now is to support a democratic transition in the country and to push the military junta to accelerate the electoral calendar. Indeed, the Prime Minister announced that the process of drafting the constitution should take twenty months, which would delay the elections until June 2017. This timetable does not represent an acceptable solution for the people, who want to see the return of a legitimate civilian government as soon as possible. The recent appointment by the government of a new commission to draft a constitution, as well as the release of several journalists, is to be welcomed. These are positive signals, but much remains to be done. Only the organization of free and transparent elections will allow the Thai government to regain the trust and respect of the population.

name: Anneliese Dodds
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I welcome this resolution on the situation in Thailand. Since the military coup in May 2014, hundreds of people have been arbitrarily arrested and detained. Sweeping and unchecked powers have been given to the military, as has been mentioned. Media outlets and websites have been censored and the rights of freedom of expression and peaceful assembly have been massively restricted. I am particularly concerned about the situation of Andy Hall, a British human rights defender. Mr Hall faces seven years in prison and a multi-million-pound fine simply for conducting research for a report by a human rights group. The report highlighted abuses of migrant workers in Thailand by a Thai company called Natural Fruits. The charges made against Andy Hall are utterly unfounded and he appears to have received this treatment simply because he had the temerity to expose labour exploitation. I call on the Thai authorities to adhere to their human rights obligations and to drop all charges against Mr Hall.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, like the previous speaker, I also want to emphasise the call for all charges against Andy Hall to be dropped. He is a workers’ rights defender and a UK, and thus an EU, citizen. Human rights defenders must have the possibility to expose human rights violations. Andy Hall contributed to a Finnwatch report in 2013, which showed that labour abuses and slavery—like practices are a reality in the activity of a Thai pineapple wholesaler, Natural Fruit. He should be rewarded for this, not threatened with seven years in prison. His next hearing will be held on 19 October 2015. The High Representative should now condemn the judicial harassment of Andy Hall and the EU should demand that Thailand investigate the allegations against Natural Fruit. The EU should provide financial support for Andy Hall’s legal defence, just as he received support as a human rights defender in 2013. Finally, the EU should find out whether Natural Fruit is still continuing to export to the EU, and should ensure that consumers have the right to know the origin of products.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – It is clear that the EP parliamentary group and the entire European Union expect the normalisation of Thai politics: we want military power to be replaced by civilian governance through free and democratic elections, and for the process of drafting the new constitution to end as soon as possible and for a basic law based on equality, freedom and the rule of law to be adopted. I think that the European Union has the opportunity to support this process, because europe is the largest working capital investor in the Member States of ASEAN. We have invested more in the region than the United States and Japan combined! And as trading partners, only China is overtaking us. Of course, respect for human rights, including the rights of national minorities, is an essential part of economic, political and cultural development. Even some EU Member States are often happy to forget this within the EU, even in their own Member States.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thailand is an important partner of Europe, not only in tourism, but also in trade. Thailand is also a strategic partner. We are therefore concerned to observe that there have been increasing restrictions on democracy, that there are more and more violations of human rights and, above all, that there is a systematic violation of social and workers' rights. I share the concern for Andy Hall. This is a symptomatic case and I hope that the Thai authorities will drop these allegations very soon. I would also like to note that there are tentative steps towards normalisation in Thailand. I hope that Thailand will have the courage to restore democratic conditions quickly and quickly. Perhaps we could use our trade policy to help make this easier and quicker.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, developments in Thailand in recent years certainly cannot be described as favourable, but they do not seem to deserve a clear condemnation either. There are signs that the situation there is gaining better prospects. Evidence is, for example, the abolition of martial law this spring. The truth, however, is that even after martial law is abolished, the current government retains a number of superior powers. An example is arbitrary and so-called security detention, in 2014 a human rights organization lists 300 people who have been thrown into it. It is precisely these powers that, in my view, need to be monitored, mindful of the complexity of the situation there, and to draw attention to cases where these rights are being violated. In my opinion, we should not be content with the promise that the return of civil rights will only be linked to the adoption of a new constitution, but, on the contrary, we should require that the circle of rights actually respected by the Thai authorities be expanded gradually already.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, since the military coup, the human rights situation in Thailand has been getting worse. No one speaks freely anymore, any word against the monarchy or the power in power is repressed and led to arbitrary arrests.  Accusations of lèse-majesté have multiplied since the military coup and anyone who has dared to speak out against the regime or monarchy is likely to undergo behavioural adjustment sessions, a form of recall to the police station and aimed at putting them back on track. Hundreds of websites have been shut down and freedom of expression is now a utopian concept.  I would like to encourage all human rights defenders who are doing all they can to defend essential rights in Thailand. I would also like to congratulate Ms. Mutita Chuachang, a Thai journalist, who has just received the 2015 Kate Webb Award from Agence France-Presse, which aims to support journalists working in very difficult conditions in Asia.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, since the coup d'état of 22 May 2014, which took place in Thailand, the arrests, prosecutions and imprisonments of all those who resist, of all those who support human rights have intensified. The situation is now unacceptable. Indeed, on August 14, 2015, the military junta passed a law banning public gatherings and even providing for up to 10 years in prison if someone violates that law. You understand, then, that this situation cannot continue, and there should be no beautification of what is happening in Thailand because there are European investments, because turnover is created.  Democracy must therefore be restored, rights must begin to be protected, elections must be held and, above all, labour rights must be protected. In fact, we have heard complaints that the situation in the fisheries sector looks like slavery. Democracy must therefore be brought back to Thailand.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We know Thailand as a country with friendly inhabitants, with great tradition, high culture, hospitable and economically also very successful. Of course, martial law does not correspond to our European democratic ideas. However, we should be careful not to apply double standards. On the one hand, we criticise the supply of arms and criticise human rights and working conditions, but we do apply double standards. I miss the same standards in other countries, such as Saudi Arabia. However, we should continue to monitor the individual political groups, the individual political players closely, and not come with our fingers and present ourselves as European schoolmasters. I am optimistic that the work on the new constitution will be successful and that the 2017 elections will be scheduled, timely and democratic.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, considering the deteriorating situation of human rights and freedoms in Thailand, as evidenced by the severe censorship of TV channels and community radio situations, the arbitrary detaining of people and the arrest of 14 activists from the Neo-Democracy Movement, I support the call on the Thai military authorities to lift repressive restrictions on the right to liberty and the peaceful exercise of other human rights, in particular those relevant to peaceful involvement in political activities. Concerning the situation of the workers’ rights defender, Andy Hall, who is facing seven years in prison and a multi-million-dollar fine for defamation after contributing to a report alleging labour abuses by a Thai pineapple wholesaler, I welcome the call in this resolution for the dismissal of all charges against him, since his actions, as a human rights defender, were directed at exposing instances of human trafficking and improving the legal situation of migrant workers in Thailand.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I completely agree with the House. Thailand is an important partner, including in our relations with the whole region. Thailand is an ancient and proud nation which is admired and loved for its nature, its culture and, most of all, for its people. Our main concern is the lack of progress in solving what seems to be a cycle of political conflict – at times violent political conflict – and military takeovers. Thailand needs to bridge divides in society as in politics. The bridges are not being built yet. Respecting human rights is essential for solving Thailand’s crisis. Human rights violations are an offence to human dignity and also a major obstacle to long-term stability and prosperity. Freedom of expression, not censorship; freedom of assembly, not restrictions or ‘attitude adjustments’; due process of law, not judging civilians in military courts: all these are prerequisites for an inclusive and peaceful process which should lead, without further delay, to the establishment of full democracy. It is against this background that we welcome the focus on Thailand’s situation and today’s debate, and I would stress the importance of Parliament’s calls for respect for human rights and for Thailand’s early return to democratic governance.  The European Union has done much already and will continue its policy of critical engagement taking a value-based approach. Our approach was first established with the Council conclusions of 23 June 2014, which called for the urgent restoration of the legitimate democratic process as well as respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. It has since been followed with public statements and work for positive change. We have stepped up our work in many different ways, such as diplomatic monitoring of key court cases and meetings with those fighting for democracy and human rights. Allow me to raise one last important problem which pre-dates the military takeover and which a number of MEPs are very concerned about: forced labour in the Thai seafood industry. We are fully aware of this dramatic problem, and we will continue to take it up with our Thai counterparts. On the positive side, the Thai authorities have publicly declared that they will address it, and have already taken some initial constructive steps, but much still needs to be done. No person should be working in slave-like conditions in the 21st century.  European consumers and European buyers are increasingly aware of how the goods they consume are produced, and demand transparency and socially responsible supply chains. The day before yesterday, Parliament strongly supported the swift ratification within the EU of the International Labour Organisation protocol against forced labour. I hope Thailand follows your example very soon. To conclude, the European Union is not just a fair-weather friend. The debate here today and Parliament’s commitment are proof of our solidarity and continued friendship with the people of Thailand. We will remain engaged with the Government of Thailand, and we call for the early return to democratic governance in the country, as was stated in the Council conclusions of June 2014. Lastly, regarding Mr Andrew Hall, a labour rights activist, I congratulate our colleagues on raising this issue. The European Union has been following the situation of Mr Hall closely for quite some time. The delegation there will arrange observation of his trial on 19 October 2015. The European Union will continue to monitor the situation closely and to raise concerns with the authorities.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, 8 October 2015 at 12:00. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. – I support this resolution due to the state of emergency in Thailand, which was triggered primarily by the fact that on 20 May 2014 the government there was overthrown by the state army, followed by lawlessness and unrest.  Restricting freedom of assembly and imposing severe penalties for offences such as disrupting the work of public services are just some of the factors in Thailand's alarming situation. Also, there are numerous cases of human rights violations, such as accusations of peaceful protests against riots and violations of the law, or the fact that the death penalty still applies regularly.  Likewise, the state of security of local communities and activists has been exacerbated by the military coup itself that military personnel have been appointed "law and order maintenance officers" to arbitrarily detain people, conduct investigations and conduct searches without a warrant.  According to international treaties, Thailand has a duty to investigate such cases and to take measures for serious human rights violations.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Author. – Today, some 1.2 million children roam north-east Nigeria, defenseless, distraught, traumatized, fleeing the barbaric violence of Boko Haram's nomadic war machine. Human rights and children's rights are of no use. This is the destruction of an entire generation. But I am also addressing the new Nigerian President: Mr Buhari, protect your children. Proof that you can make a difference, because despite the oil dollars, the country has not been able to protect its own people. Poignant of how a country can be at the top of oil suppliers, but is in the world's wealth cellar. This poverty in the first way further fuelles violence. Soldiers are demotivated and the impoverished population is easy prey for terrorists and for the doctrine of Boko Haram. And let us not forget to look in the mirror, Commissioner. Can the EU offer the country a better prospect of a better future through its current trade and development policy? A strong signal requires not only words, but also actions. Thank you.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz
text: Author. – Madam President, Boko Haram's is the most heinous face of religious and political fanaticism. Those who destroy the possibility of a decent future in the communities they attack do so precisely for this purpose. That's why they attack children, who are the future. That's why they especially attack schoolchildren and use sexual rape as a weapon. If they're left out of school, let's set up schools. If they're sexually attacked, let's give them back their dignity. Let us protect children in Nigeria and, after victimization, let us particularly support them, let us return them to the community. The most vulnerable must be our absolute priority in Nigeria and that is why we are presenting this Resolution and, therefore, we must not forget the case of Nigeria or, especially, the case of children. It's something we owe them and it's something we owe ourselves as an international community.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, when we talk about the situation of children in Nigeria, and therefore about displacement due to Boko Haram's activity in the country, it is clear that we must refer to the general situation in Nigeria, which is the richest country in Africa, but systematically one of the most dangerous countries where there is more poverty, as a paradox, and where there are situations such as the one we are describing. Millions of children are fleeing, millions of children, as reported by Unicef, the United Nations agency for the rights of the child, for whom there is also a lack of funds for water, including basic rights, and we should commit ourselves to this as the European Parliament and try to push the international community to find that money. We must not overlook another aspect, namely that it is Nigeria, and so the children we are talking about are children who are being used as child soldiers, and this is also an issue on which we are doing very little and there are a great many complaints that do not only concern Nigeria, but which relate to this issue. Above all, we should try to ensure that these children, when they are taken from the militias, are included in social reintegration programmes and not punished as soldiers.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in Nigeria, the insecurity caused by the conflict between the armed Boko Haram group, the military forces and civilian self-defence groups has forced more than 1 400 000 children, half of them under five, to leave their homes and flee.  The humanitarian situation continues to deteriorate due to difficulties in finding food, drinking water, health services and children are at risk of dying from malaria, malnutrition and being involved in a cycle of violence, separated from their families, exposed to exploitation and recruited into armed groups. Young women and girls have been kidnapped and subjected to forced marriages, physical and psychological abuse, forced labour and rape. In addition, children are often tied up in bombs and blown up in public places.  Hence this resolution and our strong call for this situation to be seriously addressesed by the international community, starting with the European Union.

name: Maria Heubuch
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The situation in Nigeria is dramatic. Meanwhile, even Boko Haram has sworn allegiance to the Islamic State, forming an unspeakable coalition – an alliance that is supposed to spread terror further across the country and, in fact, across this continent. In the last few months alone, Boko Haram has killed some 1,600 civilians. Hundreds of thousands are on the run, including many children. And Nigeria has the highest number of children in the world who do not attend school, precisely because of the terror of Boko Haram. We have heard a great deal about this from the previous speakers. This is where the international community must shoulder its responsibilities and keep its promises on humanitarian aid. I therefore very much welcome, Commissioner Stylianides, that the funds for the victims of Boko Haram are to be increased. But I think, despite everything, there is a bit of hope in Nigeria. We have seen a change of government, a democratic change, peaceful, which is not self-evident in Africa. And the new president has now presented a program that sounds promising – among other things, in terms of fighting corruption, protecting women and children, and the way the military is deployed against Boko Haram. And now we very much hope that this programme will be implemented. I believe that we must now do everything we can to support this government, to support this region, so that the new programme is truly successful.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà
text: Author. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as head of the European Union's electoral mission in Nigeria, I have been to Nigeria four times this year, and next Monday I will return to present the final report to the new Government. Within the terrible situation in the northwest of the country, due to attacks by the terrorist gang Boko Haram, the situation in which thousands of girls who have been raped, forced to convert to Islam, forced to marry and, in many cases, used as suicide girls under penalty of being buried alive , and that is not counting the thousands of displaced persons and their families, who have had to leave their homes and are in a situation of great precariousness. From Europe we cannot stand by in the face of so much horror. We must not be left alone in a formal condemnation of these terrible terrorist acts, but we must give our effective support to the new Government and the coalition of African states which has finally set out to end the terrorist scourge of Boko Haram.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: Author. – Madam President, Nigeria is the most populous country in Africa and is also one of the richest and largest economies on the continent, with significant oil reserves. However, more than seventy million Nigerians live below the poverty line. Inequality between people and despair are the perfect breeding ground for violence. There is not only a need for humanitarian assistance. Boko Haram's causes must also be found in our external policies, including trade, which continue to impoverish Africa. It is children who are the main victims of violence, as they are abducted, recruited and sexually exploited by Boko Haram and deprived of absolutely all their rights as children. The European Union must be coherent. If our trade policy continues to impoverish Africa and if we do nothing for the sake of a fair and redistributive tax system globally, then we cannot take our hands to our heads in situations as terrible as this. And that's called coherence.

name: Seán Kelly
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa PPE. – A Uachtaráin, is ábhar an-tábhactach é seo agus is dóigh liom gur cheart dúinn féachaint air i gcomhthéacs na gcainteanna a bhí ar siúl sa Phairlimint seo i rith na seachtaine. Bhí an Seansailéir Angela Merkel agus Uachtarán na Fraince, Francois Hollande, anseo agus iad ag rá gur cheart dúinn díriú níos mó ar an Afraic, cabhrú níos mó leo maidir le hábhair mhóra cosúil le hathrú aeráide, an eacnamaíocht a chur ar bun agus saol níos fearr a chothú do na daoine ann.  Nuair a fheicimid cad atá ag tarlú sa Nigéir, feicimid chomh deacair is atá sé déileáil le grúpaí cosúil le Boko Haram agus an sceimhlitheoireacht atá ar siúl acu, go háirithe maidir le daoine óga – buachaillí óga agus cailíní óga – agus fiú amháin iad ag déanamh scrios ar scoileanna. Dá bhrí sin is léir go gcaithfimid comhoibriú leis na Náisiúin Aontaithe agus le gach aon duine eile a chabhróidh linn chun saol níos fearr a chothú ansin agus troid i gcoinne Boko Haram. (Aontaíonn an cainteoir freagra a thabhairt ar cheist ó "chárta gorm" (Riail 162(8) de na Rialacha Nós Imeachta)).

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to ask Mr Kelly what the actual approach to education is. Are there possibilities to create offers in public and educational work in order to provide information on the spot and also to be able to set the necessary framework conditions?

name: Seán Kelly (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – My colleague, Mr Rübig, is absolutely correct. It is one thing to fight against Boko Haram, it is another thing to establish the culture that is necessary for the recognition of human rights and respect for individuals. It is only through a proper educational system that that can happen. There is a big difference between having a proper educational system and actually destroying schools – which is what is happening right now in Nigeria. So, yes, that is the fundamental way of approaching the problem and, unless it happens, we will never really have progress.

name: Elena Valenciano
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, we get used very speed to the tragedies around us and here, many afternoons, many mornings, we talk about the millions of human beings who suffer; of the millions of children who are being severely attacked in probably the most serious thing, which is to rob them of education. There's nothing worse for the future of those children than stealing their education. We talked about it and almost got used to the figures, but we also need to know that donors — those of us who pledged to donate an amount of money, so that the education of children could be possible and that Boko Haram's attack could be effectively fought - we have not complied: out of every three euros to which we committed , we must two. I mean, we have a responsibility, too. So I turn to the European Union and the Member States to fulfil the commitments they have made so that it is possible to end this barbarism in Nigeria, also supporting their president.

name: Bas Belder
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, paragraph 11 of the joint resolution has a phrase that has touched me deeply. I quote: 'expresses his full sympathy for women and children who have survived the blind terrorism of Boko Haram'. In this sentence I immediately think of Hassan Bitrus, 4 years old and originally from northern Nigeria. Last November, he walked out of the church with a Bible in his hand. Boko Haram extremists detained him, took his bible and threw it into a fire. Hassan tried to remove his Bible from the fire with a stick. A Boko Haram terrorist kicked him in the head. Before death, Boko Haram left him behind. Thank God Hassan Bitrus survived. Hassan Bitrus and all the countless victims of Boko Haram ask for more than our sympathy, namely for international protection, including from the EU.

name: Hilde Vautmans
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, I think everyone here has already said it today: we need to talk about Nigeria. More than a million children are on the run, many under the age of five, simply because they want to go to school, because they are killed if they want to get an education. Ladies and gentlemen, Boko Haram is afraid of people with opinions. Their truth, their cowardly truth comes from the barrel of a gun. That is why we need to step up the fight against Boko Haram. But of course we have to be careful that the cure is not worse than the ailment. That is why we should ask the president-elect to investigate human rights violations by the former army chief. Truth must be done there. Finally, Mr President, I would like to speak out again for the women who have been raped en masse there. I think we should give them all the support. I would also like to call on them to allow them to have an abortion when they become pregnant after these crimes. I would also like to thank Mrs Mogherini for her position on the matter.

name: Franz Obermayr
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her For years, we have been aware of the Union's appeals to the Member States to step up the fight against Boko Haram. Unfortunately, however, far too little has been achieved. Hostage-taking, mainly of female residents, is on the agenda. We witnessed the suicide bombings by child soldiers in the summer, and Christian villages are still systematically being wiped out. There are currently 1.2 million children on the run in northern Nigeria, and half of these children are under the age of five, according to UNICEF. Some 265 000 children have been displaced in neighbouring countries. If Europe does not pursue and support the fight against Islamism in Nigeria and the fight against the inhumane barbarism of Boko Haram, we need not be surprised if the next immigration tsunami builds up.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The six-year conflict in northeastern Nigeria has already cost more than 20,000 lives and forced more than 2 million to flee their homes. Due to the social structure of Nigeria, where more than 40% of the population is under the age of 14, a huge number of people affected by the conflict are children. Murders, separated from their parents, sexual violence, lack of access to medical care, education or hunger become a daily part of their childhood. To improve their situation, comprehensive measures are needed both to improve the overall political and economic situation in the country and to provide humanitarian support. In this context, I am pleased that in June the Commission allocated an additional EUR 21 million and recently announced a further increase in appropriations for this purpose. Let us remember, however, that Nigeria's needs continue to far outweigh the assistance offered and further efforts in this context are necessary.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab What is happening in Nigeria is an act of particular barbarism, what Boko Haram is doing. I am, like many of my foreachers, a strong supporter of the European Union taking and supporting all measures that effectively provide humanitarian aid to the people of Nigeria: women, children resettled, mutilated persons. We must also strive to keep the Nigerian authorities under constant pressure. But like Mr Belder, I would like us to talk about this with a raised helmet, without internal censorship – this hatred of Christianity is the source of this barbarism. This should be very clearly named: our brothers in the faith perish because they are Christians. This should also be very clearly named in the resolution.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, half a million people, half a million children, have been uprooted from their homes, many separated from their families. For six years Boko Haram terrorism has been terrifying the people in and around Nigeria. We should strongly condemn the use of children as sexual slaves, forced marriages, recruitment for terrorist activities and any form of violence against children. Our hearts today should be with the victims and their families. We should at least remember the schoolgirls of Chibok, who were kidnapped one-and-a-half years ago, and the thousands of girls who are abducted in Nigeria. Our message should be strong: you are not forgotten and you are not alone. But much more needs to be done to mobilise support in Europe to join forces with the rest of the international community to support the Nigerian Government and the African Union to protect children, investigate these crimes and combat impunity. Children should be given access to basic needs: water, food, shelter, healthcare and schooling. In the Intergroup on Children’s Rights we will continue to keep the fate of the children in and around Nigeria on the agenda for as long as it takes.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I want to join what has been said here. I want to thank the authors of this proposal, I want to thank all those who have spoken out and clearly condemned the violence that is taking place in Nigeria. The numbers have been falling here, and there is no need to repeat them, over two million internal refugees in this country, thousands of murdered women, children, but also ordinary civilians. More than ten million children in Nigeria can not go to school, it is the most children who do not go to school, worldwide to the population of this country. In my opinion, this needs to be debated, not underestimated simply because it does not directly affect us, as we are, for example, directly affected by the problems of the Middle East. I think that the European Commission should be very active here. Here I call on the Commissioner that the European Commission should seek to be a leader in obtaining humanitarian aid to this territory, to children and women living and displaced in the region. The money promised by donors needs to be delivered, and unfortunately that is not the case today. We also need to talk to the president.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab A few months ago, it seemed that Boko Haram was being pushed to the defensive, that the actions taken by african union countries and support for the Nigerian government would lead us to hear less and less about this dramatic problem. But today we see again that Boko Haram is active and Europe cannot close its eyes or be limited to words, because we talk a lot, and we do not realise that what is happening in Africa, from the region south of the Sahara, through the Great Lakes region and to central Africa, is one of the greatest geopolitical dramas of modern times, which is at the same time an unlikely humanitarian drama. Europe must think again, in cooperation with african union countries and the Nigerian Government, not only about how to propose further resolutions, but how to defeat and eliminate Boko Haram.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, throughout Nigeria insecurity caused by the conflict between the terror group Boko Haram, military forces and civilian self-defence has escalated into a worsening humanitarian crisis. The latest spate of attacks has uprooted 500 000 children, bringing the total number of displaced children in north—east Nigeria and neighbouring Chad and Niger to 1.4 million. These children are at risk of being trapped in a cycle of violence, separated from their families, exposed to exploitation and recruited by armed groups, despite a commitment by the Commission to provide additional funds to boost urgent humanitarian aid to the region. I would like to express my concern at the funding gap between commitments and actual payments for UNICEF operations. It is essential that we contribute to bringing to an end the violence of Boko Haram as soon as possible, re-establish stability and security across the whole country and address the root causes of terrorism and illegal migration.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, honourable Members, terrorism is today the greatest threat to the world. Under his rule are all citizens, regardless of their ethnicity and religious affiliation, and boko Haram's barbarism has repeatedly proved it. For several years now, the terrorist organization has been a growing threat to the stability of Nigeria and the West African region.  Boko Haram continues to kidnap children and women and use them for suicide bombings, expanding its activities in neighboring countries as well. In this regard, I would like to support the recent statement by the European Commission on the need for additional funds to stimulate emergency humanitarian aid in the region.  We also need, together with the international community, to provide the necessary support to nigeria's president-elect in order to adopt strict measures to protect civilians. Special emphasis must be placed on the protection of women and children and on providing assistance to victims of the atrocities of the terrorist organisation.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if we look at the news from Nigeria, unfortunately, we are reading a war bulletin, and it is children and young people aged between 5 and 14 who are being used vilely for suicide bombings.  The United Nations, through unicef's agency, has stated that, of the EUR 50 million needed, only 32% have arrived to deal with this emergency. Well, international donors, including the European Union, must do more, they must send additional funds, measures must also be taken to protect civilians and raped girls must be allowed to benefit from the relevant medical services, including abortion, with the assistance of social recovery programmes.  We must also understand, however, that if we do not adopt more forward-looking and sustainable policies and if we do not act on the origin of the terrorist problem, which are poor conditions and ineffective governance and corruption, we will never solve the problem either in Nigeria or elsewhere. We must resolve today's crises and prevent tomorrow's crises by changing our behaviour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I condemn the provoking exodus and the cruelty towards children, especially girls, carried out by Boko Haram, not only in Nigeria, where it is also a major stronghold of this terrorist group, but also in cameroon, Chad and Niger.  It is completely inadmissible that children are prevented from attending school, which deprives them of the joys of growing up and all the beauties that childhood brings with them. They kidnap them and separate them from their families.  I also point out that this terrorist group is targeting and killing Christians, and in the last few years they have killed 10,000 people. There are about 250,000 people on the run because of the terror they're carrying out.  The killing carried out by Boko Haram is an impermissible crime. I personally condemn this and call on everyone to stop these killings carried out by this terrorist group. Our answer must be clear. We must prevent financial flows to Boko Haram and support forces fighting Boko Haram and strengthen European Union humanitarian aid to children who are victims of this terrorist group.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, Nigeria is a rich country, with rich sources of wealth, with oil, with huge revenues, yet the population in Nigeria lives in poverty and is faced with the violation of human rights. Thus, underdevelopment, lack of democracy and corruption are a fertilizer for terrorism and the development of Boko Haram, this jihadist organization that works closely with ISIS. Boko Haram, therefore, is constantly developing, carrying out terrorism, responsible for murders, bombings, child abductions, rapes. Since 2009, millions of children have fled their homes to be saved.  If Boko Haram is to be defeated, poverty must be hit, the causes of terrorism must be hit, the huge oil revenues in Nigeria must go in favour of the Nigerian people themselves, and not into the pockets of multinationals.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE).
text: – Madam President, for starters, I would like to express my condolences to the families of the victims of the latest Boko Haram attack that took place in Nigeria last week. Hundreds of thousands of children have had to flee their homes in Nigeria so far because of Boko Haram and that is why we must support Nigeria and its government in its efforts and in the fight against Boko Haram. In this regard, I welcome the decision of the Conference of Presidents to invite President Buhari to come to this Parliament next year.  Of course humanitarian aid is needed, but we also need to help the Nigerian government respond to the causes of the crisis and conflicts to extreme poverty, huge social inequalities and endemic corruption, because it is unacceptable that a country so rich in natural resources has almost two-thirds of the population below the extreme poverty line, and this is actually a breeding ground for radicalism as we now see in Nigeria. That is why I think the Commission should also emphasise, within the EDF, the importance of fighting corruption.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, colleagues, thank you for giving me the opportunity to comment on the humanitarian situation in north-eastern Nigeria, in particular that of children. Thank you for your comments. It was a very rich discussion. I was there two or three months ago. I visited areas very close to the areas controlled by Boko Haram and it is very clear that the violence perpetrated by Boko Haram is still most worrying, with, unfortunately, no predictable perspective for improvement yet. Some progress in engaging against Boko Haram has been achieved by the new authorities in Nigeria, together with its neighbouring countries, but the terrorists continue to perpetrate attacks on an almost daily basis. This is not only extending insecurity and human suffering, we also see that children are increasingly used as weapons to carry out suicide attacks. This situation is unacceptable and calls for our continued commitment. The crisis caused by Boko Haram is one of the worst humanitarian crises worldwide. The number of internally displaced people (IDPs) in the north—east of Nigeria has increased to over two million. In the whole Lake Chad region, about 700 000 children have been forced from their homes. The majority of them are staying with host communities, and not in official camps, and their needs in terms of food, education and health are most often not met. Their vulnerability makes them easy targets for bad treatment and exploitation. We are following the situation closely, together with the UN and humanitarian actors on the ground. We help Nigeria with several instruments. Firstly, through humanitarian aid, the European Union is providing assistance in the areas of healthcare, food security and nutrition, shelter, protection, water and sanitation, with a special focus on children. The Commission has been the leading humanitarian donor in Nigeria since the beginning of the Boko Haram crisis, with a mobilisation of EUR 20.5 million in the current year and EUR 42.5 million for the whole Lake Chad region. We are currently preparing to provide support to the Multinational Joint Taskforce that is being set up by the countries concerned. A significant amount has been set aside, around EUR 50 million, but not all requirements are yet met to commit these funds. The coming weeks will bring more clarity.  The European Union also funds a specific counter-terrorism project that supports counter-radicalisation and de-radicalisation measures, observance of human rights in military operations, the establishment of communication systems and Nigeria’s criminal justice response to terrorism.  EU development assistance under the European Development Fund (EDF) focuses on tackling the root causes of radicalisation and violence, and is targeted in part at children – in particular with projects on child protection and juvenile justice administration, child health, psychosocial support for boys and girls who are victims of armed conflict, and involving girls in peacebuilding efforts in north-east Nigeria. Nigeria is also a priority country for the EU in the Children in Armed Conflict initiative, following the listing of the country in the UN report on children and armed conflict. In mobilising this support, we are doing our best to address the situation of children suffering the consequences of Boko Haram violence. But, of course, much of the responsibility lies with national governments. We will stay committed to supporting them, and will continue to work with the United Nations, civil society and our humanitarian partners on the ground.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, 8 October 2015 at 12:00. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I strongly support the actions of African countries and the international community against Boko Haram. It is undeniable that the European Union and the Member States should be even more involved in the fight against one of the most ruthless terrorist groups.
