I voted against the provision on access to the full range of sexual and reproductive health services.  I have a similar opinion on the issue relating to the Central African Republic. It is one of the poorest countries in the world, with extremely complex problems, on the brink of civil war and a huge humanitarian crisis. Providing unrestricted access to abortion does not solve any of them. I know this because I chaired the SEDE mission to Bangui this year. The Polish gendarmerie played an important role there. There I also met Polish missionaries who served the people of the country with dedication, even at a time of greatest tension. They were the ones who helped women and children in the most difficult moments. The situation of women is extremely severe in all armed conflicts. This topic will be discussed at the next SEDE meeting.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. – Deeply concerned about the protection of children's rights in Nigeria, where more than 40% of the population is aged between 0 and 14; convinced of the importance of adequately protecting the rights of women and children in the fight against extremism; I wholeheartedly support the resolution calling on the Nigerian authorities and the international community to work together to reverse the continuing trend towards displacement of the population. The military approach alone will not be enough to counter Boko Haram, which has deprived the world's highest number of schoolchildren of access to education. Too many children have disappeared, been abducted or recruited as fighters and domestic workers. Too many girls have been the victims of rape and forced marriages or forced to convert to Islam. Separated from their families and forced by violence to flee to save their lives, children in Nigeria account for 58% of internally displaced persons. Although several humanitarian organisations operate in the camps, access to basic rights continues to be of tremendously low quality. The European Parliament must do everything in its power to prevent the lives of so many children from being marked by daily episodes of violence and terror and by physical and psychological abuse.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "In the last five months, Islamist activities from Boko Haram have forced half a million children to flee their homes. This group, which has recently gained control in many cities in northeastern Nigeria, murders civilians, abducts women and girls, and forcibly takes boys and young men into its branches. Children flee and are mass-sent by their parents to the south of the country, as well as beyond its borders, mainly to Cameroon, Chad and Niger. One of boko Haram's main objectives, apart from the introduction of Sharia law, is to fight Western education. 10.5 million Nigerian children do not attend school, and more than 600 teachers have been killed by terrorists in Nigeria.  Bearing in mind that education is one of the most important factors in ensuring sustainable development and a pillar of a stable society, I call on the President of Nigeria and the newly established federal government to adopt strong measures to combat extremism and protect civilians, especially children, and to ensure safe living and development conditions, including education.

name: Aymeric Chauprade
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the young Shiite Ali Mohammed al-Nimr was sentenced to death by sword beheading, followed by crucifixion, by the Supreme Court of Saudi Arabia, when he was only 17 years old at the time of the events in 2012 and his alleged crimes were due to his participation in demonstrations by Shiite opponents. It is a given that it was under torture that this young boy confessed to crimes he never committed. It is also known that his most basic rights to a fair trial have never been respected. The case of this young Shiite from Saudi Arabia, whom I wanted to raise as co-editor of this resolution, has led to a broad consensus among the groups, and I welcome it. I thank the colleagues of the other groups with whom we have worked on a text that I believe is balanced, a text that is not driven by the desire to condemn an entire country, but by the desire to make it hear reason as to practices that are no longer permissible when one claims to belong to the community of nations. The immense financial strength of Saudi Arabia, its ability to absorb a number of our high-tech industrial products should not justify these excesses.

name: Charles Tannock
text: author. – Madam President, it is a tragic irony that, at a time when Saudi Arabia is being appointed to head an influential committee of the UN Human Rights Council, at home it is sentencing teenagers to death by beheading for the so-called crime of protesting.  Today’s debate focuses on the case of Ali Mohammed al-Nimr, but only yesterday reports emerged of a second teenager, Dawood al-Marhoon, who is facing a similar fate. Al-Nimr remains in prison, a place he has been since he was arrested in 2012, aged only 17, and faces imminent execution. It seems, though, that this is not only about alleged crimes, but also about Saudi Arabia’s wider sectarian war. Al-Nimr comes from a Shiite area and his uncle is a distinguished Shiite cleric. There is little coincidence that al—Marhoon is also a Shia. These cases are particularly shocking, but they are only two cases in an extensive catalogue of human rights abuses in the kingdom of Saudi Arabia. The country’s criminal justice system is the perfect blueprint for any repressive authoritarian state. I called last week on the King of Saudi Arabia to pardon al-Nimr. Today I repeat these calls for both him and al—Marhoon.

name: Frédérique Ries
text: Author. "Madam President, Ali al-Nimr, here he is. He is 17 years old in this photo, an almost child, a model student, a student who loves photography, who loves travel, who loves cycling, who loves freedom too and who obviously loves Ralph Lauren polo shirts. Like many in Qatif, this Shiite stronghold in Saudi Arabia, Ali is in love with freedom, as I said, and, like thousands of young people to whom the Arab Springs had given wings, he walked down the street in 2012.  There was no spring in Qatif. It was Ali before his arrest, before he was detained in the security quarter, before confessions were extracted under torture. It was Ali before the four years that deprived him of his family, before the four years that robbed him of his youth. Today, Ali is a man, a man sentenced to death. Sentencing can be carried out today, tomorrow, at any time.  I will not go back to human rights violations in Saudi Arabia. Our text does it and we do it throughout the session. The Saudi kingdom has just propelled its ambassador to the highest level of the UN Human Rights Council in Geneva.  I ask for coherence and I join the call of the world to ask King Salman for mercy for Ali al-Nimr.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Saudi Arabia and human rights, we are once again talking about this issue, which shows all the enormous inconsistency that we have as the European Union, because Saudi Arabia, which we consider to be our partner, a country with which we have good relations, a country not to be condemned, is one of the countries in the world where the worst human rights violations take place and with which we should have a firmer pulse.  What's going on instead? It happens that, in order to reward the fact that they condemn crucifixion or condemn to death in all the most barbaric ways possible, it happens that their ambassador is appointed as a representative to the United Nations for human rights with the support of the British Government, and Cameron, pressed on this question, did not know what to answer and kept saying yes, but we are pressing for respect for human rights. , but on the other hand he systematically supported them.  So let us try to understand, ladies and gentlemen, what kind of approach we must take towards Saudi Arabia, because Saudi Arabia is a country that we must learn to condemn and sanction, otherwise there is no point in us talking about human rights here.

name: Richard Howitt
text: author. – Madam President, Ali Mohammed al-Nimr was arrested and tortured for being part of the Arab Spring. It must not be allowed to die; he must not be allowed to die. The true bravery in this case is that of Ali himself in the face of a horrible death. The Saudi authorities must allow him to live and uphold the right to peaceful protest in their country.  Saudi Arabia chairs the UN Human Rights Council’s expert panel, but it is breaching its legal obligations under the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. It is a country which is condemning an increasing number of young people to death while Europe is demanding a moratorium. There is well-founded suspicion that Ali has been condemned to this fate only because he comes from the family of a Shia cleric who is himself a dissident. Last year in this Chamber I spoke on the agreement on counter-terrorism between the European Union and Saudi Arabia. This Parliament voted that it must be subject to respect for human rights. Today all reports suggest that this is a boy who has been sentenced to death as a terrorist on the basis of evidence that has been withheld, who has been tortured while under treatment, and who signed a confession under duress and was tried in secret. It is sickening that my own country’s Government is bidding to provide services for the very same Saudi prison service which will be responsible for inflicting the death penalty. Britain and our European partners want good relations with Saudi Arabia. But today we must ask if the treatment of Ali al-Nimr is consistent with the assurances given about the relationship we have. If those promises are to mean anything they must mean Ali’s life. Ali was a child: let him be a man.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: Author. – Madam President, Commissioner, with this resolution, we draw attention to another of the human rights violations ed by one of our trading partners, Saudi Arabia. It is good to have good economic relations with Saudi Arabia as well as good political relations, but it is also important to draw attention to what is happening in that country. In the case of Ali Muhammad al-Nimr, consideration is not taken of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, nor of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, nor of the Arab Charter on Human Rights itself. The condemnation of Ali Muhammad al-Nimr is therefore against all our values and we must fight for it to be lifted immediately. The death penalty has increased in Saudi Arabia since 2014, and this must not be overlooked by the European or international community.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: Author. Madam President, the destabilizing role of Saudi Arabia is no longer to be demonstrated in the region, as in Yemen but also elsewhere, through the financing of terrorist organisations. Horror also reigns internally: political opponents, women, immigrant workers or minorities, especially Shia, are victims of the worst discrimination and even abuses. It's a medieval country. Ali Mohammed al-Nimr is the sad symbol. Minor at the time of his arrest, tortured during his detention, victim of a biased trial, now condemned to the height of barbarism. His crime: having had the audacity to demonstrate for equal rights, in addition to being the nephew of his uncle. Lèse-majesté crime, they're Shiites. To do so, he must be beheaded and then crucified. Those who should react, at best, look elsewhere. The United Nations lets Saudi Arabia gain responsibilities in the Human Rights Council, the United States and France compete for the privilege of being its best ally. So no, Ali must not die, nor should Raif Badawi be whipped. We must not be silent. The European Union must react, demand the pardon of Ali and Raif.

name: Pascal Durand
text: Author. Madam President, two wounds are likely to lead a 20-year-old to death in barbaric and inhumane conditions. These two wounds, we can name them. They are called cynicism and indifference. The cynicism of bloodthirsty dictatorships that allow themselves to sign international conventions on human rights and children's rights. Indifference is the one that, in the name of king money, incites the great democracies to look elsewhere to recover oil or to sell arms.  Let us not leave Europe, which is not only a market but which is, first and foremost, the embodiment of values, seeing its values sacrificed, beheaded on the altar of a bloodthirsty dictatorship.  The European Union and Parliament must say loud and clear to Saudi Arabia that a child is not tortured, that he is not sentenced to death. Yes, we must ask for clemency, but beyond that we must ask Saudi Arabia to set up a commission of inquiry against torture to ensure that individual freedoms and human rights are respected in that country.

name: Jiří Pospíšil
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I want to join my speaker and clearly condemn the upcoming barbaric murder of this young Arab man. It cannot even be called punishment, because in the twenty-first century punishment simply cannot look like someone's head is chopped off and their body is hung on a cross to rot there. This is simply an unequivocal judicial murder for someone expressing their political views, wanting freedom of speech in their country, and also for being Shia and that his uncle, as has already been said here, is an influential opponent of the regime there.  It is not possible, in my opinion, to see Saudi Arabia as an equal partner, to cover our eyes and not to make it clear that, unfortunately, the number of executions is increasing in Saudi Arabia today. It must be said that this year it is already a hundred and two executions, the number is higher and higher, and most importantly, children and foreigners are executed without being guaranteed a proper and fair trial. Today, Saudi Arabia is third in the world in executions. It needs to be condemned and pressure exerted.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: on behalf of the group. – Madam President, the condemnation of the young Shiite Ali Mohammed al-Nimr to death by beheading, followed by crucifixion, is yet another medieval, cruel punishment against human rights activists in Saudi Arabia, persecuted for exercising freedom of expression and other civil and political rights, in cases that do not clearly meet international standards of fair trial. The High Representative, Federica Mogherini, and the Member States must publicly express outrage at this sectarian condemnation, which is attentive to the most basic dignity of the human person, and must put pressure on the Saudi authorities at all levels to put an end to barbarism.  Considering this case and many others, such as the whipping and imprisonment of Raif Badawi, the Union and the Member States must put an end to the 'business as usual' and reassess their relations with Saudi Arabia in other areas such as trade, energy, security and military cooperation. The silence of European rulers is intolerable because Saudi Arabia supplies oil and buys weapons. This silence translates complicity (...) (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker.)

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, arresting, torturing and condemning a young man of 17 to beheading, followed by crucifixion. I do not associate such practices with the country that chairs the UN Human Rights Council but with Daesh or al-Qaeda. And the comparison doesn't stop here. Since the 1970s, Saudi Arabia has invested tens of billions of dollars in the eradication of pluralistic Islam. Today, in mosques from Morocco to Pakistan and Indonesia, Sufis, moderate Sunnis and Shi's are being denounced under the impulse of Saudi Wahhabism. Terrorist groups such as al-Qaeda, Daesh and the al-Nusra Front are the ideological heirs. Antimodern, anti-Western, anti-pluralist and against women's rights. This Parliament has always been very strict on the human rights situation in Saudi Arabia. Nevertheless, I see friendly Heads of State or Government far too easily for sale for the Saudi oil dollars. They sign the death sentence of Ali Mohammed al-Nimr. Not in my name! Pardon him! Release him!

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, it has been said that Saudi Arabia is an important country in the Middle East. We share the same objectives in the peace process, and it is in both of our interests to work together on a number of issues. It is sad that the human rights record of Saudi Arabia is a tragic one, and here we are facing yet another example of this. I appreciate what President Hollande said. He made a very strong statement on behalf of his country, which has traditionally strong ties with Saudi Arabia. He made a very strong statement to Saudi Arabia.  What is missing is a statement and a clear-cut position from Ms Mogherini. We should all agree that this is an area in which we expect Ms Mogherini to take a strong line. We should also agree that if this record continues there should be a strong EU reaction, irrespective of common issues that we have traditionally shared.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, like everyone here, I believe that we cannot be content with formal protests. All European institutions must do everything to prevent the beheading and crucifixion of the young Ali Mohammed al-Nimr. After more than 2,200 executions in the last ten years, Saudi Arabia is pushing our common humanity into the dark caverns of barbarism of another age. Nothing can justify silence or the slightest complacency. Our institutions must, on the one hand, be heard, with greater force and act, including by questioning certain cooperations, certain trade agreements. Nothing beats human life. We must also challenge the presidency of that country at the UN Human Rights Council. Yes, by all means, let us demand that Ali Mohammed al-Nimr and now for Daoud al-Marhoun be spared.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Saudi Arabia is going to behead a young man who committed a crime at the age of 17. Actually, Saudi justice this year has broken all its records. He's beheaded a hundred and thirty people. And that's the horrible luck Ali's going to run if we don't raise our voices in favor of his release. This Parliament will not fail to point out to the Saudi Government the inhumaneness of its law, the inhumaneness of its action. Eight months after we adopted an emergency resolution on the case of Raif Badawi, whose freedom we are asking for today today, this Parliament is once again raising its voice in favour of Ali Mohamed al-Nimr; we're not going to shut up. The Saudi government must take note. We will not allow them to continue to behead innocent people, young people whose only crime committed is to fight for their freedom.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for bringing up the case of Ali Mohammed al-Nimr. As we all know, Saudi Arabia is an important partner for the European Union but, like many in Europe, we are concerned by the death sentence imposed on Mr al-Nimr by a Saudi court earlier this year. Mr al-Nimr was a juvenile when he was arrested in 2012 on charge of, inter alia, joining a criminal group and attacking police forces after he took part in demonstrations in the Saudi Arabia’s Eastern Province. We have been closely following developments related to his case, as well as the overall human rights situation in Saudi Arabia. The basis and conditions of Mr al-Nimr’s sentence, as well as the nature of the punishment handed down to him, are matters of grave concern for the European Union. In addition, the sentence appears manifestly disproportionate. We have therefore been engaging the Saudi authorities, in close coordination with EU Member States represented in Riyadh. Our Delegation in Riyadh has been tasked to convey to the Saudi authorities our strong view that the sentence is disproportionate and the proposed modalities of the execution particularly degrading, and to call on them to review Mr al-Nimr’s sentence. This is, of course, also an opportunity to reiterate, once more, our principled EU position on the death penalty, as well as to stress the worrying increase in the use of the death penalty in Saudi Arabia. We also constantly reiterate the need to respect the UN minimum standards, especially concerning the issue of execution of minors and renew our offer to engage in a more constructive human rights dialogue with Saudi Arabia. The pace of executions in Saudi Arabia is reaching unprecedented levels, with capital punishment being increasingly imposed for non-lethal crimes, such as drug offences.  Obviously, we will continue to call on our Saudi partners to suspend the sentence and to review the court ruling. Let me once again assure you that we will continue to remain engaged with the case of Mr al-Nimr and to voice the EU’s concern through appropriate channels.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, 8 October 2015 at 12:00. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. Mr President, on 14 February 2012 Mohammed al-Nimr, who took part in a demonstration against the Government of Saudi Arabia, was arrested at the age of 17. He was subsequently sentenced to execution by decapitation and public crucifixion. According to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, each country is prohibited from imposing the death penalty and life imprisonment on persons under the age of 17. However, Saudi Arabia has not only violated this UN Convention by imposing the death penalty on Mohammed al-Nimr, but has declared it illegal to participate in a protest against the government, which also violates the right to free expression. In the face of this violation of basic human rights, the EU is called upon to make its opposition to the sentencing decision of Mohammed al-Nimr immediately clear, to demand that the sentence not be carried out and to ask for a pardon. At the same time, the EU must contribute to compliance with the rules established for the protection of underage children.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. My predecessors spoke of the tragic fate of Mr. al-Nimr, who was sentenced to death. Like everyone before me, I ask for a pardon for him and for him to be released immediately. But I must also say here a few words about the EU's behaviour in relation to countries where human rights are being violated in the most severe way.  I see the discussions about the truly tragic fates of innocent people that we have on the agenda at every Thursday session as a wash of an immate conscience burdened with about 152 billion euros in economic exchanges with gulf countries expected this year. Is money really worth more than people's lives? And where does that end? Why don't we ask ourselves how many refugees Saudi Arabia has taken in so far and why do refugees prefer to go to Europe?  I ask myself and you together, what the European Union will do specifically, in financial and economic terms, to show the Saudi ruler and those like him in the Middle East that he disagrees with their policies and that protecting human dignity and life is more important to her than money.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I have a point of order concerning Article 130 of the Rules of Procedure. Limiting the maximum number of written questions that each Member can submit is an aberrant measure that limits the political intervention of Members. Now, to present more than five questions we have to justify the urgency of handing over that question. The situation is so aberrant that I received a response yesterday from Parliament's services to reject a question I asked because they do not consider it urgent to question the European Commission about alleged military aggression stun refugees in recent days. How is it possible for bureaucrats to decide whether or not what Members consider politically urgent is urgent? Do the services of this Parliament serve to support the work of Members or to prevent the work of Members?

name: President. –
text: Ms Zuber, thank you for your intervention but I would like to inform you that it was not bureaucrats but the plenary of this Parliament which, in the last part-session, decided to limit the number of written questions. I am sorry. That is a fact: it was not bureaucrats, it was the plenary which decided on that.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Linda McAvan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this is simply an oral amendment because the Commission has now published what they are terming a ‘staff working document’ on gender. So it is to update the resolution.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - I voted in favour of the report on the regulation of financial services. I consider the strict regulation of financial services to be particularly important as a Hungarian, because every day I encounter the consequences of bank fraud, abuse and conduct in breach of consumer protection rules when examining complaints from hundreds of thousands of Hungarian foreign currency borrowers.  It is not only in this area that financial services need to be regulated, but also, for example, that, despite all this, despite the foreign currency credit tragedies, various credit schemes and credit cards are still being forced on hungarian people in a very violent way – whether at airports or elsewhere, this must also be regulated very strictly.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Thank you, Mr President. Today's economy is no longer conceivable without electronic financial transactions, and unlike in ancient times, when it was possible to pay either on the barter principle, either through direct transactions, from hand to hand, or the Middle Ages, when the bill of exchange system appeared, the modern world is increasingly paying directly through electronic transactions.  Consequently, the clearer the legalisation of all the principles for implementing these activities will be, the more effective it will be both to bring them into life and to gain some impetus for economic development precisely because of better standardisation. The possibility of a clearer choice of payment services and their transparency, the establishment and constant development of a more integrated and secure internal market for electronic payments, the standardisation of the rights and obligations of all parties to payments between Member States, including the commissions of intermediaries and the principles for their operation – all and much more relevant to the successful development of the European Union economy and to strengthening consumer confidence.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I also subscribe to the fact that I supported this motion for a resolution, this report by my colleague Tajani. The creation of a single market for payments, electronic transactions, consumer protection – financial literacy in general, I think that all the values I am talking about here are important and relevant to the specific users of these products and services. I supported this draft report because I see the crucial importance of creating a single safe environment for such payments. In general, this report fits into the framework that we have discussed here on other days, whether it is an electronic payment order or the integration of capital markets, these are all financial instruments that consumers need to familiar with. We should inform them and these uniform integrated procedures are intended to make it easier for them to work with these instruments.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo chomh maith agus is doigh liom go bhfuil an-jab déanta ag an rapóirtéir Tajani agus ag na daoine eile atá ag cabhrú leis.  Déanfaidh sé seo an-mhaitheas d'eacnamaíocht na hEorpa i gcoitinne. Mar a dúradh, tá níos mó agus níos mó oibre á déanamh anois trasna teorainneacha agus ar an idirlíon agus mar sin de, dá bhrí sin tá sé an-tábhachtach go mbeadh rialacha soiléire dochta ag baint leis sin, go háirithe mar a bhaineann le hío. I mo thír féin, tá a lan fiontair bheaga agus mheánmhéide á gcruthú faoi láthair, no tá siad ann le blianta beaga anuas, agus a lán díobh siúd, beidh siad ag easpórtáil a lán earraí amach anseo thar an ihar andirlíon agus.  Dá bhrí sin, chomh fada agus is féidir linn, caithfimid an margadh inmheánach a chríochnú agus a chruthú trasna na hEorpa ar fad, agus cabhróidh sé sin go mór linn amach anseo.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I also supported this proposal. I consider the streamlining of electronic transactions, especially across national borders, to be an important element when we are creating an internal market. Yesterday we debated how to better deal with cross-border litigation, we are debating how to connect individual digital markets, to enable cross-border trade in goods electronically. All these instruments are intended to lead to what I consider to be very important, the completion of the internal market within the European Union. So I welcome this proposal, I welcome the things that touch on other options for paying individual claims electronically, I see that the proposal makes fees cheaper, this will be of particular interest to our citizens, it makes bank charges cheaper. I also consider it important to better protect the personal data and personal data that banks count on and work with in banking. So the proposal is correct.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Directive, which updates the 2007 Payment Services Directive in order to take account of the emergence of new players on this market.  The text agreed with the Council increases consumer protection, thanks to the work of our group, in relation to the 2007 text and the Commission's initial proposal. In particular, an unconditional right to reimbursement of amounts not owed by the payment card holder is included. Surcharges for using cards whose fees are already limited by the recently approved Payment Card Commission Regulation are also prohibited.  It was also possible to include in the tripartite dialogue the express prohibition on the cancellation of the payment card service for transfer from the holder to another Member State, an example of bad banking practice to be eradicated and which cannot survive in the future single capital market.  In this regard, it is important to ensure that the important Capital Markets Union project does not set aside families and users of financial services, including cross-border ones, given the long list of barriers to the movement of capital.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report significantly improves the privacy and security of electronic payments over the Commission's proposal, while strengthening customers' right to receive compensation in the event of unauthorized transactions. That's why I voted for it.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to make internet or mobile payments safer and cheaper by opening up the market to two new payment service providers (PSPs) within the EU. While this proposal generally allows for greater protection for consumers when making online payments, there is some uncertainty about the treatment of the information collected by PSPs. No details are provided about this data.  In the face of these uncertainties, I abstained on this report.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposed directive. The Payment Services Directive is an important piece of legislation which creates new prospects for SMEs and budding start-ups by opening up the banking industry to what are known as third-party providers (TPPs). Not only does this create more employment and business opportunities but it also allows for more consumer choice. Colleagues of mine have worked on this proposal on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group for a number of months and have been proactively involved in the negotiations leading up to this vote. Our focus was to engage in trilogues to ensure that sustainable economic growth and growth-friendly fiscal measures were the core aims. During discussions in preparatory meetings of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, the need to break the dominance of the big banks, which currently control the payments market to the detriment of small businesses and budding entrepreneurs, was highlighted. Moreover, we sought to ensure that the legislation would strengthen consumer protection and regulate operators who previously functioned with no regulatory or supervisory framework. All competitors will now be forced to comply with the financial rules, which is crucial for any economy. It was for these reasons I voted in favour of this legislation.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this directive is to further secure online payments within EU Member States. To do this, it is proposed to open the market to two new payment service providers (PSPs), namely ACCOUNT manager PSPs and third-party PSPs. The text as a whole attaches particular importance to consumer protection. However, in the case of third-party PSPs, some points remain unclear as to the confidentiality and exploitation of the information collected by the provider. For this reason, I preferred to abstain.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I have no option but to vote against anything which provides the unelected Commission with the power to issue delegated acts. I also note the interference in freedom of contract shown in Article 62, and the suggestion of ‘full harmonisation’ in Article 107.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to make online payments safer by establishing data protection and accountability rules for all online payment service providers.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Since the digitisation process in the world continues to escalate very rapidly, the original Payment Services Directive, which was adopted eight years ago, must be revised to reflect the current situation and address new risks. So I very much welcome the second Payment Services Directive (PSD 2) and I believe that it will lead to the development of, and innovation in, the internal market in payments, which is essential for the proper functioning of our single market.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Directive, which updates the 2007 Payment Services Directive in order to take account of the emergence of new players on this market.  The text agreed with the Council increases consumer protection, thanks to the work of our group, in relation to the 2007 text and the Commission's initial proposal. In particular, an unconditional right to reimbursement of amounts not owed by the payment card holder is included. Surcharges for using cards whose fees are already limited by the recently approved Payment Card Commission Regulation are also prohibited.  It was also possible to include in the tripartite dialogue the express prohibition on the cancellation of the payment card service for transfer from the holder to another Member State, an example of bad banking practice to be eradicated and which cannot survive in the future single capital market.  In this regard, it is important to ensure that the important Capital Markets Union project does not set aside families and users of financial services, including cross-border ones, given the long list of barriers to the movement of capital.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to increase competition in the payment services market. The updated payment service rules aim to promote the efficiency, security and innovation of this market. The new rules should open up the payment market more widely to new service providers, who, for example, rely on smartphone or electronic money technologies, while maintaining the necessary security requirements for payment. In addition, the conditions for the establishment and operation of payment institutions shall be laid down, as well as the circumstances of the refund and fees for the use of the payment service.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report initiates amendments to previous regulations on payment services in the internal market. The purpose of the amendment is to enable market and new service providers, irrespective of the business model used by payment service providers, to provide their services within a clear and harmonised regulatory framework. Payment transactions should be secure and protect consumers from the risk of fraud. Member States, the Commission, the European Central Bank and the Network of European Central Banks should guarantee fair competition in this market, avoiding discrimination against any of the existing operators. Any payment service provider should be able to offer orderly online transfer services. This provision will support consumers and increase their sense of security, so I voted in favour.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This directive, which has been under discussion for a year and a half, aims to make payments via the internet or mobile media safer and cheaper within the EU, by opening up the market to two new payment service providers (PSPs), account manager PSPs (ASPSPs) and third-party PSPs (PSPs). The text imposes transparency and information requirements on these payment service providers. Ultimately, the stated goal is to increase security by extending the so-called strong authentication requirement for online payments. However, the problem remains the legal vacuum around Third PSPs. No details are given on the confidentiality and exploitation of the information collected by third-party PSPs when consolidated information is collected on the various accounts held by payer or when initiating payment with the account holder PSP. That's why I abstained.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for further development of the e-payments market across the EU. This directive is part of a wider plan launched by Parliament to create an integrated single market for safe electronic payments to support the EU's economic growth and so that consumers, traders and all businesses can have the choice and benefit from transparent payment services in order to take advantage of the benefits of the internal market.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on payment services in the internal market because of the importance of this agreement in relation to retail payments. This act establishes a revised EU legal framework applicable to payment services and, in particular, the collection of exchange fees for card-based transactions, and seeks to accelerate the achievement of an effective integrated market in the field of card payments.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This directive, which has been under discussion for a year and a half, aims to make payments via the internet or mobile media safer and cheaper within the EU by opening up the market to two new payment service providers (PSPs), account manager PSPs (ASPSPs) and third-party PSPs (PSPs). The expected effect is lower transaction costs while raising the level of security of online payments. The text also imposes requirements for transparency and information of PSPs. Overall, this text therefore benefits consumers.  Nevertheless, this directive creates third-party payment service providers, who will be able to initiate payments at the request of the payer without holding the funds concerned. Moreover, the problem remains the legal vacuum around third-party PSPs. No details are given on the confidentiality and exploitation of the information collected. So I decided to abstain.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text expresses in a way that I share the need to adapt the regulations on payment services to current needs in the European internal market, I remain in doubt that the solutions found will really create the optimal conditions for consumers and greater and fair competition in the sector, for these reasons I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Legislative Resolution updating the Directive on payment services in the internal market and amending Directives 2002/65/EC, 2013/36/EU and 2009/110/EC and repealing Directive 2007/64/EC. Thanks to the work carried out by the Social Democratic Group, the text agreed with the Council increases consumer protection in relation to the 2007 text and the Commission's initial proposal. Specifically, an unconditional right to reimbursement of amounts not owed by the payment card holder is included and surcharges are also prohibited for using cards whose fees are already limited by the recently approved Payment Card Commission Regulation.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament supports the Commission's proposal to amend the provisions of the Directive on payment services in the internal market. Improvements are needed as the retail payments market has introduced important technical innovations, with a rapid increase in electronic and mobile payments and the emergence of new types of payment services on the market, which pose challenges for the existing system. The Commission carried out a consultation and presented a Green Paper entitled 'Towards an integrated European market for card, internet and mobile payments', in which it stressed that important areas of the payments market, in particular card, internet and mobile payments, remain fragmented across national borders. In addition, it has become clear that, in certain cases, the scope of the existing Directive and, in particular, the elements not covered by it, such as certain payment-related activities, have proved too ambiguous, too general or simply outdated in the light of market developments. This has created legal uncertainty, potential security risks in the payment chain and does not guarantee consumer protection in certain areas.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 The new directive on payment services in the internal market is a major change that is difficult to summarise briefly. The most important are to ensure competitiveness across all categories of payment service providers, to ensure a single market for all retail payments, to reduce the cost of internal payments within the EU, to maintain stronger control over new payment products and, of course, to ensure continued protection of the consumer and his rights in payment transactions. The EPP rapporteur is pleased with the final proceeds and is convinced that this will not only increase competitiveness but also protect the consumer through greater transparency, and therefore my support for the proposal for a directive.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this Report, which is an agreed compromise between the European Parliament and the European Council. This Report ensures the development of new procedures and new entrants to payment services with guaranteed safety and transparency for consumers.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the second Payment Services Directive because it interferes in freedom of contract, grants the Commission power to issue delegated acts and demands ‘full harmonisation’ in a way that prevents the UK from having its own approach to such matters.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposed directive. The Payment Services Directive is an important piece of legislation which creates new prospects for SMEs and budding start-ups by opening up the banking industry to what are known as third-party providers (TPPs). Not only does this create more employment and business opportunities but it also allows for more consumer choice. Colleagues of mine have worked on this proposal on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group for a number of months and have been proactively involved in the negotiations leading up to this vote. Our focus was to engage in trilogues to ensure that sustainable economic growth and growth-friendly fiscal measures were the core aims. During discussions in preparatory meetings of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, the need to break the dominance of the big banks, which currently control the payments market to the detriment of small businesses and budding entrepreneurs, was highlighted. Moreover, we sought to ensure that the legislation would strengthen consumer protection and regulate operators who previously functioned with no regulatory or supervisory framework. All competitors will now be forced to comply with the financial rules, which is crucial for any economy. It was for these reasons I voted in favour of this legislation.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe it is important that a payment system should be completed in the Union's internal market as uniformly as possible, as there would be countless positive effects of this solution.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this proposal is to secure online payments in the European Union and make them cheaper for customers. To this end, the rapporteur recommends opening up the market to new payment service providers (PSPs), including account manager PSPs and third-party PSPs. They will be responsible for making payments at the request of customers. To guard against any risk, the text imposes a duty of transparency on them, especially in terms of authentication for online payments. Consumers are protected in the event of theft, loss or misappropriation of the payment instrument within 8 weeks of the transaction.   However, the legal vacuum surrounding the activity of PSPs, especially on the exploitation of the collected data, leaves me skeptical. These providers will have at their disposal the means of authentication of customers, which impairs their confidentiality. If the objective of the report is to secure online payments, why do they not better regulate the activity of third-party PSPs? To denounce this inconsistency, I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on payment services in the internal market brings new regulations, in line with technical innovations and the rapid increase in the number of electronic payments and the emergence of new types of payment services on the market. Significant progress has thus been made in integrating small-value payments into the Union, in particular in the context of Union legislation on payments. Developments in payment services in the internal market have given rise to important regulatory challenges. For example, important segments of the payment services market, in particular card payments, on the internet, from mobile devices end up fragmented along national borders.  The lack of a clear legislative framework to regulate this issue has led to legal uncertainty, the emergence of potential security risks in the payment chain and a lack of consumer protection in certain areas, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on payment services in the internal market.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote. The text is aimed, in fact, at credit institutions and companies that provide "electronic money" through credit cards. Among the things that do not convince much are the far too positive references to the possibilities for developing e-commerce and its potential contribution to growth. It does not convince us that the EBA, the European banking authority, is over-emphasised in relation to the competences of the Member States.  Furthermore, the text does not seem to take due account of the problems caused by the dominant position of certain operators (especially in the credit card sector) who have trade policies that are too often aggressive towards small businesses and, even, towards local or rural banks. Of course, we are dealing with a directive (preferable solution to a regulation) and the hope is that Italy will be able to legislate independently, despite the residual areas of regulatory competence. In short, the need to adapt the regulations on payment services to current needs can be shared. Many of the targets are, too. However, there is still no doubt that the solutions found will really create optimal conditions for consumers, more competition in the sector and services adapted to current technological developments.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Directive, which updates the 2007 Payment Services Directive in order to take account of the emergence of new players on this market.  The text agreed with the Council increases consumer protection, thanks to the work of our group, in relation to the 2007 text and the Commission's initial proposal. In particular, an unconditional right to reimbursement of amounts not owed by the payment card holder is included. Surcharges for using cards whose fees are already limited by the recently approved Payment Card Commission Regulation are also prohibited.  It was also possible to include in the tripartite dialogue the express prohibition on the cancellation of the payment card service for transfer from the holder to another Member State, an example of bad banking practice to be eradicated and which cannot survive in the future single capital market.  In this regard, it is important to ensure that the important Capital Markets Union project does not set aside families and users of financial services, including cross-border ones, given the long list of barriers to the movement of capital.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The revision of the Directive on Payment Services in the Internal Market will further defragment the European payment services market. To ensure the proper functioning of the internal market, payments must be made as quickly and efficiently as possible. The revised directive will reduce the costs of this fragmentation, estimated at around 130 billion euros per year. Payments will be cheaper and more secure. This will also allow the emergence of new players, which will foster a greater capacity for innovation, for example for online payments. I voted in favour of this new directive.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful consideration and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the supplementary report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on payment services in the internal market. Indeed, I am convinced that the development of an integrated single market for secure electronic payments is essential in order to support the growth of the Union's economy. This must take into account the primary value of consumer protection, which must obtain the highest possible system of protection of both transactions and transmitted data. For European legislation that is protective and that exalted growth, transparency of processes, legal clarity, uniform application of the legislative framework and equal operating conditions are therefore categorical imperatives. However, the signals coming from the last Court of Justice ruling of 6 October 2015 declaring the so-called 'safe harbour' regime invalid must be followed, ruling that this trade agreement does not guarantee adequate protection of personal data transferred from Europe to US markets. I am convinced that, in order to increase the transparency of the operation of payment institutions, we need to ensure that the public has easy access to the list of entities providing payment services.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposed directive, on which I was a shadow rapporteur. The Payment Services Directive is an important piece of legislation which creates new prospects for SMEs and budding start-ups by opening up the banking industry to what are known as third-party providers (TPPs). Not only does this create more employment and business opportunities but it also allows for more consumer choice. As a member of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, I worked on this proposal on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group for a number of months. My role was to engage in trilogues to ensure that sustainable economic growth and growth-friendly fiscal measures were the core aims. During discussions in preparatory meetings of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, I highlighted the need to break the dominance of the big banks which currently control the payments market to the detriment of small businesses and budding entrepreneurs. Moreover, I sought to ensure that the legislation would strengthen consumer protection and regulate operators who previously functioned with no regulatory or supervisory framework. All competitors will now be forced to comply with the financial rules, which is crucial for any economy. It was for these reasons I voted in favour of this legislation.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the second Payment Services Directive because it interferes in freedom of contract, grants the Commission power to issue delegated acts and demands ‘full harmonisation’ in a way that prevents the UK from having its own approach to such matters.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The main aim of this proposal is to reduce costs, improve the security of payments and facilitate the emergence of new players and innovative new mobile and internet payment methods. I voted in favour as it will help in providing a better service to consumers in a more secure environment.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent years, great progress has been made in integrating the retail payments market into the European Union, in particular with the adoption of Eu ropean Union legislation on payments: the Payment Services Directive regulates payment services in the European Union by establishing fees and obligations for both payment service providers and consumers. Voted on during the seventh parliamentary term, the trialogue negotiations made the text less acceptable than the first version voted on in April 2014. In the light of the above, I and my colleagues abstained.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on payment services in the internal market . Significant progress has been made in recent years in the integration of retail payments in the Union, in particular in the context of Union operations on payments. The revised Union framework for payment services is complemented by Regulation (EU) 2015/751 of the European Parliament and of the Council. This Regulation introduces, in particular, rules on the imposition of interbank commissions for card transactions and elements to speed up the achievement of a meaningful single market for card payments.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on payment services in the internal market. The proposal for a directive aims to promote greater development of the electronic payments market in the EU. It contains adaptations to the existing directive and imposes certain obligations on Member States, even if they have a margin of discretion as regards transposition into the internal market. Finally, the text of the agreement provides for a reduction in costs and an improvement in the security of payments.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I congratulate Mr Tajani on the excellent work he has done, especially in the last phase of negotiating this measure. I voted in favour because I too take advantage of the need to better regulate the market for payment services: on the one hand, we must make room for new technologies and ensure that payments, especially in electronic commerce, are always easier and faster, while on the other hand we need to ensure ever higher safety standards. I do not want companies in my territory to miss a deal because the terminal they hold is incompatible with the potential customer's credit card, and so I applaud the emphasis on interoperability of systems. Who can, must be in a position to turn the economy around!

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The final compromise on electronic payments approved today by a large majority of the European Parliament represents a significant step forward in favour of European citizens and businesses. The new rules will impact positively on their daily lives, reduce costs and increase security for both consumers and businesses. The European payment services market is still too fragmented and expensive, with costs of approximately EUR 130 billion a year. The new directive will reduce these costs while opening up the market to new operators, which will be subject to the same regulatory and supervisory framework as other credit or payment institutions. The new rules will further improve consumer protection in cases of alleged fraud.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the second Payment Services Directive because it interferes in freedom of contract, grants the Commission power to issue delegated acts and demands ‘full harmonisation’ in a way that prevents the UK from having its own approach to such matters.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the Tajani Report by considering that this proposal on payment services in the internal market sets out a harmonised legal framework for establishing a fairer and safer integrated payment market for users. The new rules, already agreed with the Council, strengthen, on the one hand, the security of online transactions (internet or mobile payment services), protecting European consumers from fraudulent situations or payment incidents. I applaud the provisions that make information clearer to consumers, such as charges payable, the maximum period of execution of the payment service, the contact of the payment initiation service provider and the applicable exchange rate in online payment services. To save the elimination of barriers and costs in the payment system.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because we need to move forward with the area of secure electronic payments in the internal market. This is crucial for the Union's economic growth and to ensure that consumers, traders and businesses enjoy the full benefits of the single market through choice and transparency in payment services, in line with Europe 2020 and the Digital Agenda. Progressive integration is all the more important as a trend towards direct customer traffic towards a digital economy is emerging worldwide.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this important report which will enable us to achieve important objectives in the field of payment services, increasing the regulatory framework still in force. Firstly, to reduce costs, improve payment security and facilitate the emergence of new actors and innovative payment methods. Another important aspect is the improvement of online services, with great attention to measures of respect for personal data, privacy in general, fighting fraud.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The current Payment Services Directive is in need of change, and I applaud this directive for moving to update the payment services industry. Consumers need a level playing field, and innovations in this area also need to be regulated. This directive aims to accomplish this. Reducing restrictions on third-party payment services providers means the consumer can have more options when shopping or conducting financial business online. This measure will also improve the security of payments online and allow for a competitive payment services market.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report significantly improves the privacy and security of electronic payments over the Commission's proposal, while strengthening customers' right to receive compensation in the event of unauthorized transactions. That's why I voted for it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The continued development of an integrated internal market for secure electronic payments is essential in order to support the growth of the Union economy and to ensure that consumers, traders and businesses have choice and transparency in relation to payment services. The European Parliament's resolution goes in this direction and will ensure that there will be greater legal clarity for operators and that the costs of online payment services will be reduced, which will also become safer for consumers. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft resolution adopted by parliament on payment services in the internal market aims to complement and update its internal market rules on payment services. Parliament agrees with the agreement reached at first reading between the institutions. The reforms will reduce the cost of money market services, providing consumers with free information on financial transactions, increased payment security and innovative new payment methods, bearing in mind the safe transfer of personal data. All these changes are in the interests of consumers and businesses.  The development of an internal market for secure electronic payments will also enable the EU economy to grow and the opportunities of the internal market to be fully exploited. I supported the report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Commission proposal and the legislative resolution which proposes a review of the first Payment Services Directive to reflect new market developments, particularly the need to increase the role of third-party actors in payment services. It is positive that the compromise reached ensures security and transparency for consumers and provides also better protection in case of transactions where the amount of money is known in advance and in the framework contract between a consumer and a payment services provider.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the continued development of an integrated internal market for secure electronic payments is crucial to support the Union's economic growth and to ensure that consumers, traders and businesses can fully enjoy the variety and transparency of payment services in order to fully benefit from the internal market.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to create an integrated EU-wide payments market, complementing the existing legal framework. These provisions aim to reduce the costs of payment services by encouraging competition in the sector and promoting innovation, including through mobile and online payment methods. Supporting these objectives and considering that users' banking data will be better protected during transactions, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on payment services in the internal market. In my view, it is important to ensure free competition between all categories of payment service providers. This will increase payment choice, efficiency, transparency and security.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. – More and more stores are offering products for sale on the Internet. However, the online payment systems have followed this trend less. We need to make sure we have more efficient online payment systems. In this way, there will be more choice and these systems will work more transparently. This is very important to increase confidence in e-commerce, which in turn will further grow e-commerce and the economy.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The draft Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on payment services in the internal market represents an important step towards greater European integration in the field of the services market. In fact, many sectors in this market today suffer from high fragmentation, such as card, internet and mobile payments. Greater coherence in this area is desirable in order to give greater protection to consumers, succeeding in reducing the distorting elements present in the implementation of non-integrated national policies. This text therefore manages to ensure greater legal clarity by standardising the legislative framework. Greater transparency in this market means a more efficient market for payment system services, and therefore greater choice for the consumer. Once again, Parliament has improved a Commission text in order to increase consumer confidence. Another positive aspect of this draft resolution is the legislator's attempt to prevent abuses within the framework of the right of establishment, in order to protect European actors from unfair competitors.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is necessary to update EU rules on payment services in order to keep pace with innovation and to make mobile and online payment methods safer, cheaper and more attractive to both consumers and businesses.  The proposal aims to improve consumer protection against fraud, abuse and payment incidents, for example in the event of a disputed transaction. Under the proposed new provisions, all payment service providers operating in the EU will also be subject to appropriate rules, including monitoring. This new framework should create the right conditions for the emergence of new players and the development of innovative internet and mobile payment methods in Europe. Consumers and businesses will benefit from a wider choice and more advantageous terms.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report intends to facilitate online payments to make them safer and less expensive, by opening the market to payment service providers, who will be able to pay without holding the funds, while having information on the accounts in question. However, there is no guarantee as to the use of the data to be made by third-party payment service providers and the protection of personal banking information. This new possibility, as interesting as it may be, can leave a significant legal vacuum. It is not conceivable to open such a breach in the exploitation of personal data. Attached to freedom of enterprise and innovation, I remain convinced, however, that the issue of the protection of personal data is a subject on which a political leader cannot ignore. The European Union cannot once again implement new mechanisms that are judged on the market without studying the problems that may arise from them. That is why I objected.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported my colleague Tajani's report as I believe it complements the existing framework for the benefit of consumers by providing them with improved choice and promoting competition and transparency, while emphasising consumer security, especially when making retail payments. Legal clarity and a level playing field for all market participants shall be ensured. These objectives should be achieved by ensuring a level playing field between all service providers, as well as a regulatory framework covering innovative forms of payment services and instruments. I support the objectives of the proposal to update the already existing framework to the dynamically changing environment of electronic payments, taking into account, in particular, the development of e-commerce to further develop a broad EU e-payments market that will enable all market participants to reap the benefits of the EU internal market.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Payment mediation services should not be allowed to claim selectivity for the unrestricted exclusion from the scope of Directive 2007/04/EC. The creation of "collection plants" and "payment factories" should not be excluded from the scope of the Directive for reasons of potential tax evasion. Finally, the imposition of interbank commissions on card transactions is completely unfair and wrong.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against the second Payment Services Directive because it interferes in freedom of contract, grants the Commission power to issue delegated acts and demands ‘full harmonisation’ in a way that prevents the UK from having its own approach to such matters.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Directive aims to enhance the security of online operations, protect consumers from fraud or payment incidents, cover new providers and encourage the development of innovative services. With the expansion of e-commerce, it is necessary to update the rules on payments to promote security, competition and innovation. The drop in costs and a wider range of choice for users are some of the benefits i agree with.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this deliberation because there is a legal vacuum with respect to third countries and the security of payments is not really assured.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In general, we follow the concerns that have been expressed by economic operators about the lack of transparency regarding the actual costs of payment cards, barriers to entry into the payment market and multilateral interchange fees. Data from the European Central Bank (ECB) show a huge disproportion between the costs of these operations and the amounts charged to beneficiaries and consumers. Further studies on the actual costs of electronic payment methods are needed to address the lack of transparency. The existing situation today would justify legislative interventions in a number of areas. This directive, however, does not fully respond to this need. In the first place, limits were imposed on the fees charged by banks to third party payment service providers, which is not the case. This is just one example, among other possible, of how, in the end, they weigh even though the pious intentions expressed, in practice, everything can stay the same. It is not the first time that these topics here are discussed. Once again, essential issues remain unresolved.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour because changes constitute a positive development for both consumers and SMEs across all Member States.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from this report on credit institutions and companies providing "electronic money" through credit cards. There are far too positive references to the development possibilities of e-commerce and its potential contribution to growth.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Although the report is moving in the right direction, the supervisory instruments are not precisely defined so that the powers exercised are exercised in accordance with fundamental rights, including the right to privacy. The report introduces concepts contrary to the principles of the free market. Payment service providers and special means of payment may not automatically change from specific to general purpose. Grouping all payment services removes the independence of payment subcategories, circumvents many rights related to provision and use, and can raise problems of financial transaction security and sensitive personal data. For the above reasons my vote is against.  Payment mediation services should not be allowed to claim selectivity for the unrestricted exclusion from the scope of Directive 2007/04/EC. The creation of "collection plants" and "payment factories" should not be excluded from the scope of the Directive for reasons of potential tax evasion. Finally, the imposition of interbank commissions for card transactions is completely unfair and wrong.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I congratulate the rapporteur for his work on the consensual outcome of the report. I would congratulate him especially for ensuring the development of new practices and new players in payment services in response to the challenges the current framework faces, while ensuring safety and transparency for consumers. Transparency of payment services is a key element in terms of guaranteeing that consumers benefit fully from the internal market, and strengthening trust in a harmonised payments market. The payments institutions’ access to accounts maintained with a credit institution will allow the unrestricted and efficient provision of payment services. Lastly, consumer protection is a shared competence of the EU and Member States and, especially in the field of financial services, it falls within the broader aim of protecting economic interests. Therefore, I support the elements added to strengthen the provision for consumer protection, such as the unconditional right to reimbursement, better protection in relation to transactions and in the framework contract between a consumer and a payment services provider.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the significant progress made towards integrating retail payments into the European Union. In recent years, however, the retail payments market has experienced remarkable technical innovations that pose a challenge to the validity of the current framework. There is no doubt that the continued development of an integrated single market for secure electronic payments is essential to support the growth of the EU economy, so it is necessary to establish new provisions that fill legal loopholes while providing more legal clarity and ensuring uniform implementation of the regulatory framework across the Union.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal, which updates the 2007 Payment Services Directive in order to take account of the emergence of new players in this market.  The text agreed with the Council increases consumer protection, thanks to the work of our group, in relation to the 2007 text and the Commission's initial proposal.   In particular, an unconditional right to reimbursement of amounts not owed by the payment card holder is included. Surcharges for using cards whose fees are already limited by the recently approved Payment Card Commission Regulation are also prohibited.  It was also possible to include in the tripartite dialogue the express prohibition on the cancellation of the payment card service for transfer from the holder to another Member State, an example of bad banking practice to be eradicated and which cannot survive in the future single capital market.  In this regard, it is important to ensure that the important Capital Markets Union project does not set aside families and users of financial services, including cross-border ones, given the long list of barriers to the movement of capital.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because it is an update to the Payment Services Directive for 2007, in order to take account of the emergence of new players in this market.  The text agreed with the Council increases consumer protection, thanks to the work of our group, in relation to the 2007 text and the Commission's initial proposal.   In particular, an unconditional right to reimbursement of amounts not owed by the payment card holder is included. Surcharges for using cards whose fees are already limited by the recently approved Payment Card Commission Regulation are also prohibited.  It was also possible to include in the tripartite dialogue the express prohibition on the cancellation of the payment card service for transfer from the holder to another Member State, an example of bad banking practice to be eradicated and which cannot survive in the future single capital market.  In this regard, it is important to ensure that the important Capital Markets Union project does not set aside families and users of financial services, including cross-border ones, given the long list of barriers to the movement of capital.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report will bring great benefits to both businesses and consumers. The market is opening up, costs are being reduced and fraud is being combated. This is an extraordinary result which demonstrates the excellent work done by the rapporteur, which has made it possible to achieve very broad parliamentary convergence.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of updating the Payment System Directive because I firmly believe in the need to make the online payments market less and less fragmented, reduce costs and above all the risks of fraud. I therefore warmly welcome the efforts made by our colleagues at ECON who have generously worked to create the conditions for the creation and strengthening of a European electronic payment system. The importance of this new piece, which complements the so-called legislative package on payment systems, lies in the fact that the retail payments market in the EU is evolving as evidenced by some relevant data: 34% of European citizens shop on the Internet and more than 50% own a smartphone, through which they access the world of mobile payments. The agreement with the Council is based on new rules aimed at: stimulating competition between payment service operators, expanding information for consumer citizens, promoting innovative and equally secure payment methods, in view of technological innovations in recent years, recognising reimbursement rights in the event of fraud, reducing expenditure related to payment services and, not least, , a greater focus on data processing.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on payment services in the Single Market. Mr Tajani has done an excellent job. Payment services are of fundamental importance when we talk about the common European internal market.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support my colleague's report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on payment services in the internal market, amendments to Directives 2002/65/EC, 2013/36/EU and 2009/110/EC, and the repeal of Directive 2007/64/EC. The creation of an internal market for payments and electronic transactions makes an important contribution to the protection of EU consumers. More and more work is being done across borders and over the Internet. The lack of a clear legal framework leads to legal uncertainty and a lack of consumer protection.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the second Payment Services Directive because it interferes in freedom of contract, grants the Commission power to issue delegated acts and demands ‘full harmonisation’ in a way that prevents the UK from having its own approach to such matters.
