I have no option but to vote against anything which provides the unelected Commission with the power to issue delegated acts. I also note the interference in freedom of contract evident in Article 62, and the suggestion of ‘full harmonisation’ in Article 107.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this report, which will allow to ensure the development of new practices and new actors in payment services while ensuring safety and transparency for consumers. It will make electronic payments safer for consumers and encourage competition and innovation in the market. As we continue to push to stop card schemes and banks from unnecessarily increasing fees we expect savings to be passed on to consumers.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. We do more online shopping every day. It is therefore necessary to improve the security of payments we make online and to ensure the privacy of buyers' data, as well as to facilitate the entry of new competitors into the European market for payment services, which will allow a reduction in costs. That directive therefore has my vote in favour.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this proposal, which is advancing the establishment of clear regulation of transactions and payments in Europe. The aim is to improve consumer protection against fraud and erroneous or un authorised payments, so that the payment system is safer in all Member States. On the other hand, legislative change reduces the cost of payments both online and by card, for the benefit of consumers and small businesses, as the current market is extremely fragmented and dominated by large banks.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the European Parliamentary Labour Party, I voted in favour of the Payment Services Directive because it will make electronic payments safer for consumers and encourage competition and innovation in the market. As we continue to push to stop card schemes and banks from unnecessarily increasing fees, we expect savings to be passed on to consumers.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Directive, which updates the 2007 Payment Services Directive in order to take account of the emergence of new players on this market.  The text agreed with the Council increases consumer protection, thanks to the work of our group, in relation to the 2007 text and the Commission's initial proposal. In particular, an unconditional right to reimbursement of amounts not owed by the payment card holder is included. Surcharges for using cards whose fees are already limited by the recently approved Payment Card Commission Regulation are also prohibited.  It was also possible to include in the tripartite dialogue the express prohibition on the cancellation of the payment card service for transfer from the holder to another Member State, an example of bad banking practice to be eradicated and which cannot survive in the future single capital market.  In this regard, it is important to ensure that the important Capital Markets Union project does not set aside families and users of financial services, including cross-border ones, given the long list of barriers to the movement of capital.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as I am in favour of setting a basis for a harmonised legal framework for the creation of an integrated payments market, which also aims to update and complement the current framework on payment services. Ensuring a competitive level playing field for all categories of payment service providers and ensuring the adequate and consistent protection of consumer interests in the context of payment transactions, including extending regulatory protection to new payment services, are proposals well aligned with the principles of the EU.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. This proposal is the final confirmation of the compromise negotiated in the trialogue procedure in July between the EP, the Council of Ministers and the Commission. It builds on an earlier Directive, 2007/64/EC, thus completing the scheme for a common electronic payment market. This includes opening up the market for so-called payment initiation services and account information services. In this respect, the proposal is pro-innovation, promotes competition between payment providers and is another building block on the road to a well-functioning European internal market. The level playing field is defined in a transparent manner with this common regulation. I am therefore voting in favour of this report. I hereby call on the Commission, the ECB and the EBA to take care, when implementing the directive and later as supervisory authorities, to ensure that the following aspects are implemented: - data protection and security against unauthorised access are non-negotiable and must be guaranteed in all circumstances. - The Account Information Service uses strong customer authentication for account queries. - The condition for access to the third-party service is insurance cover, which ensures full compensation to the credit institution holding the account for any damage. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this proposal, which is advancing the establishment of clear regulation of transactions and payments in Europe. The aim is to improve consumer protection against fraud and erroneous or un authorised payments, so that the payment system is safer in all Member States. On the other hand, legislative change reduces the cost of payments both online and by card, for the benefit of consumers and small businesses, as the current market is extremely fragmented and dominated by large banks.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It will allow the development of new practices and new players in payment services while, at the same time, ensuring safety and transparency for consumers.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a directive from Parliament and the Council on internal market payment services and amendments to Directives 2002/65/EC, 2016/36/EC and 2009/110/EC and the repeal of Directive 2007/64/EC, as this reduces differences between Member States and balances the legal framework within the Union in that domain, and guarantees a greater degree of legal certainty. In addition, the European payment market, consumer protection and payment security are being empowered and lower prices are encouraged.  I believe, however, that particular attention should be paid to the transparency of such processes, ensure data protection and clearly inform consumers of their rights, and encourage new technologies in line with the growing needs of innovation.  In this way, payment services provide consumers with more choice and reflect the balance between the open market and payment security. That's why I support this proposal.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this directive is to secure online payments made within member states. With this in mind, it is proposed to open the market to two new payment service providers (PSPs), namely account manager PSPs and third-party PSPs. Overall, the text focuses heavily on consumer protection.  However, with respect to third-party PSPs, certain provisions remain unclear, particularly with regard to the confidentiality and exploitation of the information collected by the provider.  So I abstained.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Antonio Tajani's report on payment services. This vote validates the agreement reached with the European Commission and the Council, which allows for increased security of transactions and a reduction in costs. Payment service providers will be required to adopt secure authentication technologies, ensure that personal data flows through secure channels and that it will be shared only with the user's consent and as small as possible. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which allows consumers' payments to be adapted to new forms of payment (mobile, electronic). This text aims to promote the efficiency of the payment system as a whole and to offer consumers more choice while ensuring the protection of data and payments and imposing the obligation to inform consumers of their rights.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The text clarifies to what extent the current e-payments framework is no longer adequately aligned with innovation and partly eliminates regulation or to what extent individual national regulations contradict each other and thus payment services cannot operate across borders. It aims to make payment services more efficient, to have customers more choice, to create more transparency in this field and to increase confidence in such services. I support all these proposals and am therefore voting in favour of the report.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive on payment services in the internal market at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg because I believe that it will contribute to the development of electronic means of payment and simplify electronic payments for both citizens and businesses. The Directive will create more favourable conditions for existing and new ent.3 players by facilitating access to the wider market for new payment means and ensuring a high level of consumer protection for the use of these payment services in the EU. The aim is to create a favourable environment for the future creation of new and innovative payment instruments. Initiatives to reduce fragmentation of the EU market, particularly in the financial sector, are to be welcomed, which is why I voted in favour of this directive.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, as it will allow to ensure the development of new practices and new actors in payment services while ensuring safety and transparency for consumers.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. This proposal is the final confirmation of the compromise negotiated in the trialogue procedure in July between the EP, the Council of Ministers and the Commission. It builds on an earlier Directive, 2007/64/EC, thus completing the scheme for a common electronic payment market. I hereby call on the Commission, the ECB and the EBA to take care, when implementing the directive and later as supervisory authorities, to ensure that the following aspects are implemented: - data protection and security against unauthorised access are non-negotiable and must be guaranteed in all circumstances. - The Account Information Service uses strong customer authentication for account queries. - The condition for access to the third-party service is insurance cover, which ensures full compensation to the credit institution holding the account for any damage.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – In addition to the surge in card payments in trade and services, there is a dynamic development of internet, mobile and other new payment methods. Given that these are largely cross-border transactions, I supported the report in the interests of consumer safety, which provides a clear and harmonised regulatory framework at EU level. It aims to ensure that payment transactions are secure and to protect against the risk of fraud.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour because this proposal lays the foundations for a harmonised legal framework concerning the creation of an integrated payments market. The aim is to update and integrate the current framework on payment services, ensuring a level playing field between all categories of payment service providers. This will make it possible to provide greater choice as well as greater efficiency, transparency and security of retail payments.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive from Parliament and the European Council on payment services in the internal market. In recent years, the European payments market has undergone significant and profound technical changes. In order to support growth in Europe, it is necessary to support these technical innovations by offering new payment services adapted to current needs. I have therefore supported this proposal for a directive to enable citizens, consumers, entrepreneurs and merchants to benefit from a wider range of payment services, whose security and transparency will be enhanced.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Directive, which updates the 2007 Payment Services Directive in order to take account of the emergence of new players on this market.  The text agreed with the Council increases consumer protection, thanks to the work of our group, in relation to the 2007 text and the Commission's initial proposal. In particular, an unconditional right to reimbursement of amounts not owed by the payment card holder is included. Surcharges for using cards whose fees are already limited by the recently approved Payment Card Commission Regulation are also prohibited.  It was also possible to include in the tripartite dialogue the express prohibition on the cancellation of the payment card service for transfer from the holder to another Member State, an example of bad banking practice to be eradicated and which cannot survive in the future single capital market.  In this regard, it is important to ensure that the important Capital Markets Union project does not set aside families and users of financial services, including cross-border ones, given the long list of barriers to the movement of capital.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. Because of the current situation in which we find ourselves, with security risks in the payment chain and consumer protection in certain areas, it is necessary to carry out this report in order to ensure that consumers and retailers can enjoy effective, convenient and secure payment methods at Union level. For the sake of legal certainty, it is necessary to establish new provisions that end existing legal loopholes; why this report was born. It is also fighting to ensure that traders and businesses in general can take advantage of the advantages offered by the internal market.  In addition, this Directive is intended to ensure market continuity so that all service providers (both new and existing) can offer their services within a harmonised regulatory framework. Similarly, Member States, the ECB, the Commission and EBA are urged to ensure fair competition on this market.  I consider this report of great importance and support it, as it will help to consolidate a clear legal framework that will generate efficiency throughout the payment system and increase the range of payment services available and their transparency.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. This proposal is the final confirmation of the compromise negotiated in the trialogue procedure in July between the EP, the Council of Ministers and the Commission. It builds on an earlier Directive, 2007/64/EC, thus completing the scheme for a common electronic payment market. This includes opening up the market for so-called payment initiation services and account information services. The level playing field is defined in a transparent manner with this common regulation. I am therefore voting in favour of this report. I hereby call on the Commission, the ECB and the EBA to take care, when implementing the directive and later as supervisory authorities, to ensure that the following aspects are implemented: - data protection and security against unauthorised access are non-negotiable and must be guaranteed in all circumstances. - The Account Information Service uses strong customer authentication for account queries. - The condition for access to the third-party service is insurance cover, which ensures full compensation to the credit institution holding the account for any damage.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this supplementary report, which further regulates something that goes against the freedom of the treaty and should therefore be left to the contractual freedom of trading partners, e.g. Article 62. Furthermore, I am also against the fact that Article 104 empowers the Commission to adopt implementing acts. The full harmonisation referred to in Article 107 is better suited to the Regulation than to the Directive.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This proposal for a Directive aims to create a harmonised legal framework to create a single and integrated payment system in the European Union. The measures covered by this proposal for the Directive aim to standardise and enable inter-operationality of services for card, mobile and internet payments; encourage competition from different payment service providers with a view to raising efficiency and transparency and security in the field of payments; encourage the cross-border use of innovative cards, the internet and mobile payments in order to ensure a single market for small payments; and ensure adequate consumer protection in the area of payment, especially in the area of new forms of payment.  This proposal will reduce payment costs and allow new service providers to enter the market, while raising the level of safety for consumers. I therefore supported Representative Tajani's report.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – Today, globalisation is turning traditional trade into a digital economy while developing the offer of electronic payments to users. These changes also require proper adaptation of legislation that will increase legal certainty and protection of entities in these relationships. The proposal on the table responds to the development of electronic and mobile operations and the emergence of new types of payment services. The introduction of more accurate rights and obligations for the individual, payment institutions as well as member states will contribute to the transparency and security of payment operations, to increased competition, while eliminating unfair practices such as data misuse or money laundering.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Supplementary Report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on payment services in the internal market and amending Directives 2002/65/EC, 2013/36/EU and 2009/110/EC and repealing Directive 2007/64/EC, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/10/2015 and because the proper functioning of the internal market requires a secure payment system in order to support the development of the economy in the Union and to ensure that consumers benefit from transparency in payment services. It is therefore clear that all Member States should ensure that the rules on access to payment services are objective and non-discriminatory and that there is also security in electronic transactions. This will stop barriers between national markets while helping the internal market to create e-commerce. At the same time, however, I would like to point out that the European Union is not entitled to exclude the elderly, but also other portions of consumers from the single market, by imposing the compulsory use of cards and thus leading to a 'unnecessary' society.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As consumers and undertakings are not in the same position, they do not need the same level of protection. While it is important to guarantee consumer rights by provisions from which it is not possible to derogate by contract, it is reasonable to let undertakings and organisations agree otherwise when they are not dealing with consumers.  However, Member States should be able to provide that micro-enterprises, as defined in Commission Recommendation 2003/361/EC, be treated in the same way as consumers. In any case, certain core provisions of this Directive should always apply, irrespective of the status of the user.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the proposal for a directive on payment services in the internal market. The report promotes growth in the European development of the electronic payments market, stressing the importance of having rules and procedures that are consistent throughout Europe, thus also promoting legal certainty. It is these important aspects that must be taken into account and work on with quality, in the light of the current situation at European level and also in the evolution of consumer needs, which must be adequately protected. In addition, the provision for a reduction in costs is a detail of considerable importance, including greater security of payments, thus protecting consumers' rights.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on revised EU rules on payment services. The cost of paying the bill should be reduced by ing new businesses on the market to use mobile and online tools to make payments on behalf of the customer. The new rules also aim to secure electronic payments by setting data protection and liability standards for all providers of electronic payment services. The bank managing the payer's account will only be able to prevent access to it from a third-party service provider on the basis of objectively justified and documented security reasons reported to the supervisory authorities. This safeguard measure should prevent the possibility of 'blocking' the market for new payment services in any way. Payments should therefore be much safer, which is why I supported the proposal.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report in order to facilitate the updating of the regulation of payment services. I am convinced that this report, which has been adopted by the vast majority of those present, represents an important step forward that will have a positive impact on the lives of European citizens. In addition to the improved security of online payment services, emphasis has been placed on the processing of personal data.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. In recent years, online payments have undergone profound changes. Not long ago, they were exclusively organized by banking operators. Now, other players are taking advantage of the emergence of new payment techniques to enter the market. That is why the European legislator has committed to giving a legal scope for this development. The new Payment Services Directive (DPS2), which Parliament voted on at the last plenary session, is specifically aimed at framing these new practices, which have been appropriated by many European companies.  Therefore, by voting for the Tajani report, I wished to give demanding support to these regulatory efforts. If I am convinced of the need to legislate in this area, I want to remain vigilant: the new provisions must in all circumstances protect European citizens, and in particular their personal data. Innovation can and must contribute to the well-being of our societies, but for this to happen, it must be accompanied by strong safeguards of general interest.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report emphasises the extent to which the current e-payments framework is no longer adequately aligned with innovation. In some cases, regulations are withdrawn or individual national regulations are mutually opposed, so payment services cannot operate across borders. The report aims to make payment services more efficient, to make customers more choice, to create more transparency in this field and to increase confidence in such services. In principle, these are not bad proposals, but they would still be expandable. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The proposal aims to repeal the current Payment Services Directive (PSD). The aim is to extend the scope of this directive in order to improve the functioning of the internal market for payment services. Indeed, with the emergence of new types of payment services and the rapid growth of electronic and mobile payments, the retail payments market has undergone significant technical innovations that are testing the current legislative framework. By facilitating transactions within the Union, the Commission hopes to promote growth. However, low consumption has little to do with the means of payment. Rather, it would be a matter of increasing the income available to individuals. Nevertheless, the text proposes tighter control of payment institutions in the light of combating money laundering and terrorist financing. Particular attention is also paid to the shareholders of the payment institutions. To encourage this, I vote For but without enthusiasm.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this directive is to further secure online payments within EU Member States. To do this, it is proposed to open the market to two new payment service providers (PSPs), namely ACCOUNT manager PSPs and third-party PSPs. The text as a whole attaches particular importance to consumer protection. However, in the case of third-party PSPs, some points remain unclear as to the confidentiality and exploitation of the information collected by the provider.  For this reason, I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. The choice and transparency of payment services is essential for consumers, traders and businesses to take full advantage of the internal market, which is fundamental to the growth of the Union economy.  For this reason, I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive by the European Parliament and of the Council on payment services in the internal market.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution features much wording that has been amended by Parliament on the Commission’s proposal regarding payment services in the internal market. The final, amended, proposal will work to harmonise the rapidly changing payments market and its regulation in the European Union across national borders – focusing on digital and mobile payments in particular. Such standardisation will improve consumer welfare and ease the burdens on payment services firms attempting to operate transnationally. Therefore I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The advent of a digital market in Europe, conditioned by the emergence of European champions of new technologies, is one of the liberal priorities of the European Parliament. We have just approved the updating of the rules on the currently fragmented and expensive payment services market, which is estimated to cost 130 billion euros per year. It is expected that European citizens will spend 45 billion euros on mobile payments in 2015, an increase of almost 90% compared to 2014. These figures confirm the inevitable growth of digital technology in everyday life. This new regulatory framework will reduce costs, improve security and facilitate payments mainly via mobile and on the internet.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the proposal for a directive on payment services in the internal market because of the continuous development of an integrated internal market, which is of great importance for supporting the growth of the economy in the Union. The guiding principle of full integrity and efficiency is security and transparency in payments and the use of payment services. It is therefore necessary to harmonise the market and to further strengthen consumer confidence. New rules should be laid down and equivalent conditions guaranteed to ensure uniform application of the legislative framework in the EU. I consider it important to focus on providing adequate protection for consumers and businesses to whom the right to know the actual costs of payments and services is attached and to be clearly informed of their rights and obligations, which aims to enhance certainty towards a harmonised payment market. I appreciate the development of an integrated market and agree with the regulations that will prevent different approaches within the internal market in order to fully reap the benefits of it. The volume of electronic payments and the use of ever-new services are constantly increasing, which I see as a trend on a global scale. It is therefore necessary to recognise that it is essential to accelerate the creation and harmonization of an effective integrated payment market.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on payment services in the internal market, ensuring the development of new practices and new players in payment services while ensuring safety and transparency for consumers, which is essential.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission proposed to Parliament and the Council amending Directives 2002/65/EC, 2013/36/EU and 2009/110/EC and repealing Directive 2007/64/EC on payment services in the internal market. The EP's Economic and Financial Committee, adopting the report by Antonio Tajani of the Italian People's Party, is proposing to Parliament at first reading an amendment to the Commission's draft. I supported the proposal of the Committee on Economic and Financial Affairs.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The review of the Union legal framework on payment services and, in particular, the analysis of the impact of Directive 2007/64/EC and the consultation on the Commission's Green Paper of 11 January 2012 entitled "For an integrated European market for card, internet and mobile payments", have shown that developments have posed significant regulatory challenges. I am voting in favour of this report which aims to close the existing regulatory gaps, while ensuring greater legal clarity and consistent implementation of the legislative framework throughout the Union. Operators already present on the market and new entrants should be guaranteed equivalent conditions for the exercise of the activity, allowing the widespread deployment of new means of payment on the market and ensuring a high level of consumer protection in the use of these payment services across the Union I also believe that the continued evolution of an integrated internal market for secure electronic payments is essential to support the growth of the EU economy and to ensure that consumers, traders and businesses can enjoy the choice and transparency of payment services in order to take full advantage of the internal market.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The vote aims to adopt a new directive on payment services to open up the market to new players. The expected effect is lower transaction costs with an increase in the level of security of online payments. However, this directive creates a new category, that of third-party payment service providers, which will be able to initiate payments at the request of the payer without holding the funds concerned. Uncertainty about the way information is handled by these new players remains. So I decided to abstain.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Payment Services Directive because it will make electronic payments safer for consumers and encourage competition and innovation in the market. As we continue to push to stop card schemes and banks unnecessarily increasing fees, we expect savings to be passed on to consumers.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report which will improve the effectiveness of the European Parliament and Council directives on payment services in the internal market.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposed directive, on which my colleague Matt Carthy was a shadow rapporteur. The Payment Services Directive is an important piece of legislation which creates new prospects for SMEs and budding start-ups by opening up the banking industry to what are known as third-party providers (TPPs). Not only does this create more employment and business opportunities but it also allows for more consumer choice.  During discussions in preparatory meetings of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, Matt Carthy highlighted the need to break the dominance of the big banks, which currently control the payments market to the detriment of small businesses and budding entrepreneurs. Moreover, he sought to ensure that the legislation would strengthen consumer protection and regulate operators who previously functioned with no regulatory or supervisory framework. All competitors will now be forced to comply with financial regulation, which is crucial for any economy.  It was for these reasons I voted in favour of this legislation.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on payment services in the internal market, which is the result of a long negotiation between the EP and the Council containing a number of complex technical details. The resulting form ensures a level playing field between all categories of payment service providers, while at the same time giving greater choice between retail payment means and increasing their security and transparency. I also positively assess the facilitation of the cross-border provision of innovative payment services when paying by card, internet or mobile.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This report clarifies why the current e-payments framework is no longer adapted to the current state of innovation and is partly out of regulation. It also notes that individual national regulations are mutually contradictory and therefore payment service providers cannot operate across borders. The report calls for payment services to become more efficient, for customers to have more choice, for greater transparency in this field to be created and for confidence in such services to be strengthened. In principle, the report does not have any bad proposals, but there are a few points that need to be defined more precisely. That is why I abstained.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Supplementing the Rules on Payment Services in the European Union will reduce the costs of payment services, improve the security of services and be necessary to keep pace with innovation.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – In order to improve the legal regulation of payment services, it is appropriate to extend the scope of the Directive. In order to promote competition, it is important to ensure that legal certainty legislation is applied in the field of payment services. It is also necessary to ensure safe, efficient, competitive and innovative electronic payments.  The protection of the rights and interests of users of payment services must play a particular role. It is important to promote and ensure the principle of the functioning of the single market so that consumers, retailers and businesses can benefit from the single market. It should be noted that the new regulation must be flexible, easily adaptable to new market developments and new services, as the services market is undergoing constant active development. In order to achieve an efficient single market, it is essential to identify in advance barriers that limit innovation and efficiency gains.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on payment services in the internal market. In recent years, security risks regarding electronic payments have increased. This is due to the increasing technical complexity of electronic payments, the continuous increase in the number of electronic payments made worldwide and the advent of new types of payment services. The security of payment services is a fundamental condition for the proper functioning of the relevant market. It is therefore appropriate to establish new rules in order to fill regulatory gaps, while ensuring greater legal clarity and uniform application of the legislative framework throughout the Union. Operators already active on the market and new operators should benefit from equal operating conditions, so as to make it possible for new means of payment to be disseminated more widely on the market and to ensure a high level of protection for consumers using these payment services. This should generate efficiencies in the payment system as a whole and result in greater transparency of payment services, and should also strengthen consumer confidence in a harmonised payment market.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I would vote in favour because I believe it is necessary to implement the integrated single market for secure electronic payments, in order to promote the growth of the Community economy and at the same time ensure the transparency of payment services to European citizens.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The revision of the Payment Services Directive will bolster e-commerce and provide significant advantages for European consumers, whose interest lies at the heart of every piece of legislation that we in the EU institutions produce. I therefore welcome the new measures contained in PSD 2, such as enhanced legal protection, information on transactions and unconditional refund in case of unauthorised payments or fraud.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒today's payment market in the European Union is fragmented and expensive. Its cost is over 1% of the GDP of the European Union or €130 billion per year. These costs cannot be afforded by the economy. The Digital Single Market should be encouraged, making online payments cheaper and safer for retailers and consumers. Exchange fees paid by retailers are found in invoices issued to consumers. Not only are consumers most often unaware of this, but they are now encouraged to use the cards that provide their banks with the highest revenues.  A level playing field will be created for payment service providers, new providers will get the chance to be part of the market and offer innovative services, retailers will make big savings by paying lower fees to their banks, and consumers will benefit thanks to lower retail prices.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote aims to adopt a new directive on payment services to open the market to new players. The expected effect is lower transaction costs with an increase in the level of security of online payments. However, this directive creates a new category, that of third-party payment service providers, which will be able to initiate payments at the request of the payer without holding the funds concerned. Uncertainty about the way information is handled by these new players remains. So I decided to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The proposal for a directive is of utmost interest as significant areas of the payment market, in particular card payments and online and mobile payments, remain fragmented by national borders and it is difficult for payment service providers to introduce innovative, secure and easily usable digital payment services. The Proposal with amendments from the European Parliament fills certain regulatory gaps, seeking to modernise the legislative framework for payment services in line with the development of technology and markets, increase consumer choice, encourage price reductions for payment services and improve the security of online payments. Amendments to the proposal for a directive clearly define the conditions and implications of the exclusion of individual payment transactions from the scope of Directive 2007/64/EC, and extended the scope of services touched by the Directive to account information services and payment initiation services, with a view to increasing the transparency and security of such business. In order to prevent arbitrary use of exclusion practices from the Directive in different Member States, service providers should be obliged to communicate relevant activities to the competent authorities of the Member States, and a notification procedure should be set for all exclusions based on respect for the threshold. As pointed out by the Committee on Finance and the State Budget of the Croatian Parliament, this proposal for a directive would certainly enable consumers, retailers and other market participants to make simpler and more complete use of the benefits of the EU internal market.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I agree with colleague Antonio Tajani's proposal on payment services in the internal market. Further market integration and reduction of fragmentation in this area are aimed at.  Given that there are great opportunities for innovation in europe's electronic payment market, this initiative should give consumers and traders the opportunity to take full advantage of the free market. Thus, it is to encourage further development of the european union-wide electronic payment market, which corresponds to today's global processes of abandoning traditional trading methods, and moving closer to the digital economy.  The aim is also to reduce costs and prices for payment service users, create greater choice and transparency of payment services, improve payment security, and facilitate the emergence of new entities and innovative payment methods. In addition to updating the current framework for payment services, rules should also be adopted that will achieve the principles of transparency and security, taking into account the legitimate needs of consumers. Payment suppliers should ensure the safety of users, as well as reduce the risk of fraud. Personal data will only be able to be transmitted through secure channels and shared only with the consent of the user.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The functioning of the internal market requires consumers to be able to make electronic payments smoothly. I therefore voted in favour of the supplementary report on the proposal for a directive on payment services in the internal market. This adjustment is undoubtedly in place at a time of increasing number of transactions made over the Internet and via mobile applications. I also voted in favour of forcing financial institutions providing an electronic payment service to set up professional liability insurance in the territory where they offer services or a similar guarantee of liability, and for eba to be responsible for the establishment and later review of the guidelines setting out the minimum amount of money for such liability insurance. I also voted in favour of the establishment of a public online register of financial institutions authorised to provide electronic payments, which should ensure greater transparency in the field of paying agents. As I am convinced of the importance of preventing any financial fraud, I also voted in favour of allowing the processing of personal data by payment systems. However, this does not alter the fact that personal data must be respected and must not be processed or stored without the consent of users for purposes other than investigating and detecting fraud. I believe that a more efficient and secure electronic payment system will support the further growth of the European economy.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a directive aims to promote greater development of the electronic payments market throughout the European Union. This measure was presented taking into account the fact that the digital economy is supplanting traditional trade and that consumers are changing their payment habits. The proposed new directive contains many adjustments to the existing directive on payment services and imposes certain new obligations on Member States, leaving them considerable discretion as regards how they are transposed into national law. The proposed principles, rules, procedures and standards must be consistent in all Member States, so as to achieve legal certainty and equal treatment among all market participants. I believe that the rapporteur has done an excellent job and I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of his proposal.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted the text on the revision of the Directive on Payment Services in the Internal Market. I voted in favour of this report because it helps to make payment services in the Union more efficient and to simplify existing procedures.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. MEPs voted this lunchtime on the Tajani report to update the rules on the payment services market. Services are booming but are currently characterized by their fragmented and expensive aspect, at an overall cost estimated at 130 billion euros per year. A study predicts that European citizens will have spent 45 billion euros on mobile payment in 2015, an increase of almost 90% compared to 2014. These figures confirm the inevitable impact of digital technology in everyday life. I have of course supported this adaptation of the "payment services" legislation to new technological supports. This is the kind of legislation that reconciles citizens with Europe. This directive certainly brings added value for the consumer who will soon benefit from payment solutions (online, via mobile or tablet and card) facilitated and at a lower cost. This legislation allows us to take a date and anticipate the major trends and the way in which consumers now buy goods and services. The most visible of these is certainly the fact that trade via smartphones in Europe will increase by 42% on average each year.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Directive, which updates the 2007 Payment Services Directive in order to take account of the emergence of new players on this market.  The text agreed with the Council increases consumer protection, thanks to the work of our group, in relation to the 2007 text and the Commission's initial proposal. In particular, an unconditional right to reimbursement of amounts not owed by the payment card holder is included. Surcharges for using cards whose fees are already limited by the recently approved Payment Card Commission Regulation are also prohibited.  It was also possible to include in the tripartite dialogue the express prohibition on the cancellation of the payment card service for transfer from the holder to another Member State, an example of bad banking practice to be eradicated and which cannot survive in the future single capital market.  In this regard, it is important to ensure that the important Capital Markets Union project does not set aside families and users of financial services, including cross-border ones, given the long list of barriers to the movement of capital.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The vote on this report is an update of the Payment Services Directive. The adopted text aims to improve eu rules on payment services in order to encourage innovation in this area in Europe and to free itself from American systems such as PayPal (the European Parliament would indeed like to see other European companies break through, as is already the case in Germany with the Sofort scheme...).  The adopted text should therefore help to break the lock on banks that still prevent the emergence of new payment services, but also to promote the development of innovative settlement methods in the European Union. By stimulating the market for alternative online payment methods, the European Parliament also hopes to lower transaction costs.  However, cheaper payment services, however, cannot be less secure, so this directive will clearly force banks and other payment service providers to use technologies that guarantee a safe authentication procedure for users and reduce the risk of fraud for consumers. Once formally approved by the Council, the new legislative framework will come into force within two years, but the technical specifications will have to be applied beforehand.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on payment services in the internal market, which amends Directives 2002/65/EC, 2013/36/EC and repeals Directive 2007/64/EC, aims to establish a new harmonised legal framework for the creation of an integrated payment market.  The proposed measures aim, inter alia, at ensuring a level playing field between all categories of payment service providers, facilitating the provision of an innovative card with mobile payment services, removing barriers to competition, in particular for card and internet payments, among others.  For its correct implementation, I believe it is essential to ensure consistent application of the legislative framework, aligning the practical functioning of licensing and surveillance rules between Member States and adequate and consistent protection of consumer interests in the context of payment transactions, including the extension of regulatory protection for new payment services. In line with the proposed amendments, I gave my vote in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposed Payment Services Directive, which aims to reduce costs, further secure payments, encourage new players to enter the market and stimulate innovative new methods of online payment.  The European payment services market is fragmented and costs 130 billion euros a year, which can hurt European competitiveness in the long run.  It is therefore urgent and necessary to update the European rules on the mobile and online payment services market. Thus, fees charged for payment tools, such as bank cards, will be prohibited.  Given that 34% of European citizens shop online, this proposed directive is essential for securing payments.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on payment services in the internal market because I believe it is necessary to promote a greater and more harmonised development of electronic payments throughout the European Union, which at present are still very expensive and too heterogeneous between Member States. The digital economy is gradually replacing traditional trade and changing consumer payment habits, and that is why the principles, rules, procedures and standards must be consistent in all Member States, so as to achieve legal certainty and equal treatment among all market participants. The text provides for a reduction in costs, improved security, such as reducing the risk of fraud and protecting against un authorised payments and innovative new payment methods.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this proposal, which is advancing the establishment of clear regulation of transactions and payments in Europe. The aim is to improve consumer protection against fraud and erroneous or un authorised payments, so that the payment system is safer in all Member States. On the other hand, legislative change reduces the cost of payments both online and by card, for the benefit of consumers and small businesses, as the current market is extremely fragmented and dominated by large banks.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – I supported the revision of the Directive on payment services in the internal market because it contains a number of measures to strengthen the security and transparency of payment services for consumers. This is particularly important in the current trend of developing new types of payment options, such as mobile or internet payments, and the growing number of providers of these services. Payment security and the protection of personal data are essential for consumer confidence in digital payment technologies.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report significantly improves the privacy and security of electronic payments over the Commission's proposal, while strengthening customers' right to receive compensation in the event of unauthorized transactions. That's why I voted for it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Security risks related to electronic payments have increased in recent years. This is due to the increasing technical complexity of these new payment methods. Thanks to this proposal, consumers, traders and businesses will be guaranteed both a higher level of protection and greater choice and better conditions of transparency in relation to payment services. For this reason, I voted in favour of the directive, which aims to develop a large European market for electronic payments, so that all users can enjoy greater advantages in the European internal market.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as I do not wish to see the EU create more legislation in this area. In addition I do not believe that this is an EU competency.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As we continue to push to stop card schemes and banks from unnecessarily increasing fees, we expect savings to be passed on to consumers. Ultimately, I voted in favour of the Payment Services Directive because it will make electronic payments safer for consumers and encourage competition and innovation in the market.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the case of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on payment services in the internal market, I voted in favour of adopting this resolution. In fact, the EU must also reflect the advent of modern technology and its use by citizens in paying for goods or services. However, two aspects need to be taken into account. The first is that it is necessary to further protect the personal data of account holders so that they are not misused. And the second is to protect users from inadequate charges, whether on the part of traders or the banks themselves. It was these two aspects that were the main pillars of the proposal.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The retail payment market is very dynamic and innovative. 34% of EU citizens buy virtually exclusively online. The regulation adopted also regulates payment services over the Internet, which is very useful, as the vast majority of people nowadays use smartphones to pay online. The final agreement to change the regulation will also allow for a reduction in the percentage of fraud. Consumers will be guaranteed lower costs of using payment online and better and greater protection. The new directive will increase competitiveness and thus reduce the prices of services for consumers. As a result of the increase in the use of e-commerce in the field of payment transport, a revision of the Regulation was urgently needed and will now be sufficient to make changes in this area. I believe that we have had a good legislative text and we can be pleased with the final outcome of the negotiations with the Council. For the reasons set out above, I supported the amendment of Directives 2002/65/EC, 2009/110/EC and 2013/36/EU and Regulation (EU) No 1093/2010 and the repeal of Directive 2007/64/EC.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. This proposal is the final confirmation of the compromise negotiated in the trialogue procedure in July between the EP, the Council of Ministers and the Commission. It builds on an earlier Directive, 2007/64/EC, thus completing the scheme for a common electronic payment market. This includes opening up the market for so-called payment initiation services and account information services. In this respect, the proposal is pro-innovation, promotes competition between payment providers and is another building block on the road to a well-functioning European internal market. The level playing field is defined in a transparent manner with this common regulation. I am therefore voting in favour of this report. I hereby call on the Commission, the ECB and the EBA to take care, when implementing the directive and later as supervisory authorities, to ensure that the following aspects are implemented: - data protection and security against unauthorised access are non-negotiable and must be guaranteed in all circumstances. - The Account Information Service uses strong customer authentication for account queries. - The condition for access to the third-party service is insurance cover, which ensures full compensation to the credit institution holding the account for any damage.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cashless transactions and card payments are an increasingly important way to transfer money. The directive that we have approved will allow for a more efficient use of modern technologies and better consumer protection.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this Report because the development of the digital economy is of great importance for the establishment of an integrated single market for electronic payments and the economy as a whole. This establishment will enable consumers, traders and companies to enjoy all the benefits of the internal market.  Over the past few years, there has been a significant improvement in the integration of retail payments within the Union. However, important areas of the payment market, in particular card payments and online and mobile payments, remain fragmented within national borders. It is important to point out that the continuous growth in the volume of electronic payments worldwide and increasing technical complexity and feasibility lead to security risks. Security services are one of the key conditions for the payment services market due to the protection of service users themselves. Payment service users should be fully insured against risks, so that the market can function smoothly and contribute to key economic and social activities.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Payment Services Directive because it will make electronic payments safer for consumers and encourage competition and innovation in the market. As we continue to push to stop card schemes and banks from unnecessarily increasing fees, we expect savings to be passed on to consumers.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This proposal includes, but also revokes, the Payment Services Directive (DUPP), which lays the ground out for a harmonious legal framework programme for the creation of an integrated payment market. Some of the measures aimed at improving and complementing the current framework payment service programme include increasing competitiveness among all categories of payment service providers, ensuring a single market for all forms of retail payments, paying attention to standardisation and interoperability for card and online payments, as well as ensuring adequate and constant protection of consumers' interests in the context of payment transactions, which in practice will mean extending the prescribed protection to new forms of payment services.  I support this report, as improving regulations in the context of payment services in the EU will achieve better consumer protection and make available to them more forms of payment services. Furthermore, paying attention to the standardisation of existing and new services will facilitate the process of using different payment methods for EU citizens.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as it aims, in particular, to adapt EU legislation to today's conditions.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on payment services in the internal market. The efficiency of electronic transactions, especially cross-border transactions in the European Union, must be increased, and we must do everything we can to protect consumers. Today's economy is very difficult to imagine without electronic transactions, so we need legal principles that will regulate these relationships precisely and clearly. This report will also help to create a single market in the European Union.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on payment services in the internal market concerns the harmonisation of rules throughout the territory of the Union's internal market, at the same time as liberalises these services. This is the third report which revises the existing rules on payment services, an EU policy that we have always been sceptical about, because it is based precisely not on the proper functioning of payment services and the functioning of rules on it, but on the logic that when a market is liberalised it becomes automatically and more orderly.  Although the report itself was very technical in nature, we abstained, since on the one one, simplifying payments both by card and online is to the benefit of consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises. On the other hand, however, the liberalisation of payment services opens the window to a kind of shadow banking system, which becomes even more complicated for the legislator to control.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report is moving in the right direction on many points such as the review clause, the right of appeal, the execution of electronic money payment transactions, the continuation of cash or cheque payment transactions within the single market, the regulation of supervisors of payment start-up services for consumer protection, security and liability, competition and data protection. However, supervisory instruments are not precisely defined so that the powers exercised are exercised in accordance with fundamental rights, including the right to privacy. The report introduces concepts contrary to the principles of the free market. Payment service providers and special means of payment may not automatically change from specific to general purpose.  Payment intermediaries should not be allowed to claim selectivity for the unrestricted exclusion from the scope of Directive 2007/04/EC. The creation of "collection plants" and "payment factories" should not be excluded from the scope of the Directive for reasons of potential tax evasion. Finally, the imposition of interbank commissions on card transactions is completely unfair and wrong.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the additional report. Technical innovation in payment services is ongoing and it is therefore inevitable that our Community rules will follow these changes. I welcome the fact that the report has placed great emphasis on the security of card-based payments, since without it an efficient integrated market for card-based payments cannot be achieved. I think it is important that the report contains detailed lists of practices that distort individual competition and that it further strengthened the data protection parts of the original text. In assessing the supplementary report, I also noted that it highlighted the need to ensure a harmonised regulatory framework and a high level of consumer protection.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The economy of the Common Market of the European Union can only function when optimal monetary movement is ensured with a view to the purchase and sale of products and services between citizens and commercial agents in the Member States. From this point of view, payment services are a key element, which can have a significant impact on the economic development of the Member States. The European Commission issued the first directive to regulate this area in 2007, but important progress has since been made requiring its revision. The use of third parties to carry out these payment services gives more transparency and safety to consumers. The new document provides more protection against erroneous payments, to protect invoice-based payments and to protect consumer rights. The surcharges applied to transactions on the basis of certain payment instruments, in particular on the basis of bank cards, for the purpose of setting limits, at least at the level of interchange fees within the Union, shall also be regulated.  I believe that this document makes important changes to the regulation of payment services, which support European citizens and the development of the Union economy.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Mr. Tajani on the European Parliament and Council's proposal for a directive on payment services in the internal market and amending the directives 2002/65/EC, 2013/36/EU and 2009/110/EC and repealing the 2007/64/EC directive following the opinion of the experts in my political group. In particular, this regulation establishes rules for the billing of interchange fees on card-related payment transactions and aims to further accelerate the achievement of an efficient integrated market for card-related payment transactions.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The objective of this report is to generate efficiencies in the payment system and lead to more choice and more transparency of payment services, and I voted in favour of it. It calls for Directive 2007/64/EC to be repealed because, since its adoption, the retail payments market has experienced significant technical innovation, which challenges the current framework. The report stresses that the continued development of an integrated internal market for safe electronic payments is crucial in order to support the growth of the EU economy and ensure that consumers and businesses enjoy choice and transparency of payment services, so as to benefit fully from the internal market.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒I see the Commission proposal as an excellent example of the healthy added value that the Union can provide to individual Member States in a more appropriate and efficient manner than could be achieved individually in any Member State. I consider the establishment of a harmonised legal framework for an integrated payment market as a necessary and necessary consequence of upgrading an already existing framework that changes dynamically and progressively in line with the times, and in particular with the development of e-commerce. The vote of this legislative proposal will result in market rules that will improve consumer choice, not only by emphasising transparency, competitiveness and the protection of market innovation, but also by strengthening security in the retail payments segment; all to protect consumers.  In the conditions of comprehensive and unstoppable digitalisation, proposals that lead through the levelling of rules for all towards expanding choice opportunities and a higher level of protection for end-users - consumers, will always receive my wholehearted support.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Additional report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on payment services in the internal market, amending Directives 2002/65/EC, 2013/36/EU and 2009/110/EC and repealing Directive 2007/64/EC, as I believe it is extremely important for the further development of the internal market and that it benefits EU citizens. The proposal for a directive will further strengthen secure electronic payment and will also strengthen controls that prevent criminal offences and misuse of data.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this proposal, which is advancing the establishment of clear regulation of transactions and payments in Europe. The aim is to improve consumer protection against fraud and erroneous or un authorised payments, so that the payment system is safer in all Member States. On the other hand, legislative change reduces the cost of payments both online and by card, for the benefit of consumers and small businesses, as the current market is extremely fragmented and dominated by large banks.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. This proposal is the final confirmation of the compromise negotiated in the trialogue procedure in July between the EP, the Council of Ministers and the Commission. It builds on an earlier Directive, 2007/64/EC, thus completing the scheme for a common electronic payment market. This includes opening up the market for so-called payment initiation services and account information services. In this respect, the proposal is pro-innovation, promotes competition between payment providers and is another building block on the road to a well-functioning European internal market. The level playing field is defined in a transparent manner with this common regulation. I am therefore voting in favour of this report. I hereby call on the Commission, the ECB and the EBA to take care, when implementing the directive and later as supervisory authorities, to ensure that the following aspects are implemented: - data protection and security against unauthorised access are non-negotiable and must be guaranteed in all circumstances. - The Account Information Service uses strong customer authentication for account queries. - The condition for access to the third-party service is insurance cover, which ensures full compensation to the credit institution holding the account for any damage.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this proposal, which is advancing the establishment of clear regulation of transactions and payments in Europe. The aim is to improve consumer protection against fraud and erroneous or un authorised payments, so that the payment system is safer in all Member States. On the other hand, legislative change reduces the cost of payments both online and by card, for the benefit of consumers and small businesses, as the current market is extremely fragmented and dominated by large banks.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – Although transactions in bank cards and money transfers within the European Union are arranged, ensuring that payments throughout Europe are as simple and secure as in the consumer's country of residence, it should be noted that, following the adoption of the Payment Services Directive in 2007, innovative methods for initiating payments in the field of e-commerce have been developed.  It is important to further develop the internal market for integrated and secure electronic payments in order to ensure that consumers, traders and businesses have the choice and transparency of payment services. I therefore voted in favour of a regulation which will, among other things, open up more opportunities for making payments through mobile or online tools, improve the security of payment services, data protection and financial accountability on the part of service providers.   The new payment services must be secure and protect the user in the event of theft or loss of the payment instrument in the event of misuse. Therefore, the aid rule that if an unauthorized payment is made from the payer's account will not allow the account holder to lose more than EUR 50.  It is equally essential that the costs of using payment instruments be proportionate and that the charges charged by the payment service provider to the buyer do not exceed the direct costs incurred for the use of the payment instrument.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a directive to update EU rules on payment services, which will cut the cost of paying bills by enabling new market players to use mobile and online tools to make payments on customers’ behalf.  The reason I supported the report is that it aims to achieve greater safety by laying down data protection and liability rules for all online payment service providers. It also makes for much greater convenience as, from now on, a payer using an online account will have the right to use payment software, devices and applications provided by an authorised third party and to have payments executed on his or her behalf by that provider.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The proposal lays down the basis for a harmonised legal framework for the creation of an internal market for payment services. This will help reduce costs, improve payment security and facilitate the emergence of new players and innovative new means of payment in the sector. That is why I believe it is necessary to vote in favour of reaching an agreement at first reading.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Directive, which updates the 2007 Payment Services Directive in order to take account of the emergence of new players on this market.  The text agreed with the Council increases consumer protection, thanks to the work of our group, in relation to the 2007 text and the Commission's initial proposal. In particular, an unconditional right to reimbursement of amounts not owed by the payment card holder is included. Surcharges for using cards whose fees are already limited by the recently approved Payment Card Commission Regulation are also prohibited.  It was also possible to include in the tripartite dialogue the express prohibition on the cancellation of the payment card service for transfer from the holder to another Member State, an example of bad banking practice to be eradicated and which cannot survive in the future single capital market.  In this regard, it is important to ensure that the important Capital Markets Union project does not set aside families and users of financial services, including cross-border ones, given the long list of barriers to the movement of capital.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the introduction of the Payment Services Directive (PSD) in 2002, the sector has seen rapid growth in the number of electronic transactions and the emergence of revolutionary mobile payment services, which have called into question the rules of this market. Therefore, the objective of the PSD II reform, voted on by the previous legislature in April 2014, was to increase competition and efficiency in the payment services sector, first and foremost by ensuring consumer protection. The negotiations undertaken by the present Parliament during the trialogues with the Council, however, have been far from satisfactory. Although controls on access to personal information have been strengthened while avoiding fraud and abuse, the new text includes some derogations and exemptions. Debit card payment services and, in part, the telecommunications sector remain outside the directive. In addition, important consumer guarantees already approved by Parliament are being removed, for example with regard to the right of withdrawal, and various derogations have been introduced for certain operators in order to escape the rules of the directive. The downward compromise reached during these negotiations once again highlights the subordination of the European Parliament to the particular interests of the Member States. For these reasons, I abstained from voting on this report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. According to studies, European citizens spent €45 billion on mobile devices in 2015. This represents about a 90% increase on the previous year. These figures indicate an ever increasing impact of online payments in our daily lives. It is estimated that trade through so-called smartphones increases by about 42% annually. I voted in favour of this report, of course, because it adapts European legislation to the ever-changing technological requirements. The European directive provides added value for European citizens who will benefit from simplified payment options at a lower cost.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We follow many of the concerns of economic operators, including the lack of transparency regarding the actual costs of payment cards, barriers to entry into the payment market and multilateral interchange fees. Data from the European Central Bank (ECB) show a huge disproportion between the costs of these operations and the amounts charged to beneficiaries and consumers. Further studies are needed on the actual costs of electronic payment methods and the lack of transparency in this area. Having said that, it would be desirable for this directive to give every citizen the right to open an account with minimum and free banking services, taking into account the advantages this brings to society at large. Instead, despite the effort of this legislative initiative, we have yet another legislative tangle, where we want to move in one direction, while creating conditions to circumvent the legislation. The non-application of any limit to the fees charged by banks to third parties and payment service providers is just one example.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report emphasises the extent to which the current e-payments framework is no longer adequately aligned with innovation. In some cases, regulations are withdrawn or individual national regulations are mutually opposed, and payment services cannot therefore operate across borders. The report aims to make payment services more efficient, to make customers more choice, to create more transparency in this field and to increase confidence in such services. In principle, these are not bad proposals, but they would still be expandable. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I do not agree with the revision of the Directive on payment services in the internal market. The aim is to strengthen the common European market. As a result, however, there will be a system of freedom-restricting monitoring of those involved in payment transactions. Furthermore, I do not consider regulation to be pro-competitive, but to prevent competition. Small Internet providers will have a harder time competing with the place deer. Finally, I think that the capping of credit card charges is wrong. Ultimately, the prohibition on charging means that the cost of paying credit cards is passed on to users of other payment methods through prices.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal which was unanimously adopted by the competent Commission. This text strengthens the legal status of the payment services concerned by setting a more harmonised framework for the benefit of creating a unified payment market and protecting consumers.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. The European payments market has proven to be very dynamic and has experienced a significant pace of innovation over the past few years. However, it remains a fractional market, the cost of which, according to studies by the European Commission, accounts for more than 1% of the European Union's GDP.  Payment systems are a source of continuous development, constituting a basic piece for the economic activity of any developed country.
