Thanks to the agreement we voted on and the agreement we already voted on in the Multilateral Interchange Fees Regulation in March of the same year, we are moving towards the development of a European payment market.  Thanks to a European payments market, consumers, retailers and other companies will be allowed to take full advantage of the benefits of the European Union's internal market in line with the Europe 2020 Strategy, which we design to support growth, job creation and productivity in Europe.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Payment Services Directive (PSD) of 2002 regulates payment services in the EU by establishing fees and obligations for both payment service providers and consumers. The purpose of its review (PSD II) is to increase competition and efficiency in the payments sector, ensuring fair conditions for consumer protection. During the negotiations with the Council, progress was made both through the inclusion of additional payment service providers in the directive and in the area of access to information, preventing fraud and abuse. On the other hand, however, the negotiating group had to accept a watered-down compromise on certain points such as an exemption for the telecommunications sector, the free right of withdrawal for the consumer guaranteed only after 6 months and finally an increase in the threshold from EUR 1 million to EUR 3 million of annual transactions as a necessary clause to derogate from the provisions of the directive. These derogations make the text much less acceptable than the first version voted on by the European Parliament, and I therefore do not fully support it.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on payment services in the internal market, as I believe it is necessary to adapt the legal framework to such rapidly changing and evolving areas as electronic payments undoubtedly are. And consumer protection, innovation, transparency and payment security are topics that are very important when making payments, such as via tablet or smartphone. On the other hand, however, I do not share the fact that the report does not deal at all with the possibility of adapting payment services to persons with visual impairments. In fact, despite all modern technologies, these persons cannot benefit from the benefits to which other consumers normally have access, as operators do not respond to their specific needs and, unfortunately, the European Union does not in its legislation.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Data from the European Central Bank (ECB) show a huge disproportion between the costs of these operations and the amounts charged to beneficiaries and consumers. Further studies are needed on the actual costs of electronic payment methods and the lack of transparency in this area. It would be important for every citizen to be given the right to open an account with minimum and free banking services, taking into account the advantages this brings to society at large. This legislative initiative does not provide for it, which is negative.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Of course, I voted in favour of the report on easing the situation for mortgage debtors. Let me quote one figure: every day in Spain, 95 families lose their living dwellings. The situation in Hungary is even more serious. As I said in my speech, enforcement proceedings are starting on foreign currency borrowers. The moratorium on evictions will be lifted, and families will lose their homes if this is not prevented.  To prevent this, I strongly recommend that professionals, legal colleagues or NGOs and advocacy organisations read this report, which I therefore publish on my website and Facebook page.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – One of the main reasons, as well as the consequences of the last ten years in cases of economic and financial crises in several countries, including my country, Latvia, was precisely the inability of citizens to repay the loans received by credit institutions for the purchase of houses, cars and other goods. While it is perfectly logical that, in the case of obtaining a loan, the borrower must repay both the loan and the interest associated with it after the agreed period, it is insane that such a large number of people have to separate from their homes or other properties, which are often used as pledges to obtain these loans. Colleagues, a person's right to a roof over the head is one of the most fundamental, so it is absolutely necessary to work out with the reform of a mortgage legislative system that allows people both to obtain credits and to pay them in full. I support it, I voted in favour.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I will admit that I did not support this report. The reason is quite prosaic. In my opinion, it always hurts if national problems, national political disputes are transmitted to the European level without the practical impact on the establishment of a common European position. I, of course, sympathise and express solidarity with the 600,000 people who have lost their homes in Spain as a result of the banks' progress and mortgage management. I see the contradictions that exist in the area of preferential shares, but I also see it as a positive government of the Spanish Prime Minister, who has sought to remedy these shortcomings that arose under the previous Socialist governments. Therefore, I could not support this proposal, which I think was non-consensual.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish mortgage legislation, as the CJEC has been collecting in different judgments, is not in accordance with European legislation (Directive 93/13/EEC) by allowing the inclusion of unfair terms in mortgage contracts. The legislative amendments made by the Government of Spain are insufficient and do not have the real will to solve the social drama of the evictions and family insolvencies that have come, as the data show (social rent: 0.4%; payment: 0.7%; moratoriums: 8%; 35 billion euros still in mortgage contracts with unfair terms) and the EU Advocate General in his May 2015 report. Banking abuses in Spain have not only affected mortgage contracts, but some 700,000 savers have seen their savings trapped, without being able to recover them, or subjected to removing up to 70% for poor application of the right to information by banks, contrary to consumer guarantees. With this resolution, the Spanish Socialists are promoting an analysis of Spanish legislation by the Commission so that the Commission can take appropriate measures where appropriate.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution as I consider it vital that the European Parliament positions and responds to the high number of requests recorded in recent years in which the infringements committed by the Spanish authorities are reported both in guaranteeing the right to housing and in protecting against bank abuses suffered by more than 700 000 people , scamming with the preferred ones.  The text adopted is a totally inadequate step because, by voting against all the amendments tabled and eliminating parts adopted by the Committee on Petitions, Social Democrats, Conservatives and Liberals have left a resolution completely decaffeinated, relegating the European Parliament to a secondary role by preventing the Resolution from including calls for the European Commission to initiate the process of adopting legislation aimed at promoting the introduction of the payment and effectively guaranteeing the right to housing across the EU.  However, the Resolution includes some notable parts such as the call for the Government to act to end the intolerable number of evictions that occur in the State or the need for the Commission to verify and investigate complaints received for preferred fraud.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which was concerned with the mass evictions currently taking place across Spain and the risky financial instruments which are one of the causes of these evictions. At present, 95 families lose their home every day. This is due to the economic, social and financial crisis. However a majority of the evictions are cause by a combination of abusive practices on the part of financial institutions, a lack of accurate essential information on financial instruments for consumers and insufficient legal protection of mortgage debtors. Regarding the abusive practices, 700 000 citizens are estimated to have been sold risky financial instruments by their Spanish banks in bad faith. In Ireland, where we are also currently experiencing an unprecedented homelessness crisis, we now have 130 000 families in need of housing, and many families forced into bankruptcy. In May of this year, my colleague Pearse Doherty brought legislation to the Dáil which would have allowed the regulator to set a cap on the rates being charged by banks but the Irish Government voted against it. This is a matter on which my party will continue to fight, both on the European front and at domestic level.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 With this report, which I supported, the Committee on Petitions of the European Parliament deals with the burning issue of the lack of protection of borrowers at risk of losing their homes in the wake of the epidemic of seizures and exiles in Spain.  Unfortunately, due to a conservative majority in plenary, some issues, which also concerned Greek borrowers, namely the rapid increase in "red" loans and loan contracts concluded in Swiss Francs involving more than 75,000 families, were removed from the final text of the resolution.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. When the economic crisis occurred in 2008, many Spanish individuals were unable to repay their loans. This resulted in the expulsion of many financially cornered borrowers. However, many rightly feel aggrieved (lack of information, non-verification of the creditworthiness of customers on the part of banks, abusive practices, etc.). 700,000 Spanish citizens denounced this fact. Together with my colleagues in the National Front, we are opposed to citizens being forced to pay for the mistakes of governments and banks. So I voted for this draft oral question.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against because this resolution calls upon the Commission to legislate on more than one matter – namely ‘family insolvency’ and harmonisation of mortgage contracts, as well as to determine which financial institutions should be blacklisted.   Nevertheless, I have sympathy with the situation in Spain. I merely believe that it is appropriate for this situation to be resolved through the Spanish government rather than legislating for all 28 countries in the European Union. It is a classic EU power-grab to suggest that a problem in one nation should require legislation in 28.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish mortgage legislation, as the CJEC has been collecting in different judgments, is not in accordance with European legislation (Directive 93/13/EEC) by allowing the inclusion of unfair terms in mortgage contracts. The legislative amendments made by the Government of Spain are insufficient and do not have the real will to solve the social drama of the evictions and family insolvencies that have come, as the data show (social rent: 0.4%; payment: 0.7%; moratoriums: 8%; 35 billion euros still in mortgage contracts with unfair terms) and the EU Advocate General in his May 2015 report. Banking abuses in Spain have not only affected mortgage contracts, but some 700,000 savers have seen their savings trapped, without being able to recover them, or subjected to removing up to 70% for poor application of the right to information by banks, contrary to consumer guarantees. With this resolution, the Spanish Socialists are promoting an analysis of Spanish legislation by the Commission so that the Commission can take appropriate measures where appropriate.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on mortgage legislation and risky financial instruments in the EU. Many petitions received inform about thousands of tragic personal cases where citizens lose some or all of their lifetime savings. In many cases, banks did not adequately inform consumers about the extent of the risks associated with the proposed investments. In addition, a significant number of affected citizens are elderly people who have used life savings for investments that were not said to be risky. I support calls on all EU financial institutions to stop abusing customers in the areas of mortgage loans, complex financial products and credit cards, including the application of excessive interest rates and arbitrary termination of the service. The Commission should draw up a comprehensive EU-wide blacklist that includes financial institutions that regularly engage in inappropriate banking practices. The Commission needs to harmonise the terms of mortgage agreements and debt repayment procedures in order to strengthen consumer protection across the EU.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution calls on the Commission to monitor the implementation in all Member States of Directive 93/13/EEC on the principles of fair retail lending of financial institutions in order to ensure their full compliance by national authorities. The precedent is that in Spain banks have deceived the population with Swiss franc loans and other financial instruments in the same way as in Hungary.  The motion for a resolution refers to Regulation (EEC) No 93/13 on fair banking and says that the Commission should monitor their implementation in certain Member States. I agree with the proposal, of course, especially given that Hungary has had to deal with this serious problem alone and to this day, without the assistance of the Commission, and even in the midst of attacks over its banking regulation.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. It is clear that Spanish banks have resorted to unfair practices towards their customers. With the economic crisis that hit Spain hard, borrowers were no longer able to repay their loans and were evicted from their homes... which guaranteed their loans, by mortgage. What is requested by this text is certainly akin to some interference by the Commission on a sovereign state. But the pressure on Spain remains limited, and this pressure should prove favourable to the interests of consumers while limiting the abuses of banks. That is why I supported this text.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Mortgage banking laws and practices vary from one European country to another. Different repayment terms exist, therefore, within the Union itself. This has led to a striking example of non-protection of consumers in Spain. Indeed, civil society has protested against the hundreds of thousands of evictions, the abusive clauses of mortgage contracts and the lack of protection of borrowers. The crisis has only worsened the situation of evicted families who continue to pay off their mortgage debt. In addition, 700,000 Spanish citizens believe they have been victims of financial scams as their savings banks have sold them speculative financial instruments. Consumers were not properly informed of the magnitude of the risks associated with the proposed investments and the banks did not verify that they had sufficient knowledge to understand what financial risks their choice involved. I therefore called with other colleagues for a revision of the guidelines on this issue.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because it is essential to ensure the correct transposition of several European consumer protection directives which, in the case of Spain, have been repeatedly infringed, as evidenced by a number of national and European judgments.  Since we cannot rely on the latest legislative reforms by the Government of Spain, as the Advocate General of the CJEO points out, Mr Szpunar, in his may report this year, we call on the European Commission to carry out the necessary investigations and not to allow fraud and negligence to happen again by the Spanish Government and the banks ever again. We therefore call for an end to abusive behaviour towards customers in the mortgage, sophisticated financial products and credit card sector, including the imposition of excessive interest and arbitrary cancellation of services, and urge the European Commission to follow 'carefully' the implementation of the new measures adopted by the Spanish Government in the banking sector to prevent abuses in banking.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. – I believe that the Spanish Government should introduce real 'datio in solutum' into mortgage law, which requires borrowers to be released from further servicing of debt in the event that the property is returned to the bank. However, I do not believe that the problem is of a cross-border nature. That is why I do not believe that there is a need for EU legislation. The responsibility lies solely with the Spanish Government. Therefore, I cannot support section 7 of the text.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution in line with my speech on this resolution last Monday. My vote has gone counterceding to that of my group in many of the amendments tabled by the GUE and Verts/ALE groups. Some of them convey the reality that many people are suffering in the Spanish state because of their mortgage contracts and, therefore, I voted for many of them and against the line of my group.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution entitled "Legislation on mortgages and financial instruments at risk in the European Union: the case of Spain" aims to ask for clarification on banking reforms carried out by the Spanish government.  Indeed, the economic crisis led to numerous foreclosures to borrowers who could no longer pay. Similarly, 700,000 Spanish citizens believe they have been victims of fraud by their banks and this shows that Spanish legislation does little to protect borrowers.  The text calls for clarification on the government's reforms, investigates whether European reforms of the legislation will be necessary and questions the Commission on how it intends to respond to the C-415/11 Aziz case relating to abusive clauses in consumer contracts. While this text may amount to a form of interference, it appears to be limited; furthermore, this text is favourable to the interests of consumers and would limit the abuses of banks. So I voted for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report analysing mortgage legislation and risky financial instruments in Spain took shape after countless petitions from Spanish citizens and families denouncing the situation in Spain, the text is balanced and i certainly support it, so I wanted to vote in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish mortgage legislation, as the CJEC has been collecting in different judgments, is not in accordance with European legislation (Directive 93/13/EEC) by allowing the inclusion of unfair terms in mortgage contracts. The legislative amendments made by the Government of Spain are insufficient and do not have the real will to solve the social drama of the evictions and family insolvencies that have come, as the data show (social rent: 0.4%; payment: 0.7%; moratoriums: 8%; 35 billion euros still in mortgage contracts with unfair terms) and the EU Advocate General in his May 2015 report. Banking abuses in Spain have not only affected mortgage contracts, but some 700,000 savers have seen their savings trapped, without being able to recover them, or subjected to removing up to 70% for poor application of the right to information by banks, contrary to consumer guarantees. With this resolution, the Spanish Socialists are promoting an analysis of Spanish legislation by the Commission so that the Commission can take appropriate measures where appropriate.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution, which deals with the situation of numerous petitions received about thousands of tragic personal cases where citizens lose some or all of their lifetime savings. In many such cases, banks did not adequately inform consumers of the extent of the risks associated with the proposed investments, and in such cases banks did not carry out fitness checks to determine whether customers had sufficient knowledge to understand the financial risks they bear. Many of the affected citizens are elderly people who have used their lifetime savings for investments that they were told were not risky. The European Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to initiate legislation harmonising the terms of mortgage contracts and debt repayment procedures in order to strengthen consumer protection throughout the European Union. In addition, the Commission should share best practices and assess the impact this has on consumers and businesses.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The resolution was not supported in accordance with the opinion of our rapporteur. It is inappropriate to adopt a resolution only in the case of one country, knowing that the problem of abuse in the area of risky financial instruments is much wider, and there has been no listening for further finishing. In Slovenia, too, people were misled when they bought subordinated bonds and lost their entire stake as part of the bank's bailout. It is not a problem in the financial instrument, but in the poor and lack of information of individuals. That is why we need a comprehensive solution in this area, not just country-by-country resolutions.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this issue on mortgage and risky financial instruments legislation in the EU based on the example of the Spain case. Then hundreds of thousands of people lost their homes due to unfair consumer credit and must never be allowed to do such a thing again. The implementation of the Mortgage Act should be monitored, given a second chance to individuals and blacklisted entities that regularly engage in poor banking practices.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It should not be the business of the EU to instruct Spain on how to treat its own people. This motion for a resolution calls for the Commission to do all manner of things, including harmonising mortgage terms across the EU, and seeks to grant the Commission the power to decide to blacklist financial institutions. For these reasons UKIP voted against it.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which was concerned with the mass evictions currently taking place across Spain and the risky financial instruments which are one of the causes of these evictions. At present, 95 families lose their home every day. This is due to the economic, social and financial crisis. However a majority of the evictions are cause by a combination of abusive practices on the part of financial institutions, a lack of accurate essential information on financial instruments for consumers and insufficient legal protection of mortgage debtors. Regarding the abusive practices, 700 000 citizens are estimated to have been sold risky financial instruments by their Spanish banks in bad faith. In Ireland, where we are also currently experiencing an unprecedented homelessness crisis, we now have 130 000 families in need of housing, and many families forced into bankruptcy. In May of this year, my colleague Pearse Doherty brought legislation to the Dáil which would have allowed the regulator to set a cap on the rates being charged by banks but the Irish Government voted against it. This is a matter on which my party will continue to fight, both on the European front and at domestic level.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is important for the Eu ropean Union to monitor and punish those banking institutions that follow unfair banking practices. The crisis we are currently experiencing has broken out as a result of practices of this kind, and it is essential that the institutions prevent and punish those actors who continue to follow them.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Before the financial crisis, many Spaniards took out variable-rate loans by mortgage their property. Faced with soaring interest rates during the financial crisis, some of them were unable to repay these loans and were evicted from their own homes. They are now complaining that they have not been sufficiently informed of the dangers posed by these financial products. The number of trials resulting in invalidating abusive clauses shows that Spanish legislation has failed on this issue. The purpose of the text is whether the Commission can combat abusive practices and the glaring lack of information in credit contracts against borrowers in Spain.  Even if we oppose any interference by the European Commission in the national affairs of the Member States, we consider that it is in the interest of millions of Europeans who are not sufficiently protected from the greed of financial institutions willing to do anything to increase the profitability of their business.  So I voted for this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote on this resolution is absolutely positive. Of course, the text is a harsh accusation against the Spanish Government and calls for European intervention on behalf of the many families affected by the absurd situation of losing their homes, but at the same time having to pay the mortgage. It seems, in fact, that the Committee on Petitions has received numerous requests from citizens who are experiencing dramatically the shortcomings of Spanish legislation on loans and financial instruments. Most petitions call for the introduction of 'datio in solutum' into Spanish legislation (return of the property to pay off the debt), and have brought to light thousands of tragic personal cases of citizens who have been evicted from home or lost part or all of their life savings, as well as their assets and even that of relatives. There are also many obstacles encountered by these citizens in trying to obtain precise and essential information on financial instruments.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish mortgage legislation, as the CJEC has been collecting in different judgments, is not in accordance with European legislation (Directive 93/13/EEC) by allowing the inclusion of unfair terms in mortgage contracts. The legislative amendments made by the Government of Spain are insufficient and do not have the real will to solve the social drama of the evictions and family insolvencies that have come, as the data show (social rent: 0.4%; payment: 0.7%; moratoriums: 8%; 35 billion euros still in mortgage contracts with unfair terms) and the EU Advocate General in his May 2015 report. Banking abuses in Spain have not only affected mortgage contracts, but some 700,000 savers have seen their savings trapped, without being able to recover them, or subjected to removing up to 70% for poor application of the right to information by banks, contrary to consumer guarantees. With this resolution, the Spanish Socialists are promoting an analysis of Spanish legislation by the Commission so that the Commission can take appropriate measures where appropriate.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on legislation on risky mortgages and financial instruments in the EU in order to protect citizens as much as possible against unfair terms and practices that have occurred in the Spanish mortgage credit sector. In recent years, there have been numerous victims of financial fraud, which several credit institutions have led to the purchase of risky financial instruments. The rules laid down in the Directive on the provision of investment services by companies and credit institutions must therefore be updated, as many consumers have had to overcome numerous obstacles before obtaining precise information on the financial instruments purchased.  Several civil court rulings found such practices abusive, and the Spanish Parliament also intervened to restructure mortgages on the main residence.  It is therefore necessary to harmonise the conditions of mortgage credit contracts and debt repayment procedures in order to increase consumer protection in the Union, so I voted in favour of the text.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which was concerned with the mass evictions currently taking place across Spain and the risky financial instruments which are one of the causes of these evictions. At present, 95 families lose their home every day. This is due to the economic, social and financial crisis. However a majority of the evictions are cause by a combination of abusive practices on the part of financial institutions, a lack of accurate essential information on financial instruments for consumers and insufficient legal protection of mortgage debtors. Regarding the abusive practices, 700 000 citizens are estimated to have been sold risky financial instruments by their Spanish banks in bad faith. In Ireland, where we are also currently experiencing an unprecedented homelessness crisis, we now have 130 000 families in need of housing, and many families forced into bankruptcy. In May of this year, my colleague Pearse Doherty brought legislation to the Dáil which would have allowed the regulator to set a cap on the rates being charged by banks but the Irish Government voted against it. This is a matter on which my party will continue to fight, both on the European front and at domestic level.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It should not be the business of the EU to instruct Spain on how to treat its own people. This motion for a resolution calls for the Commission to do all manner of things, including harmonising mortgage terms across the EU, and seeks to grant the Commission the power to decide to blacklist financial institutions. For these reasons UKIP voted against it.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because I do not believe that this legislation will decrease the numbers of evictions and resolve bad banking practices in Spain. The resolution refers to the numerous petitions received that have brought to light thousands of tragic personal cases in which citizens experienced the partial or entire loss of their life savings, and these petitions highlight the barriers that consumers face when seeking to obtain accurate and essential information on financial instruments. Inter alia, the resolution asks the Commission to put forward a legislative proposal on family insolvency and second chances for individuals and households, and calls on the Commission to reflect on a possible review of the scope of Directive 2014/17/EU, in line with the review clause set out in the directive itself, to ensure that debt-settlement procedures and the contractual consumer-lender relationship are included in all contract phases. It also calls on the Commission to draw up a comprehensive EU-wide blacklist of financial entities that regularly engage in bad banking practices.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In Spain, civil society organisations continue to protest against the hundreds of thousands of evictions, the presence of unfair terms in mortgage credit contracts and the lack of protection for borrowers. During the first quarter of this year alone, there were 19,261 evictions. Since 2008, more than 397,954 evictions have been in the country and more than 100,000 families have lost their homes. In the light of the above, I am proud to vote in favour of a text which aims to protect the social rights of Spaniards.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. Spanish civil society strongly opposes banking legislation, which does little to protect borrowers. The economic crisis led to numerous foreclosures of borrowers who were no longer able to pay, leading to an increasing number of petitions submitted to Parliament. This oral question asks for clarification on the reforms carried out by the Spanish Government as well as on the application of European jurisprudence and the planned reforms. So I voted for that question.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution calls on the Commission to monitor closely in all EU Member States the transposition of Directive 2014/17/EU on consumer credit agreements for residential immovable property (Mortgage Credit Directive). The Commission is also called upon to launch legislation harmonising mortgage terms and debt settlement procedures with a view to strengthening consumer protection across the EU, including the possibility of introducing transfer instead of payment in all EU Member States.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this proposal on legislation on risky mortgages and financial instruments in the EU as the text of the resolution departs from the principles of the Group of the European People's Party.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because the many petitions received have brought to light thousands of tragic personal cases of citizens who have lost some or all of their life savings. What's more, more than 100,000 families have lost their homes. In addition, the impact of the crisis has aggravated the situation for the families involved, who have to continue to repay their mortgage and the rising interest that comes with it, but in addition there are many cases where consumers have not been properly informed by the banks about the extent of the risks associated with the proposed investments and with which banks have not even carried out an eligibility test to determine whether customers have adequate knowledge to understand the financial risks to which they were exposed.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It should not be the business of the EU to instruct Spain on how to treat its own people. This motion for a resolution calls for the Commission to do all manner of things, including harmonising mortgage terms across the EU, and seeks to grant the Commission the power to decide to blacklist financial institutions. For these reasons UKIP voted against it.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In Europe, insufficient consumer protection in the delicate processes of subscribing to mortgages or other banking instruments is sadly evidenced by tragic personal cases of citizens losing their homes and life savings. In Spain, in particular, there are a large number of petitions denouncing violations of fundamental rights and infringements of European legislation, in terms of unfair terms and practices within mortgage or other banking contracts.  I therefore fully agree with this proposal, stressing the need to regulate at European level the regulations governing such negotiations. The regulation of these rules will promote fair and uniform protection for each country of the European Union and will be the starting point for a common fight against financial fraud. To ensure this, it will be necessary to ensure, through appropriate consumer protection regulations, that citizens themselves are properly informed about the true extent of the risks of the proposed investments and that banks carry out fitness tests to determine whether customers have adequate knowledge to understand the financial risks to which they are exposed.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution as I consider it vital that the European Parliament positions and responds to the high number of requests recorded in recent years in which the infringements committed by the Spanish authorities are reported both in guaranteeing the right to housing and in protecting against bank abuses suffered by more than 700 000 people , scamming with the preferred ones.  The text adopted is a totally inadequate step because, by voting against all the amendments tabled and eliminating parts adopted by the Committee on Petitions, Social Democrats, Conservatives and Liberals have left a resolution completely decaffeinated, relegating the European Parliament to a secondary role by preventing the Resolution from including calls for the European Commission to initiate the process of adopting legislation aimed at promoting the introduction of the payment and effectively guaranteeing the right to housing across the EU.  However, the Resolution includes some notable parts such as the call for the Government to act to end the intolerable number of evictions that occur in the State or the need for the Commission to verify and investigate complaints received for preferred fraud.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is the result of numerous petitions that have brought to light thousands of personal cases of citizens who have lost their life savings by investing in high-risk financial instruments. According to recent estimates, 95 families in Spain lose their homes every day and in Greece the total value of unpaid mortgages has exceeded EUR 21 billion, and 75 000 Greek citizens are at risk of losing their homes. In spite of these premises, it has been extremely complicated to adopt the report. It is not intended to be and is not an indictment of governments – particularly the Spanish government – but the sensitive response of institutions responsible for the well-being and protection of their citizens. This is the ultimate aim of the initiative and, frankly, regrets the PPE's vote against. Petitions are probably the most democratic and open instrument available to European citizens. They meet the needs and needs of citizens, especially the most harassed. To deny them answers - for calculations or political defences of their own motion - is tantamount to denying them a right. We are Parliament, we must always be the voice of the European citizens.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the text of the motion for a resolution on spanish mortgage legislation and risky Spanish financial instruments, in line with the People's Party position. The draft motion for a resolution was drafted in the Committee on Petitions and, in its drafting, it included amendments that were out of touch with reality and not based on petitions received on the subject. The timing of the adoption of the motion during the election period in Spain shows that its initiators are trying to use the document as part of the election campaign to try to use the mortgage issues of citizens and consumers in Spain as part of the election campaign, overshadowing the interests of citizens. As Vice-President of the Committee on Petitions, I also see that the issues highlighted by petitions, which draw attention to the inadequate transposition or implementation of EU law within the Member States, need to be examined professionally, bearing in mind the opinion of the European Commission and the practice of the Court of Justice of the European Union.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which was put forward by the petitions committee and calls on the Commission and the European Central Bank to evaluate the Spanish arbitration mechanism which hears cases of citizens who are victims of financial fraud. This resolution is based on a large number of petitions to the European Parliament denouncing abusive terms in mortgage contracts and risky financial instruments in Spain. The petitions brought numerous tragic personal cases where citizens have lost their homes and where a number of people, mainly elderly people lost all or part of their life-savings. I agree with the request to the Commission to put forward a legislative proposal on family insolvency and second chances for individuals and households and to elaborate a comprehensive EU-wide blacklist of financial entities that regularly engage in bad bank practices.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution denounces the abusive clauses in mortgage loan contracts that have led to hundreds of thousands of evictions in Spain. Mortgage banking laws and practices vary from country to country in the EU, resulting in a different degree of consumer protection and different repayment terms from one Member State to another. Through this resolution, we call on the European Commission to better monitor the implementation of Directive 93/13/EEC by Member States, aimed at protecting citizens from this type of clause. We also call on the Member States and the European Commission to undertake a number of reforms to prevent this problem from happening again. Considering that this resolution is aimed at combating fraudulent practices, I voted in favour.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. – Following the banking crisis, it is important to better protect consumers and introduce stricter rules, to restore confidence and increase investment in the financial sector. This will lead to further growth in the financial markets and of the economy. We have created new European legislation with the European Parliament to better inform and protect consumers when taking out a home loan. But the specific Spanish situation is the result of Spanish national legislation, something which needs to be addressed in the country concerned and not at European level.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 What happened in Spain, and the thousands of tragic cases of citizens with partial losses of their savings and the vast majority who lost everything, could have been prevented. This resolution calls for a legislative initiative on the harmonisation of mortgage contractual terms and debt settlement procedures with a view to strengthening consumer protection across the EU. I agree in part because such legislation is necessary, but I believe that it should be at national level and not at European Union level, and that is why I abstained. Yet abuse of banking practices must be prevented!

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We vote against because we are opposed to the practice of "Transfer instead of payment", because this has also been implemented and applied in Greece with disastrous consequences for the poor people.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – It should not be the business of the EU to instruct Spain on how to treat its own people. This motion for a resolution calls for the Commission to do all manner of things, including harmonising mortgage terms across the EU, and seeks to grant the Commission the power to decide to blacklist financial institutions. For these reasons UKIP voted against it.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In Spain, civil society organisations continue to protest against the hundreds of thousands of evictions, unfair terms in mortgage contracts and the lack of protection of borrowers. According to the latest figures, there were 19,261 evictions in Spain during the first quarter of 2015 (an increase of 6% compared to the first quarter of 2014), with more than 100,000 households losing their homes. Financial entities should cease abusive behaviour with customers in the field of mortgages, sophisticated financial products and credit cards, including excessive interest rates and arbitrary cancellation of services, and avoid the use of eviction of families living in their single dwelling, but rather promoting debt restructuring and social leasing.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation because it is in the direction of better control of the activity of the banks.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Since the end of the most acute phase of the capitalist crisis in which Europe and the world plunged (2007-2008), millions of citizens have lost their life savings, lost their jobs, lost their homes. In Spain, the problem of evictions has been felt and felt with particular acuity. Several social organizations continue to protest against the hundreds of thousands of evictions allowed by unfair terms in mortgage contracts and the lack of protection of borrowers. According to the Mortgage Victims Platform (PAH), there were 19,261 evictions in Spain during the first quarter of 2015 (an increase of 6% compared to the first quarter of 2014) and it is estimated that there have been more than 397,954 evictions in Spain since 2008. The Mortgage Credit Directive has not substantially altered the table in attendance. As so often happens, myrific "regulatory measures", supposedly designed to curb the abuses of the financial system by those who do not want to tackle the problem in the background, have revealed their ineffectiveness. The result: thousands of families continue to live this drama of evictions. Everything remains the same as far as barriers to access to housing, particularly for millions of young people who are out of work and will continue to be so, despite the millions of empty fires.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as sign of solidarity to Podemos.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Austerity policies have led millions of European Union citizens to poverty. In Spain, 95 families lose their roofs every day. In many cases, however, banks have failed to inform consumers, failed fitness tests, and often it is the elderly who have been affected by poor investment in their lifetime savings. In recent years, more than 700 000 Spaniards have fallen victim to financial fraud due to banks buying risky financial instruments. I support the call throughout the European Union for financial actors not to resort to inadequate methods, such as the eviction of a family from their single dwelling, and instead to deal with the effective debt restructuring that they have made a significant contribution to their policy.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully support this resolution. The text is in favour of the many Spanish families affected by the absurd situation of losing their homes, but at the same time having to honour their mortgage.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against EU legislation on high-risk mortgages and financial products: the case of Spain, because I am opposed to the practice of 'Transfer instead of payment', because this has also been implemented and applied in Greece with disastrous consequences for the poor people.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe, considering the large number of petitions received by the EP denouncing abusive terms in mortgage contracts and risky financial instruments in Spain, that it is very appropriate to request the Commission to make effective enquiries as to whether there have been violations of fundamental rights and infringements of European legislation. We must be straightforward and take the lead in order to put an end to bank-related infringements of EU consumer-rights law in Spain. The situation there is critical: since 2008, more than 700 000 people have completely or partially lost their savings and nearly 400 000 have been evicted from their homes. The Spanish Government should act as soon as possible to put an end to this situation, and should put forward initiatives to stop it happening in the future.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish mortgage legislation, as the CJEC has been collecting in different judgments, is not in accordance with European legislation (Directive 93/13/EEC) by allowing the inclusion of unfair terms in mortgage contracts. The legislative amendments made by the Government of Spain are insufficient and do not have the real will to solve the social drama of the evictions and family insolvencies that have come, as the data show (social rent: 0.4%; payment: 0.7%; moratoriums: 8%; 35 billion euros still in mortgage contracts with unfair terms) and the EU Advocate General in his May 2015 report. Banking abuses in Spain have not only affected mortgage contracts, but also some 700,000 savers have seen their savings trapped, without being able to recover them, or subjected to removing up to 70% by a poor application of the right to information by banks, which goes against consumer guarantees. With this resolution, the Spanish Socialists are promoting an analysis of Spanish legislation by the Commission so that the Commission can take appropriate measures where appropriate.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. With this resolution, the Spanish Socialists are promoting an analysis of Spanish legislation by the Commission so that the Commission can issue appropriate measures where appropriate. Spanish mortgage legislation, as the CJEC has been collecting in different judgments, is not in accordance with European legislation (Directive 93/13/EEC) by allowing the inclusion of unfair terms in mortgage contracts. The legislative amendments made by the Government of Spain are insufficient and do not have the real will to solve the social drama of the evictions and family insolvencies that have come, as the data show (social rent: 0.4%; payment: 0.7%; moratoriums: 8%; 35 billion euros still in mortgage contracts with unfair terms) and the EU Advocate General in his May 2015 report. Banking abuses in Spain have not only affected mortgage contracts, but some 700,000 savers have seen their savings trapped, without being able to recover them, or subjected to removing up to 70% for poor application of the right to information by banks, contrary to consumer guarantees.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on mortgage law and risky financial instruments in Spain, because I believe that this issue does not only concern Spain, even though Spanish citizens were the most affected by the crisis, first financial, which has affected the EU since 2008, and in particular by the housing bubble that has further aggravated the conditions of thousands of families in Spain, because they are unable to pay their mortgage. As well as national legislation, mortgage lending is based on important directives of which the EP has been co-legislator with the Council, I am referring to Directive 2014/17/EU on mortgage credit, which is being implemented in the Member States, and to the MiFID2 Directive on the markets for financial instruments, which has also been amended and is being transposed in the Member States. This piece of legislation, however copious, has not prevented thousands of people from being expelled from their homes in the meantime, because they were morose. I therefore fully support the call for the EC to promote a wide-ranging information campaign on financial products and to promote financial education, and I hope that the structural reform of the European banking sector will be completed quickly in order to stabilise the financial system.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today against the report on mortgage legislation and risky financial instruments in the EU: the case of Spain, because I believe that the proposals and approaches it contains are the wrong way to go.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I did not support the report on mortgage legislation and risky financial instruments in Spain. I consider it problematic for national issues and conflicts to be transferred to the European level, but do not have any practical impact on the search for a common European position. This is the responsibility of the Member States.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It should not be the business of the EU to instruct Spain on how to treat its own people. This motion for a resolution calls for the Commission to do all manner of things, including harmonising mortgage terms across the EU, and seeks to grant the Commission the power to decide to blacklist financial institutions. For these reasons UKIP voted against it.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report given we need to put an end to infringements of EU consumer rights laws in Spain relating to banks. The situation in Spain has been shown to be critical, where since 2008, more than 700 000 people have lost completely or partially their savings and nearly 400 000 have been evicted from their homes. We call on the Spanish government to act to put an end to this situation and we put forward initiatives to avoid this happening in the future.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The financial crisis and the explosion of the housing bubble left hundreds of thousands of Spanish citizens on the street. This housing crisis was further exacerbated by the sale of abusive products by some banks. A total of 16 complaints against the abuses of mortgage clauses in Spain and 22 against the mass sale of financial products reached the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions, which decided to submit a resolution to the plenary. It reports abuses and fraudulent practices of banks in relation to the sale of toxic financial products, so-called preferred holdings.  Preferred stocks are high-risk and very complex financial instruments that should never have been sold to most clients, usually people without financial knowledge and with a lot of risk aversion. It is essential to report that banks not only failed to adequately inform customers, but in some cases misen informed them: they were given the impression that the instruments were basically fixed-term deposits with total liquidity. For these reasons, I supported this Resolution, including the concept of payment, and almost all of its amendments.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution. Our amendments have been rejected by the joint vote of the people and European Socialists. The weight of the European Socialist Group has been decisive in backing down amendments which sought to tighten the content and tone of the Resolution, as well as to make it more executive and to introduce the specific issue of payment or that of associations of preferrs and affected by financial scams being taken into account.  The resolution, which, despite not incorporating our amendments, was overall positive and was a touch of attention from the European Parliament to Rajoy because of its non-compliance with housing and consumer rights, has finally been adopted. We hope that it will serve as an opening of an in-depth debate on the risk instruments that banks use without regard to previous assessments.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the European Parliamentary Labour Party, I voted in favour of this resolution, which builds on 15 petitions regarding mortgage legislation in Spain and 21 petitions on risky financial instruments in Spain received by Parliament’s Petitions Committee between 2011 and 2013. The petitions concerned poor consumer protection for mortgage borrowers and home owners in Spain, and this report demands that the EU Directive on Unfair Terms in Consumer Contracts be respected there.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish mortgage legislation, as the CJEC has been collecting in different judgments, is not in accordance with European legislation (Directive 93/13/EEC) by allowing the inclusion of unfair terms in mortgage contracts. The legislative amendments made by the Government of Spain are insufficient and do not have the real will to solve the social drama of the evictions and family insolvencies that have come, as the data show (social rent: 0.4%; payment: 0.7%; moratoriums: 8%; 35 billion euros still in mortgage contracts with unfair terms) and the EU Advocate General in his May 2015 report. Banking abuses in Spain have not only affected mortgage contracts, but some 700,000 savers have seen their savings trapped, without being able to recover them, or subjected to removing up to 70% for poor application of the right to information by banks, contrary to consumer guarantees. With this resolution, the Spanish Socialists are promoting an analysis of Spanish legislation by the Commission so that the Commission can take appropriate measures where appropriate.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: Written. We Swedish Social Democrats chose to abstain in the vote on the resolution as a whole. We also chose to abstain on wordings advocating EU legislative proposals on family insolvency and on the harmonisation of the terms of mortgage agreements and debt restructuring procedures. On the one hand, it is important that the consumer is given solid protection in the mortgage market. The fact that the situation has developed as it has done in Spain – where many people have had to leave their homes in recent years – is very unfortunate. Everyone must be given reasonable opportunities to deal with payment difficulties and debts. On the other hand, we are not convinced that European legislation is the right way to go in these cases. On the contrary, we see problems. Using the family as a legal entity can in many respects be wrong – not least in terms of individual rights and gender equality. Nor is it clear that EU rules on insolvency would be in line with the principle of subsidiarity. In general, extended harmonisation in this area could lead to some EU countries being forced to reduce consumer protection. That would not be acceptable.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish mortgage legislation, as the CJEC has been collecting in different judgments, is not in accordance with European legislation (Directive 93/13/EEC) by allowing the inclusion of unfair terms in mortgage contracts. The legislative amendments made by the Government of Spain are insufficient and do not have the real will to solve the social drama of the evictions and family insolvencies that have come, as the data show (social rent: 0.4%; payment: 0.7%; moratoriums: 8%; 35 billion euros still in mortgage contracts with unfair terms) and the EU Advocate General in his May 2015 report. Banking abuses in Spain have not only affected mortgage contracts, but some 700,000 savers have seen their savings trapped, without being able to recover them, or subjected to removing up to 70% for poor application of the right to information by banks, contrary to consumer guarantees. With this resolution, the Spanish Socialists are promoting an analysis of Spanish legislation by the Commission so that the Commission can take appropriate measures where appropriate.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. The resolution on the legislation on mortgages and financial instruments at risk in the Eu has been called for by far-left groups and for good reason, its aim is to denounce Spanish mortgage legislation, promoting the right to pay a debt or a tax obligation by the transfer of property. A few months before the Spanish general elections, which will take place in December 2015, this is clearly a form of instrumentalisation of the European Parliament for electoral purposes. The European Parliament is not the place of the rules of account but an assembly which strives to improve the living conditions of European citizens and the situation of the Member States in strict respect for their sovereignty. This resolution violates this principle by giving a parliamentary committee, in this case the Committee on Petitions, the power to assess the compliance of national legal provisions with European law. There is no provision in the treaties or the Internal Regulation of the European Parliament that provides for such jurisdiction. On form as well as on substance, this resolution is unacceptable and that is why I opposed it.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution. Our amendments have been rejected by the joint vote of the people and European Socialists. The weight of the European Socialist Group has been decisive in backing down amendments which sought to tighten the content and tone of the Resolution, as well as to make it more executive and to introduce the specific issue of payment or that of associations of preferrs and affected by financial scams being taken into account.  The resolution, which, despite not incorporating our amendments, was overall positive and was a touch of attention from the European Parliament to Rajoy because of its non-compliance with housing and consumer rights, has finally been adopted. We hope that it will serve as an opening of an in-depth debate on the risk instruments that banks use without regard to previous assessments.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the proposal for a Resolution on Mortgage and Risky Financial Instruments Legislation in the EU: the case of Spain, as I believe the EU has a major problem with "toxic" financial products affecting citizens. EU legislation should adequately regulate practices when selling financial products and services as well as any other type of products on the European market in such a way as to protect consumers. The process of selling such instruments should offer maximum protection for clients in the form of all necessary information in particular on possible risks and should be maximally transparent. EU legislation should offer solutions for citizens who have been put in a difficult material situation due to harmful financial instruments. In addition, EU legislation must equally regulate the types and characteristics of financial products in all Member States in order to avoid risks to consumers. An example of negative practice affecting citizens is also an example of swiss franc loans in Croatia and some other Member States.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. In 2008, with the economic crisis, many Spanish citizens were unable to repay their loans. This has resulted in the expulsion of many borrowers driven by their maturities. However, many rightly feel aggrieved (lack of information, non-verification of the creditworthiness of customers on the part of banks, abusive practices, etc.). 700,000 Spanish citizens denounced this unacceptable state of events. We believe that citizens do not have to accept the amateurism of governments and the mistakes of banks.  I voted for this draft oral question.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on legislation on mortgages and financial instruments at risk in Spain, because the compliance of Member States with EU law is not within the powers of Parliament, which therefore poses a problem of separation of powers. Moreover, this report has been largely influenced by the Spanish far-left, which seeks to exploit the European Parliament in the run-up to the December general elections in Spain. The resolution was adopted, which I regret.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted against this text on mortgages in Spain on a question of competence. Indeed, it is up to the European Commission to assess the compliance of a national text with European Union law or, ultimately, at the European Court of Justice.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision, not only because I agree with the spirit in which it moves but also because the text includes two paragraphs (M and N) that directly concern my country. The positive vote in paragraphs M and N welcomes the underlining of a problem that is not only economic but also social.  The economic justification for voting in favour of the two paragraphs is based firstly on the qualification of the consumer interest in financial products and secondly on the emphasis on the need to correct problems leading to market failures as a result of asymmetric information.  Asymmetric information can lead to a bad financial contract (in our case a home loan) that is borne by one of the parties. It has long been the intention of the EU institutions to change both MiFiD (Directive on Markets in financial Instruments, to which reference is made) and Prospectus Directive, so that the consumer and the small investor have better quality information than is currently provided. This proposal for a decision, in any case highlights this problem in the case of Spain, while the references to Greece existed to underline that such phenomena are not only found in Spain.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting against this motion for a resolution. While it is true that many people have lost their homes or livelihoods in Spain due to the credit crisis and mis-speculation with risky financial instruments, the proposals made go so far that they have nothing in common with the realities of the market economy.

name: Rina Ronja Kari (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I believe that the Spanish government should introduce real 'datio in solutum' into the mortgage legislation, which requires borrowers to be released for further servicing of debt in the event that the property is returned to the bank. However, I do not believe that the problem is of a cross-border nature, which is why I do not believe that THERE is a need for EU legislation. The responsibility lies with the Spanish Government. Therefore, I cannot support section 7 of the text.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it seeks to establish better Europe-wide best practices of mortgage lending and information provided to consumers by preventing banks from misleading consumers about the products they buy.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – An excellent example of the regulatory shortcomings of the banking system is the fact that in Spain, as in other peripheral and newly acceded countries, the population could be deceived with loans and other financial products that were said to be based on Swiss francs. I absolutely supported this motion for a resolution calling on the Commission to monitor changes in Spanish mortgage legislation and the implementation in all Member States of Directive 93/13/EEC on the principles of fair retail lending by financial institutions in order to ensure their full compliance with national authorities. In Hungary, banks have committed much more serious abuses, yet when our government has at least made some effort to improve the situation, it has been under harsh attack from the EU.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am aware of the situation in Spain with regard to the state of difficulty of some families, who have lost their case, not least as a result of the numerous petitions received. The economic crisis has affected the financial system of the various Member States and, consequently, the population of the Community as a whole. For these reasons, we have decided to relaunch European action in favour of growth and employment, primarily through the Juncker Plan. Of course, the Spanish mortgage situation must be tackled decisively, but I am opposed to the demagogic use of citizens' problems, especially if they are carried out for electoral purposes only.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish mortgage legislation, as the CJEC has been collecting in different judgments, is not in accordance with European legislation (Directive 93/13/EEC) by allowing the inclusion of unfair terms in mortgage contracts. The legislative amendments made by the Government of Spain are insufficient and do not have the real will to solve the social drama of the evictions and family insolvencies that have come, as the data show (social rent: 0.4%; payment: 0.7%; moratoriums: 8%; 35 billion euros still in mortgage contracts with unfair terms) and the EU Advocate General in his May 2015 report. Banking abuses in Spain have not only affected mortgage contracts, but some 700,000 savers have seen their savings trapped, without being able to recover them, or subjected to removing up to 70% for poor application of the right to information by banks, contrary to consumer guarantees. With this resolution, the Spanish Socialists are promoting an analysis of Spanish legislation by the Commission so that the Commission can take appropriate measures where appropriate.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution calls on the Commission to decide which financial houses to blacklist, to harmonise mortgage contracts, to issue propaganda on financial products and to propose legislation on 'family insolvency'. I had to vote no.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – The disproportionate behaviour of banking institutions in the form of bad banking practices, unfair practices and inadequate interest rates on mortgages and the lack of state control over the banking and financial markets, together with the effects of the global economic and financial crisis, have left many families at the poverty line and in financial distress. This situation applies not only to families in the countries of southern Europe, but also to many families throughout the former Eastern Europe. That is why the Commission, together with the Member States, must carefully check compliance with mortgage standards, revise them and propose measures to reverse this situation. It is essential to do everything possible to increase prevention in this area, including by increasing the financial literacy of the population.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on Spanish legislation on high-risk mortgages and financial products, on the basis of the petitions received, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 5/10/2015 and because in Greece, red home loans reached EUR 21 billion. There, the banks began selling the red loans to the well-known crows of the world market to aggressive hedge funds that are preparing to hammer, instead of lentil plates, the homes of the Greek people. In fact, with The 3rd, express procedures are also in place for auctions. More than 500,000 Greek borrowers are now at risk of losing their homes. Also, 70,000 Greeks who have taken out mortgages in Swiss francs are also at risk of losing their own homes. That is why, as a member of the Committee on Petitions, I call on the European Commission, in cooperation with the Central Bank, to take measures to protect the first residence and I call for an end to the auctions of houses in Greece and Spain.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted for this proposal. Spain is marked by numerous real estate foreclosures from borrowers who can no longer repay, and this situation is favoured by its banking legislation clearly unfair to customers. The proposal suggests seeking clarification on the reforms carried out by the Spanish government as well as on the application of European jurisprudence. This harmonisation, although Europeanist, is favourable to the interests of consumers and would help to limit the abuses of banks.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because of the risky consequences of such a measure.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. On the basis of the very large number of petitions received by the European Parliament on this subject, our Assembly has spoken out on the issue of risky financial instruments in Spain, which have led to massive property evictions. In the first quarter of 2015, nearly 20,000 Spanish tenants were evicted, for a total of 400,000 evictions since 2008. In many cases, the banks involved did not properly inform consumers of the extent of the financial risks to which they were exposed. An estimated 700,000 Spanish citizens have been victims of financial fraud linked to the sale of risky instruments. In view of this situation, and in view of the petitions brought to our attention, Parliament has finally agreed on a number of recommendations which I consider appropriate. In particular, it calls on financial institutions to put an end to abusive practices in the field of mortgage lending and to prioritise debt restructurings over real estate evictions. It also calls on the European Banking Authority and the ECB to take additional measures to force banks to separate their stock market activities from their deposit-taking activities. I'm obviously voting for.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Although the report provides for an improvement in the protection of mortgage debtors, it involves a populist recourse to the human right to housing. The EU wants to interfere with Member States' housing laws, thereby exceeding its powers. I cannot therefore support this report.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report. Numerous petitions received by Parliament’s Committee on Petitions have brought to light thousands of tragic personal cases in which citizens experienced the partial or entire loss of their life savings, and these petitions highlight the barriers that consumers face when seeking to obtain accurate and essential information on financial instruments.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. More than 700,000 Spanish citizens believe they have been victims of the financial fraud of "preferentes" (fraudulent sale of risky financial instruments by Spanish banks). Since 2012, 21 petitions alleging abuses in the sale of financial instruments to customers of savings banks in Spain have been registered in the European Parliament as admissible. They call on the European Union to urge the Spanish authorities to investigate the issue and grant compensation to affected customers. The resolution calls on the Commission to follow up on complaints received and to carry out the necessary investigations. It also calls on the Commission to present a legislative proposal on household insolvency and the granting of a second chance to individuals and households. And finally, it urges the Spanish government to develop a solution to "significantly reduce the intolerable number of evictions". I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. When the economic crisis occurred in 2008, many Spanish individuals were unable to repay their loans. This resulted in the expulsion of many cornered borrowers. However, many rightly feel aggrieved (lack of information, non-verification of the creditworthiness of customers on the part of banks, abusive practices, etc.). 700,000 Spanish citizens denounced this fact. At the National Front, we believe that citizens do not have to pay for the mistakes of governments and banks.  So I voted "for."

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution, for not accompanying the express position.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I could not support this resolution as I believe that it features a number of inaccurate claims regarding financial firms in Spain and the efficacy of the Spanish Government’s policies in combating some of the problems resulting from the 2008 financial crisis.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The economic crisis stems mainly from the irresponsible behaviour of a part of the financial world. This petition, signed by many European citizens, only underlines this further. It is important that we draw all the lessons today in order to better protect European citizens. The banking union is a significant step in this direction. But other additional measures must accompany it. The resolution voted in plenary formulates a series of proposals that deserve to be debated. In particular, it is high time that the Commission proposes legislation to harmonize the clauses of mortgage contracts. This is an important step in strengthening consumer protection in Europe. Payment for services

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution on mortgage legislation and risky financial instruments in the EU, with particular reference to the case of Spain. The situation in Spain has been shown to be critical: since 2008, more than 700 000 people have completely or partially lost their savings and nearly 400 000 have been evicted from their homes. That is why it is important to put an end to infringements of EU consumer rights laws in Spain relating to banks. The resolution calls on the Spanish Government to act to put an end to this situation, and that is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Petitions has tabled a motion for the adoption of a resolution on mortgage legislation in Spain and on risky Spanish financial instruments, on the basis of petitions received. In Spain, the number of evictions is largely tolerable due to the abusive behaviour of financial institutions towards customers. The draft calls on financial institutions in the European Union to stop such behaviour and to avoid eviction of single-resident families, to the Spanish authorities to reduce the number of evictions by the means at their disposal and to the Commission to initiate legislation to address the problem. I voted in favour of the motion.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. 'u2012 Banking legislation and practices on mortgages and other risky financial instruments in the European Union deserve increased attention. In addition to the cases cited in Spain, others are multiplying throughout the European Union. And in the face of this situation, we must consider whether it is time to try to standardise consumer rights and their levels of protection. With Member States going through financially difficult times and unemployment levels in the European Union, I argue that we should try to find mechanisms to end unfair practices and clauses in the banking and mortgage sector, to end the lack of protection of borrowers and to prevent financial fraud. The economy of the European Union also depends on the credibility of its agents and the sense of security that citizens have in their banking system. For the above reasons, I am in favour of approving this document.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this motion for a resolution is to seek clarification on the banking reforms carried out by the Spanish government. Indeed, Spanish legislation does little to protect borrowers, as demonstrated by the numerous property foreclosures that occurred after the crisis, as well as the large number of Spaniards who feel they are victims of fraud by their banks.  If this text may amount to a form of interference, it appears to be limited, since it is only a matter of seeking clarification on the situation of banks in Spain and of putting an end to unfair practices against consumers. So I decided to vote for this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which builds on 15 petitions regarding mortgage legislation in Spain and 21 petitions on risky financial instruments in Spain received by the Petitions Committee between 2011 and 2013. The resolution seeks to highlight poor consumer protection for mortgage borrowers and home owners in Spain.
