The report demands that Council Directive 93/13/EEC (the Unfair Terms in Consumer Contracts Directive) be respected in Spain, following on from the European Court of Justice judgment in case C-415. It also seeks to establish better Europe-wide best practices in relation to mortgage lending and information provided to consumers, with a view to preventing banks from misleading consumers about the products they buy.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution, which will initiate new legislation to harmonise mortgage contract terms and debt settlement procedures with a view to reinforcing consumer protection across the EU.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which was concerned with the mass evictions currently taking place across Spain and the risky financial instruments which are one of the causes of these evictions. At present, 95 families lose their home every day. This is due to the economic, social and financial crisis. However a majority of the evictions are cause by a combination of abusive practices on the part of financial institutions, a lack of accurate essential information on financial instruments for consumers and insufficient legal protection of mortgage debtors. Regarding the abusive practices, 700 000 citizens are estimated to have been sold risky financial instruments by their Spanish banks in bad faith. In Ireland, where we are also currently experiencing an unprecedented homelessness crisis, we now have 130 000 families in need of housing, and many families forced into bankruptcy. In May of this year, my colleague Pearse Doherty brought legislation to the Dáil which would have allowed the regulator to set a cap on the rates being charged by banks but the Irish Government voted against it. This is a matter on which my party will continue to fight, both on the European front and at domestic level.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this resolution by vote because I consider it inadmissible for financial institutions to deceive or not to inform customers about all aspects of the loans, deposits or financial investments they encourage them to make. Many people in Spain, but also in Romania and other EU Member States have ended up in desperate situations, losing their homes and their life savings. Unfortunately, very often it has come to this because people have not been presented with all the aspects or, in the case of investments, they have not been explained the real risk to which they are subject.  Of course, EU law provides for a number of measures and regulations which, if applied correctly and fully, would diminish drastically or did not exist. However, the reality is that these people have been deceived and the authorities in the Member States, together with all EU institutions, must improve the legislation, fully enforce it and ensure that such abusive practices and conditions and that false or incomplete promotion will not be repeated in the future.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution because I believe that the government must work with the associations to find a solution to over-indebtedness. It would be more important to find a more comprehensive approach than just talking about associations.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. I consider it important that financial sector operators behave in good faith and do not mislead or abuse the trust of customers who may not have the best knowledge of mortgages, investment and credit cards and related obligations. Consumers must make their decisions consciously and in terms of all risks.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution.  In particular, action is needed to stop all financial institutions in the Union from being abused.  Forced eviction of families from their sole residence must be prevented. First of all, we need to restructure the debt and participate in social renting activities. The fundamental right to housing and the protection of citizens in financial difficulties must be strengthened and guaranteed throughout the EU. In addition, harmonised terms and debt repayment procedures should apply. The Commission should, as soon as possible, draw up a comprehensive EU blacklist that includes financial institutions that regularly engage in inappropriate banking practices.  In view of the current situation, the Commission should present a legislative proposal on the insolvency of families and the granting of a second option to individuals and households.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – While the resolution undeniably shows the acuteness of the problems and the inability of popular families in Spain to repay loans or pay rents leading to foreclosures, house auctions and exiles, there is no explicit reference to the full protection of people households affected by the crisis and unpopular measures. On the contrary, proposals are invoked which actually safeguard the interests of the banks, burdening working-class households in other ways and leaving the way open to auctions of popular housing, maintaining the dead ends and distress of those who, because of poverty and unemployment, cannot repay the loans. The JRC has repeatedly taken up the issue with specific positions on the protection and relief of popular families, calling, inter alia, for the abolition of auctions of first and second popular housing, the write-off of interest debts and the drastic reduction of loans that the people have had to take in previous years for their needs.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I cannot help but express solidarity and concern for all those Spanish citizens who have found themselves losing their life savings due to risky financial instruments and mortgage legislation. While I recognise our duty to protect European citizens so that no other such cases occur, I did not consider the motion for a resolution to be dealt with exhaustively, so I would vote against it.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ It is necessary to find a solution to the problem that arose in Spain where many citizens lost their property due to the impossibility of paying a loan that has grown greatly in the short term. Better instruments need to be put in place to better protect citizens, with banks easuing citizens more effectively. While the proposed Resolution calls for improved situation, the steps to the end of the objective are not well enough designed and for this reason I voted against this Resolution. At such a difficult time, it is not only effective to call for something to be done and it is also not good to step towards the goal for which the necessary steps have not been made. In addition, when Spain was offered the possibility of arbitration, it refused to do so, thus concludeing that it was not fully prepared to resolve the problem together. Also, the possibility of giving in solutum is required, which is by no means the solution to the problem in Spain. By adopting the contract, we have the consequence that the original contract is not executed or changed, which is a situation in which the solution has not been reached.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution is intended to seek clarification on banking reforms carried out by the Spanish government. Indeed, Spanish legislation does little to protect borrowers, as demonstrated by the numerous property foreclosures that occurred after the crisis, as well as the large number of Spaniards who feel they are victims of fraud by their banks.  If this text may amount to a form of interference, it appears to be limited, since it is only a matter of seeking clarification on the situation of banks in Spain and of putting an end to unfair practices against consumers. So I decided to vote for this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support Parliament's efforts to more closely monitor existing laws and new legislative initiatives to protect consumers in Spain, but also other countries, from financial risks, fraud and unfair contractual terms, primarily in the case of mortgage debtors, and given the extremely difficult situation and data on the number of victims of financial fraud and evictions.  The case with loans in Swiss francs in Croatia is another example of illegal business of banks, which was confirmed by the Supreme Court in the Republic of Croatia, which indicates a general poor state of consumer rights protection. The Croatian Parliament acted by amending the Consumer Lending Act, allowing conversion in the sense that the initially approved principal of loans denominated in francs was converted into euros at the exchange rate applicable on the date of payment of the loan, and the initially agreed interest rate in the "Swiss" is replaced by the interest rate for loans in euros. In this way, I welcome the request to financial entities in the EU to suspend unfair dealings in the case of mortgages and other financial products and services, as well as the imposition of excessive interest rates. I also support the demand for an information campaign that would raise the level of financial literacy of EU citizens and make them aware of the risks they are taking.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report is called in such a way that it might give the impression that this is the case in Spain, but in its content it focuses mainly on THE ISSUES RELATED TO MORTGAGES AND BANKING. However, the proposals contained therein could, in my view, harm the European banking sector and, as a result, turn against citizens and depositors, which perhaps this regulation should protect. Similarly, weakening legal certainty in the case of mortgages would, as a result, be reversed against citizens. For this reason, I could not support the report because it could have the effect of increasing the economic risk to citizens of eu Member States.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the wake of the request received by the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions (PETI) for non-compliance of national authorities with legislation on mortgages and financial instruments at risk in the EU, Parliament adopted a motion for a resolution to call on the Spanish authorities to comply with EU legislation.  I have spoken out against this text because I do not believe that this request is within the competence of Parliament's PETI committee. It is up to the European Commission, and as a last resort to the European Court of Justice, to ensure that Spanish legislation is in compliance with European legislation.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. Petitions report tragic personal situations of citizens who have lost, in part or totally, lifetime savings and prove the obstacles consumers face in obtaining accurate information about financial instruments, by the thousands. Civil society organisations continue to protest against the thousands of evictions, unfair terms in mortgage contracts and the lack of protection of borrowers. Unfair terms and practices have been found in the Spanish mortgage sector by national and European courts. This motion for a resolution specifically suggests that the Commission monitor the implementation and ensure compliance by national authorities with existing mortgage legislation.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish mortgage legislation, as the CJEC has been collecting in different judgments, is not in accordance with European legislation (Directive 93/13/EEC) by allowing the inclusion of unfair terms in mortgage contracts. The legislative amendments made by the Government of Spain are insufficient and do not have the real will to solve the social drama of the evictions and family insolvencies that have come, as the data show (social rent: 0.4%; payment: 0.7%; moratoriums: 8%; 35 billion euros still in mortgage contracts with unfair terms) and the EU Advocate General in his May 2015 report. Banking abuses in Spain have not only affected mortgage contracts, but some 700,000 savers have seen their savings trapped, without being able to recover them, or subjected to removing up to 70% for poor application of the right to information by banks, contrary to consumer guarantees. With this resolution, the Spanish Socialists are promoting an analysis of Spanish legislation by the Commission so that the Commission can take appropriate measures where appropriate.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The text of the resolution is based on numerous petitions received to protest against the hundreds of thousands of evictions, the presence of abusive clauses in mortgage contracts and the lack of protection for borrowers in Spain. Since 2008, more than 100,000 Spanish households have lost their homes. This resolution, which I supported, calls on financial institutions across the European Union to put an end to abusive practices against their customers in the area of mortgage lending, sophisticated financial products and credit cards, including setting excessive interest rates and arbitrary cancellation of services. The text also calls on: financial institutions across the EU not to evict families living in their only homes and to prioritise debt restructuring instead; the Spanish government to take advantage of the instruments at its disposal to develop a comprehensive solution that can significantly reduce the intolerable number of evictions; the European Commission to closely monitor the transposition in all Member States of the 2014/17/EU Directive on Consumer Credit Contracts for Residential Real Estate (the Mortgage Credit Directive).

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite my solidarity and concern towards all spanish people who have lost their savings due to risky investments, I voted against this motion for a resolution because I consider it to be not exhaustive.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution. Our amendments have been rejected by the joint vote of the people and European Socialists. The weight of the European Socialist Group has been decisive in backing down amendments which sought to tighten the content and tone of the Resolution, as well as to make it more executive and to introduce the specific issue of payment or that of associations of preferrs and affected by financial scams being taken into account.  The resolution, which, despite not incorporating our amendments, was overall positive and was a touch of attention from the European Parliament to Rajoy because of its non-compliance with housing and consumer rights, has finally been adopted. We hope that it will serve as an opening of an in-depth debate on the risk instruments that banks use without regard to previous assessments.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution as I consider it vital that the European Parliament positions and responds to the high number of requests recorded in recent years in which infringements committed by the authorities of the Spanish State are reported both in guaranteeing the right to housing and in protecting against bank abuses suffered by more than 700 000 people , scamming with the preferred ones. The text adopted is a totally inadequate step because, by voting against all the amendments tabled and eliminating parts adopted by the Committee on Petitions, Social Democrats, Conservatives and Liberals have left a resolution completely decaffeinated, relegating the European Parliament to a secondary role by preventing the Resolution from including calls for the European Commission to initiate the process of adopting legislation aimed at promoting the introduction of the payment and effectively guaranteeing the right to housing across the EU.  However, the Resolution includes some notable parts such as the call for the Government to act to end the intolerable number of evictions that occur in the State or the need for the Commission to verify and investigate complaints received for preferred fraud.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I do not believe the EU should involve itself in nation states’ internal rules. I am also against the plans to harmonise mortgage contracts.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We need to put an end to bank-related infringements of EU consumer-rights laws in Spain. The situation is Spain is quite grave: almost three-quarters of a million people have lost their savings – partially or completely – since 2008; and nearly two-fifths of a million have been evicted from their homes. The Spanish Government is called upon to end this situation and to avoid its recurrence.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the very difficult consequences of the economic crisis in several EU countries is the difficult situation of evicted families who have to continue to pay mortgage payments. In many cases, banks have not properly informed consumers about the extent of the risks associated with the proposed investments and loans, which has resulted in a number of people, particularly in Spain, for their lifetime savings. I therefore voted on the basis of petitions received by the European Parliament in favour of adopting a resolution on mortgage legislation and risky financial instruments in Spain, which aims to address this serious problem.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Numerous petitions so far have highlighted thousands of tragic personal stories by Spanish citizens about partial or total loss of property, and continue to testify to consumers' inability to access quality and useful information about the use of financial instruments. As a result of the crisis in the country, many Spanish families faced not only forced evictions from their homes, but also further repayment of their mortgages, which in turn included a whole range of potentially abusive clauses and practices.  While this motion for a resolution potentially brings a number of positive changes in the mortgage market, such as stricter control over the implementation of the court's decision in case C-415 (Aziz), as well as Council Directive 93/13/EEC on mortgage legislation, and thus better consumer protection, I still cannot fully agree with this proposal, as its individual parts do not agree with the views of the EPP Group.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal. However unpopular it may be in evicting people unable to pay their mortgages, limiting it would come solely at the expense of people who pay off their mortgages and lead to moral hazard. Harmonisation of mortgage rules would also go beyond its powers and violate the principle of subsidiarity, as the diverse mortgage rules do not in any way affect the functioning of the EU single market.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted against the resolution on mortgage legislation and risky financial instruments in the EU in the case of Spain. It is a national issue, a national problem that has been passed on to the level of the European Union. The tragic personal problems relating to mortgage loans, the labour and other related matters are the responsibility of the Member States, and I do not agree with transferring this to the European level. I see no reason to call on the Spanish Government in the European Parliament to use all the tools at their place in finding solutions in the resulting situation.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are opposed to the practice of "Transfer instead of payment", because this has also been implemented and applied in Greece with disastrous consequences for the poor people.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the resolution calling on the EU to assert its weight and its rules in favour of the thousands and thousands of Spanish families who bought the house using risky financial instruments fraudulently sold by banks and who now have to pay unsustainable mortgages and/or be evicted. Moreover, the 'lightness' with which banks sell complex financial instruments is certainly only a non-Spanish problem. The difficulties in paying home loans and evictions are unfortunately common in all the Mediterranean countries that suffered most from the financial crisis that began in 2008 and which received only deadly doses of austerity from the EU, rather than helping to recover. The EU as a whole – through austerity and beyond – has helped to unload the consequences of the financial crisis on the weakest classes, not on the large economic and financial groups that caused it or on the social strata that could best withstand a policy of economic rigour and cutting services. The adoption of this resolution opens a breach in the odious and damaging wall of these policies. A significant breach that we will endeavour to widen.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Petitions are a very important tool, through which the European Parliament keeps in touch with the citizens it directly represents and the problems they face. The interest of the citizen, as a consumer, must take precedence in all the measures we adopt. One such case is the legislation governing mortgages in the Member States. At present, citizens are signalling to us that there is a problem in Spain in terms of incomplete information for mortgage-backed loans that leads to tens of thousands of people who have trusted this type of lending instrument, which has been presented in a light which is far too favourable by certain banks. The problem is also found in other countries affected by austerity policies that have been implemented without an assessment of the social impact they can have. It is our duty to correct these shortcomings and to support citizens who have resorted without bad faith to this type of credit, but who have come to dramatic situations. We must be aware that, for many of our citizens, we are perhaps one last chance that they still have in a normal life.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution, which I supported, draws attention to thousands of tragic personal cases in which citizens have experienced evictions and the loss of their life savings – particularly in Spain – due to abusive terms in mortgage contracts and a lack of protection for borrowers. Some of these abusive clauses have been identified by national and European courts. It is estimated that over the past few years 700 000 Spanish citizens have been victims of financial fraud because they were sold risky financial instruments without being duly informed of the implications. The resolution calls on the Commission to monitor the implementation in all Member States of the ruling in Case C-415 (Aziz) and of Directive 93/13/EEC on mortgage legislation, in order to guarantee full compliance by national authorities. At the same time, it appeals to financial entities across the EU to stop engaging in abusive behaviour towards clients in the field of mortgages, sophisticated financial products and credit cards.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Given the unfair clauses and practices in the mortgage sector in Spain established by national and European courts, I consider that the answers to the questions raised by the European Parliament's Petitions Committee are very necessary at this time. Namely, due to the impossibility of paying the mortgage debt, 95 Spanish families are evicn daily.  I believe that the Commission should take effective measures to prevent further unfair practices, both in Spain and in other Member States. This is necessary as an estimated 700 000 Spanish citizens have been the victim of financial fraud, as their banks have sold them risky financial instruments through a lack of information.  It is obvious that unless the Commission takes appropriate steps to protect EU citizens from concluding contracts without sufficient understanding of the financial risks they are taking, more families will be left without their homes. Unfortunately, the same sad practice takes place daily in my homeland.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on mortgage legislation and risky financial instruments in the EU. I do not think that the case of Spain is an isolated case. We need to protect our citizens, and getting accurate information is crucial, especially when we talk about the importance of personal investment. At EU level, the aim remains to increase transparency on the general problem of bad banking practices and risky financial instruments, so proposals that go in this direction are welcome.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In the years of crisis in most European regions, especially in the countryside, there was observed the fall in house/apartment prices. As a result in many Member States even after eviction from their housing due to failure to pay debts or mortgage fees people owe huge sums to banks and this undermines their ability to organise their life properly (for example, to lease another adequate housing). Debtors’ housing may be sold by a bailiff in enforcement procedure (sometimes below market price) but it still may not be enough to pay off debts. One of the most evident solutions to this problem is 'datio in solutum', i.e. the possibility for the debtor to unilaterally force the full extinction of the loan debt at any time by delivering of the mortgaged property to the lender.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution. Our amendments have been rejected by the joint vote of the people and European Socialists. The weight of the European Socialist Group has been decisive in backing down amendments which sought to tighten the content and tone of the Resolution, as well as to make it more executive and to introduce the specific issue of payment or that of associations of preferrs and affected by financial scams being taken into account.  The resolution, which, despite not incorporating our amendments, was overall positive and was a touch of attention from the European Parliament to Rajoy because of its non-compliance with housing and consumer rights, has finally been adopted. We hope that it will serve as an opening of an in-depth debate on the risk instruments that banks use without regard to previous assessments.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome the approval of this resolution of the European Parliament. Hundreds of thousands of citizens in Spain suffered and still suffer due to the bad practices of the financial sector, and it is fundamental that Europe is willing and able to denounce it. The politics of avoiding naming and shaming in order to protect each other from criticism should be superseded to represent better the interest of our citizens.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The substance of the issue is interesting, as Spanish banks have effectively resorted to unfair practices towards their customers by granting toxic or variable-rate loans.  Of course, the harmonization of the rules in this area is akin to some interference by the Commission on a sovereign state. However, this pressure is limited, favourable to consumer interest and would limit bank abuses. I voted for it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution. Our amendments have been rejected by the joint vote of the people and European Socialists. The weight of the European Socialist Group has been decisive in backing down amendments which sought to tighten the content and tone of the Resolution, as well as to make it more executive and to introduce the specific issue of payment or that of associations of preferrs and affected by financial scams being taken into account.  The resolution, which, despite not incorporating our amendments, was overall positive and was a touch of attention from the European Parliament to Rajoy because of its non-compliance with housing and consumer rights, has finally been adopted. We hope that it will serve as an opening of an in-depth debate on the risk instruments that banks use without regard to previous assessments.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution about mortgage legislation and risky financial instruments in the EU, with particular reference to the case of Spain. Legislation on mortgage banking differs across the EU, resulting in different levels of consumer protection and debt settlement conditions. A number of abusive clauses and practices in the Spanish mortgage sector have been identified by national and European courts. Civil society in Spain has also been protesting against hundreds of thousands of evictions, abusive terms in mortgage contracts and a lack of protection for borrowers. It is necessary to improve the situation in Spain and, at the same time, all Member States should learn something from this case. With the text we call on the Commission closely to monitor the effective implementation of the new measures adopted by the Spanish Government; to launch information campaigns on financial products; to enhance financial literacy through education, in order to ensure that European citizens are better informed about the risks involved when subscribing to financial products; and to share best practices that enhance the protection of citizens in financial difficulty. Basic financial education should be considered as a complementary asset for avoiding the consequences of over-indebtedness and should help to protect European citizens.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish mortgage legislation, as the CJEC has been collecting in different judgments, is not in accordance with European legislation (Directive 93/13/EEC) by allowing the inclusion of unfair terms in mortgage contracts. The legislative amendments made by the Government of Spain are insufficient and do not have the real will to solve the social drama of the evictions and family insolvencies that have come, as the data show (social rent: 0.4%; payment: 0.7%; moratoriums: 8%; 35 billion euros still in mortgage contracts with unfair terms) and the EU Advocate General in his May 2015 report. Banking abuses in Spain have not only affected mortgage contracts, but some 700,000 savers have seen their savings trapped, without being able to recover them, or subjected to removing up to 70% for poor application of the right to information by banks, contrary to consumer guarantees. With this resolution, the Spanish Socialists are promoting an analysis of Spanish legislation by the Commission so that the Commission can take appropriate measures where appropriate.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution seeks to highlight poor consumer protection for mortgage borrowers and home owners in Spain. After the 2008 crisis that trashed the mortgage markets as over-extended banks called in poorly designed and audited loans, it is imperative that we remain vigilant to any further examples of bad practice in the mortgage sector. By establishing better Europe-wide best practices on mortgage lending and information provided to consumers, and by preventing banks from misleading consumers about the products they buy, we can put banking across Europe on a surer footing. Furthermore, it is important that the European Parliament is responsive to petitions and alive to the concerns and problems that the citizens of Europe bring its attention. I was therefore happy to vote in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Financial speculation encouraged by an "all-owner" policy with tax advantages and interest rates favouring long-term debt of Spanish households has driven thousands of people to the streets after the speculative bubble burst. Since 2008, nearly 400,000 evictions have already taken place, and this continues.  However, international and European courts, including the European Court of Justice (ECJ), have declared the expulsions illegal. All foreclosures made during this period should therefore have been declared illegal and the corresponding proceedings re-opened. The Spanish government has remained deaf to all the reminders to order. This resolution, supported by the GUE/NGL, responds to numerous petitions lodged with the European Parliament. Despite the offensive of the European right, this resolution calls on the European institutions and the Spanish government to respect European law and the ECJ's decision condemning abusive banking practices in mortgage lending. I voted in favour, even though this resolution is above all declarative. It is moving in the right direction by calling for additional protection for the most vulnerable households.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the economic and financial crisis, thousands of citizens have lost, in part or totally, the savings of a lifetime. In Spain, civil society organisations continue to protest against the hundreds of thousands of evictions due to unfair terms in mortgage contracts and against the lack of protection of borrowers. According to the Mortgage Victims Platform (PAH), there were 19,261 evictions in Spain during the first quarter of 2015 (an increase of 6% compared to the first quarter of 2014), and more than 397,954 evictions have occurred in Spain since 2008. The famous Mortgage Credit Directive came only to try to make up the situation with the usual regulatory measures, supposedly designed to curb abuses of the financial system. That is, nothing has been done to solve this drama of thousands of families. And everything remains the same as far as access to housing, particularly for young people who are out of work and will continue to be so, despite the millions of empty fires.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Although the report provides for an improvement in the protection of mortgage debtors, it involves a populist recourse to the human right to housing. The EU wants to interfere with Member States' housing laws, thereby exceeding its powers. I cannot therefore support this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I do not agree with the motion for a resolution on mortgage legislation in Spain. Firstly, it is a national matter that Spain should regulate without EU interference. Secondly, I see no reason to take away from mortgage debtors the economic consequences of their wrong decision. With all due respect to the difficult situation of the people, it is not acceptable for the taxpayer to take on the risks of those who have acquired residential property on credit – and thus speculatively. Undoubtedly, it should be noted that the misery has been caused by the single European interest rate mediated by the euro. It has caused the real estate bubble in Spain. However, there is no indication that the euro is the root of the problem.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – While the resolution undeniably shows the acuteness of the problems and the inability of popular families in Spain to repay loans or pay rents leading to foreclosures, house auctions and exiles, there is no explicit reference to the full protection of people households affected by the crisis and unpopular measures. On the contrary, proposals are invoked which actually safeguard the interests of the banks, burdening working-class households in other ways and leaving the way open to auctions of popular housing, maintaining the dead ends and distress of those who, because of poverty and unemployment, cannot repay the loans. The JRC has repeatedly taken up the issue with specific positions on the protection and relief of popular families, calling, inter alia, for the abolition of auctions of first and second popular housing, the write-off of interest debts and the drastic reduction of loans that the people have had to take in previous years for their needs.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In Spain, civil society organizations continue to protest against the hundreds of thousands of evictions due to unfair terms in mortgage contracts and the lack of protection of borrowers According to the Mortgage Victims Platform ('Mortgage affected platform' – PAH'), there were 19 261 evictions in Spain during the first quarter of 2015 (an increase of 6% compared to the first quarter of 2014) and it is estimated that more than 397 954 evictions in Spain since 2008. The famous Mortgage Credit Directive came only to try to make up the situation, with the usual regulatory measures supposedly designed to curb abuses of the financial system. That is, nothing has been done to solve this drama for thousands of families, which extends to more and more countries.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – The death penalty was in Hungary until 1990 or 1991. As a university lecturer, I was in criminal law seminars at the time, both in court hearings where the death penalty sentence became final. That's where I had to face the man who would be hanged in the name of Hungarian society. We've also been on a prison visit so I can look into the cell where the specific person sentenced to the death penalty was.  I've been in a much tougher position since this happened to me. After all, it is extremely difficult to say that I support the death penalty, that is, to take the life of a particular person in my name. At the same time, I see, precisely as a criminal lawyer, extremely violent acts of violence, e.g. against children, as resifiables, when this question makes me think carefully. We need a debate, a conversation about the death penalty.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this proposal because I believe that the European Union, as an international institution, must defend human rights in the world. We are constantly debating human rights violations in the world, so we must also be those who will fight the death penalty. In short, there are still fifty-eight countries that have the death penalty, and in some states it is carried out very barbarically. I want to name China here, I want to name Iran here, I want to name Saudi Arabia here, these are countries where the death penalty is clearly abused and we also debated today in the morning bloc how a young dissident should be brutally executed, murdered in Saudi Arabia. It is therefore necessary to combat this and to try to enforce the prohibition of this punishment in all international fields and, on the contrary, to say and say that an adequate punishment for the greatest crimes is a life sentence.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Thank you, Mr President. Any person should have the right to both life and to lawful punitive procedures in the event of infringements, as well as the possibility of reimbursing the public the penalty received from the court, no matter how much time it may not have to do so in its entirety.  In the modern world, however, the death penalty can no longer be regarded as an effective method of punishment, especially given that there is always the possibility that such punishment could be wrongly imposed, so that a person would lose his or her life for crimes he has never committed. In recent years, the number of death sentences has increased significantly in some countries around the world. A fact that is rather regrettable, especially considering that a number of cases concern people who have not done what they have been punished for.  I supported this resolution.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé freisin i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo agus dar ndóigh tá sé áthasach go bhfuil níos mó agus níos mó tíortha, de réir a chéile, ag cur deireadh le pionós an bháis; agus tá sé sin tábhachtach. Go háirithe ón taobh istigh den Aontas, ní ceart go mbeadh muid ag caint faoi phionós an bháis a thabairt ar ais in aon chor.  Tuigim go dtarlaíonn rudaí uafásacha agus bíonn fearg ar a lán daoine agus bíonn fonn orthu, b’fhéidir, an duine sin a chur chun báis; ach tá sé níos sibhialta cearta an duine a aithint i gcónaí. Dar ndóigh, mar a dúradh, is minic a cuireadh daoine chun báis agus fuaireamar amach tamall fada ina dhiaidh sin nach raibh sé tuillte acu in aon chor.  Dá bhrí sin is ceart glacadh leis mar cheart daonna ar fud an domhain ar fad nach cóir dúinn daoine a chur chun báis, agus ba cheart deireadh a chur leis an scéim sin.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: I'm against the death penalty. In 2014, 2,500 people died as a result of the death penalty. Every day there are people sentenced to death for common law offences or for exercising their freedom, and I am referring to the case of the demonstrators, the case of those who participate in the protests, in particular, for example, in the case of the minor Ali Mohammed al-Nimr from Saudi Arabia, who participated in the protests and was killed. Not many months ago, Saudi Arabia hired horses to behead prisoners or amputate the limbs (legs or hands) of those convicted of lesser crimes. I ask: are we all in 2015 or just some of us?

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the countries of the European Union have committed themselves to the prohibition of the death penalty. It is a European value, but it comes from the general principle of the inviolability of human life. The heaviest crimes should be punishable by life imprisonment. In 2014, two thousand and four hundred and sixty-six people were executed, most of them in China. I supported the resolution that I signed and supported not because I am in favour of exporting European values to the world, but because the death penalty is being abused. It is used for dealing with political opponents or for persecuting people for religious reasons and for reasons of other sexual orientation. I think this is unacceptable, which is why I am glad that the European Parliament has adopted this resolution.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution on the Death Penalty as we share its objective: the total abolition of the death penalty and criticism of all the countries in which it is practiced, from the United States to Iran. Moreover, it seems relevant to us that it particularly condemns the death penalty on grounds such as sexual orientation or adultery, which continues to take place in many countries around the world, such as Saudi Arabia.  World Day Against the Death Penalty was celebrated on 10 October 2015, which this year set out to raise awareness of capital punishment in cases of drug-related crimes, which applies in up to 33 countries; in this regard, the Resolution urges the Commission and the European External Action Service to establish the abolition of capital punishment for such crimes as a requirement for aid or support in anti-drug policies. We therefore understand that this resolution reiterates the European commitment, which we share, to combat this type of state crime and urges the Commission to take this into account in all its foreign policy.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this joint resolution as it highlighted aptly concerns I share about the use of the death penalty internationally, and reaffirmed Europe’s commitment to opposing, and encouraging others to oppose, the use of the death penalty.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 With this resolution on which I had the honour of signing the Socialists' Proposal, but also the Joint Resolution which was finally adopted by the plenary of the European Parliament, the countries which are still applying the death penalty are condemned and it is proposed to restrict exports of substances that may be used for the implementation of the Death Penalty.  As a progressive man, I find it unacceptable that there are still countries in the so-called 'developed' world that are applying this unacceptable practice and I believe that the European Union should use its political weight on the international stage by pushing for its abolition.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. With my colleagues at the National Front, we are not against the death penalty as it is practised within a strictly defined legal framework that ensures respect for the rights of the defence and fair trials.  The text put to the vote of the European Parliament has a radically different position. It is about preventing any Member State from re-establishing the death penalty, putting pressure on Belarus , the last European country to still do so , restricting trade with countries that have not yet withdrawn it from their legislation, etc. Thus, this proposal intends to interfere in the internal affairs of states.  The moralizing discourse of the European Union on the issue of the death penalty is perfectly inappropriate. As is often the case, the Europeanist elites want to shape the world to their liking and impose their vision on all those who do not share it by questionable means and very disrespectful towards independent states and their people.  For these reasons, I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I am no supporter of the death penalty on a personal level, given my concerns over the ability of a nation state to enforce it in a fair and appropriate manner in practice, I cannot support a resolution which interferes with the right of other nations to make that decision for themselves.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, which aims to condemn the use of the death penalty and to support the decree of a moratorium with a view to its abolition.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. The universal abolition of the death penalty is one of the main priorities as far as the EU policy on human rights is concerned. I hope that we can become more consistent in our actions, and pay systematic regard to this clause during all EU external dialogues and negations. I believe the EU must be a pioneer of the abolitionist campaign to put an end to capital punishment worldwide. Moreover, we cannot keep turning a blind eye to what is going on in our closest neighbourhood: there is still one country in Europe, Belarus, which retains and applies capital punishment. The EU needs to use all the diplomatic tools at its command to exert pressure for a moratorium on the death penalty which would eventually lead to the complete abolition of this punishment in Belarus.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution condemning the use of the death penalty. The abolition of the death penalty contributes to strengthening human dignity and the EU's main objective is its complete abolition. In 2014, 2,466 people were sentenced to death in 55 countries, an almost 23% higher than in 2013. I support calls on the EEAS to continue to fight the use of the death penalty and to strongly support the moratorium as a step towards the abolition of the death penalty. The Commission should provide assistance and political support to countries that are making progress in the abolition of the death penalty.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Interference, interference, always interference. Instead of seeking at all costs to impose its morals on the whole world, while sparing allies such as Qatar and Saudi Arabia, the European Union would do better to address first the real democratic deficit of its technocratic institutions.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. According to Amnesty International, 607 executions and 2,466 death sentences were recorded in 22 countries in 2014. Yet there is no evidence that the death penalty would have a greater deterrent effect than the prison sentence for criminal acts, according to the NGO. But above all, the death penalty is contrary to European values and European law. The Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union explicitly prohibits the death penalty (Article 2). At a time when some countries are going so far as to consider the reintroduction of the death penalty, including within the continent, it is the Union's duty to recall its outright condemnation of the death penalty and its ultimate goal, which is total abolition at the global level. I can, of course, only support this resolution in line with respect for human rights and human dignity.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the death penalty, in addition to being one of the co-signers, because of the need to reiterate the condemnation of the use of the death penalty and thus strongly support the introduction of a moratorium as a step towards abolition. It's a 21st century scourge. Moreover, this abolition will contribute to the improvement of human dignity. The ultimate objective of the Union is that this abolition is also universal.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This EU resolution on the death penalty allows it to re-engage in the policies of nation states in order to raise awareness while continuing to engage in partnerships with countries in the Middle East such as Saudi Arabia or Qatar, which do not hesitate to practice it, as we have seen recently with the tragic case of Ali Mohammed Al-Nimr. On the other hand, the text calls for a check on Belarus, which is the only European country to still authorise and practice the death penalty, or to ban the death penalty in cases of drug trafficking. Nevertheless, Amendment 9 — to which I was in favour — proposes to abolish the death penalty in states that still penalize homosexuality, and it is not normal that in this day and age such a case may still exist. But this does not seem to disturb our rulers who do not hesitate to deal with states using this motive ...  Nevertheless, I believe that a debate can be opened on the death penalty as a punishment for certain crimes and it is not for the European Union to dictate the policies of States in this area. So I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text is acceptable in its main content, although there are ambiguities in the analysis of the EU's role in third country policy, I wanted to support this resolution condemning the use of the death penalty.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 The 13th World Day Against the Death Penalty will be celebrated on 10 October. Even with substantial progress in several countries, we are far from global abolition. Of the 58 countries that still include the death penalty in their order, 22 of them were carried out in 2014. In several cases, the number of executions remains alarmingly high or has increased over the past few years. This year's World Day focuses on sentences issued for drug-related crimes. There are a growing number of countries that have passed death-related laws for drug trafficking offences. EU guidelines on the death penalty specify that such crimes cannot be punished with capital punishment.  We want to know what concrete measures the EU has put in place to advance the abolition of the death penalty, in particular in its bilateral relations with the countries that maintain it and specifically with those where there has been an uptick or restart of this practice. That is why I supported this motion for a resolution.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament condemns the use of the death penalty and strongly supports the declaration of a moratorium on the death penalty as a step towards its abolition. The abolition of the death penalty helps to strengthen human dignity and the EU's main objective is its complete abolition. Parliament also condemns all executions wherever they are carried out and is deeply concerned about the imposition of the death penalty on minors, persons with mental or intellectual disabilities, and calls for such practices to be put to an immediate and definitive end. The European Parliament therefore calls on the European External Action Service (EEAS) and the Member States to continue to combat the use of the death penalty and calls on countries still applying the death penalty to comply with minimum international standards in order to limit the scope and use of the death penalty, to publish clear and accurate data on the number of such sentences and executions. Calls also on the EEAS, the Commission and the Member States to make recommendations on a comprehensive and effective European death penalty policy, given that tens of EU citizens in third countries are at risk of the death penalty.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ On the occasion of the 13th anniversary of the 9/11 attacks, The New York Times On the day of the fight against the death penalty, questions have been raised about the direction and relations of the European Union towards countries that support the death penalty. I believe that the death penalty is a bad and extremely inhumane way of punishing the perpetrators of a crime, especially if we bear in mind that throughout history there have also been a number of cases in which innocent people have been sentenced to death. Therefore, I fully support these questions and I am interested in how the EU plans to set itself up in the future towards countries that continue to support the death penalty as a form of punishment for perpetrators of crime.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Any vote on the death penalty is a vote on a sensitive and personal issue that is a matter of conscience. Any decision on the death penalty within a state’s penal system is entirely a matter for that individual nation state, through free and fair consultation with its electorate.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I am strongly opposed to the application of the death penalty and I believe it is important that the European Union, as a homeland and beacon of human rights, works to ensure that this barbaric practice continues to be applied throughout the world.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The death penalty is an instrument that violates the right to life, enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, is ineffective as a deterrent and is irreparable in the event of judicial errors. Furthermore, in most cases, the poorest or most marginalised are the victims of the death penalty because they do not have the economic and cultural resources to deal with the costs and demanding procedures of a process of this level. The death penalty also denies any possibility of rehabilitation and change of person and affects the family members of the king, who are not to blame for the actions he has committed. If we look at the data on its application over the last twenty years, it is significant to note that the main promoters of the death penalty are unseen states, which apply it to intimidate minorities and target political or religious opponents such as Saudi Arabia, Iran, China, Syria, North Korea and numerous African dictatorships. The European Union must therefore use all its political weight to ensure that there is an international moratorium on the death penalty and its progressive abolition in all countries with which the EU has trade or diplomatic relations.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. 2,466 people were sentenced to death in 2014, a 23% increase over 2013. In this text, the rapporteur is outraged at the stoning of hundreds of women, the death sentences of homosexuals and the mentally ill in the Arab countries that apply Sharia law. In addition, the report calls for the fight against the application of the death penalty for drug trafficking offences.  We have always fought the barbarity of states that apply stoning and execute individuals for their sexual orientation. We have always fought alongside ethnic minorities who are being persecuted by totalitarian regimes. Nevertheless, we are categorically opposed to the worldwide abolition of the death penalty, as we consider it not to be contrary to human rights when applied for crimes of exceptional gravity. Finally, we are against strengthening export controls on products used to impose the death penalty. This has only resulted in injections of lethal products that are ineffective in the past, as was the case in the United States.  So I voted against it.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against, I am in favour of the death penalty.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. "No one can be sentenced to death or executed." This is the second article of the European Union's Charter of Fundamental Rights. The death penalty is abolished in all EU Member States. This is also a prerequisite for any country wishing to join the Union. Finally, it is a fundamental value that the Union must export to the whole world.  I am staunchly opposed to the death penalty. The case of Ali Mohammed al-Nimr is a recent example of the most revolting. The young man was sentenced to be beheaded and then crucified for taking part in the Arab Spring protests in Saudi Arabia. He was sentenced to death for expressing his opinion. We must fight for the abolition of the death penalty in the world. This is one of the European Union's fundamental human rights missions. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote is in favour of the motion for a resolution on the death penalty because Europe must reaffirm its leading role in the fight for the abolition of the death penalty and a moratorium on executions worldwide.   Unfortunately, in recent years we have seen a resurgence of executions, especially in countries where they have not occurred for several years or where a moratorium has been in place. We must take up the Holy Father's appeal to abolish the death penalty, legal or illegal, and in all its forms. Europe has been free of the death penalty since 1997, apart from belarus. Much remains to be done, just as slavery has been abolished, and this cruel, inhuman and degrading punishment must also be abolished.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ ‒ I supported this joint resolution as it highlighted aptly concerns I share about the use of the death penalty internationally, and reaffirmed Europe’s commitment to opposing, and encouraging others to oppose, the use of the death penalty.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We believe that any vote on the death penalty is a vote on a sensitive and personal issue that is a matter of conscience. Any decision on the death penalty within a state’s penal system is entirely a matter for that individual nation state, through free and fair consultation with its electorate. We acknowledge, however, that there are some states whose use of the death penalty breaches internationally agreed human rights standards, and we support work to curtail this through appropriate international institutions.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because I believe that there are better alternative approaches for punishment rather than the use of death penalty. I am also a strong advocate of human rights.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 October 2 was World Day against the Death Penalty. This is yet another sad day, not least because, unfortunately, we have to note that this crime against humanity is still in force in very civilised countries that are friends of Europe, such as the United States and Japan. It is also so in some of our strategic allied countries such as Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Pakistan, not to mention China and its 1,200 death sentences, which have always been seen as the EU's great trading partner. How much we could do if we used trade and the economy as a means of strengthening human rights and not the other way round. What I hope is that Europe will once again become Europe, that it will combat this shame and that it will pronounce the only right death sentence: the one against the death penalty itself.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Fifty-eight countries across the globe still retain the death penalty. Although much is being done to eradicate it in certain countries, the number of executions has been on the rise in recent years. Today, we reaffirm our commitment to abolish this barbaric practice worldwide.  One of our fellow Irishmen, Ibrahim Halawa, is currently facing a death sentence in Egypt, where he was arrested, at the age of 17, in August 2013. There is no evidence that links him to any of the crimes he has allegedly committed, and yet, in August, he was tried, alongside 493 others, in an extremely unfair mass-trial. There is no other way for Ibahim to seek justice unless the Irish Government and the EU intervene in this very clear violation of human rights. My thoughts are with Ibrahim.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the death penalty, among others, calls on the EU and its Member States to ensure that the special session of the UN General Assembly on the global drug problem in April 2016 examines the use of the death penalty for drug-related offences and condemns its implementation. At the same time, it further welcomes and encourages the activities of NGOs working to abolish the death penalty around the world .

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution of the death penalty. Its abolition in the world is one of the fundamental objectives of the Union's foreign policy. To date, 160 UN Member States have abolished or are not practising the death penalty; however, in 2014, 2,466 people were sentenced to death and 607 executions took place around the world, some through stoning and for drug-related or homosexuality offences. In addition, some European citizens are awaiting justice in third countries for drug trafficking offences. With this resolution, the EP strongly condemns the death penalty, supports the moratorium as a step towards its abolition and welcomes the decisions of some US states to abolish it. Finally, it reaffirms that the death penalty is incompatible with the values on which the Union is founded and urges the European External Action Service (EEAS), the Commission and the Member States to act in defence of European citizens awaiting execution in third countries.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the abolition of the death penalty because I believe that this is a practice to be eliminated throughout the world because of a matter of humanity and respect for each individual on the other. The death penalty is not, in my view, the solution to punish and combat crimes, even the most serious. I think it is good that more than 160 UN Member States, with different legal systems, cultures and traditions, have already abolished or never practised the death penalty. It should not be forgotten that some countries such as Chad and Tunisia are considering reintroducing this practice. I intend to ensure, also on behalf of the European Parliament, that this punishment ceases immediately and definitively, given that the abolition of the death penalty is one of the main objectives of the EU's human rights policy.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We believe that any vote on the death penalty is a vote on a sensitive and personal issue which is a matter of conscience. Any decision on the place of the death penalty within a state’s penal system is entirely a matter for that individual state, through free and fair consultation with its electorate. We acknowledge, however, that there are some states whose use of the death penalty breaches internationally agreed human rights standards, and we support work to curtail this through appropriate international institutions.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The death penalty is not compatible with the values that are at the heart of the European project, with emphasis on Human Dignity. Its reintroduction by a Member State would constitute a flagrant violation of the European Charter of Fundamental Rights and the Treaties. A few days before World Day against the Death Penalty (10 October) I support this Resolution which clearly expresses how many countries that practice it, too many condemned people, too many executed ones are still too many. There are 33 countries and at least 2,466 convicted and 667 executed in 2014 alone.  It seems clear to me that the Union cannot refrain from leading the change in the global status quo. It is, however, necessary to take the first steps, such as drawing up a strategy by the External Action Service and the Member States to influence our partners. This Resolution does just this: it calls for - much needed - concrete steps for the universal abolition of the death penalty.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution because I strongly condemn the death penalty. Respect for human rights and respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality and the rule of law are the cornerstones of human coexistence. It is therefore our task, for example.B to condemn the practice of stoning to the utmost.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I signed and voted for this important resolution on the death penalty. I share the condemnation of all executions, wherever they take place and, in particular, those concerning minors and those that take place in a ferocious manner, such as the stoning of women.  I also support the abolition of the death penalty and the need to introduce a moratorium as a first step towards its abolition. I welcome the abolition of the death penalty in many US states and join the Pope's appeal a week ago, on his visit to the US Congress, 'Abolish the death penalty!' The hope is that the Member States, the Commission and the European institutions will all be able to work, each for their own competences, to achieve this objective on a global scale as soon as possible.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The abolition of the death penalty is essential for the protection of human dignity, which is fundamental in the effective protection of human rights. When we speak of the abolition of the death penalty, we are not saying that crimes should remain unpunished. Without getting engrossed in the debate about punishments being proportionate to the crime, there is, in relation to the death penalty, an even more fundamental issue at stake. We cannot tolerate the imposition of a punishment which is itself a violation of human rights since it attacks the very core of human dignity. When one considers that vulnerable persons, such as minors, are still subject to capital punishment, and when one sees that the death penalty is often associated with judicial systems which do not aspire to – never mind attain – the highest standards of fair process, then the EU must show a stronger commitment towards abolishing this punishment worldwide. It is good that the European institutions and Member States are acting to raise awareness against the death penalty on the day dedicated to this cause, but stronger and ongoing commitment is needed. We need to strengthen our political and financial support and take concrete steps to secure legal assistance and fair trials.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution on the Death Penalty as we share its objective: the total abolition of the death penalty and criticism of all the countries in which it is practiced, from the United States to Iran. Moreover, it seems relevant to us that it particularly condemns the death penalty on grounds such as sexual orientation or adultery, which continues to take place in many countries around the world, such as Saudi Arabia.  World Day Against the Death Penalty was celebrated on 10 October 2015, which this year set out to raise awareness of capital punishment in cases of drug-related crimes, which applies in up to 33 countries; in this regard, the Resolution urges the Commission and the European External Action Service to establish the abolition of capital punishment for such crimes as a requirement for aid or support in anti-drug policies. We therefore understand that this resolution reiterates the European commitment, which we share, to combat this type of state crime and urges the Commission to take this into account in all its foreign policy.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The death penalty is a practice contrary to the fundamental values of the European Union, but it is still practised in many parts of the world. I therefore believe that the European Union must export its fundamental principles and values to other regions of the world for the total abolition of the death penalty. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution calling on the European External Action Service and the Member States to continue the fight against the use of the death penalty and to support the introduction of a moratorium as a step towards its abolition, to urge countries that still practise it to comply with international minimum standards and to publish clear and precise data on the number of convictions and executions.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. The abolition of the death penalty is one of the main objectives of EU human rights policy worldwide. More than 160 UN Member States have either abolished the death penalty or are not applying it in practice, according to the office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights. Despite this, according to the latest figures, at least 2,466 people were sentenced to death in 55 countries in 2014, an increase of 23% on 2013. Furthermore, in 2015, death penalty and executions continued at an alarming rate. In particular, I consider it reprehensible that certain countries use the death penalty to break down resistance, on the basis of differences in religion or belief, homosexuality or adultery, or for other reasons which can be considered either insignificant or cannot be classified as a crime at all. I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution condemning the use of the death penalty and strongly supports the introduction of a moratorium on the death penalty as one of the stages on the road to the abolition of the death penalty, which states that the abolition of the death penalty contributes to strengthening human dignity and that the EU's ultimate aim is to abolish the death penalty universally.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because even though we are in 2015 there is still a very long way to go before the death penalty is abolished world-wide. Out of the 58 countries in the world that still have the death penalty, 22 of them carried out executions during 2014. The 13th World Day Against the Death Penalty will take place on 10 October 2015 and will be the opportunity for the European Union to reaffirm its leading role in the drive for the abolition of the death penalty and a moratorium on executions.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the World Day against the Death Penalty of 10 October 2015 focuses on a better awareness of the application of the death penalty to drug-related offences, I believe that it is incompatible with values such as respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, on which the Union is based, and that any Member State that would reintroduce the death penalty would be in breach of the Treaties and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 On November 30, 1786, the Grand Duchy of Tuscany was the first state in the world to abolish the death penalty. More than 200 years later, on 18 December 2007, the United Nations General Assembly adopted the resolution on the universal moratorium on the death penalty, thanks in part to the strong and strong support of the Italian Government. The defence of the right to life and the ban on the sentencing of a person to death are affirmed today in Article 2 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. As a European citizen, born in Tuscany, I therefore wholely supported this resolution, which defines the European Union's concrete commitment to the total abolition of the death penalty. In order to achieve this, I believe that the Union must step up its activities and projects in third countries, with particular attention to neighbouring countries, including through institutional, financial and political support to UN agencies and civil society organisations promoting this objective under the Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights (EIDHR). I therefore welcome the text of the resolution which once again reaffirms the leading role of the Union and its Member States in the fight for the complete abolition of this barbaric practice.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution is part of the 13th World Day Against the Death Penalty on 10 October, this year dedicated to death sentences for drug-related crimes. While the EU's guidelines on the death penalty, revised in 2013, make it clear that the death penalty should not be applied for drug-related crimes, this phenomenon still exists. In support of this resolution, we call on the Member States and the Commission to take the necessary measures to contain this phenomenon.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against, our Movement is in favour of reinstating the death penalty for particularly heinous crimes, such as drug trafficking in large quantities and rape of minors.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We believe that any vote on the death penalty is a vote on a sensitive and personal issue that is a matter of conscience. Any decision on the death penalty within a state’s penal system is entirely a matter for that individual nation state, through free and fair consultation with its electorate. We acknowledge, however, that there are some states whose use of the death penalty breaches internationally agreed human rights standards, and we support work to curtail this through appropriate international institutions.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The total abolition of the death penalty is one of the main objectives of EU human rights policy. In fact, the death penalty is incompatible with the values of human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and human rights, which form the foundations of the Union. Thus, the reintroduction of the death penalty by a Member State would constitute a violation of the TREATIes and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.  It should be noted that in 2014, more than 2,466 people in 55 countries were sentenced to death, an increase of 23 % compared to 2013. In 2014, at least 607 people were executed and these figures did not include the number of people who were executed in China, who continued to execute more people than the rest of the world. The death penalty is often used against the most disadvantaged, the mentally ill and members of national and cultural minorities. I reiterate the conviction of the use of the death penalty. The abolition of the death penalty contributes to the strengthening of human dignity. I condone all the executions and Express my deep concern at the practice of stoning, which continues to be used in several countries.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We condemn the death penalty and advocate its abolition. We regret that capital punishment is still applied by at least 55 countries and we are concerned about the growing trend of promoting the discussion for the reversal of the abolition of the death penalty by some countries, notably in Europe. We are generally in accordance with the content of the resolution. We cannot fail, however, to record elements of the usual hypocrisy imposed by the majority of the European Parliament in the considerations made with traces of interference and in the discrepancy of the analysis, where, for example, it is not in the same way the maintenance of capital punishment in countries such as the USA and China, or when it places the European External Action Service as an instrument in the fight against capital punishment , the same instrument that promotes aggression interventions in third countries responsible for the deaths of hundreds of people. Despite these observations, we voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as I oppose the death penalty.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 10 October celebrates World Day Against the Death Penalty, but in 2014 at least 22 states carried out executions and at least 2,466 people were sentenced to death. Dozens of Europeans are also at risk of execution in countries that still apply the death penalty. It is our duty to make every effort to abolish the death penalty, at least in relation to acts contrary to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and the death penalty should not be imposed for drug-related offences. It is important that the European External Action Service, the Commission and the Member States provide guidance on a comprehensive and effective European policy on the death penalty with regard to the dozens of Europeans facing this threat in third countries.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The opposition to the death penalty is rightly reaffirmed.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against all the reports on the death penalty, since the Movement I represent is in favour of reinstating the death penalty for particularly heinous crimes, such as drug trafficking in large quantities and rape of minors.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am very concerned by the fact that, in opposition to the general trend of recent decades, an increasing number of countries have enacted laws permitting the death penalty for drug related offences. I therefore strongly support the call on the Commission to mainstream the campaign to abolish the death penalty in EU foreign policy and external relations; and to have talks with third countries that are responsible for a significant rise in the number of executions or for re-starting executions. The death penalty is the ultimate cruel, inhuman and degrading punishment, which violates the right to life, as enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, and it is an act of torture unacceptable to states that respect human rights. We need to stick to our strong position against the death penalty, seeking the establishment of a universal moratorium with a view to the global abolition of capital punishment, as a key objective of the Union’s human rights policy.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
