text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution fully convinced that the abolition of the death penalty worldwide should be one of the main objectives of EU human rights policy. To achieve this end, it is necessary that, as in the case of the ESM, the Commission and the Member States work in a coordinated manner within the EU and the United Nations.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I fully support Mrs Valenciano's question to the Commission on the death penalty because it gives us all the opportunity to reflect once again, on 10 October, on the thirteenth World Day against the Death Penalty, on how unacceptable and distant it is from both the human soul and the European spirit to reflect on a punitive method that promotes the culture of death and the violation of the right to life as a response to violence.  Human life is sacred, and it is the task of politics to protect the good and respect of the person. Whatever the crime committed, "Just and necessary punishment must never exclude the dimension of hope and the objective of rehabilitation" as Pope Francis himself reminded us all only a few months ago in the Strasbourg Chamber, calling for the cancellation of the death penalty.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the death penalty because I firmly believe that justice can never take place through murder. The abolition of the death penalty in the world is one of the main objectives of the EU's human rights policy. I therefore believe it is essential for the EU to commit itself to a moratorium on the death penalty with a view to its abolition, since only the abolition of this extreme measure can contribute to the strengthening of human dignity.  The death penalty does not discourage crime but incites social resistance and the fight against the government and justice system. Unfortunately, to date, thirty-three states in the world continue to apply it for drug-related crimes with around 1 000 executions a year and eight countries provide for this penalty for homosexuality, all of which are in violation of basic rights, including a fair trial. Finally, I would like to stress the basic premise of sanctions/detentions, which should be that of the re-education and reintegration into society of those condemned and not death by the State. This, among other things, diseducases the generations because the authorities respond to violence with just as much violence.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the death penalty today because, as a Christian and a democrat, as a member of the only Christian Democratic Party in Europe (ECPM), I strongly oppose the death penalty.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I welcome the outcome of the vote of 07.10.2015, in which the European Parliament adopted a resolution on the death penalty, strongly condemning its application and supporting any action to abolish it.  The death penalty is still widely used in many countries around the world. According to the latest figures, at least 2,466 people were sentenced to death in 2014 in 55 countries, an increase of almost 23% compared to 2013. Such judgments m.in offences relating to the trafficking and distribution of drugs, acts of terrorism, but also homosexuality or adultery. Their substrates are conditioned by the legal system of the country that applies it, its tradition, culture and religious conditions.  In this context, I am deeply concerned about the growing use of the death penalty. The abolition of the death penalty is one of the main objectives of our Community and its application is incompatible with the fundamental principles of the European Union as set out in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Our resolution calls for an immediate end to the death penalty and for reforms of justice systems in the countries that continue to provide for it.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We believe that any vote on the death penalty is a vote on a sensitive and personal issue which is a matter of conscience. Any decision on the place of the death penalty within a state’s penal system is entirely a matter for that individual state, through free and fair consultation with its electorate. I cannot support a resolution which interferes with the right of other nations to make that decision for themselves.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The latest figures show that at least 2 466 people in 55 countries were sentenced to death in 2014 and at least 604 executions were carried out worldwide the same year. Often used within skewed justice systems, as a political tool against political opponents, or against underprivileged people, the death penalty is – regardless of who is accused – a cruel and inhuman act that simply denies the fundamental right to life. The EU has a crucial role to play to promote the abolition of the death penalty worldwide, and this is one the main objectives of its human rights policy. I therefore strongly supported this resolution that condemns the use of the death penalty worldwide and calls for the introduction of a moratorium as a step towards its abolition.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: In writing. I must say that this resolution leaves me with an impression of unease, as it puts everything into perspective or mixes everything. It calls for the total abolition of the death penalty at the global level.  It does so in the name of respect, in particular, for human dignity. That of the criminals, of course. For the terrorists? Indulgence! Were they lenient, the terrorists who killed in Paris in January? Do they have leniency, those who send girls to blow themselves up in the middle of markets in Africa? No death penalty for, I quote, "drug-related offences" in the name of absurd international texts. As if large-scale drug trafficking, often linked to other forms of heinous trafficking, was an "offence"! So for the traffickers? Indulgence! And also for serial killers, multi-recidivist assassins! In many cases, the first denial of dignity, the first denial of humanity, the first act of hatred, is the criminal who commits them! It is to the victims, to those whose lives have been interrupted or ransacked, who must first and foremost justice and respect. And sometimes it involves the death sentence of their tormentors.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution on the Death Penalty, as we believe that the death penalty should be abolished in all countries of the world. It is true that within the EU there is unanimity on this issue, however, we believe that many more efforts should be made, mainly in foreign policy. The EU should review its trade policy with third countries that do not comply with international law and do not respect human rights, namely, in this case, the right to life.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the Socialist & Democrats Group, I voted in favour of this resolution reaffirming the EU’s leading role in the drive for the abolition of the death penalty and a moratorium on executions, and calling on the Commission to respond to a number of questions by Parliament about the measures being taken to mainstream in EU foreign policy and external relations the campaign to abolish the death penalty. While progress has been made in a number of countries, there is still a long way to go before the death penalty is abolished worldwide: executions were carried out last year in 22 of the 58 countries and territories in the world that still use the death penalty. The EU needs to do more to push third countries to abolish this despicable practice.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution. Just 17 years old when he was arrested, accused of participating in the anti-government movement, young Ali Al-Nimr was sentenced to death by crucifixion and beheading. These totalitarian and arbitrary judgments clearly violate international law and the moral principles dear to France and the European Union. That is why I strongly condemn these particularly barbaric acts of torture and call on France and the international community to react swiftly and forcefully.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion, as the abolition of the death penalty worldwide is one of the main objectives of the EU’s human rights policy. The latest figures record that 2 466 people in 55 countries are known to have been sentenced to death in 2014 – almost a 23% increase on 2013. We must continue to campaign until this inhumane practice is abolished globally.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution as I believe that the death penalty should be abandoned as a form of punishment. There are profound moral and philosophical grounds for eradicating the death penalty from legal codes worldwide. It is inconsistent with the values of modern democratic societies and human dignity. Especially morally shocking is the use of the death penalty for minors and people with mental or intellectual disability. The EU should collaborate with other players on the international stage to promote the abolishment of the death penalty worldwide. It is also deeply regrettable and morally unacceptable that this form of punishment is being used as a tool of political repression – not to mention the immense cruelty of stoning, which is still being pursued in some regions of the world. In addition, I believe that the euro must be abolished. It leads to dissension and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, more than 106 UN member states have abolished or no longer practice the death penalty, despite different legal systems, traditions, cultures and religious contexts. I welcome the rallying of many States, but do not forget that to date 193 States are members of the organisation and that among these countries, large democracies continue to use the death penalty. That is why I supported this resolution, which calls for a moratorium on the death penalty. I know that this debate is not new and that things are slowly moving, but I remain convinced that the role of the European Union is to keep the debate open and to reaffirm its commitment to the humanist values that are incompatible with this practice.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution on the Death Penalty, as we believe that the death penalty should be abolished in all countries of the world. It is true that within the EU there is unanimity on this issue, however, we believe that many more efforts should be made, mainly in foreign policy. The EU should review its trade policy with third countries that do not comply with international law and do not respect human rights, namely, in this case, the right to life.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the abolition of the death penalty and salute the EU’s paramount aim on this matter – universal abolition. I am also deeply concerned about the number of death sentences delivered in recent months and I believe that such practices violate international human rights standards. Furthermore, it is clear that the death penalty is at odds with the values upon which the EU was founded. The Commission should pay attention in relation to aid and political support flowing towards countries that do not make progress towards abolishing the death penalty.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted for the European Parliament's Resolution on the Death Penalty, as the death penalty is against the principle of humanity and human rights. The abolition of the death penalty is a modern civilizational and democratic reach as well as an achievement of the rule of law. In addition, it is important to take into account the fact that there is a likelihood that someone innocent will be wrongly accused, which has been known to happen, as well as examples of abuse of court proceedings. On the other hand, the fact remains that there are extremely serious crimes, where the gravity of serving a prison sentence is not appropriate to the gravity of the crime committed.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. With my colleagues at the National Front, we are not against the death penalty if it is carried out within a strictly defined legal framework that ensures respect for the rights of the defence and fair trials.  The text put to the vote of the European Parliament has a radically different position. It is about preventing any Member State from re-establishing the death penalty, putting pressure on Belarus, the last European country to do so, restricting trade with countries that have not yet withdrawn it from their legislation, etc. Thus, this proposal intends to interfere in the internal affairs of states.  The moralizing discourse of the European Union on the issue of the death penalty is perfectly inappropriate. As is often the case, the Europeanist elites want to shape the world to their liking and impose their vision on all those who do not share it by questionable means and very disrespectful of the independence of the States and the will of their people.  For these reasons, I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the death penalty, which recalls the European Union's commitment against the death penalty and takes stock of the death sentences handed down and carried out around the world. In particular, the text points to the ineffectiveness of these penalties in combating the crimes they target, as well as the use of the penalty for discriminatory or political purposes in some countries, and welcomes the processes of abolition of the death penalty in a number of countries. This resolution was adopted by a very large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because the death penalty is still present in some countries around the world. The European Parliament must regularly remind that the abolition of the death penalty contributes to the strengthening of human dignity and that the aim remains total abolition at the global level.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The motion for a resolution is clearly opposed to the barbarity of the death penalty and therefore calls for an equally clear EU position on this issue, including in its foreign policy. I am therefore voting in favour of this motion.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. I supported the resolution because I believe that the death penalty must be abolished as a sanction. The moral and philosophical reasons for the removal of the death penalty from the law books worldwide are profound. It is incompatible with the values of a modern, democratic society and human dignity. The use of the measure against minors and persons with a mental disability is particularly shocking. The EU should work internationally with other actors to promote the global abolition of the death penalty. It is equally deeply shocking and morally reprehensible that this form of sanctions should be used as a means of political pressure. Not to mention the cruelty of stonings that are still practised in some regions of the world.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the joint motion for a resolution by several parliamentary groups on the death penalty. Once again, we have condemned the use of the death penalty around the world, in all its forms, more inhumane than the other, including by stoning. We therefore call for a global moratorium on the death penalty and urge the governments of the countries still practicing it to take the necessary measures to abolish it in the name of respect for life and human dignity.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. On 10 October, the 13th World Day Against the Death Penalty will be held on 13 October, an annual event that offers a new opportunity for the EU to re-entrust its international leadership in efforts to abolish capital punishment and for a moratorium on executions.  Although substantial progress has been made in several countries, we are still a long way from achieving global abolition. Of the 58 countries that still include the death penalty in their order, 22 of them were carried out in 2014. In several cases, the number of executions remains alarmingly high or has increased over the past few years.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. I supported the resolution because I believe that the death penalty must be abolished as a sanction. The moral and philosophical reasons for the removal of the death penalty from the law books worldwide are profound. It is incompatible with the values of a modern democratic society and human dignity. The use of the measure against minors and persons with a mental disability is particularly shocking. The EU should work internationally with other actors to promote the global abolition of the death penalty. It is equally deeply shocking and morally reprehensible that this form of sanctions should be used as a means of political pressure. Not to mention the cruelty of stonings that are still practised in some regions of the world.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The death penalty is an utterly cruel, inhuman and degrading punishment that violates the right to life enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The European Union is taking a firm stand against the death penalty. It turned out that the death penalty had no effect on deterring crime and drug trafficking and that most individuals convicted on this basis were at the bottom of the drug trafficking hierarchy.  The European Parliament resolution stresses the necessity of abolishing the death penalty in order to respect human dignity and ethical standards, and calls for an immediate and absolute cessation of this practice. We urge all Member States to continue the fight against the death penalty and call on the Commission to continue funding this project.  I supported the resolution because I am absolutely opposed to the death penalty and support the fight against this inhuman and degrading act. I believe that every person has an innate right to life, and that right must be respected.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – The use of the death penalty in the world is on a downward trend. Nevertheless, there are still countries in the world that use it as a legitimate punishment. Statistics in this area are inaccurate because some countries keep this data secret. The execution of this sentence is often carried out in silence, without communication to the public or family, in a degrading and bitter manner. There is no doubt that this punishment and the way it is executioned is inhumane. History has shown many times that there has been intentional or negligent abuse of this punishment, the consequences of which are irreversible and irreparable. The EU and its Member States reject the existence of the death penalty in the rule of law and advocate its abolition worldwide. I therefore support any initiative taken by the EU institutions and bodies to contribute to this.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Joint Motion for a Resolution on the death penalty for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 6/10/2015 and because the right to life should not be taken away from anyone and in any way. The sentences imposed on a defendant, following a fair trial, must be, on the one hand, punitive and, on the other, dissuasive. On the basis of these principles, it is unacceptable for certain governments, which openly or covertly propose the reintroduction of the death penalty, thus questioning respect for human dignity and human rights. However, for specific heinous crimes or offences, heavy penalties must be imposed, which will be exemplary and dissuasive, but which do not go far enough in imposing the last sentences, which is the imposition of the death penalty. I am therefore in favour of the cessation of the death penalty throughout the world.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support this resolution which ‘Reiterates its condemnation of the use of the death penalty and strongly supports the introduction of a moratorium on the death penalty, as a step towards abolition; emphasises once again that the abolition of the death penalty contributes to the enhancement of human dignity and that the EU’s ultimate aim is universal abolition’.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this decision, which strongly condemns the use of the death penalty and supports the decree for a moratorium with a view to its overall abolition.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report condemns the use of the death penalty and ultimately reaffirms its abolition. The death penalty is not compatible with values such as respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. The report also calls on the Commission to strengthen controls on the export of products that can be used to carry out the death penalty. On the basis of these facts, I supported this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. October 10 is the date of the European and International Day Against the Death Penalty. This year, the day is dedicated to the death penalty applied in cases of drug trafficking. The resolution therefore details the countries practising the death penalty, without omitting to mention the five most active in this area: Iran, Saudi Arabia, Iraq, China and the United States. The resolution reiterates the European Union's position in favour of the abolition of the death penalty and is concerned about exported European products that can be used for torture or execution. Unfortunately, the text does not go any further. The Union cannot contemplate anything that annoys the United States, even if it hates China and Iran. I vote for the abolitionist aspects of this text, while deploring its lack of ambition in this area.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I followed the vote in favour of Parliament's motion for a resolution on the death penalty, affirming the condemnation of all executions, wherever they take place.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it affirms the Union’s commitment to a moratorium on, and an eventual end to, the death penalty internationally. We are against the death penalty wherever it is used.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The need to abolish the death penalty is, for a humanist and a universalist like me, a no-brainer. This extremely serious issue affects the right to life, the right not to be subjected to cruel, inhuman or degrading punishment or treatment, the first of human rights and respect for human dignity. The man who kills man is a disgrace to humanity. Cruel and unacceptable, the death penalty is the negation of humanity, which lives in every human being. It is neither fair nor effective. It is neither sanctimonious, nor intimidating, nor a deterrent. It carries all social poisons, starting with racism and inequality. The abolition of the death penalty therefore meets a goal of universal justice. As European parliamentarians, we have a duty to campaign for the universal abolition of the death penalty in all national and international for a. We must keep this debate alive, weigh on our governments and ensure that respect for life is mentioned in any trade, bilateral or multilateral agreement.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As such, the Union as such has a huge number of outstanding issues today and more are emerging on a daily basis. However, this cannot make us blind to the outside world, as a result of which the death penalty for Europeans often becomes only a fact that they accept. I find it appalling that people in the world are still dying today with the death penalty, but the fact that this method is on an upward trend is sounding alarm bells. I therefore call for the fight against such an inhumane end of life to continue, and I am in favour of introducing a moratorium on the death penalty as a step towards its abolition. According to the available data, we know of at least 2 466 people in 55 countries who were sentenced to death in 2014, an increase of almost 23% compared to 2013. The number of death sentences and executions continues to increase alarmingly in 2015, and even minors and persons with intellectual disabilities or mental retardations are executed, and dozens of Europeans are also at risk of execution in third countries. I am also concerned about the mass trials that have led to a huge number of death sentences, although respect for the right to a fair trial cannot be talked about at all. Finally, I would like to express my support and thank all the institutions, bodies and NGOs for their tireless efforts in the fight against the death penalty.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution, which calls for the abolition of the death penalty worldwide. The 13th World Day Against the Death Penalty is on 10 October 2015 and is an opportunity for the European Union to reaffirm its leading role in the drive for the abolition of the death penalty and a moratorium on executions. While substantial progress has been made in a number of countries, there is still a long way to go before the death penalty is abolished worldwide. In 2014, executions were carried out in 22 of the 58 countries and territories in the world that retain the death penalty. In some of these, unfortunately, the number of executions either remains high or has risen significantly in recent years. The theme of this year’s international day focuses attention on death sentences for drug-related crimes. Contrary to the general trend of recent decades, an increasing number of countries have enacted laws permitting the death penalty for drug-related offences. This development also needs to be addressed by the European Union. The EU guidelines on the death penalty, revised in 2013, state clearly that the death penalty ‘shall also not be imposed for drug-related crimes’.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Verts/ALE, ECR, PPE, EFDD, ALDE, GUE/NGL and S&D political groups submitted a motion for the adoption of a resolution on the death penalty for oral answers. With the exception of the EFDD, the political groups that tabled the motion reached an agreement on the content of the resolution, and I supported the compromise motion.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Portugal was the first European country to adopt the abolition of the death penalty for all civil crimes in the form of a law in the Criminal Reform and Prisons of 1867. It is with this same avant-garde spirit that I support this motion for a Resolution, which strongly condemns the use of the death penalty and supports the introduction of a moratorium on capital punishment as a step towards definitive abolition. We are talking about human dignity and the ultimate objective of the Union's foreign policy, which is universal abolition.  A note to non-governmental organisations and UN agencies that reiterate efforts and present initiatives to encourage states to abolish the death penalty. I believe that the Commission should continue to finance projects in this area through the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal for a joint resolution of the EPP - ALDE - ECR - Greens - GUE focuses on the universal condemnation of the use of the death penalty and supports the immediate establishment of a moratorium with a view to an imminent abolition. In my view, the use of capital punishment should be the responsibility of only States, whether or not they are members of the European Union, according to conceptions determined by the peoples and transcribed into their respective legislative systems, and not international norms and the moral imperialism of the European Union. With the exception of the paragraph condemning the appalling use of the death penalty for political or moral crimes, following the example of Muslim countries applying it for the "crimes" of homosexuality, adultery or apostasy, I voted against this text which also envisages limiting our cooperation with states implementing it as part of their anti-drug policy. Singapore or Indonesia.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 "If we want life, we give life", so Pope Francis speaks of the "responsibility to protect and defend human life at every stage of its development". My vote confirms the sad topicality of these words. In 2015, death sentences and executions continue at an alarming rate. The abolition of the death penalty throughout the world is one of the main objectives of European human rights policy. World Day against the Death Penalty wanted to point out that its application in the case of drug-related crimes is contrary to international law and standards. Death sentences do not discourage drug trafficking or abuse, and countries that retain the death penalty should be encouraged to introduce alternatives that focus on drug prevention and harm reduction programmes. Deeply concerned about the application of the death penalty to children and disadvantaged persons suffering from mental illness belonging to national or cultural minorities; to suppress the opposition; for reasons of religious belief; for homosexuality or adultery; For other reasons which may be considered to be of little importance or not to be considered a crime, the European Parliament calls for this practice to cease immediately and definitively.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution that reiterates the long-standing opposition of the European Union to the death penalty in all cases and under all circumstances, and emphasises once again that the abolition of the death penalty contributes to the enhancement of human dignity.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ ‒ I supported this joint resolution as it highlighted aptly concerns I share about the use of the death penalty internationally, and reaffirmed Europe’s commitment to opposing, and encouraging others to oppose, the use of the death penalty.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it comes at a critical time in the world. Instead of the human rights situation improving, it seems to be deteriorating worldwide. More and more executions take place in Asia, and also in Iran and Saudi Arabia. The penalty is also applied in the USA and Japan and I consider this method of punishment to be barbaric and outdated, no longer in line with modern standards and respect for human rights. In particular, the barbaric and even arbitrary way the death penalty is being used in some countries, including in south-east Asia, coupled with the serious doubts we have over the stability and independence of the judiciaries in these countries, the almost inexistent appeal recourses for people on trial and the low standards of professionalism employed by some of their law enforcement agencies lead to the unavoidable conclusion that innocents are being executed under the guise of a legal death penalty. Death penalty as a practice should be outlawed everywhere in the world immediately!

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the death penalty, which calls for its abolition on a global scale and highlights not only its ineffectiveness, but also its incompatibility with values such as the protection of human rights. I welcome the fact that the resolution specifically mentions states that apply the death penalty, and I could imagine even sharper rhetoric in this regard. In many countries, the death penalty is linked to the trampling of fundamental human rights, and we, as Europeans, should never accept this situation. I therefore want the EU to persevere in its fight against the death penalty and to be even stronger and more consistent in it, for example through the use of development policy instruments.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I believe that the number of death sentences handed down is worryingly high. In 2014, at least 2,466 people were sentenced to death in 55 states, an increase of nearly 23% compared to 2013. In addition, the death penalty was carried out at least 607 times worldwide in 2014.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The European Union must continue to strive to persuade countries practicing the death penalty to abolish it. In many countries, death row deaths have increased and the death penalty also penalises homosexuals, adulterers and people with disabilities, for example. Executions are also carried out, for example, by stoning, which is torture by international standards. This approach to people's lives must end.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The JRC is in favour of abolishing the death penalty. At the same time, however, we note the HYPOCRITICAL attitude of the EU to the issue, which it supports by all means, politically, economically and militarily, the most reactionary states and governments, which use executions to a large extent as a means of oppressing their peoples, as allied forces in its imperialist interventions, as it typically does with oil monarchies and other reactionary urban regimes in the Middle East, North Africa. , South America and elsewhere. The Joint Resolution of the European Parliament even uses the sensitive issue of the death penalty as another vehicle for EU interventions in third countries. It treats it, as in general, 'human rights' and 'democracy' as the EU selectively perceives it, as a pretext for the use of the various EU funds intended to finance such actions ('Stability and Peace Mechanism', 'European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights') to exert pressure and sometimes covertly intervene. , sometimes open to the internal third countries, with the aim of exploiting their sources of wealth and fixing the positions of European monopolies in raging intra-imperialist competition.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the firm belief that the death penalty must be abolished once and for all and that the introduction of a moratorium can contribute to achieving this objective, I would vote in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the death penalty because the abolition of the death penalty worldwide is one of the main objectives of the European Union's human rights policy and because the death penalty is incompatible with values such as respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for the human rights on which the European Union is founded.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I strongly oppose the execution of the death penalty but it still exists in some countries in Africa, the USA, especially China. Recently, the execution of the death penalty has increased, especially in situations where the death penalty is imposed for drug abuse-related crime. The rise of terrorism is also affecting the increase in executions. Under international law, the death penalty can only be ruled in the case of serious crimes, but the imposition of the death penalty for drug abuse or adultery certainly does not fall within the scope of the most serious crimes. The death penalty does not address the problems of drug abuse, human trafficking or terrorism crime. I voted for this resolution because I feel that human life has no price, that it is a precious gift that we have no right to take away from anyone. With the adoption of this Resolution, we are involved in the fight against the degradation of human dignity and endangerment of human rights and we are working on the prevention and abolition of the death penalty, as well as the abolition of stoning and endangering the human dignity of minors and mentally ill people. In addition, it encourages the resolution of real problems through effective solutions such as financing the fight against drug crime, not punishing people.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal for a joint EPP resolution - ALDE - ECR - Greens - GUE focuses on the universal condemnation of the use of the death penalty and supports the immediate implementation of a moratorium for imminent abolition. In my view, the use of capital punishment should be the responsibility of only States, whether or not they are members of the European Union, according to conceptions determined by the peoples and transcribed into their respective legislative systems, and not international norms and the moral imperialism of the European Union. With the exception of the paragraph condemning the appalling use of the death penalty for political or moral crimes, following the example of Muslim countries applying it for the "crimes" of homosexuality, adultery or apostasy, I voted against this text which also envisages limiting our cooperation with states implementing it as part of their anti-drug policy. Singapore or Indonesia.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Given that international agreements and UN opinion list the death penalties as highly permissible in cases of 'serious crimes', data on the increasing number of death sentences for drug abuse but also homosexual relations are alarming. While the EU opposes the death penalty in every form, these specific situations should be condemned in particular and further efforts should be called for and the introduction of a moratorium on the death penalty in all countries should be called for, as a step towards its eventual abolition. I support, in all, efforts to establish greater scrutiny within the EU on the transparency of anti-narcotics support and assistance in countries that carry out the death penalty in order to ensure that this assistance is not used to facilitate law enforcement actions leading to the imposition of death sentences. Furthermore, it should be noted that all data indicate that the death penalty does not combat drug trafficking, and that it is often a court case in which there is no respect for the right to a fair trial. Finally, special attention should be paid to cases of execution of minors, as well as persons with reduced mental or intellectual abilities, and to insist on the immediate cessation of such practices.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. According to the most recent known data in 2014, at least 2466 people in 55 countries were sentenced to death, and in 2014 at least 607 people were executed worldwide, but these are not included persons presumed to have been executed in China, where more death sentences continue to be carried out than in all other countries in the world combined. The number of death sentences imposed and carried out during 2015 remains alarming, as the increase in the number of death sentences imposed is closely linked to court rulings in mass trials that are in response to terrorism-related crimes in countries such as Egypt and Nigeria. The death penalty is often used against socially vulnerable people, mental patients and members of national and cultural minorities. It is important to point out that its abolition contributes to strengthening human dignity and that the EU's ultimate objective is to abolish it altogether. According to the Office of the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, more than 160 United Nations Member States with different legal systems, traditions, cultures and religious practices have abolished the death penalty or do not apply it. The death penalty is inequitable with the values on which the Union is founded, such as respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality and respect for human rights, so I support the Resolution on the Abolition of the Death Penalty.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On the basis of my own convictions and in the light of Article 6 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and Freedoms of the Czech Republic and Article 2 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, I today, of course, voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution re-condemning the death penalty and calling on the countries concerned to introduce a UN moratorium as a step towards the lifting of this sanction. I welcome the Council's assured us that the issue of the death penalty is also topical in dialogue with our partners, such as the US or Japan, regardless of the EU's strategic objectives. 32 of the 50 US states still apply absolute punishment. In 2014, there were 72 convicts and 35 executed. Thousands are on death row, with up to 4% wrong, according to a recent study by Stanford University . It is worth remembering that this is the same country with which we are going to conclude the greatest trade agreement in history. I do not agree with the arguments of colleagues who seek to justify the death penalty in selected countries by classifying and comparing crimes of different legal or non-legal systems. Double standards are absolutely unacceptable on this issue. Mr Schmit today quoted Pope Francis' message to the US Congress: 'A just and necessary punishment must never exclude the dimension of hope and rehabilitation'. I do not understand the church on a number of issues, but here one cannot disagree.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The resolution was adopted by the European Parliament on the occasion of world day against the death penalty, which falls annually on 10 October. One of the main objectives of THE EU's human rights policy is the complete abolition of the death penalty. It is a sad fact that, despite the growing number of countries that have abolished the death penalty, the number of death sentences is increasing, just as some extremely brutal techniques or "wrongdoings" covered by the death penalty persist, such as homosexual relations. In many countries, the death penalty is imposed on minors or persons with intellectual disabilities. This year's anti-death penalty day focused on the death penalty for drug crimes, which have increased by tens of percent in the past 12 months. However, the threat of the death penalty will not deter drug trafficking or stop drug abuse, and the punishment will usually affect those who are part of the drug trafficking network involuntarily. Although the vast majority of the sentences handed down take place outside Europe, it should be recalled that the institute of the death penalty still persists in Belarus, which shares borders with the EU. As the EU's relations with Belarus have been slowly improving recently, we should use our growing negotiating potential to do our utmost to make the death penalty a history for the whole of Europe.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on the death penalty. I appreciate that the prohibition of the death penalty is a priority item in the European Union's human rights policy. It is an inhuman, cruel and humiliating punishment that also violates the right to life enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and Freedoms. Alarmingly, last year the death penalty was handed down in 55 countries to nearly two and a half thousand people, an increase of about twenty-five percent from the previous year. We must not take these numbers lightly. It is therefore also important to express our support for all organisations that have long advocated the abolition of the death penalty worldwide. I very much hope that there will be more countries applying a general moratorium and, in particular, countries that will ban the death penalty altogether.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. While EU Member States have abolished the death penalty, the practice is still used by some states around the world. In 2014, nearly 240 people were still sentenced to death in 55 different countries. And 607 people were executed in 2014. These numbers are revolting. I supported the European Parliament's resolution condemning the practice of the death penalty unilaterally and internationally.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The universal abolition of the death penalty is one of the EU's main human rights objectives.  The death penalty is incompatible with the values on which the EU is founded and, in this regard, it is important to bear witness here of the strong condemnation that its application raises and a call for the European institutions and the Member States to remain attentive to developments in this area and to continue with determination their fight to abolish the use of capital punishment , strongly supporting the moratorium as a step towards such abolition, and insisting on countries still resorting to the death penalty to comply with international minimum standards, reduce its scope and use and publish accurate and unequivocal data on the number of convictions and executions.  I voted in favour.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 On October 10, the World Day Against the Death Penalty is celebrated. The abolition of the death penalty globally remains one of the main objectives of EU human rights policy. In 2014, at least 2,466 people in 55 countries were sentenced to death (up 23% from 2013), not counting China, which condemns more than all other countries combined. The EU continues to condemn the use of the death penalty, a practice incompatible with the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, equality and democracy, which underpine its constitution. This proposal encourages us all, and specifically the Member States, not to give up and make every effort to put an end to this practice with third countries.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 The 13th World Day Against the Death Penalty will be celebrated on 10 October. Even with substantial progress in several countries, we are far from global abolition. Of the 58 countries that still include the death penalty in their order, 22 of them were carried out in 2014. In several cases, the number of executions remains alarmingly high or has increased over the past few years. This year's World Day focuses on sentences issued for drug-related crimes. There are a growing number of countries that have passed death-related laws for drug trafficking offences. EU guidelines on the death penalty specify that such crimes cannot be punished with capital punishment.  We want to know what concrete measures the EU has put in place to advance the abolition of the death penalty, in particular in its bilateral relations with the countries that maintain it and specifically with those where there has been an uptick or restart of this practice. That is why I supported this motion for a resolution.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I signed the proposal for a joint resolution on the death penalty, "considering that the abolition of the death penalty worldwide is one of the main objectives of the European Union's human rights policy". As a humanist, I find it unbearable that executions are still in force. The death penalty is unworthy of the human race. It's an ultimate form of torture. It stems from a desire for revenge and is by no means an appropriate response. Among the convicts are minors, people with mental or intellectual disabilities, individuals convicted because of their sexual orientation... The death penalty is a violation of international standards on fundamental rights, which is why I call for an immediate moratorium on its total abolition. In 2014, at least 2,466 people were sentenced to death in 55 countries, an increase of nearly 23% over 2013. Regardless of the facts alleged against these individuals, deliberately taking their lives is tantamount to denying their humanity. And we cannot accept that.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. On the eve of the 13th World Day Against the Death Penalty, I voted in favour of this resolution, which recalls the European Union's commitment to this struggle.  This 13th World Day focuses in particular on the increase in death sentences for drug-related offences. Thus, as this resolution points out, it is important to remember that the death penalty fails to prevent drug trafficking or prevent anyone from succumbing to drug addiction.  The death penalty remains incompatible with the values defended by the European Union of human dignity, freedom, democracy and fairness.  The resolution also calls for the introduction of a global moratorium on the death penalty, the first step towards its abolition.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the death penalty because I am in favour of abolishing the death penalty, as it violates the right to life recognised by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution on the Death Penalty, as we believe that the death penalty should be abolished in all countries of the world. It is true that within the EU there is unanimity on this issue, however, we believe that many more efforts should be made, mainly in foreign policy. The EU should review its trade policy with third countries that do not comply with international law and do not respect human rights, namely, in this case, the right to life.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution on the Death Penalty as we share its objective: the total abolition of the death penalty and criticism of all the countries in which it is practiced, from the United States to Iran. Moreover, it seems relevant to us that it particularly condemns the death penalty on grounds such as sexual orientation or adultery, which continues to take place in many countries around the world, such as Saudi Arabia.  World Day Against the Death Penalty was celebrated on 10 October 2015, which this year set out to raise awareness of capital punishment in cases of drug-related crimes, which applies in up to 33 countries; in this regard, the Resolution urges the Commission and the European External Action Service to establish the abolition of capital punishment for such crimes as a requirement for aid or support in anti-drug policies. We therefore understand that this resolution reiterates the European commitment, which we share, to combat this type of state crime and urges the Commission to take this into account in all its foreign policy.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this resolution as it calls for the European External Action Service (EEAS) to involve itself in foreign political matters. I do not think the EU should involve itself in foreign affairs.  I did however support the amendments that condemned the use of the death penalty for reasons of religion, sexuality or adultery.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With the 13th World Day Against the Death Penalty approaching, it is perhaps poignant that we have the chance to vote on this motion for resolution. I remain staunchly against the death penalty and I hope that this motion for resolution will once again reaffirm the EU’s commitment to opposing the punishment.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. It is worrying that the number of countries that have passed laws authorising the death penalty for drug-related offences has increased in the last 10 years. The mere fact that 22 countries have carried out executions and at least 2,466 people were sentenced to death in 2014 is worrying. As many as 33 countries around the world apply the death penalty to any drug-related offences, resulting in 1,000 executions per year. There are many European citizens at risk of the death penalty in third world countries, mainly for alleged drug-related crimes. The International Convention of Civil and Political Rights provides, inter alia, that the death penalty should be used only and only for the most serious crimes and should not apply to drug-related crimes. At this point, I would like to stress that the abolition of the death penalty contributes to a better respect for human dignity. Furthermore, I would like to raise concerns about the use of the death penalty for minors and persons who have any mental or intellectual disabilities. Such a practice must stop immediately, as it violates international human rights. For the reasons set out above, I supported the resolution and voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution on the death penalty, which comes just before World Day against the Death Penalty on 10 October 2015 and which aims this year to raise awareness of the application of the death penalty for drug-related crimes. Although more than 160 UN member states have abolished the death penalty or do not practise it, recent but partial data show that nearly 2,500 people in 55 countries were sentenced to death in 2014, an increase of almost 23% on 2013. With this resolution, we call in particular on the European External Action Service and the Member States to continue the fight against the use of the death penalty and to strongly support in all international bodies the introduction of a moratorium as a step towards its abolition. It is only by continuing to exert worldwide pressure to do so, to strongly urge those countries that still practise it to comply with international minimum standards and to provide more transparent information that it will be possible gradually to move towards the abolition of the death penalty, which is a fundamental objective of the EU as a player on the international stage.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Although a number of countries have made significant progress on this front, much still needs to be done to finally abolish the death penalty worldwide, and for this reason it is necessary to continue to support this initiative. In the last year, executions have been carried out in 22 of the 58 states where the death penalty is still in force. This number should continue to be reduced until the full regulation of the death penalty in all countries. Also, a question arises about death sentences for drug-related crimes. More and more countries are legising to allow the death penalty for drug abuse, although EU guidelines for 2013 state that the death penalty is not set for such crimes. The Union needs to address measures in the framework of foreign policy and external relations to campaign for the abolition of the death penalty, and to see what action can be taken when it comes to accountability of third countries. For these reasons, I supported the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution in which the EU reiterates its condemnation of the use of the death penalty and strongly supports a moratorium as a step towards abolition. At least 607 executions took place worldwide in 2014 and executions are occurring at an alarming rate in 2015. The death penalty is incompatible with fundamental values such as respect for human dignity and the rule of law, and so it is essential that the Union expresses in no uncertain terms that the practice is unacceptable.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the death penalty. The abolition of the death penalty in the European Union is a civilisational achievement and one of the EU's main human rights objectives. I support the resolution condemning the death penalty and strongly support the introduction of a moratorium as a step towards its abolition. The abolition of the death penalty worldwide will contribute to strengthening human dignity. I also share the view that the death penalty is absolutely incompatible with respect for human dignity and human rights, freedom, democracy and the rule of law.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's resolution on the death penalty, because I believe that the prohibition of the death penalty is one of the fundamental principles to which the Member States of the European Union subscribe, and whose extension to other countries in the world is desirable and must be supported. I therefore find the proposed text useful, also in the absence of the abolition of the death penalty in individual third countries, but at first only in the absence of it.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Our Movement is in favour of reinstating the death penalty for particularly heinous crimes, such as drug trafficking in large quantities and rape of minors.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the decision with conviction because of the principled importance of the issue. In my vote, I also took into account the topicality: the 13th anniversary of the introduction of World Day Against the Death Penalty (10 October) is a good opportunity for the European Parliament to realise that the European Union remains to be awaiting principled and practical leadership in global efforts to eradicate this inhumane and outdated form of punishment. To this end, I believe it is important that the High Representative and the USSR ensure that, in the EU's external relations, we consistently represent the rejection of the death penalty in multilateral and bilateral contacts against all our partners, unfortunately too many, where this practice still a lives. I consider the resolution to be appropriate to draw attention to the fact that, in its role as flag bearer against the death penalty, the European Union cannot be credible if it tolerates unscrupulous politicians in its own ranks who are trying to make political capital by infusing the menial instincts that live on in society and by sometimes 'waving' the reintroduction of the death penalty, as the Hungarian Prime Minister did recently. I expect our clear resolution now that, in similar cases, the Union will act as decisively in the future as the EP has done in relation to Orban's policies, so that all authoritarian leaders can understand that the threat of the death penalty is a dangerous political adventure that calls into question the essence of democratic exercise of power.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The complete abolition of the death penalty is one of the main objectives of the European Union's human rights policy. Thanks to the actions of international organisations and social change, more than 160 United Nations countries have now waived or are not practicing the death penalty. However, almost 2,500 executions have been carried out in more than 55 countries in the last year, an increase significantly compared to previous years. Of particular concern is the increasing use of the death penalty in the context of the fight against terrorism or drug trafficking.  It is therefore necessary to take further steps of a diplomatic, political and economic nature in order to eliminate this inhumane practice altogether. The European Parliament resolution calls on the European External Action Service, the European Commission and the Member States to step up their efforts to completely abolition of the death penalty worldwide. For these reasons, I have decided to support this resolution.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The death penalty is one of the vestiges of the long-gone eras of humanity, which still persists today in some parts of the world. It constitutes an outdated legal instrument, designed for a type of society based on fear and terror in the face of death in unnatural ways. In the meantime, humanity has progressed and reached a stage that involves a society based on rational arguments and legal instruments designed to ensure the reintegration of troubled individuals into society. From this point of view, the European Union must give a clear message to other international partners and actors that it does not agree with maintaining this practice and become a model for humane resolution of the problem of legal punishments for criminals, including drug traffickers, for states in other parts of the world. In this context, it should be noted that the emphasis should not be on the elimination of the person concerned, for the education for which the State and society have invested important resources, but on the co-ordination of that behaviour and the constructive reintegration of individuals into society, through unfettered access to retraining courses and personal rehabilitation within society. Such an approach is much more advantageous for all of us and for the world we live in.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. With this resolution, we intend to strongly condemn the use of the death penalty and fully support the establishment of a moratorium on the death penalty with a view to its abolition. We stress once again that the abolition of the death penalty contributes to strengthening human dignity. Finally, we are deeply convinced that the abolition of the death penalty is an established ethical standard!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ On the occasion of the World Day Against the Death Penalty, on 10 October 2015, the European Parliament is adopting this resolution, which I supported. It condemns the use of the death penalty and all executions worldwide. Paying particular attention to the death penalty in relation to drug trafficking, it reminds the Commission and the Member States of the recommendation that the abolition of the death penalty for drug-related offences should be made a precondition for any support for drug-law enforcement policy. It urges the European External Action Service, the Commission and the Member States to provide guidance for a comprehensive and effective European death penalty policy with regard to dozens of European nationals facing execution in third countries.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The Death Penalty has no place in the 21st century. Europe has its own position on the death penalty and it is almost unanimous. I am happy that our societies have transcended this outdated method and we are treating even the most serious criminals today as befits people whose civilization was shaped by Christianity. I believe that such a European position on the death penalty should be promoted around the world, especially in relations with those third countries with which strong trade, diplomatic or military partnerships connect us. But in doing so, we must always bear in mind cultural differences and at this delicate political moment choose the means by which we will achieve our goals.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the death penalty, condemning the use of the death penalty as a method of punishment. I believe that the death penalty does not affect the deterrence of crime or drug smuggling. In 2014, at least 2,466 people in 55 states were sentenced to death. As the percentage is higher at the annual level, it is right that the European Parliament should also touch on this issue.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution on the Death Penalty, as we believe that the death penalty should be abolished in all countries of the world. It is true that within the EU there is unanimity on this issue, however, we believe that many more efforts should be made, mainly in foreign policy. The EU should review its trade policy with third countries that do not comply with international law and do not respect human rights, namely, in this case, the right to life.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support such resolution because I am strongly against the death penalty punishment, I think it's a barbarian old method which should be abolished worldwide, starting from Iran and China! I want to refer to Hands off Cain’s 2015 Report, which presents the most important facts regarding the practice of the death penalty in 2014 and the first six months of 2015.  Data shows that China, Iran and Saudi Arabia were the top three “Executioner-Countries” in the world in 2014, while the top executioners of 2015 (as of 30 June) were China, Iran and Pakistan.  I strongly support the ongoing campaign not only against the death penalty, but also its proposals to strengthen the next Pro-Moratorium Resolution that will be voted by the UN General Assembly in 2016.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union maintains a strong opposition of principle to the death penalty, and its abolition is one of the major priorities of human rights policy in the EU. The European Union is the main institutional player in the fight to abolish it. The death penalty is a cruel and inhumane penalty, with much evidence demonstrating that it has no deterrent effect on crime. Its abolition is essential, on the one hand, for the protection of human dignity, freedom, democracy, the rule of law, and, on the other, for the development of human rights. Despite the numerous texts adopted at European and international level in recent years, in 2014 there was an increase of 23% compared to the previous year, with 2466 people convicted in 55 countries. Therefore, with this resolution, the EU reaffirms its concern about the sentencing of the death penalty, in particular for minors and persons with mental disabilities, and calls for the definitive cessation of these practices, which constitute a serious violation of international human rights rules. In view of the increasing use of this sanction, as well as the wishes of other countries to reintroduce it into their national systems, I support the European Parliament resolution on the death penalty.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution on the Death Penalty, as we believe that the death penalty should be abolished in all countries of the world. It is true that within the EU there is unanimity on this issue, however, we believe that many more efforts should be made, mainly in foreign policy. The EU should review its trade policy with third countries that do not comply with international law and do not respect human rights, namely, in this case, the right to life.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I condemn the use of the death penalty and strongly support the declaration of a moratorium on the death penalty as a step towards its abolition; I stress once again that the abolition of the death penalty helps to strengthen human dignity and that the EU's main objective is its complete abolition.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which condemns the use of the death penalty. Europe needs to set up an example by sharing its democratic principles and firmly calling for an end to the inhuman practice of the death penalty around the world. The ultimate goal is to achieve the total abolition of the death penalty, not only in Europe – where Belarus remains the last country to retain and apply capital punishment – but also in the United States, which should commit to abolishing this terrible practice as soon as possible.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. By this motion for a resolution, this Parliament expresses its strong condemnation of the death penalty and calls on the European Commission, the European External Action Service and Member States to continue to fight the death penalty in third countries. That is why I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU has always worked to marginalise the death penalty and establish a moratorium on its use. However, it is worrying that the long-term decline in the number of executions worldwide has been reversed in the past few years, with 2013-2014 showing a 23% increase in the number of executions. Given that several nations which practice the death penalty have been in receipt of European aid to fund anti-narcotics programmes, there is a real concern that executions could, in essence, have been funded by the EU. It is imperative that we increase the transparency of this aid package so that we can rest assured that European money is not underwriting the continuing use of the death penalty, as this would be an affront to our European values and a contravention of EU guidelines on the death penalty, as well as Article 2 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and Protocols 6 and 13 of the European Convention on Human Rights. By extending our oversight, the Commission can allow European taxpayers to rest easy, knowing that their money is not being used to fund state-sanctioned killing. Therefore, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. On 10 October it was world day against the death penalty and a few months ago Mr Orban came to the European Parliament to announce that he was thinking of reintroducing the death penalty. Reason enough to highlight this barbaric punishment. Firstly, it has never been shown that judicial execution would have a deterrent effect on crime. On the other hand, it has been proven that a lot of innocent people are executed every year. The idea behind the 'modern' death penalty also contains an immense contradiction: we are not going to brutally slaughter the condemned with a guillotine, no, we pretend to have the decency to do so in a 'civilised' way. The result remains the same: we deprive someone of the right to life, a right we agreed in 1948 with the Declaration of Human Rights that it would be inalienable. Hypocrisy is the pitfall for this so-called 'ethical' thinking. The abolition of the death penalty is not only morally the right choice, it is also clearer, more just and it is a choice that transcends the flame politics and stands the test of time.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In the last 12 months, there has been a resurgence worldwide in the application of the death penalty for drug-related crimes, with states where the number of executions for these crimes has increased significantly (such as Iran and Saudi Arabia). Other states seek to reintroduce the death penalty for drug-related crimes (such as Oman), and some states have ended the moratorium on the long-enforced death penalty (as is the case in Indonesia and Pakistan). Of the 14 countries that apply the death penalty for drug-related offenses, 12 are Asian or Middle Eastern countries. In 2015, 14 people were executed in Indonesia for drug trafficking, including 12 foreigners. Dozens of people are awaiting execution on death row, including European citizens such as Frenchman Serge Atlaoui. At a time when the European day against the death penalty is being celebrated, it is time to express our opposition to this practice, which is an affront to the dignity of the human being, and to hope that these recent trends will not jeopardise the progress made over the last century in this respect.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report condemns the use of the death penalty and ultimately reaffirms its abolition. The death penalty is not compatible with values such as respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. The report also calls on the Commission to strengthen controls on the export of products that can be used to carry out the death penalty. On the basis of these facts, I supported this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. On 10 October, the international community is commoing its International Day against the Death Penalty. The European Parliament is making its contribution to this with this own initiative resolution. In many countries – Pakistan, Nigeria, Afghanistan, Iran, Iraq, Yemen, Sudan, Somalia, and Saudi Arabia – people are still sentenced to death by stoning. Hundreds of women have been stoned in these countries for adultery in recent years. Countless people from this culture are currently migrating unchecked and en masse to the EU Member States – and especially to Germany. However, a state governed by the rule of law, which at the same time sees itself as a state of culture, cannot legitimise the creation of the death of a person 'of its own motion'. The abolition of the death penalty can break the vicious circle of violence. There are more hopeful and effective means of countering the increase in violent crime. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D)
text: Writing. 10 October marks the 13th anniversary of the European Day against the Death Penalty. That is why we must once again and again consistently speak out against the death penalty. Although some progress has been made towards abolition in recent years, the death penalty for drug offences was 23% more common worldwide in 2014 compared to the previous year.  We know that death sentences have little deterrent effect. They therefore do not contribute to the restriction of drug trafficking, nor do they prevent individuals from drug abuse. The debate on a death sentence for drug offences is illegal under various international conventions, such as the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Convention on Human Rights. The punishment is not appropriate for the crime. That is why the Commission and the Member States should support the abolition of the death penalty and support projects to combat drug abuse.  The use of the death penalty in general, but especially for drug offences or homosexual acts, does not correspond to the values of the European Union. The abolition of the death penalty should be a prerequisite for financial and technical support for anti-drugs projects. European support must not be linked to a judiciary that issues death sentences and, in the worst case, also executes them. The ultimate objective of the European Union must be the complete abolition of the death penalty.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The JRC is in favour of abolishing the death penalty. At the same time, however, we note the HYPOCRITICAL attitude of the EU to the issue, which it supports by all means, politically, economically and militarily, the most reactionary states and governments, which use executions to a large extent as a means of oppressing their peoples, as allied forces in its imperialist interventions, as it typically does with oil monarchies and other reactionary urban regimes in the Middle East, North Africa. , South America and elsewhere. The Joint Resolution of the European Parliament even uses the sensitive issue of the death penalty as another vehicle for EU interventions in third countries. It treats it, as in general, 'human rights' and 'democracy' as the EU selectively perceives it, as a pretext for the use of the various EU funds intended to finance such actions ('Stability and Peace Mechanism', 'European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights') to exert pressure and sometimes covertly intervene. , sometimes open to the internal third countries, with the aim of exploiting their sources of wealth and fixing the positions of European monopolies in raging intra-imperialist competition.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this motion for a resolution because I consider it to be an expression of one of the most important long-term EU policies for strengthening human rights in the world. I praise the EU efforts invested in combating torture and the death penalty. The need to abolish these inhuman practices should be further highlighted. We must aim especially at abolition of the death penalty for drug-related crimes and acts which should not be considered as crime. I also believe that we need to lead a constructive dialogue with one of our most important partners, the United States, to prevent further executions in that country. I would like to see the Commission preserving the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights, while increasing its effectiveness and its geographical scope.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have, of course, supported the resolution on the death penalty. The abolition of the death penalty worldwide is one of the European Union's most important human rights objectives, as well as one of the accession criteria for states wishing to become part of it. And yet the figures published on World Day Against the Death Penalty are more than alarming. And that does not include the number of death sentences carried out in China, which reportedly executes more people than the rest of the world combined. I condemn all kinds of application of the death penalty, whether it is a link to drug offences or, in particular, the use of that punishment as a means of politically combating political opposition. And its application to minors, persons with mental or mental disabilities, or the death penalty by sedation for adultery, is also particularly serious. I share the view that the death penalty is totally incompatible with human dignity, freedom, democracy and human rights, and I am of the opinion that every human being has the right to respect for his or her natural right to life, human dignity, as well as the right to due and fair trial. I therefore fully support any such resolution which strongly condemns the use of the death penalty and encourages its abolition.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We condemn the death penalty and advocate its abolition. We regret that capital punishment is still applied by at least 55 countries, and we are concerned about the growing trend of promoting the discussion for the reversal of the abolition of the death penalty by some countries, particularly in Europe.  We are generally in accordance with the content of the resolution. We cannot fail, however, to note elements of the usual hypocrisy imposed by the majority of the European Parliament, in the considerations made with traces of interference and in the discrepancy of the analysis, where, for example, it is not in the same way the maintenance of capital punishment in countries such as the USA and China, or when the European External Action Service is placed as an instrument in the fight against capital punishment , the same instrument that promotes aggression interventions in third countries responsible for the deaths of hundreds of people. Despite these observations, we voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the resolution against the death penalty because it is an initiative that I have carried out in parallel with the DROI Committee, implementing the text in particular with content against the practice of stoning. The condemnation of this atrocious torture, which is still present in countries such as Iran, Sudan, Pakistan, Afghanistan, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Yemen, is in fact the result of a long journey born thanks to the reports of some associations of Iranian exiles and continued through the organization of events both on the territory and in the European Parliament that have contributed to raising awareness among civil society and other Parliamentarians on the subject.
