To date, the death penalty by stoning is one of the most atrocious violations of international human rights standards and particularly afflicts women who, without the possibility of defending themselves in court, are killed in stone, mainly for adultery or even because they report rape. A cruel, inhuman and degrading punishment that countries are now called upon to abolish by law.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: –'The purpose of the sentence is to avoid preventing the offender or others from committing a crime in the future.' Why am I Hungary passage from the Hungarian Penal Code in connection with one of the greatest recent tragedies of the year, the red sludge disaster? That's because I don't think the argument that we should stop caring about what happened is wrong. Let's not look to the past, look to the future, try to prevent another disaster like this from happening again. In order to fulfil the obligation of prevention, the conclusions and consequences of the tragedy in relation to accountability must be drawn. Precisely in order to identify the perpetrators and their responsibilities, we serve the purpose and principle of prevention.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Thank you, Mr President. Five years ago, Hungarians suffered the most serious industrial as well as ecological disaster in their country's history. As a result, ten people died and one and a half hundred were injured. I would like once again to express my sincere condolences to the families of the victims and to the Hungarian people. In general, europe's most recent history has been the scene of major disasters, which have caused huge losses, such as the oil spill of the PRESTIGE tanker in Gryi, in 2002, but fortunately no one died at that time. However, there is a large difference between disasters, which are very difficult even in theory to predict, and those where problems were systematically accumulated, and often failed to put safety techniques into practice. Given that there are still several factories and other institutions in Europe where health and life-threatening materials are processed or stored, it is absolutely necessary to actively inform people living side-by-side about the current situation.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: Five years ago, the biggest industrial Hungary in the history of the world, the red sludge disaster, occurred. In this context, the Committee on the Environment referred oral questions to the Commission and the Council. Specific questions: what measures, changes in legislation, will you take to ensure that this never happens again, or what financial resources the claims settlement may have if it does occur.  Unfortunately, we did not get a substantive response from the Commission in the debate. I am therefore pleased that this subject has also been followed by the submission and adoption of a proposal for a decision, which sets clear tasks, clear deadlines, states the enforcement of the polluter pay principle and provides the basis for the establishment of a mandatory, harmonised financial security. On this basis, I supported the decision.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Resolution addresses the disaster that occurred on 4 October 2010 in Hungary, when the rupture of a raft of waste freed almost one million cubic meters of red mud (a waste from the highly alkaline extractive industries) that flooded several villages and left 10 people dead, 150 wounds and large areas of contaminated land, including four Natura 2000 spaces.  I voted in favour of the Resolution, since, inter alia, it points to the risk in a number of Member States of a repeat of a similar catastrophe due to the poor application of environmental legislation; calls for more inspections on waste rafts; highlights the existence of serious environmental pollution problems in several Member States due to mining activities (e.g. the use of cyanide in gold mines); requests the Commission, on the occasion of the current revision of the Environmental Responsibility Directive, to ensure that the proposed review fully implements the 'polluter pays' principle, or to involve local authorities, citizens and civil society in the decision-making process on the disposal of hazardous waste and in the planning of risk management measures.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Five years ago, Hungary was facing a ruptured waste tank, which had dramatic consequences. The red sludge produced during the manufacture of alumina and aluminum had caused the death of ten people.  Following this accident, Parliament wants to establish a legislative framework to prevent this kind of disaster.  The sad anniversary of this event is a good pretext to increase the powers of the Union to the detriment of its Member States, to call for 'always more Europe'. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Having sympathy with the victims of this terrible disaster, I abstained on the final vote. Nevertheless, much of the content of the report calls for more European action. Once again, a need for legislation in one Member State is taken as a green light for action in all 28.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. In the wake of the so-called "red sludge" disaster on 4 October 2010, I voted in favour of this deliberation, which aims to learn from it to prevent this from happening again in the future.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the red sludge disaster. October 4, 2010 In Hungary, almost 1 million tonnes of waste spilled out of waste storage. cubic meters of very high alkalinity red slag, which flooded several villages and caused 10 deaths and almost 150 injuries. This catastrophe is linked to poor implementation of EU legislation, insufficient checks, gaps in relevant EU legislation and the performance of the storage manager. Unfortunately, this catastrophe has not been learned as the relevant EU legislation and international conventions continue to be misunderstood, and checks continue to be inadequate. I support the calls for the Commission to pay more attention to research and development in the field of prevention and the management of hazardous waste. The Commission should develop guidelines for stress tests in existing mines equipped with large waste storage facilities.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, in which wishful thinking comes to the eurocrats' leitmotif, repeated as a litany: 'always more Europe', i.e. further strengthening the Commission's powers and powers to the detriment of the Member States.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this resolution in which Parliament first commemorates the victims of the red sludge disaster and recalls the support that has been given to Hungary in civil protection and the development of recommendations to eliminate and mitigate the damage caused.  Five years later, the resolution sets out the positive and negative lessons of this red sludge disaster, a dangerous waste that had caused the pollution of vast areas of land. In particular, Parliament underlines its concern at the lack of awareness in recent years of the need to compensate for the poor implementation of European legislation, which is the cause of the industrial disaster.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the conclusions drawn from the red mud disaster five years after the accident in Hungary. It was the worst industrial accident in the history of the country and you don't have to forget its victims. The intervention of the authorities was effective and the immense efforts of civil society commendable and unprecedented. But we must be vigilant so that there are no similar sites in other countries of the Union.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. On 4 October 2010 in Hungary, the rupture of a waste tank caused considerable pollution and the death of ten people. These were red sludge, produced during the manufacture of alumina and aluminum. This motion for a resolution on the lessons learned from the red sludge disaster, five years after the accident in Hungary, should allow for the development of a legislative framework to prevent these disasters, but this naturally implies a greater grip on the European Union. The positive point, which is to call for a strengthening by the Member States of their national environmental inspection bodies, unfortunately remains drowned out by calls for ever more Europe. So I decided to vote against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the issues raised in the resolution recalling the environmental disaster caused by the industrial accident in Ajka, Hungary in 2010. I believe that the Member States should do more to fill the regulatory gaps in the application of EU law and international environmental conventions in order to protect our citizens, our territories and prevent similar future disasters.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 The rupture of a raft of waste from a mining company on 4 October 2010 caused a red mud tide of one million cubic meters that caused ten dead, 150 injured and flooding of several municipalities and vast areas of land, including four spaces of high ecological value, and highlighted the lack of implementation of EU legislation and significant deficiencies in inspections.  I have supported this Resolution which criticises the lack of adequate implementation of European legislation and international conventions in this area both in Hungary and in other Member States. As he rightly points out, disaster prevention needs to be strengthened through research, the development of hazardous waste treatment and the implementation of stricter environmental inspections.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution, which deals with the situation regarding the disaster in Hungary, when, on 4 October 2010, the Commission adopted a proposal for a directive on the In Hungary, almost 1 million tonnes of waste spilled out of waste storage. cubic meters of very high alkalinity red sludge. It flooded several villages, killed 10 people and injured nearly 150 and contaminated vast areas of land, including four Natura 2000 sites. This red-sweeping accident is the worst industrial disaster in Hungary. During this time, the national authorities responded swiftly and effectively to the accident, and civil society made great efforts to help in the disaster. However, the European Parliament is concerned that the experience of the past five years seems to have not been learned in practice and the lack of implementation of the relevant EU legislation and international conventions, the continuation of inadequate checks, and the fact that almost no gaps in the relevant EU legislation have been filled in the meantime. In addition, there are concerns that similar sites exist in several Member States, and Parliament therefore calls on all Member States that have red sludge tanks to check that red sludge is properly classified as hazardous waste as soon as possible and to correct all authorisations with incorrect classification.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support this question, raised about the lesson learned from the environmental disaster that occurred in Hungary five years ago. The collapse of the waste tank at the aluminum plant at the time, where there was heavy pollution caused by red mud, and over 150 injuries should be a warning to all of us. Proper implementation of EU laws and addressing shortcomings in inspections are key measures so that this sort of thing does not happen again in the future, and the fight for a clean environment must be a priority for us, not only for us, but for the many generations that come after us.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In the wake of this tragic disaster we would like once again to express our support and solidarity for Hungary and its people. With regard to EU proposals of intervention to prevent similar situations in the future, we believe that implementing laws in order to prevent similar accidents should be a governmental competence of each Member State. We oppose the creation of further EU regulation in this field and we oppose the introduction of an EU environmental inspections law.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is important for the Eu ropean Union to learn from its mistakes in order to prevent further industrial disasters of this kind from happening again in the future.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. October 4, 2010 was marked by the rupture of a waste reserve, composed of red sludge, from the manufacture of aluminum. The accident caused an ecological disaster and killed 10 people. It is in this context that this motion for a resolution attempts to provide solutions to improve the legislative framework so that such a tragedy is no longer relived.  While the text calls on EU Member States to strengthen their environmental legislation, particularly through supervisory bodies, it proposes above all to give more power to European bodies. This tragic event is therefore being hijacked by the Europeanists to grant the Commission additional prerogatives.  That is why I voted against it.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The resolution refers to this serious environmental disaster in Hungary five years ago. There is concern that almost no lessons have been learned by Member States in these five years, as the deficient application of EU rules and relevant international conventions continues, as well as deficiencies in inspections. Member States are therefore being asked to do more to fill these gaps.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 'red sludge disaster', an environmental accident in the town of Ajka in Hungary five years ago caused by the rupture of a catchment area, with the spillage of about a million cubic metres of high-level red sludge that flooded several villages, killing ten people , injuring nearly 150, polluting vast expanses of land and causing ruins to local flora and fauna. Although the rapid and effective intervention of national authorities and hungary's activation of the EU civil protection mechanism effectively mitigated the damage caused to the territory, the accident highlighted the poor implementation of EU rules. It is therefore necessary to strengthen national environmental inspection bodies, in particular by ensuring their independence and by providing them with adequate resources to enable transparent and cyclical controls to be carried out on industrial sites.  Therefore, in order to give greater emphasis to the prevention of environmental disasters, as well as to arrive quickly at a legislative proposal on environmental inspections, I have decided to vote in favour of the text.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted on the resolution ‘Lessons learned from the red mud disaster five years after the accident in Hungary’. In the wake of this tragic disaster we would like once again to express our support and solidarity for Hungary and its people. With regard to EU proposals of intervention to prevent similar situations in the future, we believe that implementing laws in order to prevent similar accidents should be a governmental competence of each Member State. We oppose the creation of further EU regulation in this field and we oppose the introduction of an EU environmental inspections law.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ There are certainly many lessons that can be learned from the red mud disaster in Hungary. We must take steps to prevent the loss of lives as wells as destruction of the environment. This is an opportunity to strengthen, and focus more closely on, the implementation of EU law, as an analysis of the causes of the disaster showed that there were links between the spill and non-compliance with EU law. Hence not only Hungary but all Member States can learn from this. I agree that more control and preventive measures need to be introduced. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because it calls on the Commission to provide a number of guarantees which I believe are essential, such as: greater attention to research and development for the prevention and treatment of hazardous waste; to strengthen national environmental inspection bodies in order to better carry out checks on industrial sites; present a legislative proposal on environmental inspections and implement a mandatory financial guarantee system for all industrial sites, as well as further develop the idea of an EU-wide mechanism for sharing the risks of industrial disasters, funded by a harmonised insurance premium on a scale. The Commission and the Member States are also asked to ensure transparency in the financial aspects relating to the repair of damage caused by environmental disasters, including the economic compensation of victims. Finally, I welcome the fact that our amendment on access to justice has been adopted.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on the lessons learned from the destruction of red sludge, five years after the accident in Hungary, underlines the importance of involving local authorities, citizens and civil society in the decision-making process concerning the disposal of hazardous waste and in the design of risk management measures. The Commission is also called upon to further elaborate on the concept of a pan-European mechanism for sharing industrial destruction, with full respect for the polluter pays principle, in order to cover any costs beyond a high level of compulsory financial guarantees.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution on the lessons learned from the red sludge disaster, five years after the accident in Hungary. On 4 October 2012, the leakage of a slurry tank caused the escape of red sludge with a high alkaline rate, considered hazardous waste, causing the death of 10 people and the wounding of almost 150 and huge damage to four Natura 2000 sites. However, the Environmental Liability Directive has not been properly transposed and implemented at Eu ropean level. With this motion for a resolution, the EP recalls that Hungary has activated the EU protection mechanism and that the authorities have acted promptly. However, the red sludge disaster is linked to the non-implementation of EU legislation. The report calls on the Commission and the Member States to step up their efforts to ensure the correct application of EU legislation and reiterates its call on the Commission to present a legislative proposal on environmental inspections.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because I recall that it was the worst industrial disaster ever to happen in Hungary, causing the deaths of ten people, the wounding of almost 150 and the contamination of vast expanses of land. In view of the risk that, in the past, red sludge may have been wrongly classified as non-hazardous waste in other Member States as well and that it has therefore been released, I call on the latter to ensure that the appropriate inspections, which are essential to safeguard European citizens, are carried out. Finally, in accordance with the proposal, I believe it is necessary to place greater emphasis on disaster prevention by drawing up guidelines for testing the resistance of mines with large decanting basins for infertile.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted on the resolution ‘Lessons learned from the red mud disaster five years after the accident in Hungary’. In the wake of this tragic disaster we would like once again to express our support and solidarity for Hungary and its people. With regard to EU proposals of intervention to prevent similar situations in the future, we believe that implementing laws in order to prevent similar accidents should be a governmental competence of each Member State. We oppose the creation of further EU regulation in this field and we oppose the introduction of an EU environmental inspections law.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 An analysis of hungary's situation, carried out five years after the ecological disaster, showed that the European Union has not been effectively engaged in strengthening European legislation and implementing environmental and health regulations. The Environmental Liability Directive (2004/35/EC) has been poorly implemented in the Member States and there are still many obstacles to be overcome, such as the lack of inspections in basins containing substances with a high alkaline content, the control of mining activities and the use of measures for the disposal of industrial waste. I hope that this motion for a resolution on protection against environmental risks will make European businesses and citizens aware of their responsibility towards the territory, thereby strengthening the Community 'polluter pays' principle. In order to improve European legislation in this area, national legislation and control measures should be harmonised. Member States should strengthen their national inspection mechanisms in order to ensure transparent, regular and systematic controls of industrial sites, while avoiding creating additional administrative burdens for businesses.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2010, the red sludge disaster in Hungary threatened the lives of many people, caused casualties and injuries and endangered the health of the environment and in particular the fauna and water aquifers of drinking water. This is the disaster at the Ajka aluminium factory, which has poured at least one million cubic metres of red sludge from open-air tanks into an area of at least 40 km2. The motion for a resolution calls on the Commission and the Member States to continue and improve research into the prevention and treatment of hazardous waste in order to avoid future environmental disasters. It aims to implement a bill that can guarantee environmental inspections and implement a compulsory financial guarantee system and economic transparency on environmental and people's compensation.  With regard to the principles of the European Union's environmental policy, I am in favour of this.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Resolution addresses the disaster that occurred on 4 October 2010 in Hungary, when the rupture of a raft of waste freed almost one million cubic meters of red mud (a waste from the highly alkaline extractive industries) that flooded several villages and left 10 people dead, 150 wounds and large areas of contaminated land, including four Natura 2000 spaces.  I voted in favour of the Resolution, since, inter alia, it points to the risk in a number of Member States of a repeat of a similar catastrophe due to the poor application of environmental legislation; calls for more inspections on waste rafts; highlights the existence of serious environmental pollution problems in several Member States due to mining activities (e.g. the use of cyanide in gold mines); requests the Commission, on the occasion of the current revision of the Environmental Responsibility Directive, to ensure that the proposed review fully implements the 'polluter pays' principle, or to involve local authorities, citizens and civil society in the decision-making process on the disposal of hazardous waste and in the planning of risk management measures.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the red sludge disaster is linked to poor implementation of EU legislation, shortcomings in inspections and legislative gaps, relevant EU legislation and international conventions continue to be not properly applied and shortcomings in inspections persist at national level. I voted in favour of this resolution because it calls on the Commission and the Member States to step up their efforts to ensure the full implementation of EU legislation and all international conventions on the ecologically correct management of red sludge and hazardous waste in general. I also agree with the idea of developing a European mechanism for sharing the risks of industrial disasters.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament's resolution focuses on the lessons learned from the red sludge disaster in Hungary five years ago and reiterates the need for common solutions and cooperation in Europe in the event of and prevention of environmental and industrial disasters. Ten people were killed, many wounded, and the mudslity flooding the affected villages caused significant environmental damage, and we are talking about the worst industrial disaster in Hungary history of the colony. Rescue and recovery work following the colonial accident has become a symbol of unity. The resolution adopted was adopted with multiparty agreement, and I voted in favour of its text. I would like to point out that the decision points to the future and calls on the European Commission to continue its work on the creation of an EU disaster insurance system capable of applying the polluter pays principle even in the event of large industrial disasters. As long as there are no mandatory financial guarantees, the polluter will not be able to compensate for the damage caused by him, the polluter-pays principle will not be able to apply in practice. This poses a risk in the event of each industrial accident. Tightening up facility controls without bureaucratic constraints and promoting the use of appropriate technologies by Member States play an important role in preventing similar disasters in the future.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which highlights that even now Hungary and other Member States with mining plants should be correctly implementing EU laws. Furthermore, it is important that legislation be reinforced and properly applied. I agree with the resolution which states that there needs to be a stronger emphasis on disaster prevention, through research and development into the treatment of hazardous waste, and by more stringent environmental inspections.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe and reinforce the idea expressed in this motion for a resolution, namely: the Commission must further develop the concept of an EU-wide instrument for risk-sharing in the event of industrial disasters, in full compliance with the polluter pays principle, in order to cover any costs beyond a high level of mandatory financial guarantees.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. On 4 October 2010, the rupture of a waste reservoir in Hungary resulted in the dumping of nearly one million cubic metres of highly alkaline red sludge, causing flooding in several villages, killing ten people, injuring nearly 150 people and polluting large areas of land, including four Natura 2000 sites. This accident highlighted the poor implementation and shortcomings of European legislation. Knowing that similar sites exist in several Member States, this resolution aims to challenge the Council on the lessons learned from the accident. We also call on Member States and the European Commission to ensure better enforcement of EU legislation and to consider additional measures to eliminate pollution from mining activities in the future. Supporting these objectives, I voted for the resolution.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. In October 2010, 700,000 m3 of corrosive mud spilled after the tank of an aluminum plant in Hungary, west of Budapest, ruptured, killing 10 people and burning 150. This resolution is a reminder of our commitments from this industrial disaster. We pay tribute to the victims of this tragic event while intensifying our efforts to regulate the manufacture of aluminum and the management of red sludge in an environmentally friendly manner. More generally, this resolution calls for better management of our hazardous waste.  I have reservations about a paragraph to develop a legislative proposal on access to justice in the environment by the end of 2016. I am in my policy for access to justice in the area of the environment, however such a proposal is not feasible by the end of 2016. This deserves reflection and work so that its development and application are perfect. This resolution on the lessons learned from the red sludge disaster, five years after the accident, is very important anyway, which is why I voted for it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour because strict controls on industrial waste are needed. Although Hungary has made great efforts since the destruction of red sludge, the legislation must be tightened up and the same for everyone.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted on the resolution ‘Lessons learned from the red mud disaster five years after the accident in Hungary’. In the wake of this tragic disaster we would like once again to express our support and solidarity for Hungary and its people. With regard to EU proposals of intervention to prevent similar situations in the future, we believe that implementing laws in order to prevent similar accidents should be a governmental competence of each Member State.We oppose the creation of further EU regulation in this field and we oppose the introduction of an EU environmental inspections law.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The collapse of a waste reservoir in Hungary has poured nearly one million cubic metres of highly alkaline red slous slats and flooded several villages, killing ten people, injuring about 150 and polluting vast areas, including four Natura 2000 sites. It was the most serious industrial disaster in Hungary and I pay tribute to the victims on the occasion of the fifth anniversary of this tragic event. It is necessary to draw consequences and compliance with EU law and international conventions is urgently needed.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it is a hidden call, once again, for more European federalism.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The bursting of a reservoir of toxic slamas from an aluminium oxide plant has contaminated several villages and towns in Hungary. Ten people died, 150 were injured. This accident has put the poor application and potholes of environmental legislation on industrial toxic waste in the EU. This isn't the first time accidents like this have happened. This was the biggest. The resolution calls for efforts to understand the current situation of mine waste, its management and treatment. Further investment is needed in research and development of the prevention and treatment of this type of toxic waste. It is called for compliance with the polluter pays principle (we underline: in its original meaning, without the sprains that were subsequently introduced to it, seeking to transmute it into a different user-pays principle). Stricter environmental rules for environmental inspections are advocated, alongside sufficient means for the national bodies responsible for these inspections. Regular information to the public on pollution levels and degrees of threat to ecosystems and public health is advocated. Despite some doubts about some of the proposals put forward (such as the suggested risk-sharing instrument), we voted in favour.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as it calls for positive developments for environmental practices.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report calling on The Member States to do more to fill the regulatory gaps, bearing in mind the Hungarian case mentioned.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. I am voting in favour of this report because strict controls on industrial waste are needed. Although Hungary has made great efforts since the destruction of red sludge, the legislation must be tightened up and the same for everyone.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Poor implementation of EU laws, deficiencies in inspections and gaps in relevant EU legislation are issues that, if not addressed effectively, can lead to a situation similar to the one exposed by the red mud disaster in  Hungary and in some neighbouring countries. It seems that, even now, Hungary and other Member States with similar mining plants are not correctly implementing EU laws; that legislation needs to be reinforced and properly applied; and that nothing is being learned from the disasters of the past. I therefore strongly support the call for greater emphasis on disaster prevention through research and development into the treatment of hazardous waste, and for more stringent environmental inspections. The Commission and the Member States must step up efforts to improve, and ensure the proper implementation of, all EU legislation governing the extractive waste industry so as to avoid a repeat of such an environmental and human disaster. Let us protect the environment more effectively. Let us fight pollution. Let us fight climate change!

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution in considering the serious consequences of breaking a waste raft in Hungary that freed almost one million cubic metres of highly alkaline red mud that flooded several villages, claimed the lives of 10 people, injured nearly 150 and contaminated large areas of land. Despite the tragedy experienced, similar sites continue to exist in several Member States, so we must ensure that adequate inspections are carried out and that red sludge is correctly classified as hazardous waste.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the resolution 'Lessons from the red sludge disaster in Hungary , five years after the accident', because I believe that we are learning lessons after disasters far too rarely and far too slowly in Europe and around the world. That needs to change. We have to learn.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the motion for a resolution on the lessons learned from the red sludge disaster in Hungary. We must ensure that appropriate inspections are carried out and that the red sludge is rightly classified as hazardous waste.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This series of proposed regulations represents the latest encroachment upon the sovereignty of Member States by this organisation (the EU). The Hungarian people were the ones affected by this disaster and it should be for their elected representatives in their parliament to determine how best to avoid a similar disaster in the future, and not for the unelected Commission to impose its will on an entire industry and an entire people – potentially at the cost of that entire industry and the jobs it sustains. That is why I abstained in this vote.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. "U2012 Five years after the environmental disaster that affected Hungary, it is a good time to remember the importance of respect for European environmental regulations. We therefore call on the Commission and the Member States to intensify their efforts to ensure the full implementation and proper implementation of all EU legislation and all international conventions on the environmentally sound management of hazardous waste.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, which is trying to take over, now that five years of the accident in Hungary have passed, where we are at and where a stricter waste policy has to go. We note here the question in its exhibition phase: on October 4, 2010, the rupture of a raft of waste in Hungary released almost one million cubic meters of highly alkaline red mud. It flooded several villages, claimed the lives of ten people, wounded nearly 150 and contaminated large areas of land, including four natura 2000 network spaces. The accident highlighted the poor application of EU legislation, deficiencies in inspections and gaps in relevant EU legislation. We hope that this question and the subsequent resolution will draw attention to the Commission and that the Commission will focus its efforts on assessing waste bag assessment methods so that these catastrophes do not recur. We also expect a consistent sanctions policy and a subsidy policy equally in cases where the law is broken or complied with.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion, as there is a grave concern that almost no lessons seem to have been learned in the past five years, as poor implementation of the relevant EU laws and international conventions, as well as inspection deficiencies, continue and almost none of the gaps in the relevant EU legislation have since been closed. In order to prevent the recurrence of disasters, in which valuable lives are lost, we must address these matters abruptly and firmly.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. On 4 October 2010, the rupture of a waste reservoir in Hungary resulted in the dumping of nearly one million cubic metres of highly alkaline red sludge, flooding in several villages, the death of ten people, the death of nearly 150 people and the polluting of vast areas of land, including four Natura 2000-listed sites. This disaster is the most serious industrial disaster in Hungary in decades.  On the occasion of the fifth anniversary commemorating this tragic accident, it is important to remember how responsible management of industrial sites and better disaster prevention are essential to prevent such accidents from happening again. That is why I have unhesitatingly supported this resolution, which reminds us of our responsibility as a legislator on environmental and environmental matters.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, which is trying to take over, now that five years of the accident in Hungary have passed, where we are at and where a stricter waste policy has to go. We note here the question in its exhibition phase: on October 4, 2010, the rupture of a raft of waste in Hungary released almost one million cubic meters of highly alkaline red mud. It flooded several villages, claimed the lives of ten people, wounded nearly 150 and contaminated large areas of land, including four natura 2000 network spaces. The accident highlighted the poor application of EU legislation, deficiencies in inspections and gaps in relevant EU legislation. We hope that this question and the subsequent resolution will draw attention to the Commission and that the Commission will focus its efforts on assessing waste bag assessment methods so that these catastrophes do not recur. We also expect a consistent sanctions policy and a subsidy policy equally in cases where the law is broken or complied with.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We must avoid a repeat of such environmental and human disasters. The resolution clearly stipulates that Member States with similar mining plants are not correctly implementing EU laws. The legislation needs to be reinforced and properly applied.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament - Lessons learned from the disaster caused by red mud, five years after the accident in Hungary, given that it is necessary to mark the anniversary of the disaster not only because of the rooster towards the victims, but also to do whatever it takes to avoid or prevent these disasters. Although red mud is explicitly classified as hazardous waste today, at the time of Hungary's biggest industrial disaster on 4 October 2010, this was not the case. The accident demonstrated the importance of the EU's civil protection mechanism, pointing out the shortcomings of European environmental regulation and the problem of poor implementation of European laws. Unfortunately, no improvements have occurred in this regard in recent years and there are still shortcomings both in the eu legislation, supervision and implementation responsible. The importance of preventing possible disasters should be emphasised, the most advanced technological solutions must be used and the necessary research carried out. Local self-government, citizens and civil society should also be involved in the decision-making process regarding hazardous waste disposal, planning of measures and risk management.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Five years ago, Hungary faced the dramatic consequences of a waste tank rupture. Red sludge from alumina and aluminum killed ten people. Today, Parliament was thinking about a legislative framework to contain this kind of disaster. More concretely, this issue raises the need for a stronger government grip at EU level. The Community administration is using this sad anniversary as a pretext to tighten the greenhouses of its control. Although Article 15 calls on "Member States to strengthen their national environmental inspection bodies", this possibility was immediately bogged down in the torrent of calls for a strengthening of the Community level.  That is why I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the lessons learned from the red sludge disaster that occurred five years ago in Hungary. The text takes stock of the consequences of this environmental disaster and the shortcomings in the implementation of European standards in this area and raises a number of concerns about the evolution of the level of control in Europe of facilities similar to those where the accident took place. Finally, the text makes a number of recommendations to the European Commission and the Member States so that such a disaster cannot happen again. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. This disaster, which left 10 people dead and 150 injured by the rupture of a waste tank in Hungary, must not happen again. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution in order to intensify controls and strengthen prevention in order to avoid any further incidents.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This resolution calls for existing EU environmental legislation to be fully adopted and properly applied and for the extractive industries to comply with the BAT principle. The authors also regret that the Commission has not yet presented the report on the Environmental Liability Directive. It also calls on the Commission to propose harmonised compulsory financial security or to draw up a legislative proposal on access to justice in environmental matters. I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution in the light of these proposals.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution, the Member States and the Commission must step up efforts to improve and ensure the proper implementation of all EU legislation governing the extractive waste industry to avoid a repeat of such an environmental and human disaster.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Just 5 years ago, the biggest industrial disaster in my country's history occurred when almost one million cubic metres of highly alkaline red sludge spilled into the environment, flooding several municipalities, causing the deaths of 10 people and invading some 150 people, as well as large areas affected by pollution, including four NATURA 2000 sites. I supported the resolution, of course, because it is worrying that similar industrial sites exist in several Member States, so there is still a risk of such misfortune.  It is incomprehensible that almost no lessons have been learned from what has happened over the last five years, that the effectiveness of the implementation of the relevant EU legislation and international agreements remains low, that the backlog of controls has been maintained and that almost none of the shortcomings of the relevant EU legislation have been eliminated. I am particularly concerned about the Mining Waste Directive and the European Waste List.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. On 4 October 2010, the rupture of a catchment area in Hungary caused the spillage of about 1 million cubic metres of high-alkaline red sludge, which, by pouring into several villages, killed 10 people and injured around 150. Vast expanses of land have been polluted and the accident has highlighted the problems of waste disposal in the extractive industry. Many things need to be changed if we really want to prevent such disasters from happening again in the future. Member States need to strengthen their environmental inspections and monitoring systems, together with greater development in the prevention and treatment of hazardous waste. We had already asked, in 2008, to present a legislative proposal on environmental controls, and so we can only reiterate the same demand, in a stronger way. The directive on the management of waste from the extractive industries must be implemented in good time, and we have therefore asked the European Commission to monitor its full implementation.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the lessons learned from the red sludge disaster, five years after the accident in Hungary. On 4 October 2010 in Hungary, the rupture of a waste tank caused considerable pollution and the death of ten people. The question is how a sophisticated legislative framework will prevent these disasters in the future. As a watermark, the question strongly suggests the need for a stronger government grip at the community level. Wishful thinking follows one another and inevitably calls for "more Europe". Article 15, which directly calls on "Member States to strengthen their national environmental inspection bodies," can only be noted. This positive point, however, is drowned out by the systematic calls for a strengthening of the community level.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Hungary collapsed on 4 October 2010 with the collapse of an industrial waste tank from which nearly 1 million cubic metres of red mud leaked, flooding several villages. Ten people were killed, nearly 150 people were injured and vast areas of land were contaminated. The Commission Decision 2014/955 / EU clearly classifies red sludge as hazardous waste and applies from 1 June 2015.  It is noted that this disaster can also be linked to inconsistent enforcement of EU law and inspections. Member States are invited to ensure adequate transparent, regular and systematic control and the classification of red mule as hazardous waste so that such accidents do not happen again. It is also important to inform the public about pollution and possible impacts on flora and fauna, but also on the health of the local population. It also highlights the importance of cooperation and solidarity at EU level in the event of natural and industrial disasters.  I supported the European Parliament's resolution aware of the inextricable consequences, human casualties and material damage. Both in Croatia and in the European Union, the greater the technological development, the more exposure to natural disasters increases, and their effects become more devastating, and preventive action is necessary.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – The case of the October 2010 environmental disaster in Hungary, when a dam of hazardous waste broke and caused damage to lives, health and property, raised more questions. This is the need to compensate for the damage incurred from EU resources, but also sufficient preventive measures in the area of the management of hazardous waste and the associated protection of the environment. Red sludge and other hazardous wastes are still at risk of such environmental and industrial disasters in other EU countries. We must therefore require the Commission to present a report on compliance with EU environmental responsibility standards and, on the basis of its results, to come forward with proposals for new measures that will strengthen prevention effects in this area.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the lessons learned from the destruction of red sludge five years after the accident in Hungary, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/10/2015, in which, among other things, I referred to the contamination of many Greek rivers, mainly by industrial and urban sewage. Strymonas, Nestos, Axios, Loudias, French, Pinias, Aliakmon and, above all, Asopos are rivers that face, each to a different degree, pollution problems. The problems are acute in Aliakmon and Pinies, in the wider region of Asopos, but the situation is dramatic and the problem is chronic. Measurements in the area indicate the presence of heavy metals and hexavalent chromium that are hazardous to public health. Local authorities and, above all, residents have been fighting this environmental crime for years. That is why the Greek government must take, here and now, all the necessary measures to stop environmental crime in Asopos, but also in the other rivers of Greece, otherwise it will, like previous governments, bear criminal responsibilities in this regard.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution. The disaster killed ten people and caused considerable pollution in Hungary. We recognise the need to ensure that such a disaster does not happen again, but the content of this proposal is inadequate: it consists of a long series of wishful thinking and calls, of course, for more Europe. Even if we are in favour of strengthening the national environmental inspection bodies, we cannot support this empty shell.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution which ‘notes that the red mud disaster can be linked to the poor implementation of EU laws, inspection deficiencies, gaps in relevant EU legislation and the performance of the site operator’ and, even more worryingly, ‘is concerned that almost no lessons seem to have been learned in the last five years, as poor implementation of the relevant EU laws and international conventions as well as inspection deficiencies continue and almost none of the gaps in the relevant EU legislation have since been closed.’

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the lessons learned from the red sludge disaster five years after the accident in Hungary. On 4 October 2010, there was a very serious accident, considered the most serious disaster of its kind ever to hit Hungary. Following the breakage of the lock of an aluminum processing plant, more than 1 million cubic meters of toxic red mud came out, causing the deaths of 10 people and over 115 injured, invaded two villages and compromised local crops for years, as well as exterminating the fauna and flora of the waterways involved. Bearing this disaster in mind, it is of the utmost importance that all Member States ensure that, if such waste such as red sludge is present on its territory, they classify it as hazardous. A real and strong commitment to prevention is needed, with strict standards for environmental inspection. Cooperation and solidarity at EU level in the event of environmental and industrial disasters is fundamental, in line with the principle, in environmental matters, of preventive action and that of 'the polluter pays'.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we commemorate 5 years since a major environmental event in Hungary, when almost 1 million cubic meters of highly alkaline red sludge escaped in October 2010, several villages were flooded and 10 people lost their lives and 150 were injured. The text under discussion emphasises the need for lessons learned from such disasters, a responsible approach to environmental protection, calls on the Commission to support environmental inspections and also calls on the Member States to place particular emphasis on preventing such disasters. I voted in favour of this text.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the conclusions and lessons learned from the red mud disaster five years ago when the disastrous accident in Hungary took place.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This resolution should be supported by calling for existing EU environmental legislation to be fully adopted and properly applied. The authors also regret that the Commission has not yet presented the report on the Environmental Liability Directive. It also calls on the Commission to propose harmonised mandatory financial security (by the end of 2016) or to prepare a legislative proposal on access to justice in environmental matters. Furthermore, the resolution provides that there will be no additional burden on industry.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. On 4 October 2010, the collapse of a waste reservoir in Hungary dumped nearly one million cubic metres of highly alkaline red sludge containing aluminum, which flooded several villages, killed ten people, injured nearly 150 and polluted large areas of land, including four Natura 2000 sites. Five years later, the European Parliament is taking this opportunity to call for better prevention of industrial disasters, including mining waste and waste in general. It calls on all Member States with red mud basins to examine whether it has been properly classified as dangerous and to revise all permits based on misclassifications. The resolution also calls for legislation on access to justice in environmental matters, the establishment of a "European system for sharing risks in the event of a disaster linked to industrial installations" and better application of the polluter-pay principle. It calls for greater emphasis on research and adequate resources in Member States to inspect industrial sites. Although the industry has sought to minimize its site security costs by influencing right-wing MPs, I am voting for it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. Five years ago, Hungary faced the dramatic consequences of a waste tank rupture. Red sludge, produced during the manufacture of alumina and aluminum, had caused the death of ten people. Today, Parliament was thinking about a legislative framework to contain this kind of disaster. More concretely, this issue raises the need for a stronger government grip at EU level. The community administration is using this sad anniversary as a pretext to tighten the greenhouses of its control. Although Article 15 calls on "Member States to strengthen their national environmental inspection bodies", this possibility was immediately bogged down in the torrent of calls for a strengthening of the Community level.  Therefore, I voted "against."

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Five years after the accident in Hungary, there is still poor enforcement of EU law and relevant international conventions, as well as poor control. It is essential to draw conclusions and lessons from the disasters and to implement further prevention and supervision.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as it examines the lessons to be learned from this tragedy and urges Member States to reflect on how their own policies might incorporate them.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of a resolution on the lessons to be learned from the industrial disaster of the red sludge in Hungary, five years after the events. With this resolution, and in order to prevent further disasters, Parliament calls for the proper implementation of EU legislation and for strengthening environmental inspections, particularly in the area of waste management in the extractive industry. In this regard, Parliament is asking the Commission, among other things, to present a legislative proposal on environmental inspections. European environmental legislation is one of the most ambitious in the world. It is crucial that it is respected and properly implemented. In particular, the prevention of industrial disasters and the careful management of hazardous waste such as red sludge must be high on the agenda.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The rupture of the waste dam in Hungary on 4 October 2010 was the last, but certainly not the only, such accident in Europe in recent decades. That is why it is really appropriate to learn enough and take measures to ensure that the disaster that claimed the lives of ten people in Hungary five years ago and almost 150 injured remains. All the more so because its consequences did not end with this calculation. As a doctor, I note that after drying out the mud left in the environment after getting into it almost a million cubic meters high of alkaline red sludge, there was a fine dust that settles in the airways and reaches the circulatory system, which can cause other health problems. In addition, the mud dust after the crash contained other hazardous pollutants. In this case, the content of arsenic, which can cause cancer in case of its penetration into the lungs, is dangerous. As the accident has shown a lack of implementation of EU law, shortcomings in inspections and gaps in relevant EU legislation, I join colleagues' questions directed at the Commission: what lessons have been learned from this accident?

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which is timed to coincide with the 5th anniversary of the collapse of a waste reservoir at an aluminium plant in Hungary, on 4 October 2010, releasing almost one million cubic metres of highly alkaline red mud, flooding several villages and killing 10 people. There were up to 150 injured and the pollution covered vast areas of land, including four Natura 2000 sites. The accident highlighted the poor implementation of EU laws, deficiencies in inspections and gaps in relevant EU legislation. Red mud is waste generated in the industrial production of aluminium, and it poses one of the biggest disposal problems in the extractive industries. Therefore, the Commission and Member States must step up efforts to improve, and ensure the proper implementation of, all EU legislation governing the extractive waste industry in order to avoid a repeat of such an environmental and human disaster.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety has tabled a motion for the adoption of a resolution on the lessons learned from the red sludge disaster in Hungary to an oral question. I consider the draft resolution to be politically motivated, which, among the lessons learned, only commends the Hungarian Government and the national authorities and makes the European institutions responsible for all the negatives. So I couldn't support the eight-party agreement.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The red sledge disaster in Hungary in 2010 draws attention to a serious environmental situation, which gives rise to cooperation and solidarity at EU level. Red slamas are hazardous waste until proven otherwise, in accordance with Commission Decision 2014/955/EU, and may be incorrectly classified in other Member States, causing danger to the European community and giving rise to undue authorisations. Prevention measures to prevent other industrial disasters are essential by correctly applying European environmental legislation and international conventions. Progress is also needed in the development of surveillance and inspection tools in this area at EU level. Member States shall assume guarantees in line with respect for the "polluter pays" principle. I am in favour of this motion for a resolution, stressing the need to fill the gaps in European legislation and by call for the cooperation of all Member States for the prevention of environmental disasters and the sharing of financial risks.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution to assess the lessons learned from the 2010 red sludge disaster in Hungary comes as part of the macabre "anniversary" of the toxic flood that hit the Veszprém county. Inventory in the Prévert drawing its sole basis from the publicity offered by this date, the various measures inevitably call for an increase in the Commission's powers in environmental matters and for a strengthening of the European legislative arsenal under the usual 'more Europe' antienne. The strengthening of the Community level and the dispossession of French sovereignty brought about by this proposal led me to vote against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. In 2010, the rupture of a waste reservoir in Hungary resulted in the dumping of nearly one million cubic metres of highly alkaline red sludge. The sludge flooded several villages, killing ten people and injuring 150 others. They have caused extensive damage and pollution of large areas of land, including four Natura 2000 sites.  I voted in favour of this resolution, which pays tribute to the victims and calls on the European Union to learn from this disaster. In particular, Member States are asked to take into account the classification of red sludge as a hazardous waste under Directive 91/689/EEC and to check existing ponds. I believe it is important to set safety requirements for waste management in the extractive industry to ensure their safety.  It should be remembered, however, that the transposition of the Environmental Responsibility Directive has not resulted in equal responsibilities in all Member States. It is therefore important not to place additional administrative and financial burdens on companies located in countries where strict standards are already being applied.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution, which will further elaborate the concept of an EU-wide industrial-disaster risk-sharing facility, with full observance of the polluter-pays principle, to cover possible costs beyond a high level of mandatory financial security.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this resolution in my vote today because I believe that the repetition of an accident similar to that of 2010 in Hungary, in which a very large amount of red sludge has spilled, flooding several villages, killing 10 people and polluting very large areas of land, including protected areas, must be prevented by all possible means. Of course, subsequent investigations found a lack or poor application of EU law and a poor control and inspection system. Unfortunately, this is no stranger to other Member States where there are such deposits of red sludge or other hazardous chemicals. It is imperative that EU legislation in this area is re-examined and supplemented in order to close loopholes. At the same time, without the accountability and punishment of the polluter and without the full application of the legislation, such cases, unfortunately, will be repeated.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because, in my opinion, environmental protection also means homeland protection. The motion contains important and correct approaches. It also calls for the Commission to finally present the legislative proposal on environmental inspections.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The resolution points out that more lessons should be learned from the disaster that has occurred. Prevention of similar disasters is necessary by strengthening environmental safety requirements and compliance with them and by supplementing EU and international legislation.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution.  The disaster revealed gaps in the implementation of EU legislation, which have not yet been filled. It is a shame, but no lessons have been learned from past mistakes. There is no progress in the implementation of EU and international legislation and checks continue to be inadequate.  In this context, the Commission and the Member States need to step up their efforts to make progress in this area. More attention needs to be paid to research and development in the field of prevention and the management of hazardous waste. It is necessary to strengthen supervision and implement the polluter pays principle more effectively. The Commission should submit a legislative proposal on environmental inspections as soon as possible. However, the new regulation must not create an additional financial burden for the industry. It should be noted that particular attention should be paid to the transparency of the financial aspects of the elimination of the effects of environmental disasters, including the payment of financial compensation to victims. In addition, the Commission should prepare a legislative proposal on access to justice in environmental matters.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the fact that, five years after the Hungarian disaster, inspections are still inefficient and European regulations still do not see full implementation, I believe that further emphasis needs to be placed on disaster prevention, especially through the implementation of actions to ensure that inspections are carried out correctly and regularly. I would therefore vote in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on the experience gained in the event of the red mud disaster in relation to the disaster in Hungary. The experience gained in the event of this disaster must be used to prevent similar future disasters and to draw up appropriate rules and legislation to prevent similar events in the future, based on the knowledge gained in resolving the disaster.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The disaster caused by red sludge in Hungary as hungary's worst industrial accident ever, warned of the danger of many, unfortunately still unresolved, "black spots" in the EASTERN EU Member States. Tackling industrial pollution that was caused for years during communist-run eastern states without proper care and proper activities to ensure the harmless management of hazardous industrial waste is expensive, and the cost of disposal must be borne by states as owners of waste, in most cases failed plants.  I support this Resolution of the European Parliament and, precisely to prevent the recurrence of similar events, I call for a debate as soon as possible on the implementation of the Environmental Liability Directive on the prevention and elimination of environmental damage. Unfortunately, the Commission has not yet submitted a report on the implementation of this Directive, and the application of the polluter pays principle in many situations across the EU is either circumvented or not fully applied. Similarly, the revision of the Directive itself is not a solution, as appropriate other conditions such as the European Soil Regulation and the relevant waste classification regulation in terms of the concept of a circular economy are lacking. Furthermore, the competent authorities of individual Member States, and due to the cost of taking appropriate action, often do not opt for necessary (costly) measures, leaving increased risks of industrial accidents occurring with serious consequences.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution on the assessment of lessons learned from the 2010 red sludge disaster in Hungary comes as part of the macabre "anniversary" of the toxic flood that hit the Veszprém county. Inventory in the Prévert drawing its sole basis from the publicity offered by this date, the various measures inevitably call for an increase in the Commission's powers in environmental matters and for a strengthening of the European legislative arsenal under the usual 'more Europe' antienne. The strengthening of the Community level and the dispossession of French sovereignty brought about by this proposal led me to vote against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Given the principles of environmental protection in EU law, in particular in the area of preventive action and the principle that the polluter pays for the environmental and safety of citizens, I welcome the efforts of this resolution to increase surveillance instruments and strengthen environmental inspections and increase environmental standards in sites with red mud barren landfills. Worryingly, following the 2010 accident in Hungary, the necessary measures were not taken to amend and complement shortcomings in the legislation relating to environmental and safety inspections. I therefore support the Call on the Commission to increase control over Member States and to publish by the end of 2016 a report on the measures taken by Member States in terms of classification and control of red mud barren lands, but also to increase efforts to ensure environmentally correct waste management in general. It commends the initiative for greater cooperation and coordinated action by national environmental inspection authorities of different Member States. Also, as the case in Hungary has shown, it is necessary to raise awareness and empower citizens and involve civil society and local authorities in deciding on waste management.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ On October 4, 2010, a waste tank ruptured in Hungary, resulting in the leakage of nearly one million cubic metres of extremely alkaline red mud, causing the deaths of ten people, and pollution of a large area of land. The red mud in that waste tank was hazardous waste, and this disaster is considered the worst industrial disaster in Hungary.  This disaster can be linked to poor enforcement of European Union rules, failures during inspections, deficiencies in relevant Union legislation and operator work at the site in place. All Member States should verify that red mud is properly qualified as dangerous, while the Commission is invited to publish a report by the end of 2016 on the measures taken by Member States. In addition, the Commission and the Member States are urged to apply the rules and relevant international conventions appropriately, to improve supervision and solidarity and to cooperate in the event of a disaster. By 2016, the Commission should submit a legislative proposal on access to justice in environmental matters in line with the provisions of the 7th Environmental Action Programme, and develop the concept of risk-sharing instruments for industrial disasters, in full respect of the principle that the polluter pays. Consequently, I agree with the proposal for a Resolution.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. On 4 October 2010, a waste tank in Hungary ruptured and resulted in the dumping of more than one million cubic metres of red sludge that was hazardous to the environment and the health of surrounding populations. This catastrophic incident killed ten people and severely polluted the surrounding area. The European Parliament wished to recall the importance of this disaster and the need to ensure control of waste reservoirs. Indeed, there has been a sometimes lax application of European legislation, laxity that can lead to such disasters. The aim of this text is to remind Member States to learn the lessons of this disaster and to control their reservoirs by ensuring compliance with European legislation.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. On 4 October 2010, the rupture of a waste reservoir in Hungary poured nearly one million cubic metres of highly alkaline red slous slands and flooded several villages, killing ten people, injuring about 150 and polluting vast areas, including four Natura 2000 sites. Five years later, it is important to leave a word of homage to the victims here. On the other hand, it will also be important to take a view of developments in disaster prevention of this nature. Parliament is concerned that, in practice, the lessons learned from this tragic event have not been taken, since none of the shortcomings in EU law have in the meantime been addressed and there is still a low level of application of EU legislation and relevant international conventions and there are shortcomings in controls. The Commission and the Member States must therefore step up their efforts to ensure pollution prevention and treatment of hazardous waste. I voted in favour.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. The resolution seeks to demonstrate that no serious lessons have been learned from this disaster. Again, as is all too often the case in industrial accidents, repairs and compensation are paid for by public money and not by the industrialists responsible for the disaster. That is why the European Parliament has asked the European Commission to propose new harmonised rules requiring industrialists to put in place sufficient financial security so that the polluter pays principle can be fully implemented. The Commission should also put in place inspection requirements that could be coordinated at European level to avoid national conflicts of interest. All Member States have a duty, even in times of austerity, to properly fund the authorities in charge of industrial inspections, in order to avoid an accident and to enforce the regulations in force. The same is true for organizations responsible for measuring the toxicity of industrial releases and solutions to their treatment.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2010, the rupture of a waste reservoir in Hungary poured nearly one million cubic metres of highly alkaline red slats and flooded several villages, killing ten people, injuring about 150 and polluting vast areas. Commission Decision 2014/955/EU indicates that red slamas should be classified as hazardous waste. There is a risk that they have been classified as non-hazardous waste in other Member States. The proposal warns of this situation and is concerned that no lessons have been learned in the last 5 years. There is still a low level of implementation of EU law and relevant international conventions, which includes successive shortcomings in controls. We clearly call for Member States to strengthen their national environmental inspection bodies.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. U2012 The rupture of a raft of waste from a mining company on 4 October 2010 caused a red mud tide of one million cubic meters that caused ten dead, 150 injured and flooding of several municipalities and vast areas of land, including four spaces of high ecological value, and highlighted the lack of implementation of EU legislation and significant deficiencies in inspections.  I have supported this Resolution which criticises the lack of adequate implementation of European legislation and international conventions in this area both in Hungary and in other Member States. As he rightly points out, disaster prevention needs to be strengthened through research, the development of hazardous waste treatment and the implementation of stricter environmental inspections.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. On 4 October 2010, the rupture of a waste reservoir in Hungary resulted in the dumping of nearly one million cubic metres of highly alkaline red sludge, which caused flooding in several villages, killed ten people, injured nearly 150 people and polluted large areas of land, including 4 Natura 2000 sites. The resolution is concerned that almost no lessons appear to have been learned in the last five years, as European legislation on this and international conventions continue to be poorly applied, inspections remain inadequate and no or so little deficiency in EU legislation in this area has been remedied during this period.  The text adopted and which I supported therefore calls in particular on the Commission and the Member States to intensify their efforts to ensure the full implementation and proper implementation of all the EU's legislation on this subject, as well as all relevant international conventions, not only with regard to aluminium manufacturing and the management of red sludge in an environmentally friendly manner. , but also, in general, the management of hazardous waste in an environmentally friendly manner.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution on the most serious industrial disaster in Hungary, resulting from the rupture of a waste reservoir, which poured almost one million cubic metres of highly alkaline red slands and flooded several villages, killing ten people and injuring about 150. Five years after the tragic accident, I pay tribute to all the victims, also praising those who, with great effort, have quickly and effectively intervened in resolving this event, trying to find the best solutions to eliminate and reduce harm. This incident has also served to show that there is still poor and incorrect implementation of European legislation, so it is essential to carry out work at the level not only of the correct legislative application, but also in the level of inspections, inspections and the prevention of future disasters, so that serious incidents such as these do not happen again in the future.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the lessons learned from the red sludge disaster five years after the accident in Hungary, because it is necessary for the European Union to take action to find concrete solutions in order to prevent the occurrence of events similar to the one that happened.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, which is trying to take over, now that five years of the accident in Hungary have passed, where we are at and where a stricter waste policy has to go. We note here the question in its exhibition phase: on October 4, 2010, the rupture of a raft of waste in Hungary released almost one million cubic meters of highly alkaline red mud. It flooded several villages, claimed the lives of ten people, wounded nearly 150 and contaminated large areas of land, including four natura 2000 network spaces. The accident highlighted the poor application of EU legislation, deficiencies in inspections and gaps in relevant EU legislation. We hope that this question and the subsequent resolution will draw attention to the Commission and that the Commission will focus its efforts on assessing waste bag assessment methods so that these catastrophes do not recur. We also expect a consistent sanctions policy and a subsidy policy equally in cases where the law is broken or complied with.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This Resolution addresses the disaster that occurred on 4 October 2010 in Hungary, when the rupture of a raft of waste freed almost one million cubic meters of red mud (a waste from the highly alkaline extractive industries) that flooded several villages and left 10 people dead, 150 wounds and large areas of contaminated land, including four Natura 2000 spaces.
