I voted in favour of the Resolution, since, inter alia, it points to the risk in a number of Member States of a repeat of a similar catastrophe due to the poor application of environmental legislation; calls for more inspections on waste rafts; highlights the existence of serious environmental pollution problems in several Member States due to mining activities (e.g. the use of cyanide in gold mines); requests the Commission, on the occasion of the current revision of the Environmental Responsibility Directive, to ensure that the proposed review fully implements the 'polluter pays' principle, or to involve local authorities, citizens and civil society in the decision-making process on the disposal of hazardous waste and in the planning of risk management measures.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. The importance of proper treatment of hazardous waste is unquestionable. Hungary was a regrettable witness to this. I take this explanation of vote to complement my statements in plenary, reiterating that I consider it essential to find solutions for the good management of this waste and that they have two approximations. On the one hand, conditions must be created for hazardous waste to be effectively treated, giving them economic value and creating extraordinary guarantees to fill losses from accidents. At the same time, I believe that transparency must accompany the whole process of handling hazardous waste. This process must start at the level of planning its use to its final destination and includes a possible remediation phase, which is not expected to be necessary. These were some of the reasons why it voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this issue as this calls for further EU Regulation. I believe that any regulation relating to Hungary’s industrial sector should be controlled and voted on by the Hungarian Parliament.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission and Member States must step up their efforts to improve, and ensure the correct implementation of, all legislation from the EU governing the extractive waste industry in order to avoid a repeat of such a human and environmental disaster.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The tragic events of 4 October 2010, when a waste tank with bauxite sludge resulting from aluminium production broke, affected the entire surrounding area of Veszprém County. I therefore appreciate that the European Parliament is returning to this event in order to improve the repair of the damage that still lingers after the accident. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. On 4 October 2010, a waste tank broke in Hungary, resulting in a spill of almost one million cubic metres of heavily alkaline red sludge (considered hazardous waste – Council Directive 91/689/EEC), which flooded several villages, left ten people dead and nearly 150 injured. The spill also caused contamination of a large area, including four NATURA 2000 sites. The draft motion for a resolution concludes that the red sludge disaster was the most serious industrial disaster in Hungary and can be attributed to poor implementation of EU laws, lack of inspections and gaps in relevant EU legislation. The motion for a resolution calls on all Member States with red sludge tanks to review whether this has been properly categorised as dangerous and to correct as quickly as possible all permits based on incorrect categorisation.  I agree that a strong focus on disaster prevention is essential, as this is not an isolated example of this type of environmental catastrophe. Member States should step up their efforts to fully implement and correctly apply all relevant EU legislation. However, I also believe that research and development in the field of prevention and treatment of hazardous waste must be strengthened. For this purpose, I voted in favour of the draft motion for a resolution.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this resolution because attention should be paid to environmental issues and the elimination of previously caused pollution. The rupture of a waste tank in Hungary on 4 October 2010 has left nearly one million cubic metres of extremely alkaline red mud into the environment. The accident killed 10 and injured nearly 150 people and polluted large areas of land. Failures during inspections and shortcomings in relevant EU legislation have resulted in disasters, both for the population and the environment. Red mud is a waste in industrial production of aluminum and is a problem of waste disposal in the material extraction industry, therefore, for the benefit of the population, member states, but also of the system as a whole, it is necessary to focus on the possible consequences that such factors cause.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution, recognising the red mud disaster as Hungary’s worst industrial disaster and commemorating the victims on the fifth anniversary of the event. I urge the Commission to put more emphasis on research and development in the prevention and treatment of hazardous waste, and to produce guidelines for carrying out stress tests on existing mines with large tailings ponds, in the hope of preventing any further industrial disasters of this nature.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ On October 4, 2010, the collapse of a waste reservoir in Hungary caused the release of nearly one million cubic metres of alkaline red seed, toxic waste. Several villages were submerged, ten people died, nearly 150 people were injured and vast land areas were polluted, including four NATURA 2000 sites. According to the Commission Decision of 1 June 2015, it is explicitly stated that red sludge should be classified as hazardous waste, in the absence of evidence to the contrary. Furthermore, the inappropriate treatment of hazardous waste in a number of Member States, as well as mining to mine ores, cause serious environmental pollution problems. The European Parliament highlights the 2010 red-mule disaster as Hungary's worst industrial disaster, linked to the poor implementation of EU laws. There are currently concerns that no lessons have been learned since the accident and reinforcing disaster prevention is key. This is why the Commission is asked to put particular emphasis on research and development in the treatment of hazardous waste. I fully support the proposal to step up disaster prevention measures, as well as to work with the EU on this problem, so that such accidents do not happen again in the future.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the resolution on the experience gained from the red mud disaster, five years after the disaster in Hungary. We have to learn from every history. We need to pull positive and negative things and decide not to do it again. Because if we haven't learned anything from history, we're going to have to live it again. The red mud disaster in Hungary five years ago reminds us that we need to better implement the relevant EU laws, including inspection. As the resolution rightly observes, no gap has been filled in this area in these five years. I support the call on the Commission and the Member States to step up their efforts to ensure full implementation and proper application of all relevant EU legislation and all relevant international conventions.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Strict controls on industrial waste are need. Although Hungary has made great efforts since the destruction of the red sea, the legislation must be tightened up and the same for everyone.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion to mark the fifth anniversary of the colonial red sludge disaster. I was a co-author in the process of designing the document, in which we managed to actually focus on environmental aspects rather than praising the hungarian government's doubtful achievements. The motion is not only about red sludge, but also about hazardous waste from other industrial production. This is also important because there are currently several reservoirs saturated with similar hazardous waste in the European Union, and the resolution encourages the Commission to take steps to establish a transparent financial mechanism for disaster situations. Other specific elements of the motion include the polluter pays principle, the preference for best available techniques, the more effective involvement of civil society and stricter enforcement of relevant EU and other international rules and on-the-spot checks.  The motion also calls for transparency, both for public and private disaster funds.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Protecting the environment is one of the basic principles assumed by the institutions of the European Union. This implies a great responsibility of all economic factors in the territory of the Member States in the management of their activity, so as not to harm the natural environment. Mining activities involve quite high risks of destruction of the places where the extractive procedures are carried out, as confirmed by the tragic event that took place in Hungary five years ago. In order to avoid a repeat of such events in the future, European legislation has been amended, with a focus on the preventive and forward-looking side. However, the adoption of legislation is not sufficient to guarantee greater safety for citizens and the environment. It is necessary for Member States to implement concretely the legal provisions and to ensure by repeated checks that those dangers have been eliminated. Otherwise, there is a risk of us and new accidents and disasters that endanger human lives and irreparably destroy the environment. For these reasons, this resolution, which is a wake-up call for authorities at all levels, should be adopted in order to take appropriate measures to avoid such regrettable events.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The red sludge disaster that took place in 2010 is the most dramatic industrial disaster in Hungary. I pay tribute to the victims on the fifth anniversary of this tragic accident. We call by this text for all Member States with red sludge ponds to check whether red sludge has been properly classified as hazardous waste and to review as soon as possible all permits based on misclassifications. The Commission will have to ensure that Member States take action and report back to the Commission. Parliament calls on the Commission to publish a report on the measures taken by Member States by the end of 2016.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which reflects on the progress made in response to the red mud disaster in Hungary. The catastrophe happened in October 2010, when a waste reservoir collapsed and released almost one million cubic metres of highly alkaline red mud, flooded several villages, killed 10 people, injured almost 150, and polluted vast areas of land. The European Parliament found that little has been learned and that poor implementation of EU law, one of the causes of the disaster, continues. It calls, therefore, on the Commission and the Member States to ensure proper application of all relevant EU legislation and international conventions with regard to aluminium production and the environmentally sound management of red mud and hazardous waste in general.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the issue of the European Parliament's Environment, Public Health and Food Safety Committee, as the case of waste containers rupturing in Hungary shows that it is obvious that the European Union needs a stronger and more effective strategy for the prevention and proper implementation of EUROPEAN Union legislation.  In October 2010, almost one million cubic metres of extremely alkaline red mud was drained into the environment in Hungary, killing ten and injuring almost 150 people and polluting large land areas.  I believe that five years since this accident, it is more than enough for the Council to design and take measures to prevent such catastrophic accidents in the future and remove pollution from mining activities, which should help to preserve the environment and the safety and health of all Citizens of the European Union, not just Hungarians.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the experience gained from the red sludge disaster following the disaster in Hungary, because I believe that the disaster that occurred in Hungary in 2010, when a wastewater reservoir broke down, resulting in the spill of almost one million cubic metres of heavily alkaline red sludge, reminded us of the importance of controlling such plants. Each Member State must therefore strengthen controls and preventive mechanisms in order to prevent similar catastrophes.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, which is trying to take over, now that five years of the accident in Hungary have passed, where we are at and where a stricter waste policy has to go. We note here the question in its exhibition phase: on October 4, 2010, the rupture of a raft of waste in Hungary released almost one million cubic meters of highly alkaline red mud. It flooded several villages, claimed the lives of ten people, wounded nearly 150 and contaminated large areas of land, including four natura 2000 network spaces. The accident highlighted the poor application of EU legislation, deficiencies in inspections and gaps in relevant EU legislation. We hope that this question and the subsequent resolution will draw attention to the Commission and that the Commission will focus its efforts on assessing waste bag assessment methods so that these catastrophes do not recur. We also expect a consistent sanctions policy and a subsidy policy equally in cases where the law is broken or complied with.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this resolution, which is trying to take over, now that five years of the accident in Hungary have passed, where we are at and where a stricter waste policy has to go. We note here the question in its exhibition phase: on October 4, 2010, the rupture of a raft of waste in Hungary released almost one million cubic meters of highly alkaline red mud. It flooded several villages, claimed the lives of ten people, wounded nearly 150 and contaminated large areas of land, including four natura 2000 network spaces. The accident highlighted the poor application of EU legislation, deficiencies in inspections and gaps in relevant EU legislation. We hope that this question and the subsequent resolution will draw attention to the Commission and that the Commission will focus its efforts on assessing waste bag assessment methods so that these catastrophes do not recur. We also expect a consistent sanctions policy and a subsidy policy equally in cases where the law is broken or complied with.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the Commission and the Member States to step up their efforts to ensure the full implementation and proper application of all relevant EU legislation and all relevant international conventions with regard not only to aluminium production and the environmentally sound management of red mud but also to the environmentally sound management of hazardous waste in general. On 4 October 2010, the collapse of a waste reservoir in Hungary released almost one million cubic metres of highly alkaline red mud. It flooded several villages, killed 10 people, injured almost 150 and polluted vast areas of land. The resolution also commemorates the victims on the occasion of the fifth anniversary of this tragic event, and supporting it is also an acknowledgement that much more should be done in environmental disaster prevention and management.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This accident, which has been reported here for five years, has been the bare application and shortcomings of EU environmental laws on industrial toxic waste. It revealed the fragility of the inspection system, which is non-existent or ineffective, as well as its non-compliance by both Member States and industrialists owning factories. Unfortunately, this disaster is not unique. We all remember similar occurrences in Spain or Romania. This resolution calls for lessons to be learned five years after this major accident in Hungary and efforts to understand the current situation of mine waste, its management and treatment. The Commission is asked to invest and place more emphasis on research and development of the prevention and treatment of this type of toxic waste.  A real and effective prevention of pollution and environmental risks of extracting industries, among others, requires stricter environmental rules for environmental inspections, which means giving more resources to the national bodies responsible for these inspections. More transparency is needed, and the responsible authorities need to regularly inform the public about the state of pollution and the possible impacts on fauna and flora, as well as on the health of local populations.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This resolution should be supported by calling for existing EU environmental legislation to be fully adopted and properly applied. The authors also regret that the Commission has not yet presented the report on the Environmental Liability Directive. It also calls on the Commission to propose harmonised mandatory financial security (by the end of 2016) or to prepare a legislative proposal on access to justice in environmental matters. Furthermore, the resolution provides that there will be no additional burden on industry.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. On October 4, 2010, between 700,000 and 1 million cubic meters of red sludge leaked from the storage of an aluminium plant during the dam burst in Kolontér (Hungary). Red sludge is life-threatening, among other things, because it contains corrosive caustic soda and toxic heavy metals. Five years later, the European Parliament is reminding us of this. It notes that this environmental disaster is linked to the poor implementation of EU law, deficiencies in inspections, gaps in relevant EU law and the functioning of the plant's operator. The EU Commission has been criticised on several occasions for not closely monitoring the implementation of essential elements of the Environmental Liability Directive.B. Nevertheless, the European Parliament refuses the only logical recommendation, namely to hand over responsibility to the Member States for the in-depth control of their own national environmental laws. While deploring the fact that the existing European mechanisms are not working, the EU Parliament is immediately calling for "more Europe" through the extension of the environmental acquis, through additional capacity at European level (a new agency in Hungary?), through an additional EU-wide facility for industrial accidents. These new mechanisms will be made available in addition, although the existing mechanisms are not yet fully applied. This is not thought through to the end. Since I am not a member of the committee responsible and there was no real possibility of amending this text, I am abstaining.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In Hungary, in 2010, a waste tank ruptured in an aluminium mill near the town of Ajka, resulting in the release of nearly one million cubic metres of highly alkaline, so-called red mud. Several nearby villages were sunk, 10 people were killed, about 150 were injured, and significant land, including a Natura 2000 protected area, was contaminated. Red mud is waste from industrial aluminium production and its disposal is a huge challenge for the mining industry. The disaster that took place in Hungary revealed shortcomings in the application of European Union legislation, as well as in the methods of inspection.  The oral question to the Commission and the Council on this issue concerns the lessons learned from this disaster, in particular how the relevant legislation can be properly implemented and whether the institutions would support the adoption of an EU mechanism to pursue financial claims in the event of similar events. The experience gained from the disaster in Hungary shows the need for a more efficient preventive system, and I have therefore expressed my support in the vote.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The bursting of a reservoir of toxic slamas from an aluminium oxide plant has contaminated several villages and towns in Hungary. Ten people died, 150 were injured. This accident has put the poor application and potholes of environmental legislation on industrial toxic waste in the EU. The resolution calls for efforts to understand the current situation of mine waste, its management and treatment. Further investment is needed in research and development of the prevention and treatment of this type of toxic waste. Stricter environmental rules for environmental inspections are advocated, alongside sufficient means for the national bodies responsible for these inspections. Regular information to the public on pollution levels and degrees of threat to ecosystems and public health is advocated. We voted for it.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I abstained from voting on this report for the following reasons. The essence of the report is as follows: the European Union is giving money to so-called developing countries that are willing to implement the European Union's vision of gender equality. What's wrong with that? All the more so because I myself am committed to the principle of equal treatment, the prohibition of discrimination. Well, the problem is, it's not just about girls going to school in, say, Africa. Or ban genital mingling, because it's an unacceptable habit. But also about the forced accept of abortion as a human right by so-called developing countries, or the so-called EU standards of intersexity, transgenderism and others, in exchange for aid money. This is unacceptable to me.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Humanity, as well as several other living beings on our planet, consists of two parts: women and men. And it must be absolutely self-evident that both sides participate fully and as actively as possible in the society of their respective countries. This also applies to the transnational, national level. In many countries, unfortunately also in the European Union, women of different ages still do not have sufficient full control over their lives. Early marriages are just one such example. The impossibility of attending school, getting a full education, working in a wide range of fields according to your knowledge and abilities without any gender-based segregation or discrimination, as well as widespread poverty in lower-income families where the main breadth is a woman. Such and similar situations should not exist in our world at all.  That is why I voted in favour.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, arís bhí áthas orm go raibh mé in ann vótáil le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí seo go léir, agus glacadh leis an tuarascáil le móramh mór: 524 Fheisire i bhfabhar. Taispeánann sé sin go dtuigimid cás na mban agus go bhfuil fonn orainn cabhrú leo agus cothromaíocht a chruthú.  Ach bhíomar i gcoinne Leasú 7 agus Leasú 19, mar bhí siad ag caint faoi ghinmhilleadh a chur ar fáil saor in aisce sna tíortha atá ag forbairt. Agus ní dóigh liom, agus ní dóigh le mo ghrúpa ach oiread, go bhfuil sé sin ceart. Vótálamar i gcoinne an dá leasú sin agus tá áthas orm a rá gur chaill siad. Dá bhrí sin bhíomar in ann aontú leis an tuarascáil i gcoitinne. Mar dá mba rud é go nglacfaí le ginmhilleadh a bheith ar fáil go forleathan, gan dabht ar bith, bhainfí mí-úsáid as ina lán cúiseanna.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialist delegation in the European Parliament voted in favour of this Resolution, which defends universal access to sexual and reproductive health as a right. We Socialists are committed to defending women's freedoms, rights and empowerment in developing countries. We call for an overall approach to violence against women and girls, as well as greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization, and greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization , forced pregnancy, domestic violence and marital rape, forced and early marriage and gender-based violence in conflict and post-conflict situations. We support the removal of social and legal barriers to women's access to productive goods, as well as actions that contribute to women's economic training and respect for their economic rights, such as guaranteeing them decent work and equal pay.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution since it generally recognizes the limited progress made on gender equality in cooperation after analysing the results of the Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Training in Development Cooperation (2010-2015); this criticism of EU development policy is necessary as the European Commission does not have a reliable and effective strategy in this area. It shows that there is not even a specific section in the annual report of the European Commission's Directorate-General for International Cooperation and Development. On the other hand, I find it unsatisfactory that amendments Nos 1 and 2 to the Resolution tabled in plenary should be rejected. They requested that the provision of humanitarian aid from the EU and its Member States should not be subject to restrictions by third States, including access to safe abortion for victims of violations in armed conflict, as well as improved access to health, health education, family planning, etc. We have seen with stupor how these amendments which are eminently humanitarian have been voted against.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is intended to defend the fight against the submission of women in developing countries: the fight against female circumcision, forced marriage, equal treatment or the empowerment of women are the themes covered in this text. However, I abstained on this report because some of the recommendations are at odds with the way of life of some traditional societies. In addition, very costly measures, such as the introduction of state statistics, are, in my view, inoperative.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for increased efforts to tackle gender inequality through the renewal of the EU’s Gender Action Plan (GAP I). The resolution specifically calls for further action on two Millennium Development Goals (MDG) – increasing gender equality and women’s empowerment, and reducing maternal mortality rates. The resolution welcomes the Commission’s intention to initiate a transformative shift with GAP II and calls for it to take the form of a Commission communication. I voted in favour of Amendment 1, which calls for access to safe abortion for women and girls who are victims of rape in armed conflicts. I also voted in favour of Amendment 2, which calls for further efforts globally to ensure access to safe abortion services, in the context of addressing the MDG on maternal health by reducing the incidence of high-risk births. Sinn Féin believes that the option of a termination should be available where there is a real and substantial risk to the life of a pregnant woman – including where she is suicidal – that would be averted only by an abortion; in the case of rape or incest; and in the case of fatal foetal abnormality.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. As is often the case when it comes to these kinds of issues, the motion for a resolution we had to vote on is a catch-all that mixes good and bad measures.  The report rightly denounces female circumcision and abuse in several countries. Nevertheless, this is accompanied in return by measures derived from a radical feminist ideology, promoting parity in everything and for everything without ever taking into account complementarity and gender differences.  Since most of the amendments in favour of LGBTI communitarianism and abortion were rejected, I did not vote against it, but I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in equality; however, the proposed measures are the wrong way to go about it.  I therefore voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. Today, despite an action plan passed in 2006, gender pay differences persist and are even growing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, because it calls on the Commission to propose new legislation providing more effective means to oversee the implementation and implementation of this action plan in the Member States.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialist delegation in the European Parliament voted in favour of this Resolution, which defends universal access to sexual and reproductive health as a right. We Socialists are committed to defending women's freedoms, rights and empowerment in developing countries. We call for an overall approach to violence against women and girls, as well as greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization, and greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization , forced pregnancy, domestic violence and marital rape, forced and early marriage and gender-based violence in conflict and post-conflict situations. We support the removal of social and legal barriers to women's access to productive goods, as well as actions that contribute to women's economic training and respect for their economic rights, such as guaranteeing them decent work and equal pay.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on updating the EU plan for gender equality and women's empowerment in development cooperation. The EU is committed to promoting gender equality and ensuring gender mainstreaming in all its actions. I agree that, for better results, the European External Action Service and the Commission need to renew their political commitments.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with increasing women's empowerment and promoting it with concrete measures. I also consider a significant part of the motion to be eligible, but I abstained in the vote. One of the reasons for this is that, according to the motion: "Country-specific recommendations made in the framework of the European Semester should include targets for the effective implementation of the principle of equal treatment."  I reject the European Semester as an instrument limiting the budgetary sovereignty of national governments and parliaments. Another reason is that the motion requires that boards be obliged to ensure a balance of the nationalities on the basis of a specific quota. In my various workplaces, including the Hungarian Parliament, I have been able to work with excellent and highly respected female colleagues who would have considered it humiliating if the opportunity had been given not directly by their own performance but as a 'quota woman'.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I have decided to abstain on this report which, despite some positive points, intends above all to strengthen the sacrosanct Parity at all costs, in a purely ideological way, without the slightest concern for pragmatism.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The resolution, which I have approved, pursues the objective of promoting gender equality as part of a renewed EU action plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in the context of development cooperation and recalls that this fundamental human right, which is not yet fully respected in all States, must not be violated in the name of any religion. culture or tradition. With this resolution, Parliament aspires to a new impetus for the European Union through a strengthened commitment by the European External Action Service and the Commission. This is so that this new action plan is manifested through all aspects of the Union's action, in line with the principles of development cooperation, and applies to developing countries, neighbouring countries and candidate countries.  With this in mind, it calls for more effective implementation strategies through a comprehensive approach, intensifying efforts and increasing resources, with a view to strengthening women's rights and eliminating all forms of violence and discrimination.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on updating the Union Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Training in Development Cooperation. It is vital to have an action plan to boost the future of women in these countries and, above all, it is essential that efforts be strengthened to improve women's access to health and health education, family planning, prenatal care and sexual and reproductive health including abortion services and safe conditions , especially to achieve Millennium Goal Five on maternal health, including reducing infant mortality and preventing high-risk births.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal should encourage a "change of course for the second action plan on gender equality" and then "collect data and objectives" and finally develop the "main aspects of the new action plan on gender equality". If I obviously want us to move towards more equality between men and women in terms of employment and wage levels, or if I condemn violence against women, I think this report is just another statement of good intentions.  This report mixes foreign policy in this area, including equality actions in the context of aid to 'migrants', and internal eu policy, as it encourages Member States to intervene to promote gender equality with clear funding but also with specific indicators (they encourage to follow the recommendations without really giving any leads...).  Finally, some amendments (15, 27..) make a special distinction with regard to women, for example with the following sentence: "with particular attention to young people, migrants, HIV-positive women, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex (LGBTI) people and people with disabilities". So I abstained.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the content of the resolution being voted on, so I voted against it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2012 I voted in favour of this resolution by which Parliament is calling on the Commission to correct the shortcomings of the previous plan in the new Action Plan 2016-2020 and take a step forward. In particular, more budget is needed and to ensure in the mid-term review of programming more programmes that benefit women and girls, as well as to ensure the coherence of foreign policy by applying the Action Plan not only to development cooperation but also to all external policies, including trade.  It also calls for ensuring access to education and the physical and psychological integrity of women and girls and intensifying efforts to eliminate all discriminatory practices and combat and prosecute all forms of violence. Efforts are also needed to ensure and strengthen women's access to health, especially sexual and reproductive health, and to enhance women's economic rights and strengthen their voice and participation. In addition, the EU is demanded to put pressure on third-country governments and all parties involved in conflicts to end the violation as a weapon of war.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because gender equality and women's empowerment are a prerequisite for achieving the Sustainable Development Goals after 2015, and also as an important human rights objective in itself, which must be achieved despite its benefits for development and economic growth. Unfortunately, but still every third woman in the world has experienced physical and sexual violence at some point in her life, with 14 million girls being forced to marry every year. Gender-based violence is a serious violation of human rights and should never be justified by religion, culture or tradition. The European Parliament therefore believes that gender equality and women's empowerment should be a key area of activity for the EU institutions, providing for clear governance responsibilities, both in the central administration and in EU delegations. Parliament calls on EU delegations and Member States' embassies to prioritise and invest in quality gender analysis, which would develop country strategies and programmes. The European Union should review the national indicative plans in the light of the new action plan on gender equality.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The new Action Plan for Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment in Development for 2016-2020 will aim to address the shortcomings of the previous Plan to ensure a solid basis for action in three proposed priority areas: ensuring the physical and psychological integrity of women and girls, promoting women's economic rights and strengthening the role of women and girls and their participation in processes. I support the DEVE Board's intention to ensure that the Plan is well implemented.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP, of course, agrees in principle that gender equality should be promoted in developing nations. We also condemn violent acts against women and we condemn the use of sexual violence in conflict zones. However, we believe that this would be best done through co-operation between member states within the United Nations rather than through EU legislation. We therefore abstained on this particular motion for a resolution.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for increased efforts to tackle gender inequality through the renewal of the EU’s Gender Action Plan (GAP I). The resolution specifically calls for further action on two Millennium Development Goals (MDG) – increasing gender equality and women’s empowerment, and reducing maternal mortality rates. The resolution welcomes the Commission’s intention to initiate a transformative shift with GAP II and calls for it to take the form of a Commission communication. I voted in favour of Amendment 1, which calls for access to safe abortion for women and girls who are victims of rape in armed conflicts. I also voted in favour of Amendment 2, which calls for further efforts globally to ensure access to safe abortion services, in the context of addressing the MDG on maternal health by reducing the incidence of high-risk births. Sinn Féin believes that the option of a termination should be available where there is a real and substantial risk to the life of a pregnant woman – including where she is suicidal – that would be averted only by an abortion; in the case of rape or incest; and in the case of fatal foetal abnormality.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I firmly believe that it is essential that the Union works hard to develop its action plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in development cooperation. Gender equality and development emancipation are objectives that must be pursued for both ethical and economic reasons. On a continent with a majority of women, it is essential that women receive the same pay as their male colleagues and that they have the necessary rights to enable them not to have to choose between career and family.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report defends women who are victims of persecution around the world. One in three women is at risk of physical or sexual violence in her lifetime. Every year, 14 million women are forcibly married. 62 million girls are out of school worldwide. That is why the European Union must encourage equal treatment between women and men and the emancipation of women. If we are fully aware of the abuse of all kinds of women, especially in Arab countries where Sharia law is applied, we oppose egalitarianism between women and men. At the outset, we are against the introduction of unnecessary and costly statistics, which will ensure strict parity in all areas and promote the implementation of affirmative action.  So I voted against this report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Reiterates that women and girls should not be discriminated against within all sectors (work, education, politics, etc.) and calls for the EU to take an active part in this.  It is noted that the GAP (Gender Equality Action Plan) must address the situation of LGBTI people in third countries and include the promotion and protection of the rights of LGBTI people. It also calls for the development of specific EU actions to strengthen the rights of different groups of women, with a particular focus on young people, migrants, women with HIV, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex (LGBTI) people and people with disabilities.  It is considered that gender equality and women's empowerment should be at the heart of the activities of the EU institutions. I am voting against.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialist delegation in the European Parliament voted in favour of this Resolution, which defends universal access to sexual and reproductive health as a right. We Socialists are committed to defending women's freedoms, rights and empowerment in developing countries. We call for an overall approach to violence against women and girls, as well as greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization, and greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization , forced pregnancy, domestic violence and marital rape, forced and early marriage and gender-based violence in conflict and post-conflict situations. We support the removal of social and legal barriers to women's access to productive goods, as well as actions that contribute to women's economic training and respect for their economic rights, such as guaranteeing them decent work and equal pay.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The renewal of the European Union's action plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in development cooperation is needed to improve its effectiveness and effect in developing countries. The European strategy in this area must better correspond to the realities on the ground. Equality between men and women must be a principle rooted in people's minds from an early age. It is therefore through education that we will achieve this goal. Within the Union, much work remains to be done in this area, particularly in the area of equal pay. Our goal must be to promote equality between men and women both within and outside our borders. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote is in favour because the EU action plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in development cooperation has made it possible to intensify and improve the coordination of the efforts of the EU and its Member States on equality between women and men and women's empowerment (GEWE). The evaluations of this plan indicate a number of important results, but also weaknesses in its implementation. The Commission must commit to the mid-term review of the Development Cooperation Instrument (DCI) for 2017 and the performance assessment of the eleventh EDF to assess the impact of programmes funded by this instrument and the EDF on women and girls and to carry out the necessary realising, so as to address the shortcomings that have emerged in the implementation of gap and the post-2015 Sustainable Development Goals.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for increased efforts to tackle gender inequality through the renewal of the EU’s Gender Action Plan (GAP I). The resolution specifically calls for further action on two Millennium Development Goals (MDG) – increasing gender equality and women’s empowerment, and reducing maternal mortality rates. The resolution welcomes the Commission’s intention to initiate a transformative shift with GAP II and calls for it to take the form of a Commission communication. I voted in favour of Amendment 1, which calls for access to safe abortion for women and girls who are victims of rape in armed conflicts. I also voted in favour of Amendment 2, which calls for further efforts globally to ensure access to safe abortion services, in the context of addressing the MDG on maternal health by reducing the incidence of high-risk births. Sinn Féin believes that the option of a termination should be available where there is a real and substantial risk to the life of a pregnant woman – including where she is suicidal – that would be averted only by an abortion; in the case of rape or incest; and in the case of fatal foetal abnormality.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP, of course, agrees in principle that gender equality should be promoted in developing nations. We also condemn violent acts against women and we condemn the use of sexual violence in conflict zones. However, we believe that this would be best done through co-operation between member states within the United Nations rather than through EU legislation. We therefore abstained on this particular motion for a resolution.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is committed to promoting gender equality and ensuring gender mainstreaming in all of its actions. Gender equality and women’s empowerment (GEWE) is a precondition for achieving post-2015 sustainable development goals and is also a self-standing human rights issue that should be pursued regardless of its benefits for development and growth. It is evident that progress towards GEWE has been slow and uneven and that no country in the world has fully closed the gender gap. This lack of progress has been exacerbated by the persistent and chronic underinvestment in GEWE. I agree that we need a step-change in EU action on GEWE and a renewed political commitment by the European External Action Service (EEAS) and the Commission to improve performance. I strongly believe in and support further work in this area, but I could not vote in favour of this report as I am against the use of abortion, which the report fully supports.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the new GAP for the period 2016-2020 (GAP 2) as the text aims to address the implementation deficiencies shown by the previous GAP. In particular, emphasis was placed on an "institutional cultural change", aimed at enhancing capacity, counselling and training in the field of gender equality and women's empowerment, by reinforcing attention to information, monitoring and responsibility that take into account the gender dimension as well as a results-based profile. Three priority areas will be proposed: ensuring the physical and psychological integrity of women and girls; promoting women's economic rights; to give more voice to women and girls and to strengthen their participation.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The resolution rightly stresses the importance of increased participation of women in the formulation and implementation of the framework after 2015. Calls for greater financial support to be granted to women's rights organisations, policy-making and capacity-enhancing measures with a view to cooperation and increased participation of civil society grassroots organisations, and in particular women's organisations, in consultations between stakeholders, always at local, regional level. national and international level.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the renewal of the EU action plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in development cooperation. The EU is committed to promoting gender equality and ensuring gender mainstreaming in all its actions. Two of the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) namely the promotion of gender equality (MDG 3) and the improvement of maternal health (MDG 5) directly concern women's rights. Around 62 million girls worldwide do not have access to education and about one in three women are at risk of physical and sexual violence. Moreover, according to the OECD, investment is not sufficient to achieve the objective of gender equality. With this motion for a resolution, the EP calls on the Commission and the European External Action Service (EEAS) to radically change EU action on women's empowerment and gender equality.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of renewing the action plan because I believe it is essential to intensify and improve coordination on equality between men and women and women's empowerment, and this improvement will certainly lead to even greater results. I welcome the fact that the new GAP (Gender Action Plan) for the period 2016-2020 aims to address certain issues in three priority areas: ensuring the physical and psychological integrity of women and girls, promoting women's economic rights and giving women and girls a greater voice by strengthening their participation, issues that I believe are necessary and of the utmost importance. Finally, I agree with the institutional cultural change presented in the text, which aims to strengthen skills, advice and training in the field of gender equality and women's empowerment, by strengthening the focus on information. I am sure that this proposed change will lead to greater visibility and resources.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP, of course, agrees in principle that gender equality should be promoted in developing nations. We also condemn violent acts against women and we condemn the use of sexual violence in conflict zones. However, we believe that this would be best done through co-operation between member states within the United Nations rather than through EU legislation. We therefore decided to abstain on this particular motion for a resolution.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am fully in favour of renewing the EU Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment in Development Cooperation (GAP) because, although it has been instrumental in intensifying and improving the coordination of the efforts of the EU and its Member States on equality between women and men and important results have been achieved, its implementation still has some weaknesses. That is why I believe it is necessary to improve this project, strengthening it and thus ensuring that it is gender-sensitive and addresses the root causes of inequalities. Through the completion of the GAP project, it will be possible to guarantee the physical and psychological integrity of women and girls, to promote women's economic rights and to give a greater voice to women by strengthening their participation.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution since it generally recognizes the limited progress made on gender equality in cooperation after analysing the results of the Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Training in Development Cooperation (2010-2015); this criticism of EU development policy is necessary as the European Commission does not have a reliable and effective strategy in this area. It shows that there is not even a specific section in the annual report of the European Commission's Directorate-General for International Cooperation and Development. On the other hand, I find it unsatisfactory that amendments Nos 1 and 2 to the Resolution tabled in plenary should be rejected. They requested that the provision of humanitarian aid from the EU and its Member States should not be subject to restrictions by third States, including access to safe abortion for victims of violations in armed conflict, as well as improved access to health, health education, family planning, etc. We have seen with stupor how these amendments which are eminently humanitarian have been voted against.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The progress made in the twenty years of implementation of the Beijing Platform has been slow and uneven, so much so that no country in the world has completely closed the gender gap. Alarming figures persist, affecting only those affected the most: one in three women is at risk of physical and sexual violence, 62 million girls worldwide do not attend school, and every year 14 million girls are forced into marriage. As Europe we cannot remain indifferent, we have an obligation to defend the right of every individual to have full control over himself, without suffering any discrimination, coercion or violence. Development policies, neighbourhood policies and enlargement, are instruments that we must use to make a breakthrough in partner countries and to put pressure on the governments of third countries in regions where discrimination is greatest. In addition, the extreme vulnerability of migrant women and the need for specific protection are clear to everyone. For this reason, courageous and targeted actions are urgently needed, which, in addition to those necessary for reception, ensure respect for and defence of the weakest and most exposed subjects.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution which deals with the renewal of the EU plan of Action on Gender Equality on Women's Empowerment in Development. I completely agree with the emphasis that the resolution makes when it states that specific focus is needed to ensure girls' access to education, to allow them to live lives free from violence and remove discriminatory legislation and practices whilst we empower girls and young women globally. However the same resolution alludes to abortion which is currently illegal in Malta and which I am against. So my favour in favour is made with this proviso.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the European Union is committed to promoting gender equality and ensuring gender mainstreaming in all its actions, I believe that it is important to carry out measures to strengthen women's leadership and women's participation and organisations campaigning for women's rights in the public and private spheres.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the renewal of the European Union's action plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in the context of development cooperation. A second action plan on gender equality is needed today to put in place concrete measures to eradicate any discriminatory practice against women. In voting on this motion for a resolution, we recall the fundamental role of education, business and the European Union in the emancipation of women.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to abstain from voting on this issue because I do not believe that the shortcomings are addressed and presented correctly. I also believe that these issues should be addressed at a different level, given factors such as culture, ethnicity, traditions and other accompanying factors contributing to the current situation. Simply setting goals and providing financial support is not the solution.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Gender equality is an important factor in the social, cultural and economic development of countries. However, the use of this fundamental value, individually and without taking into account morality and morality, will lead to criminal acts and destructive practices.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Union is always committed to promoting gender equality and ensuring the integration of the gender dimension into all its actions. Gender equality and women's training are a precondition for achieving the post-2015 sustainable development goals and are also a human rights issue in itself, as gender-based violence is a serious violation of them and should never find justification in religion, culture or tradition; The conclusions of the evaluation of the first Action Plan show the need for greater attention to EU action, which must define and ensure sufficient human and financial resources to meet its IGCM commitments. This Resolution is therefore intended to identify and address potential obstacles in the revision of the Action Plan for the full implementation of EU guidelines on violence against women and girls and the elimination of all forms of violence, through a comprehensive approach to violence against women and girls and an intensification of efforts , as well as increased resources.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP, of course, agrees in principle that gender equality should be promoted in developing nations. We also condemn violent acts against women and we condemn the use of sexual violence in conflict zones. However, we believe that this would be best done through co-operation between member states within the United Nations rather than through EU legislation. We therefore decided to abstain on this particular motion for a resolution.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Union has promoted gender equality and has sought to ensure gender integration into all its actions. However, progress towards gender equality and women's empowerment has been slow and unequal. It should be found that there is progress to be made in all countries. According to the latest figures, around 800 women die worldwide on a daily basis due to complications during pregnancy and childbirth; around 222 million women in developing countries do not have access to safe and modern family planning methods; most of the world's poor are women and households run by women; in the world, 62 million girls do not attend school. Having said that, I agree that the Action Plan should develop specific actions to strengthen the rights of different groups of women, paying particular attention to young women, migrants, women and people with disabilities.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this deliberation because it has too many riders in favour of gender theory.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution states that progress towards gender equality and their empowerment, as well as maternal health, has been slow and unequal. No country in the world has completely bridged the gender gap. It is noted that the share of development aid for family planning for total global health aid has decreased. A significant shift in EU action on gender equality and women's empowerment is advocated and measures are being pointed out. It insists on the use of qualitative and quantitative indicators that take into account gender and the collection of gender-disaggregated data, timely and systematically, and in this sense Member States are invited to set up gender-sensitive monitoring systems. It underlines the need for the EU to provide sufficient human and financial resources to meet its commitments in this area. The resolution recommends the inclusion in the Second Gender Action Plan of very concrete measures. Among others: the call to guarantee the protection of the rights of different groups of women (young people, migrants, HIV-infected, LGBTI and disabled people); recognition of the importance of universal access to sexual and reproductive health care and rights; recognition of the premism of removing social and legal barriers. We voted in favour.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as it is positive step in making gender equality a reality.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union's objective has always been to promote gender equality and ensure its application in all activities. Gender equality and women's empowerment are also a prerequisite for achieving sustainable development for the period 2015 and represent a separate chapter in the field of human rights. I must also remind you that the vast majority of people living beyond the poverty line in the world are women or families led by women, and that even today, almost 62 million girls in the world do not go to school and every year 14 million girls are forced into marriage. It is therefore important that we appeal to the Member States to strengthen their gender equality policies and to create better conditions also in the area of merging employment and family policy.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 As always, the FEMM committee uses the pretext of the title of the report and uses women as a political tool in order to insert LGBTI instances and more.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Gender equality is an important factor in the social, cultural and economic development of countries. However, the use of this fundamental value, individually, and without taking into account morals and morals, will lead to criminal acts and destructive practices. I am voting against this report.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the importance of empowering women, not only as a self-standing human rights issue but also as a precondition for achieving post-2015 sustainable development goals, I believe that the 2017 mid-term review of the Development Cooperation Instrument presents a good opportunity to assess the impact of DCI-financed programmes on women and girls and to make reallocations if necessary. Two of the Millennium Development Goals explicitly address women’s rights: namely the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of women; and the improvement of maternal health. They remain, unfortunately, largely unachieved. Moreover, the progress towards gender equality and women’s empowerment has been slow and uneven in many countries. The conclusions of the evaluation of the Gender Action Plan 2010-2015 show the clear need for a step-change in EU action on gender equality and women’s empowerment and the fact that we need a renewed political commitment by the European External Action Service and the Commission to improve performance. I therefore strongly support the call to put in place measures that will strengthen leadership and participation by women and women’s rights organisations in both the public and private spheres.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in full favour of the EU's need to promote gender equality and ensure the integration of the gender dimension into all its actions. It is therefore essential to establish a principle of coherence between EU development policies and external policies, as well as between the new Action Plan and the next Action Plan on human rights and democracy. Women are a collective that in many countries is particularly disadvantaged and at risk, so we must concentrate the EU's cooperation and development efforts on ensuring girls' access to education, enabling them to live free from violence and eliminating regulations and practices.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialist delegation in the European Parliament voted in favour of this Resolution, which defends universal access to sexual and reproductive health as a right. We Socialists are committed to defending women's freedoms, rights and empowerment in developing countries. We call for an overall approach to violence against women and girls, as well as greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization, and greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization , forced pregnancy, domestic violence and marital rape, forced and early marriage and gender-based violence in conflict and post-conflict situations. We support the removal of social and legal barriers to women's access to productive goods, as well as actions that contribute to women's economic training and respect for their economic rights, such as guaranteeing them decent work and equal pay.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution as it advocates universal access to sexual and reproductive health as a right. We Socialists are committed to defending women's freedoms, rights and empowerment in developing countries. We call for an overall approach to violence against women and girls, as well as greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization, and greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization , forced pregnancy, domestic violence and marital rape, forced and early marriage and gender-based violence in conflict and post-conflict situations. We support the removal of social and legal barriers to women's access to productive goods, as well as actions that contribute to women's economic training and respect for their economic rights, such as guaranteeing them decent work and equal pay.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on renewing the EU action plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in development cooperation, because I believe that gender equality and women's empowerment are essential conditions for achieving the post-2015 sustainable development goals in developing countries and inescapable preconditions for full and homogeneous gender equality. I am of the opinion that these objectives should be pursued regardless of their benefits for development and growth, as gender-based violence is a violation of human rights. The new GAP2 needs to develop on different perspectives and directions than the previous action plan, which revealed the clear need for a change of approach and greater financial commitment by the EU. I share the increased efforts and resources to prevent violence against women and any other discriminatory practices that deprive them of the freedom and dignity of human beings, such as female mutilation, forced sterilisation, domestic violence and rape, painful and still too frequent phenomena in today's society and in particular for migrant women. Finally, I would like to see a stronger role for women in entrepreneurship, the social economy and microfinance.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today against the renewal of the EU Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment in Development Cooperation, as the demands made in the text do not correspond to what I represent from my own development policy experience and as ACP coordinator of my group: excessive, undefined and insensitive gender ideology hinders, rather than promotes, development policy.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I agree with the motion for a resolution on the renewal of the EU Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment in Development Cooperation.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP, of course, agrees in principle that gender equality should be promoted in developing nations. We also condemn violent acts against women and we condemn the use of sexual violence in conflict zones. However, we believe that this would be best done through co-operation between member states within the United Nations rather than through EU legislation. We therefore decided to abstain on this particular motion for a resolution.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This motion for a resolution received my support today, as protecting and empowering women and girls is of vital importance. On a daily basis, we witness reports of women and girls violated in most horrific ways, including in the context of war and conflict – the female sexual enslavement in the Democratic Republic of Congo being one example. We must guarantee that these women and girls are given all the medical care and support necessary to recover their lives. Goal 5 of the Sustainable Development Goals, recently signed in New York, emphasises what we are all surely already aware of: the need for education in empowering women and girls. We now need to back up words with action and to re-affirm our commitment to the EU Plan of Action. Therefore, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution, which, taking into account the conclusions of the evaluation of the first Action Plan on gender equality, underlines the need for radical change in EU action on gender equality and women's empowerment, while calling for renewed political commitment by the EOM and the Commission in this regard. In addition, the Resolution underlines the need for the new Action Plan to focus on all aspects of EU foreign policy — development cooperation, humanitarian aid, trade, human rights, external relations, migration and asylum; all this, in line with the principle of coherence of development policies. Finally, the Resolution also calls for measures to ensure access to sexual and reproductive health and rights as a key element for women's empowerment.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialist delegation in the European Parliament voted in favour of this Resolution, which defends universal access to sexual and reproductive health as a right. We Socialists are committed to defending women's freedoms, rights and empowerment in developing countries. We call for an overall approach to violence against women and girls, as well as greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization, and greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization , forced pregnancy, domestic violence and marital rape, forced and early marriage and gender-based violence in conflict and post-conflict situations. We support the removal of social and legal barriers to women's access to productive goods, as well as actions that contribute to women's economic training and respect for their economic rights, such as guaranteeing them decent work and equal pay.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported the resolution renewing the European action plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in the context of development cooperation because it is imperative that gender equality be part of European development policy. Women and girls are still victims of discrimination in the workplace and in education, as well as physical and/or psychological violence, which is unacceptable. The 2016-2020 action plan must enable the elimination of all forms of violence and discrimination against women and girls and achieve concrete results in EU partner countries through a comprehensive approach, mobilising more resources and efforts.  We must not forget that equality between women and men is one of the main values of the European Union and, therefore, all aspects of its foreign policy must comply with it.  The resolution calls on the Commission and the European External Action Service to promote this equality in their policies and to assess it in their annual reports. It also stresses the need to engage men in this process and to promote a particular approach for young, migrant, LGBTI, disabled and HIV-positive women, which should be aimed at in such an ambitious policy.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialist delegation in the European Parliament voted in favour of this Resolution, which defends universal access to sexual and reproductive health as a right. We Socialists are committed to defending women's freedoms, rights and empowerment in developing countries. We call for an overall approach to violence against women and girls, as well as greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization, and greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization , forced pregnancy, domestic violence and marital rape, forced and early marriage and gender-based violence in conflict and post-conflict situations. We support the removal of social and legal barriers to women's access to productive goods, as well as actions that contribute to women's economic training and respect for their economic rights, such as guaranteeing them decent work and equal pay.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution, which, taking into account the conclusions of the evaluation of the first Action Plan on gender equality, underlines the need for radical change in EU action on gender equality and women's empowerment, while calling for renewed political commitment by the EOM and the Commission in this regard. In addition, the Resolution underlines the need for the new Action Plan to focus on all aspects of EU foreign policy — development cooperation, humanitarian aid, trade, human rights, external relations, migration and asylum; all this, in line with the principle of coherence of development policies. Finally, the Resolution also calls for measures to ensure access to sexual and reproductive health and rights as a key element for women's empowerment.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolutions on renewing the EU's agenda of action on gender equality and women's empowerment in development, as promoting gender equality is one of the main principles underpinning the European Union. Greater political determination is needed to fully implement EU guidelines to prevent violence against women and girls. In this context, businesses must contribute to progress on gender equality through measures that encourage women's empowerment in the economy and the expansion of women's economic rights. I also support women's involvement in growing economic areas such as the ICT sector and the circular economy. Therefore, I believe that more efficient implementation strategies and quantitative and qualitative forward indicators in the area concerned are needed to improve monitoring and evaluation processes in the form of reaching the objectives of the post-2015 global development framework.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The report denounces, unfortunately, the fact that female circumcision and abuse of women in several countries around the world are still to be deplored in the 21st century.  But this report unfortunately serves as a pretext for a new ideological catch-all that has nothing to do with the sad subject. The text is accompanied by measures derived from a radical feminist ideology, promoting parity in everything and for everything without ever taking into account complementarity and differences between the sexes.  It is all the more unseemly to use these appalling cases to spread other ideas... Since most of the amendments marked by the LGBT and pro-abortion seal were rejected, I did not vote against it, but I abstained.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the renewal of the Union's action plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in the context of development cooperation. The text welcomes this renewal and calls for the issue of gender equality to have a greater place in development cooperation, as women are more often affected by discrimination in developing countries. The resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text because the European Union must promote gender equality and women's emancipation in its development cooperation policies. However, the results of the latest action plan are not satisfactory. It was therefore necessary to renew this action plan to intensify efforts and resources to eliminate all forms of violence against women.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the resolution on the renewal of the European Union's action plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in the context of development cooperation. This report rightly defends the fight against female circumcision and subjugation around the world. However, it over-pushes a desire for pure and perfect parity even in the implementation of statistics in the Member States, which are as useless as they are expensive. In addition, some of the recommendations are at odds with the lifestyles of some traditional societies.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's resolution on renewing the EU's agenda of action on gender equality and women's empowerment in development, as I believe that equality is the foundation of modern society and should be integrated in all countries without exception. The European Union has committed to promoting equality, which is a precondition for achieving sustainable development, but it is also a human rights issue that needs to be specifically addressed. This applies in particular to the rights of women who remain not fully realised.  Member States are called for the establishment of a system for monitoring equality, investing in national statistics and eliminating discriminatory legislation. Key aspects of the new GAP are the elimination of all forms of inequality and discrimination by enabling education and access to economic and financial resources for women and girls.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – Gender equality issues in the form of various reports often occur in the EP programme. The problem is, above all, the politicisation of this issue and the inadequate interference with the competences of the Member States. In order to address positively, I consider it necessary to reconsider existing positions on neuralgic points and to draw up a new EU Action Plan on Gender Equality, which will objectively assess the facts and propose solutions acceptable to all EU Member States.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the renewal of the EU action plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in the context of development cooperation for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 7/10/2015 and because in the period of our global financial crisis, there are strong discrimination against women, as well as differences in wages and pensions between the sexes, all over the world.
