Moreover, women's unemployment levels far exceed those of men, which shows even more strongly discrimination in terms of the recruitment criteria for workers. In impoverished Greece, women are the biggest victims of the crisis. Thus, the unemployment rate for women in the first quarter of 2015 is 30.6% compared to 23.5% for men. The Member States of the European Union must fight to eliminate the gender pay gap between men and women in the developing world and to impose transparency on gender pension systems. They should also safeguard women's rights in relation to motherhood and oppose the unfair dismissal of female workers during their pregnancy.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin abstained on this report. This text, which was originally commendable, presents the conclusions of the European Union's assessment on gender equality and women's empowerment (GEWE) and recalls obvious and shameful facts, such as the fact that one in three women is likely to experience physical and sexual violence, and that 14 million girls are forced to marry each year. Although commendable, this text is perverted and hijacked by the multiple pro-LGBTI amendments.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that this motion for a resolution stresses the importance of enhancing girls’ access to all levels of education and removing sex-based barriers to learning.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the motion for a resolution on the renewal of the European Union action plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in development cooperation. The achievement of gender equality and women's emancipation has been slow to such an extent that no country in the world has ever completely closed the gender gap. The European Union has always been strongly committed to promoting integrity on gender equality in all its actions, tenaciously protecting women's empowerment in development cooperation. Gender equality and women's empowerment are to be considered basic prerequisites for achieving the post-2015 sustainable development goals and achieving human rights goals.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the content of this resolution and have therefore voted in favour. I am convinced that it is important for the Union to commit itself to developing the action plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in development cooperation.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European Parliament gives its recommendations to the Commission for the new EU plan 2016-2020 on gender equality and women's empowerment in the context of development cooperation. Based on his assessment of the previous plan, he called for a "radical change of course": more human and financial resources to ensure the physical and psychological integrity of women and girls, to promote women's economic rights and to strengthen their participation in societies. The resolution stresses girls' education and universal access to health care and coverage, including sexual and reproductive rights, as a means of emancipation.  I note essential passages on the needs of migrant women and the specific barriers of women in the rural world. I regret the more global lack of criticism of the Union's foreign and trade policy, which is plundering these developing countries and de facto contributing to the obstacles to women's emancipation. Nevertheless, I am voting to support the political and financial efforts requested.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. As is often the case on these kinds of issues, this report is a catch-all that mixes good and bad measures.  The report rightly denounces female circumcision and abuse in several countries. Nevertheless, this is accompanied in return by measures derived from a radical feminist ideology, promoting parity in everything and for everything without ever taking into account complementarity and gender differences.  Some of the recommendations are at odds with the lifestyles of some traditional societies. I abstained.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution tabled on the basis of oral questions on the renewal of the EU Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment in Development Cooperation is another in line; which speaks an outwardly handsome language of human rights and equality between men and women, listing the necessary and commendable objectives, such as eliminating violence against women in wartime conflicts, but, in fact, it is once again just an attempt to export gender ideology from both the European continent and third world countries under the guise of 'development aid'. At a moment when similar resolutions on the right to "reproductive health" are being talked about, access to contraception and abortion is in mind. While the right to human rights belongs to health, the right to abortion does not exist in any international declaration. Moreover, "gender theory" obscures the division of mankind into two sexes, therefore it does not create preconditions either for their cooperation or for efforts to eliminate real discrimination. Moreover, I recall, on the basis of a number of articles of the Treaty of Lisbon, that the European Union does not have the competence to order other countries to do so. I therefore reject the resolution tabled.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which calls for renewal of the EU Plan of Action on Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment in Development. However, I voted against the paragraphs calling on Member States to implement measures on abortion, sexual and reproductive rights. The EU has no competences on abortion policy at national level and, therefore, cannot interfere in Member States’ policies in this area, which we should fully respect.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Development has tabled a motion for the adoption of a resolution on the renewal of the action plan "Gender equality and women's empowerment in development cooperation" to an oral question. The draft welcomes the Commission's intention to draw up a new action plan on gender equality and proposes key aspects of the new Action Plan. I supported the draft.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is essential that Member States take the opportunity to simplify and update their legislation on equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in areas related to employment and occupation. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is essential that Member States work together and articulately to promote greater equal opportunities in all employment-related matters.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution on the renewal of the European Union's action plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in the context of development cooperation is a catalogue of wishful thinking and amendments hindering national sovereignty: pushing at European and international levels for binding parity, for the generalisation of free abortion , or same-sex marriage and adoption would make me lean against this text if not for the fight against female circumcision and the various sexual violence inflicted on women around the world, as well as the recognition of access to health as a fundamental human right. Wishing to leave it to the nations and peoples to determine their way of life, with the obvious exclusion of physical violence, I therefore find myself obliged to ignore the few positive points of this resolution and to abstain.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the emancipation of women in the context of development cooperation. The Treaty on the European Union stipulates that gender equality is one of the main European values, which I support with steadfastness and determination. In the cooperation programmes it funds, Europe must promote this principle. I particularly agree with this text which considers that gender-based violence constitutes a serious violation of human rights and cannot in any way be justified by religion, culture or tradition. I would add that we must remain vigilant so that women's rights do not regress in Europe either. No country in the world has yet fully closed the rights gap between men and women, whether in developing and developed countries. The struggle for women's rights is therefore an ongoing struggle that must mobilize us all.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution that will renew the EU Plan of Action on Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment in Development and will focus on all aspects of EU external policy – development cooperation, humanitarian aid, trade, human rights and foreign affairs, migration and asylum – in line with the ‘policy coherence for development’ principle, which should apply to developing, neighbourhood and enlargement countries alike.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I have known about discrimination and abuse against women since last term, when I was on the FEMM (Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality) committee. I believe that the European Union must respond with one voice to a problem still existing in many of our societies. As one in three women at global level risks experiencing violence (physical, sexual), discrimination and coercive ness at some point in life, we need a common European action plan on women's promotion and gender equality. In order to address this problem, I believe that it is essential for Romania and the rest of the European countries for the state to promote, facilitate and strengthen girls' access to all levels of education.  Also, as the report also mentions, Member States must strengthen women's legal rights and their access to justice through legal reform that pays attention to gender issues. The role that women play is crucial in any society, which is one of the keys to economic and social development at European level.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The motion for a resolution calls for a revision focusing on women's empowerment. This includes more education and the fight against discrimination and violence. In my opinion, women have the opportunity to reach all levels of education. All further decisions should be taken by the Member States. That is why I voted against this motion.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for increased efforts to tackle gender inequality through the renewal of the EU’s Gender Action Plan (GAP I). The resolution specifically calls for further action on two Millennium Development Goals (MDG) – increasing gender equality and women’s empowerment, and reducing maternal mortality rates. The resolution welcomes the Commission’s intention to initiate a transformative shift with GAP II and calls for it to take the form of a Commission communication. I voted in favour of Amendment 1, which calls for access to safe abortion for women and girls who are victims of rape in armed conflicts. I also voted in favour of Amendment 2, which calls for further efforts globally to ensure access to safe abortion services, in the context of addressing the MDG on maternal health by reducing the incidence of high-risk births. Sinn Féin believes that the option of a termination should be available where there is a real and substantial risk to the life of a pregnant woman – including where she is suicidal – that would be averted only by an abortion; in the case of rape or incest; and in the case of fatal foetal abnormality.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Gender equality and women's empowerment should be one of the important tasks of the Institutions of the European Union and this process must be accelerated by channelling more money into it and making it a priority in the area of development cooperation.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the renewal of the EU action plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in development cooperation (GAP 2) as I believe that the conclusions of the evaluation of the First Action Plan on Gender Equality (GAP 1) clearly demonstrate the need for a radical change in EU action on gender equality and women's empowerment , as well as a renewed political commitment by the European External Action Service and the Commission to improve the results achieved. Furthermore, I am convinced that GAP 2 should focus on all aspects of the EU's external policy – development cooperation, humanitarian aid, trade, human rights and foreign affairs, migration and asylum – in line with the principle of coherence of development policies, and be applied in the same way to developing countries and those affected by neighbourhood policy and enlargement.  Finally, I argue that gender equality and women's empowerment should be at the heart of the activities of the EU institutions, with clear management responsibilities both in central administration and in EU delegations.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 While I consider gender equality and women's empowerment to be fundamental as human rights and essential conditions for achieving sustainable development, I would vote against it. I do not agree with some of the points raised in the proposal.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution on the recast of the EU Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment in Development, as I believe that in some areas need to be replaced by ineffective or less effective measures and activities with better measures that will contribute to women's empowerment in development.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Since articles that I considered highly contentious and problematic and not at all in the domain of the European Union, relating to the promotion of abortion, were expelled from the draft motion for a resolution, I supported this resolution. Also, I think it is important to note again that the concept of "safe abortion" contained in the original motion for the resolution does not exist, since abortion is never safe – not even for the mother, let alone for the child who loses her life with it. Therefore, I am satisfied that this resolution in its final text is aimed at empowering women who today make up the majority of poor people in the world, empowering girls who today 62 million in the world do not attend school, and 14 million of them a year are forced to marry, towards the protection of women, one in three of whom are subjected to violence at least once in their lives. The struggle to empower women and their equality is extremely important, it is even more important that this fight be honest and directed towards the right goals, which, unfortunately, is often not the case while under the fight for women's rights they try to push through various initiatives that actually violate and violate women's rights, and while under the fight for women's rights, the right to life must be the starting point of any fight for women's rights.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution on the renewal of the European Union's action plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in the context of development cooperation is a catalogue of wishful thinking and amendments hindering national sovereignty: pushing at European and international levels for binding parity, to the generalization of free abortion or to same-sex marriage and adoption would make me lean against this text if it were not for the fight against female circumcision and the various sexual violence inflicted on women around the world, as well as the recognition of access to health as a fundamental human right. Wishing to leave it to the nations and peoples to determine their way of life, with the obvious exclusion of physical violence, I therefore find myself obliged to ignore the few positive points of this resolution and to abstain.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ It is inadmissible that in the modern world the vast majority of poor people remain women, remain largely victims of sexual and domestic violence, that in many parts of the world they still do not have access to the full realisation of their health, maternal and reproductive rights, that 62 million girls do not have access to education, and high positions in businesses, business and economic sectors continue to err in women. As it turned out to be the cause of slowing the progress of women's empowerment and achieving gender equality by permanently and chronically lacking investment in them, there was a need for further, more concrete and more targeted action, in the form of a new EU plan for gender equality and the empowerment of women in development, which would be called GAP 2.  This proposal, which I fully support, invites work on gender equality and women's empowerment as a core activity of the EU institutions with a clear management responsibility in Central Administration, and calls on all EU delegations to submit an annual report on the implementation of the GAP. It is essential, in cooperation with competent socio-political actors, to provide a stimulating environment, by removing social and legal barriers, women's access to production assets, gender-sensitive budget planning, and, most importantly, the EU's comprehensive approach to violence against women with increased efforts and resources to prevent and abolish all discriminatory practices against women.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union is obliged to promote gender equality and to guarantee its inclusion in all areas of its work, as gender equality and women's empowerment are preconditions for achieving the Post-2015 Sustainable Development Goals and also a separate human rights issue that should address regardless of its benefits for development and growth. Given that girls and young women are particularly disadvantaged, it is necessary to focus on ensuring girls have access to education and allowing them to live free from violence, to remove discriminatory legislation and practices, and to empower girls and young women worldwide.  The EU must provide and ensure sufficient financial and human resources, and establish clear objectives and indicators to meet its commitments on gender equality and women's empowerment. With the majority of the world's poor women or people living in women-run households, and 62 million girls in the world not being schooled, the EU must promote change. I believe that the EU should promote increases in women's legal rights and access to justice, and therefore I support the Resolution.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Gender equality is one of the key topics of debate in the field of development policy. Barriers that, on the basis of gender alone, prevent women and girls from being equal should be removed. Women should have access to all levels of education as well as adequate healthcare. It is essential that the European Union take steps to improve the current situation and empower women. I am sure that the European Union can contribute to these changes and thus positively influence not only current events, but also future developments. Changes in social, economic, cultural and political areas will certainly help to improve the position of women and girls.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. We have approved the renewal of this action plan because the EU must remain a power defending gender equality and women's empowerment in our foreign policy, including our development policy. In particular, I supported the paragraphs giving women all the means to dispose of their bodies, especially in areas of armed conflict or in areas of lawlessness. European humanitarian aid must not be conditioned, it must be universal. Since the Weil Act, France has enforced this right.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Equality between men and women is one of the fundamental principles on which the EU is founded. Gender equality and women's empowerment are a precondition for achieving sustainable development goals, and the EU should ensure that they are promoting and integrating them into all its policies and actions. The truth, however, is that progress towards gender equality and women's empowerment has been slow, and these objectives remain largely unrealised. To this extent and with the Commission currently working on the new Gender Action Plan (PAG2), it is important to ensure a radical change in EU action in this area and the adoption of a renewed political commitment that can bring greater effectiveness to the results achieved. This resolution leaves a few recommendations here on the main aspects that PAG2 should address. I voted in favour.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. The figures on gender equality and women's empowerment are unacceptable: the Millennium Development Goals for women are not being met, 62 million girls worldwide are out of school, one in three women in the world is at risk of physical or sexual violence once in their lives...  What barbarity! Let us strengthen our actions on gender equality and women's empowerment. I have, of course, decided to vote in favour of this resolution, which concerns the Second Union Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Emancipation in the framework of development cooperation. These two dimensions will have to be included in all the components of the Union's foreign policy and will need to be monitored and assessed.  The new plan must improve girls' access to education, help eliminate all forms of violence against women, and contribute to women's economic empowerment. The challenges are many. Let's keep trying.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The evaluation of the Gender 1 Action Plan (PAG 1) revealed the need for radical change in gender equality and women's empowerment. This is why THIS PAG 2, which advocates gender equality (GI) as a central element of the activities of the Institutions of the European Union, has emerged, seeking to ensure that gi issues are included in the annual reports of all the Commission's Directorates-General involved in external actions in the future. It clearly highlights several areas of intervention: violence against women, rape as a weapon of war, sexual and reproductive rights, equal pay, motherhood and reconciliation of this with professional life, the role of formal and informal education, the vulnerability of migrant women, refugees and asylum seekers, among many others.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialist delegation in the European Parliament voted in favour of this Resolution, which defends universal access to sexual and reproductive health as a right. We Socialists are committed to defending women's freedoms, rights and empowerment in developing countries. We call for an overall approach to violence against women and girls, as well as greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization, and greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization , forced pregnancy, domestic violence and marital rape, forced and early marriage and gender-based violence in conflict and post-conflict situations. We support the removal of social and legal barriers to women's access to productive goods, as well as actions that contribute to women's economic training and respect for their economic rights, such as guaranteeing them decent work and equal pay.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which believes that this new action plan should focus on all aspects of the Union's foreign policy, namely development cooperation, humanitarian aid, human rights and foreign affairs, migration and asylum. The text of the report also calls on the European Union to defend the fundamental rights of women and girls as enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, as well as to make further efforts to improve women's access to health and education in health, family planning and sexual and reproductive rights.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the renewal of the Eu ropean Union action plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in development cooperation because I believe that women's emancipation must be fostered and guaranteed and all forms of discrimination against women must be combated.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution, which, taking into account the conclusions of the evaluation of the first Action Plan on gender equality, underlines the need for radical change in EU action on gender equality and women's empowerment, while calling for renewed political commitment by the EOM and the Commission in this regard. In addition, the Resolution underlines the need for the new Action Plan to focus on all aspects of EU foreign policy — development cooperation, humanitarian aid, trade, human rights, external relations, migration and asylum; all this, in line with the principle of coherence of development policies. Finally, the Resolution also calls for measures to ensure access to sexual and reproductive health and rights as a key element for women's empowerment.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution since it generally recognizes the limited progress made on gender equality in cooperation after analysing the results of the Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Training in Development Cooperation (2010-2015); this criticism of EU development policy is necessary as the European Commission does not have a reliable and effective strategy in this area. It shows that there is not even a specific section in the annual report of the European Commission's Directorate-General for International Cooperation and Development. On the other hand, I find it worrying that amendments Nos 1 and 2 to the Resolution tabled in the House were rejected. They requested that the provision of humanitarian aid from the EU and its Member States should not be subject to restrictions by third States, including access to safe abortion for victims of violations in armed conflict, as well as improved access to health, health education, family planning, etc. We have seen with stupor how these amendments which are eminently humanitarian have been voted against.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. The Plan that took effect between 2010 and 2015 contributed to the development of a set of new policies in the framework of cooperation and development. However, there are still a number of situations that need intensification and others that deserve more adjusted treatment or even new approaches. The Plan that will be in place between 2016 and 2020 should be ambitious and coherent. It is intended to call for cultural change at the level of institutions. It must welcome the social and political objectives of the European Union by aligning them with what is our role in the world. The defence of gender equality, also in other geographies, must be a key component of this new Plan. For these reasons, I voted positively for this report.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as I do not want the EU to be involved in developing nations. I do not believe the EU has a place in foreign affairs. However, I agree that gender equality should be promoted in developing nations. I also agree that institutions such as the UN should play a vital role in presenting targets to achieve these goals. I just do not wish for the EU to have an active role in this process.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU Plan of Action on Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment in Development is a crucial part of the Union’s advocacy of gender equality. I hope I will see true equality between the genders in my lifetime.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The European Union is working to break the vicious cycle of gender discrimination. This includes supporting partner countries in creating a more favourable environment for the realisation of all girls' and women's rights and in achieving long-term improvements in gender equality. It strives for a world in which all the rights of girls and women are established, valued and respected, and where everyone has the opportunity to realise their potential and contribute to a fairer society. The EU has adopted its first action plan on this issue, and now the second is in the process. In doing so, the EU focuses on four fundamental areas, which are ensuring the physical and psychological integrity of girls and women, promoting economic and social rights, strengthening the participation and voice of girls and women, and focusing the activities of the Commission and the European External Action Service into more effectively meeting the EU's commitments. I voted in favour of the proposed resolution as it addresses the key problems of EU action in the area of gender equality and the empowerment and development of women.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 'Breaking the vicious circle on gender discrimination is one of the objectives of the European project. Men and women must have the same rights that are respected worldwide, giving everyone the same chance of development and self-development. In order to achieve this goal, the European Union is renewing its Action Plan on Gender Equality. The European Parliament showed that the introduction of these regulations is not happening in many Member States and that there is a lack of political decisiveness to prioritise this issue. The new action plan does have positive angles, but it is regrettably weaker than european resolutions on gender equality previously adopted. That is why Parliament wants to make adjustments, since certain proposals in the new action plan are ineffective and do not go far enough to safeguard equal rights and prevent discrimination.  I fully support this resolution. Nevertheless, it is disappointing that there is no mention of aid for abortion in developing countries. This is because the Socialist Group is afraid of losing the support of the Christian Democrats. That is why the Greens tabled an amendment to amend this part of the proposal.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this Resolution because gender equality is one of the key issues when it comes to the development of society and the system as a whole. Today, inequality between women and men is present on basic life issues such as the right to education, equality in employment, access to healthcare.  Gender equality is something that is an integral part of the legal framework. The Union needs to be one of the main bodies advocating equality between women and men, and efforts should be made continuously to improve this situation. Every day, all over the world, women's and girls' rights are being hurt. Domestic violence, exploitation, trafficking in women and similar phenomena suggest that the European Union must not give in to its efforts to improve this situation.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly supported this resolution stating that the European Parliament believes the conclusions of the evaluation of the EU Plan of Action on Gender Equality (GAP I) show a clear need for a step-change in EU action on gender equality and women’s empowerment. At present, 62 million girls in the world do not attend school. One in three women worldwide will be a victim of sexual or physical violence in her lifetime. It is essential that the Union takes every possible action to promote gender equality, both intra-Union and internationally. Closing the gender gap on a global scale must be a priority.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union is committed to the idea of promoting gender equality at all levels, and cited this equality as one of the preconditions for achieving its SDGs for the post-2015 period. Taking into account the GAP (gender pay gap) evaluation, it is obvious that much more needs to be done during the GAP2 phase. Some of the measures envisaged in the new plan are addressing barriers to the full implementation of eu guidelines on violence against women and girls (VAWG), greater access for girls and women to education and preventing discrimination against women in the event of maternity leave.  I fully support this proposal because it promotes the basic rights of women and girls and contributes to their protection.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on the renewal of the EU Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment in Development. The main purpose of this report is to make money available to developing countries that are willing to accept the European Union's ideas on gender equality. I, too, support the principle of gender equality and am against any gender discrimination, but the report also talks about certain rights, which should also be human rights, which I do not agree with. This gives people the feeling that developing countries want to impose our views in exchange for money.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Gender equality is an important factor in the social, cultural and economic development of countries. But the use of this fundamental value individually and without taking into account morals and morals will lead to criminal acts and destructive practices.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the renewal of the Action Plan. The EU Action Plan on gender equality and women's role in development cooperation (2010-2015) has made important progress, but work cannot in any way be considered finished. I therefore support continuing it for the period 2016-2020. By working to achieve the three priorities (ensuring the physical and psychological integrity of women and girls; supporting women's economic rights; empowering and empowering women and girls), we are also contributing to the achievement of the SDGs. I agree with the recommendation that the new Action Plan should focus on all aspects of EU external policies, while also needing further progress in this area within the Union. Only with this in mind, we can expect commitment from developing and candidate countries. I particularly welcome the fact that the need to involve men and boys has been highlighted, the importance of their active engagement and responsible attitudes in the fight against discriminatory social stereotypes and violence against women and girls. It is important that young girls have access to education, but the education of young boys is just as important for building a society free from discrimination and violence.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Ensuring equality between women and men in the field of employment and work is one of the European Union's priorities. Individual Member States have adapted their national rules to ensure that they comply with Union law. The European Parliament's report basically correctly outlines the existing difficulties in applying Directive 2006/54/EC, but when it points out the action that the European Commission should take to address problematic issues, it points to sometimes very controversial solutions. Examples include the call for gender balance on the boards of listed companies, an audit of the remuneration structure of companies with foreclosure sanctions against companies, or a bizarre proposal to impose a burden of proof on the employer that he is innocent of the alleged discrimination. In addition to these examples of interference in the private sphere, there are also vague proposals in the public sphere, such as the call for states to draw up gender budgets.  These, as well as other issues, make the document submitted imprecise and many proposals almost impossible to implement. I have therefore decided to abstain on this report.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution. The plan aims to intensify and improve the coordination of the efforts of the EU and its Member States in the field of equality between women and men and women's empowerment (GEWE). I am in favour of renewal because it aims to promote cultural change in favour of women's emancipation, especially in areas relating to the physical and psychological integrity of women, in order to promote their economic rights and strengthen their participation. In addition, the plan promotes the elimination of all forms of violence against women and girls by asking the EU to have a comprehensive approach to this area: therefore to implement greater efforts and resources to eliminate and prevent all discriminatory practices, all forms of violence (such as genital mutilation, sterilisation or forced pregnancy, domestic violence and marital rape) with particular attention to young people , migrants, HIV sufferers, lesbians and gays. The plan also addresses the issue of health and recognising it as a human right and as such promotes its universal access to care and coverage for women, also placing the emphasis on health education, family planning, prenatal care and sexual and reproductive health.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is the world's leading provider of development aid. However, the resources directed by the European institutions in this area do not always reach, for more or less objective reasons, the groups that need them most. One such case is that of women around the world who do not enjoy equal status with men. Thus, worldwide, women are the category most exposed to negative phenomena such as poverty, illiteracy, domestic violence, discrimination, black work. Attempts to change this situation through development aid are met either with the ignorance of national authorities or by the persistence of attitudes based on traditional stereotypes in the citizens of those states. In this respect, there is a need for a clearer stipulation to make the granting of EU development aid conditional on compliance in practice with the gender parity criteria adopted by the UN. Only in this way will those States understand that they must apply these criteria in order to qualify for Union aid and will create favourable conditions for improving the situation of women everywhere. The current resolution is a first step towards changing these imbalances.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I have of course voted in favour of this text, as a representative of the FEMM committee in the European Parliament. The European Union is committed to promoting gender equality and integrating the gender dimension into all its actions. Gender equality and women's empowerment are essential to achieving the post-2015 Sustainable Development Goals, but they are also autonomous human rights goals that should be pursued regardless of their development and growth benefits. On the other hand, gender-based violence constitutes a serious violation of human rights and cannot be justified by religion, culture or tradition.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution that calls for a renewed political commitment to promoting gender equality and women’ empowerment (GEWE), with a special focus on EU external policy. It encourages the Commission and the European External Action Service (EEAS) to step up efforts in this respect, and calls on the Commission to introduce the new action plan in the form a communication, allowing time for scrutiny by the European Parliament. The resolution calls for GEWE issues to be part of the annual reports of all Commission directorates-general involved in external action and of the EEAS. Importantly, it stresses that gender must be included in human rights dialogues between EU and third countries. Last but not least, the resolution underlines the importance of data collection and measurable targets and it outlines key aspects of the new action plan.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the question of the renewal of the EU Action Plan for Gender Equality and The Empowerment of Women in Development for the period 2016-2020, as this renewal, as well as in most reports that should advocate equality between men and women, promotes gender ideology and seeks to impose reproductive rights that have nothing to do with promoting women's economic rights.  While I strongly support the need to give women the same rights as men in relation to economic opportunities and participation in economic activities, I cannot accept the manipulation of some groups in the European Parliament that persistently falsely classify sexual and reproductive rights under this segment, which are also promoted by the aforementioned Plan.  So I voted against another attempt to impose ideological values that cruelly endanger the lives of the most vulnerable group, namely unborn children.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I did not support the motion for a resolution on the recast of the EU Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment in Development. I support women's equality and their role in this development, but unfortunately the motion for a resolution contains too many elements that seek to promote gender ideology. That is why I believe that the original purpose of the resolution, that is to say, the objective of achieving gender equality and empowering women in development, loses its weight.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution, which, taking into account the conclusions of the evaluation of the first Action Plan on gender equality, underlines the need for radical change in EU action on gender equality and women's empowerment, while calling for renewed political commitment by the EOM and the Commission in this regard. In addition, the Resolution underlines the need for the new Action Plan to focus on all aspects of EU foreign policy — development cooperation, humanitarian aid, trade, human rights, external relations, migration and asylum; all this, in line with the principle of coherence of development policies. Finally, the Resolution also calls for measures to ensure access to sexual and reproductive health and rights as a key element for women's empowerment.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The findings of the evaluation of the first Action Plan clearly shows the need for a substantial change in the performance of the EU IGCM and we need a renewed political commitment by the European External Action Service (EEAS) and the Commission in order to improve performance. It is positive the intention of the Commission to initiate transformational change with the new Plan of Action, which should focus on all aspects of EU foreign policy: development cooperation, humanitarian aid, trade, human rights and foreign affairs, migration and asylum.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution, which, taking into account the conclusions of the evaluation of the first Action Plan on gender equality, underlines the need for radical change in EU action on gender equality and women's empowerment, while calling for renewed political commitment by the EOM and the Commission in this regard. In addition, the Resolution underlines the need for the new Action Plan to focus on all aspects of EU foreign policy — development cooperation, humanitarian aid, trade, human rights, external relations, migration and asylum; all this, in line with the principle of coherence of development policies. Finally, the Resolution also calls for measures to ensure access to sexual and reproductive health and rights as a key element for women's empowerment.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution concerning the renewal of the EU Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment (GAP) in the context of development cooperation. There is a need for a renewed political commitment by the EEAS and the Commission to improve performance, and it is important that the main recommendations of the evaluation are implemented in the successor to the current GAP, starting with a fully-fledged management response. I also agree that GAP II should focus on all aspects of EU external policy – development cooperation, humanitarian aid, trade, human rights and foreign affairs, migration and asylum – in line with with development principles, and that it should apply to developing, neighbourhood and enlargement countries alike. This is also a sign of stepping up and better coordinating efforts by the EU and its Member States in the area of gender equality and women’s empowerment. Much has been achieved in this field already, but more must be done in the future, including in terms of implementation.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialist delegation in the European Parliament voted in favour of this Resolution, which defends universal access to sexual and reproductive health as a right. We Socialists are committed to defending women's freedoms, rights and empowerment in developing countries. We call for an overall approach to violence against women and girls, as well as greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization, and greater resources to prevent and eliminate all discriminatory practices against women, such as female genital mutilation, forced sterilization , forced pregnancy, domestic violence and marital rape, forced and early marriage and gender-based violence in conflict and post-conflict situations. We support the removal of social and legal barriers to women's access to productive goods, as well as actions that contribute to women's economic training and respect for their economic rights, such as guaranteeing them decent work and equal pay.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU Plan of Action on Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment in Development has been part of a global effort to ensure that women are not marginalised, but rather are equal partners in development efforts. OECD countries have tripled the amount invested in programmes for women’s empowerment and have found this to be one of the most effective uses of aid. However, there has been a problem with aid in this area being focused overwhelmingly on social projects rather than on ensuring that women have access to the formal economy. The renewed plan places the empowerment of women at the heart of all EU development initiatives, and it is something that should be considered in all sections of policy, including foreign and migration policy. The issue of the empowerment of women is not merely indissociable from development – it is development. The plan also highlights the crucial issue of the global epidemic of violence against women and girls, and begins a strategy to tackle this, particularly with regard to women in, and fleeing, war zones where sexual assault has been used as a weapon of war. By backing this new strategic direction we make a stand for the empowerment of women globally.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The struggle for gender equality is a global issue.  While the European Union's action plan for 2010-2015 on gender equality and women's empowerment in development cooperation has achieved significant results, new measures need to be taken under the new 2016-2020 Action Plan.   It focuses on ensuring physical and psychological integrity, promoting economic rights and strengthening the voice and participation of women and girls. We can only welcome the re-establishment of targets, including improving women's access to education and health care, and in particular sexual and reproductive rights, as we had requested. But I can only regret that the vast majority of the right and the entire extreme right have once again opposed access to free abortion services for all women, demonstrating once again their opposition to the right of women to freely dispose of their bodies. But these attempts have been in vain, we can only welcome them. I obviously voted for this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Unfortunately, and despite all the speeches on the subject, most of the world's poor are women and women-run households. Even worse, the vulnerability of marginalized women is increasing. In the world, 62 million girls don't go to school. One in three women in the world may be the victim of physical and sexual violence at some point during their lifetime. Although the EU has committed itself to respecting the right of all individuals to have full control of their sexuality and sexual and reproductive health and to decide freely and responsibly on these matters, without discrimination, coercion and violence, we are again discussing this issue with the rawness of the figures demonstrating the failure of the Gender Action Plan. More actions and more means are needed. And we must not isolate this problem which is real and concrete, but which is not disconnected from the neoliberal guidelines that guide EU policies and promote the concentration of wealth and the spread of poverty.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Institutional management of values and standards through development aid instruments is a specialty of the EU. "Conditionality of development cooperation" means gender manipulation by the information offices of the EU Foreign Ministry; establishing gender-based monitoring and evaluation processes not only in administration, but also in SMEs and family businesses, which may be supported by the EU; Abolition of general legal principles by promoting special rights for non-quantifiable special groups (young women, migrant women, women living with the HIV virus, lesbian, bi-, trans and intersex (LGBTI) and women with disabilities) – unfortunately, no safeguards for heteros; the inadmissible mixing of 'women's health' and the criminal offence of abortion; Representation of marriage and motherhood as a status of discrimination; instead, promoting LGBT special rights; EU remote-controlled legal activism in foreign cultures through the targeted provision of legal aid funding (legal activism, which the EU in turn is seeking in its territory...).  For this nonsense, the EU spends the money of the citizens of the Member States! I do not agree with this nonsense, so I reject this resolution.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "No one doubts that women are the group most affected by developmental inequalities. Poverty, unemployment, ethnic and religious conflicts, lack of access to education and health care, as well as religious fundamentalism are particularly hard hit by women whose position is not denied protection either by law or by customs in developing countries. Unfortunately, once again in this House, sensible demands have been mixed with the flagship slogans of left-wing ideology. The issue of so-called 'reproductive rights', m.in free access to abortion, is not the answer to the problems of developmental inequalities. Placing this problem in this document is an error. The preparation of a second action plan on gender equality would be an excellent opportunity to highlight the specific role of women in society and to point to those areas where examples of discrimination against this group are the most glaring.  Unfortunately, despite the many points that are worthy of support in this resolution, which concern, inter alia, the need to strengthen the role of women in economic life, to combat sexual violence in armed conflicts, to increase women's access to education at all levels of education, or to stop the cruel religious practices that women in Muslim countries are victims of, I abstained from voting on this text.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution states that progress towards gender equality and their empowerment, as well as maternal health, has been slow and unequal. No country in the world has completely bridged the gender gap. It is noted that the share of development aid for family planning for total global health aid has decreased. It underlines the need for the EU to provide sufficient human and financial resources to meet its commitments in this area. The resolution recommends the inclusion in the Second Gender Action Plan of very concrete measures. Among others: the call to guarantee the protection of the rights of different groups of women (young people, migrants, HIV-infected, LGBTI and disabled people); recognition of the importance of universal access to sexual and reproductive health care and rights; recognition of the premism of removing social and legal barriers. It's a positive resolution.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the fact that the European Parliament has dealt with the report on equal treatment for men and women in the field of employment and occupation. I consider it very important to address gender pay inequality, because formally this principle has been in place for a long time, but unfortunately the practice is different.  I very much appreciate the work of our colleague, the rapporteur Jana Záborská, who has done a very good job and prepared a good proposal. I consider the fact that only three hundred and forty-four Members voted in favour of the report in the end is a clear signal that a stronger consensus has not been reached. We all want women to be rewarded the same as men for the same work. Unfortunately, amendments have been adopted in mrs Záborská's report, which I consider in some cases to be a breach of subsidiarity. It is unnecessary to include in this report mandatory quotas, mandatory plans for businesses to deal with the gender issue, in short, regulation that goes beyond the powers of the European Parliament. Unfortunately, therefore, it has not been possible to win support for a proposal that would indeed be a very practical tool for promoting gender pay equality. Nevertheless, I believe that in this report, which was finally adopted, there will be precisely the provisions that Mrs Záborská prepared, which we voted on in committee and which can be useful.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I abstained on Mrs Záborská's report on gender discrimination. And I think that the particular situation that has come up – as I understand it in the debate – is that the reporter himself abstained, that is, he did not vote for the report in his own name. That might sound a little strange to outsiders. Let me briefly explain, because it is very important for the report itself.  We are constantly valued by various external companies that are opaque to us and unknown to us, and are then referred to in our nation states by newspapers and the rest. For example, the reports are given a lot of points. Nevertheless, I am not attempting to write a report, as the example of Mrs Záborská demonstrates that she, who is a woman of conservative values and knowledge, was forced in her own report in every second sub-phrase to describe intersexity, transgender, such rights, rights... to watch a series of texts that are completely out of line with your own values. In an ugly way, they castrated his meaning with amendments. This is very often the case in this institution, which does not tolerate deviations from its own politically correct line.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Guaranteeing equality between women and men, both on labour issues, is one of the most important and fundamental principles on which the European Union is founded. It is, for example, absolutely self-evident that candidates for the best possible jobs, prepared for the purposes of their work, should also receive specific jobs, regardless of their gender or any other factors. The same applies to equal pay in the case of equal work tasks. At the same time, it is important to ensure that employers also try to maintain gender balance when drawing up lists of candidates. Wherever possible, for example, the total number of applications received for each sex, respectively. And while on purely biological grounds, women and men are not the same (at the same time that pregnancy, etc. cannot be tolerated by men), however, discrimination is not tolerated, and I am very pleased to support this document.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I voted against this report, due to the glaringly obvious contradictions. In one paragraph you call for gender-neutral job classifications, but then in another you call for a binding gender quota. Yet again this report contains a laughable amount of incompetence. Let women and men compete for jobs equally, and do not force companies into a quota system. We all live in a fair and free society and the best way to keep it that way is to allow people to get jobs and positions based on their merit and nothing else. There is nothing positive about positive discrimination.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, cheapfá ón teideal go mbeadh gach Feisire i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo, ach is léir go raibh fadhbanna acu le cuid de na moltaí ann. Caithfear é sin a thuiscint. Agus i ndeireadh na dála, ní raibh ach 344 Fheisire as 568 i bhfabhar.  Bíodh sin mar atá, bhíos i bhfabhar na tuarascála cé is moite de Leasú 17(1) agus (2); vótáil mo pháirtí, Fine Gael, i gcoinne mo ghrúpa ins an dá cheann sin.  Ach i gcoitinne, caithfimid i bhfad níos mó a dhéanamh maidir le cothromaíocht a chothú idir fir agus mná, go háirithe maidir le pinsin, tuarastail agus seansanna a thabhairt dóibh dul chun cinn a dhéanamh ina jabanna. Dar liomsa, tá a lán déanta cheana féin ina lán de na tíortha ach tá gá le rialacha nua chun cothromaíocht cheart a bhunú san Aontas amach anseo.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – The report emphasises the imbalance between work and family as a factor in the disadvantaged situation of women in the labour market. The text rightly underlines that the tension between family and professional life contributes to the postponement of childbearing and the low fertility rate in most Member States. I think that without the fertility rate going up, our society is facing an extremely unhealthy development path, so this issue will be one of the key problems for decades to come. And the increase in the desire to have children is certainly linked, along with many other factors, to inflexibility of jobs and discrimination against mothers with young children. We still have a lot of work to do in these areas, but I certainly welcome the report's finding that it may be necessary to exclude women with one or more children from the method of calculating the pay gap. Thus, this indicator would indeed reflect the pay gap resulting from discrimination.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – I very much regret that I was unable to vote in favour of my own report. I am particularly sorry because the report contains many good proposals that have the potential to improve the position of women in the labour market. I have also tried to draw attention to the fact that the pay gap between women and men begins to appear after the first child and then only deepens. I also stressed the importance of unpaid care provided predominantly by women, whether to their children or other members of the immediate family for which they are de facto penalised. In the end, however, I abstained because amendments came into my text that I cannot identify with. Efforts to address women's status are overlaid by a gender ideology that obscures the original text. This may lead to us not being able to address the practical obstacles to women's pay in the future, because the word woman may eventually disappear from the proposals altogether.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. Gender equality is an essential principle which must be guaranteed not only in abstract terms, but must be defended and, above all, applied in practice in the socio-economic context. Unfortunately, discrimination between women and men is still observed in the labour market. The gender pay gap, the gap in the pension system are just some of the indicators that show an unequal and disadvantageous situation for women, who generally also have higher family burdens. The social and welfare policies of the Member States have not so far been sufficient, as my colleague Anna Záborská has pointed out in her report, especially with regard to the application of Directive 2006/54/EC on the principle of equal opportunities. I voted in favour because we need to adapt the existing regulatory instruments in order to ensure a fairer environment in Europe. It is only through effective equal treatment that we can think of a system that does not effectively penalise the professional rise of women.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that equal treatment between women and men in employment is a fundamental principle which must be respected and promoted. Unfortunately, large differences still persist and a review is needed to improve and modernise the Equal Employment Directive.  It is unacceptable that there is still a gender pay gap of more than 16% in Europe today, so it is urgent to promote non-sexist systems for job assessment and classification, which ensure wage transparency and combat gender biases that make the pay gap systematized. It is essential that mandatory wage audits are proposed for companies listed on a stock exchange in the Member States (excluding SMEs).  It should also be mandatory for companies to develop and implement annual strategic plans on gender equality and also to facilitate the reconciliation of the working lives of women and men with family life, which remains very difficult. Finally, it is unacceptable that the proportion of women in senior management positions in enterprises is less than 18%.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it requests the European Commission to review the Directive on the application of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in matters of employment and occupation. Despite being based on the case-law of the European courts, that legislative act has failed to end the huge disparity in wages between men and women in general (16.4% on average), or between Member States; nor with discrimination in workplaces. It therefore calls for strong measures such as incorporating sanctions against undertakings that fail to comply with equality measures, an audit on this issue of large publicly traded undertakings, or the Council adopting a position to unblock the so-called Maternity Directive.  However, I believe that this report should have included some of our considerations; in particular, how austerity measures to tackle the financial and economic crisis, together with the increasing easing of employment contracts, have led to high levels of poverty among women in Europe (22% in the Spanish state).

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on equal opportunities and treatment of men and women in employment and work. While it is obviously desirable to put in place measures to establish equal pay for equal work, this report is in fact only a concentration of demands from minorities (particularly LGBT), the latter having no direct link to the subject. Moreover, the measures expressed represent a direct infringement on the freedom of French companies, the latter being among the few that have already followed the original directives.  These constraints would therefore have the sole effect of once again reducing the ability of companies to hire. It would have been desirable for this report to be more transparent and genuinely focused on gender equality in the workplace.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, calling on the Commission to address the failure by many Member States to tackle the gender pay gap, which stands at an average of 16.4% across the EU. In Ireland, women continue to earn on average 14% less than their male counterparts, a situation which is unacceptable in the 21st century. This is a positive and strong report that stresses the need to introduce binding measures in order to tackle the roots of this discrimination. It calls for pressure on unequal pay practices and for the promotion of wage transparency, as requested by trade unions and gender equality bodies. It also calls for the introduction of mandatory pay audits for companies listed on the stock exchanges, and for sanctions against those companies that fail to implement equal pay, including their exclusion from the public procurement of goods and services from the EU budget. The report calls on Member States to take steps to reverse the burden of proof, so the employer would have to prove that a difference in treatment had not been caused by discrimination. Additional elements include introducing quotas for women at management level in companies, and taking measures to improve work-family balance.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The desire to ensure equal pay for equal work between men and women is legitimate. But, as a result of the amendments that were adopted, the report was largely diverted from its original purpose. Many communitarian demands, including LGBT ones, have been inserted.  So much so that Mrs Zaborska, rapporteur on the merits, has distanced herself from her own text!  So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in equality; however, the proposed measures are the wrong way to go about it. I therefore voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. Today, despite a European action plan voted in 2006, the differences in pay between men and women persist and are even growing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it calls on the Commission to propose new legislation providing more effective means to oversee the implementation and implementation of this action plan in the Member States.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that equal treatment between women and men in employment is a fundamental principle which must be respected and promoted. Unfortunately, large differences still persist and a review is needed to improve and modernise the Equal Employment Directive.  It is unacceptable that there is still a gender pay gap of more than 16% in Europe today, so it is urgent to promote non-sexist systems for job assessment and classification, which ensure wage transparency and combat gender biases that make the pay gap systematized. It is essential that mandatory wage audits are proposed for companies listed on a stock exchange in the Member States (excluding SMEs).  It should also be mandatory for companies to develop and implement annual strategic plans on gender equality and also to facilitate the reconciliation of the working lives of women and men with family life, which remains very difficult. Finally, it is unacceptable that the proportion of women in senior management positions in enterprises is less than 18%.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to equalise the wages of men and women for the same work. Economic independence is a prerequisite for EU citizens, both men and women, to be able to control their lives and have real choices. I support the calls for the Commission to develop guidelines for systems for the assessment and classification of gender-neutral posts. The Commission and the Member States should establish effective monitoring systems to improve the collection of data on cases of discrimination on grounds of sex, including discrimination based on pregnancy, maternity, childbirth or other forms of leave.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which was distorted by amendments imposed by the LGBT lobby. I note, moreover, that Mrs Zaborska, the Slovak Member who authored this report, has herself cautiously abstained on the final vote when her group, the EPP, had called for a vote in support. The fact is that "Christian Democrats" (or so-called LGBT lobbyists) have been doing quite well for a number of years...

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. On the basis of its report on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in employment and work, the FEMM parliamentary committee believes that the current directive 2006/54/EC has reached its limits and needs to be updated. Although the principle of equal pay was enshrined in the treaties as early as 1957 and recognised by the FUE Treaty and then incorporated into the 2006/54/EC Directive, progress in this area is slow and the gender pay gap persists at an average level of 16.4% in the EU. The issue of the treatment of employment and work between men and women is a question of freedom and justice. I therefore agree with the conclusions of the report calling on the Commission to put forward a new legislative proposal based on the principles of equal treatment and social dialogue and, on the other hand, on Member States to combat unequal remuneration practices.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because of the great work done by the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality on the need to break the gap in wages between men and women today, even supporting the imposition of sanctions in the event of non-compliance with the lack of progress in this area, and promoting mandatory audits of the wages paid by large listed multinationals. It also advocates the prohibition of any discrimination based on gender identity, sexual orientation or gender change, reconciliation of work with private life by preventing, for example, unjustified dismissals during pregnancies, and positive measures to accelerate women's involvement in decision-making processes. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in employment and work should provide an update on the progress of the implementation of the 2006/54/EC directive on equal treatment between men and women in the field of work. In particular, this report proposes to apply coercive measures to companies for equal pay... Nevertheless, there is an interesting idea of studies on women's professional situations according to their personal situation but with a risk of EU interference in private life. Unfortunately, if this text seemed well oriented, it is undermined by communitarian (LGBT or ethnic) demands and proposals against freedom of enterprise. In fact, the rapporteur of the text, Mrs Zaborska, herself has dissociated herself from her text. Moreover, France is one of the few countries that has applied the original directive and, in validating this text, a lack of constraints should not be exploited. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although there are passages that we can support in the Zaborska report, I have found many contradictory and un balanced elements, which is why I did not intend to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that equal treatment between women and men in employment is a fundamental principle which must be respected and promoted. Unfortunately, large differences still persist and a review is needed to improve and modernise the Equal Employment Directive.  It is unacceptable that there is still a gender pay gap of more than 16% in Europe today, so it is urgent to promote non-sexist systems for job assessment and classification, which ensure wage transparency and combat gender biases that make the pay gap systematized. It is essential that mandatory wage audits are proposed for companies listed on a stock exchange in the Member States (excluding SMEs).  It should also be mandatory for companies to develop and implement annual strategic plans on gender equality and also to facilitate the reconciliation of the working lives of women and men with family life, which remains very difficult. Finally, it is unacceptable that the proportion of women in senior management positions in enterprises is less than 18%.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament calls on the Commission and the Member States to tackle the long-standing problem of equalising the salaries of women and men for the same work. On behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL), I have given an opinion to this report in which I call on the Member States to implement the Commission recommendation on strengthening the principle of equal pay for men and women through increased transparency as effectively and actively as possible. Furthermore, I believe that this directive should be reviewed, given that today, in almost all Member States, there are a number of problems and obstacles in this area that have led to the full implementation of this directive. I also call on the Member States to ensure maternity protection and to take measures to prevent unfair redundancies during pregnancy and to protect women and men with caring obligations from unfair dismissal.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the work of the rapporteur, Congresswoman Záborská, in the presentation of the ppe values in the report on equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in the field of employment and work. I consider it very important that the need for women's employment, which is aimed at long-term sustainability and has become a priority in creating financial stability in ageing societies, is very important in order to create a social climate where employment and childcare can be fully matched.  Nevertheless, I regretted that, despite the efforts of the rapporteur and many Members of the People's Party, although social policy, for each country, is embedded in an existing institutional system and value system, the report included a number of recommendations that deeply violate the principle of subsidiarity and thus weaken the report rather than strengthen it, such as the introduction of sanctions for employers who discriminate in each Member State. and mandatory gender equality annual business plans for companies.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Stereotypes about gender roles still influence the position of women in families, in academic and university careers and during the career path, creating as more tangible consequences the considerable pay gap between men and women and the strong discrimination related to motherhood, pregnancy and other forms of leave. Even today, it is still not possible in Europe to guarantee appropriate and flexible solutions for women workers, who are often forced to work in sectors that offer lower wages and less skilled jobs. The picture we get is alarming: employment rate of 58.8% compared to 69.4% of male colleagues in 2013, a proportion of women in management positions of less than 18% (2014) and an increased risk of poverty for women, particularly of retirement age. I voted strongly in favour of Mrs Zaborska's report on the need to update Directive 2006/54/EC currently in force. A system of greater protection, control and guarantees such as that outlined in the report would have a positive effect on European economic growth and would rigorously review the anomalies of the system.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support my colleague Zaborska's report. The wage gap is currently just over 16 per cent and exceeds 20 per cent in some Member States. Colleague Zaborska proposes sanctions for companies that operate in this way and shift the burden of proof from damaged to company. The report is very progressive and concrete.

name: Louise Bours (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report because it called for the reversal of the burden of proof between employer and employee, which would fundamentally change the UK legal system and end the principle of ‘innocent until proven guilty’. It also included calls for EU sanctions, EU audit regimes for companies and EU-imposed gender quotas for companies. UKIP believes that only the elected and accountable politicians in our own country should decide these things, not un-elected bureaucrats in Brussels. UKIP, of course, support gender equality and equal rights, and opposes any form of discrimination.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, calling on the Commission to address the failure by many Member States to tackle the gender pay gap, which stands at an average of 16.4% across the EU. In Ireland, women continue to earn on average 14% less than their male counterparts, a situation which is unacceptable in the 21st century. This is a positive and strong report that stresses the need to introduce binding measures in order to tackle the roots of this discrimination. It calls for pressure on unequal pay practices and for the promotion of wage transparency, as requested by trade unions and gender equality bodies. It also calls for the introduction of mandatory pay audits for companies listed on the stock exchanges, and for sanctions against those companies that fail to implement equal pay, including their exclusion from the public procurement of goods and services from the EU budget. The report calls on Member States to take steps to reverse the burden of proof, so the employer would have to prove that a difference in treatment had not been caused by discrimination. Additional elements include introducing quotas for women at management level in companies, and taking measures to improve work-family balance.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 There can be no real gender equality if there is no equal pay. Discrimination, direct or indirect, in the workplace arises from the difference in wages and the different opportunities for advancement that arise – still too often – from the prejudice of some employers for whom women would be less productive than their male colleagues of the same level. Although equal treatment for men and women has been clearly enshrined on several occasions in all EU law since 1957 (Treaty of Rome), the gender pay gap has remained almost stable at around 17%. It is necessary to update Directive 2006/54/EC in order to adapt it to today's socio-economic dynamics and to provide the Commission with the necessary means to impose on The Member States a real commitment to combating wage and gender discrimination in order to defend the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment for all workers for the same work or work of equal value.
