There is also a need to amend the legislation so that effective conditions are created to balance working life with private life, recognising the importance of the role played by women in parental care: real unpaid work that we must take into account.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of the original text was to defend equal treatment of women and men in employment and work. In particular, the report imposes recruitment criteria on companies that prevent managers from engaging in discriminatory behaviour against women in hiring. The rapporteur even provided for coercive measures that would reduce or even eliminate the differences in pay between women and men. We deeply regret that this text has been misguided in its meaning in order to incorporate claims into it. It is for this reason that the rapporteur has dissociated herself from this text and tabled a minority opinion in the FEMM committee. These amendments clearly run counter to our vision of equality and introduce additional constraints into the functioning of societies, thereby undermining their effectiveness. Moreover, this text does not contribute anything more to what France already applies in terms of equal treatment between women and men.  That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Gender treatment is one of the main concerns of the European Union. The principle of equal pay for work of equal value has been enshrined in the Treaties from the outset, but to date it has not been possible to mitigate the pay gap, with the wage gap having an average value of 16,4 %. Slow progress was also made in employment rates: the employment rate for men was 69.4% in the EU, compared to 58.8% among women. The report on equal opportunities and treatment between men and women in employment proposes to promote this principle on the basis of benefits, both moral and economic. Equality between men and women in the field of labour benefits the economy and society in general, as reducing the gender pay gap contributes to reducing poverty levels and increasing incomes. I voted in favour of this report because I firmly believe that the recovery of the economy, competitiveness and growth of the economy are at stares that can be achieved through equal pay and equal treatment for women and men.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. It reiterates that women and girls must not be discriminated against within all sectors (work, education, politics, etc.) and calls for the EU to take an active part in this.  It is noted that gap (Gender Equality Action Plan) must address the situation of LGBTI people in third countries and include the promotion and protection of LGBTI rights. It also calls for the development of specific EU actions to strengthen the rights of different groups of women, with a particular focus on young people, migrants, women with HIV, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex (LGBTI) people and people with disabilities. It is considered that gender equality and women's empowerment should be at the heart of the activities of the EU institutions.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that equal treatment between women and men in employment is a fundamental principle which must be respected and promoted. Unfortunately, large differences still persist and a review is needed to improve and modernise the Equal Employment Directive.  It is unacceptable that there is still a gender pay gap of more than 16% in Europe today, so it is urgent to promote non-sexist systems for job assessment and classification, which ensure wage transparency and combat gender biases that make the pay gap systematized. It is essential that mandatory wage audits are proposed for companies listed on a stock exchange in the Member States (excluding SMEs).  It should also be mandatory for companies to develop and implement annual strategic plans on gender equality and also to facilitate the reconciliation of the working lives of women and men with family life, which remains very difficult. Finally, it is unacceptable that the proportion of women in senior management positions in enterprises is less than 18%.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Equality between men and women in the labour market still faces many obstacles. It is proven that, in equal work, women often receive lower wages than men. This situation can no longer last. Member States and businesses must do everything in their power to establish full equality between men and women in employment and work. The European Union can serve as a platform for the exchange of good practices for equality in this area. In Europe, we have values and equality is a fundamental founding principle. We must do everything we can to ensure that this principle is respected within the Union. The latter should set an example for the whole world. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the application of Directive 2006/54/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 July 2006 on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment for men and women in employment and employment, because in Europe women are still under-represented in decision-making processes, both in national parliaments and governments and on the boards of directors of large companies.  In short, steps have been taken a little backwards in all sectors but it will take 81 years to close the gap of employment opportunities between men and women. The Eu ropean Union can no longer confine itself to mere denunciation, but must ensure that European legislation on gender equality is actually complyed with. It is right to ensure the same opportunities and rights for men and women.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, calling on the Commission to address the failure by many Member States to tackle the gender pay gap, which stands at an average of 16.4% across the EU. In Ireland, women continue to earn on average 14% less than their male counterparts, a situation which is unacceptable in the 21st century. This is a positive and strong report that stresses the need to introduce binding measures in order to tackle the roots of this discrimination. It calls for pressure on unequal pay practices and for the promotion of wage transparency, as requested by trade unions and gender equality bodies. It also calls for the introduction of mandatory pay audits for companies listed on the stock exchanges, and for sanctions against those companies that fail to implement equal pay, including their exclusion from the public procurement of goods and services from the EU budget. The report calls on Member States to take steps to reverse the burden of proof, so the employer would have to prove that a difference in treatment had not been caused by discrimination. Additional elements include introducing quotas for women at management level in companies, and taking measures to improve work-family balance.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report because it called for the reversal of the burden of proof between employer and employee, which would fundamentally change the UK legal system and end the principle of ‘innocent until proven guilty’. It also included calls for EU sanctions, EU audit regimes for companies and EU-imposed gender quotas for companies. UKIP believes that only the elected and accountable politicians in our own country should decide these things, not un-elected bureaucrats in Brussels. UKIP, of course, support gender equality and equal rights, and opposes any form of discrimination.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe in the equality of men and women, especially in the workplace, and I think it especially unjust that people should receive different salaries for the same work simply on the basis of gender. I also believe that there should be balanced gender representation on boards. Discrimination against women in the workplace is not only unfair but also damaging to society, the economy and the upbringing of future generations.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, there are still many cases of undeclared work and the compulsrement of women to work in the black economy, with negative repercussions also with regard to contributory and welfare rights. In view of a stasis in the gender pay gap, which has remained almost stable over the past decade, from 17.5% in 2008 to 16.4% in 2012, the rapporteur is inclined to conclude that the current Directive 2006/54/EC has reached its limits and should therefore be updated. Although I found the report positive overall, I wanted to abstain on the final vote because a key vote on sanctions on companies passed.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider it right that a man and a woman should be rated equally if they are demonstrably doing the same job. On the other hand, I am not in the advocate of mandatory quotas or other forms of social engineering for which the report advocates. That is why I abstained.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. The text in question was initially a good intention, and it was intended to ensure equal pay for equal work for women and men. However, it was then amended to claim the cause of LGBT communitarians and ethnic minorities. Proposals for measures have thus become incompatible with freedom of enterprise, the breeding ground for employment. In addition, rapporteur Mrs Zaborska has dissociated herself from this text and has tabled a minority opinion in the FEMM committee. I voted against it.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Addressing the unequal pay gap is an aspiration as old as the European Community itself, yet we still have an average pay gap of 16% between men and women, with Ireland faring just slightly less badly, at over 14%. Equal pay for equal work was enshrined in the founding treaties over 60 years ago, and an equal pay directive was put in place in 1975 and recast a decade ago. This is not just a matter of principle, equality and justice. This baseless pay discrimination between men and women for the same kind of work entails compounded losses in income and pension rights over a woman’s contributory lifetime. And that is without counting the increased periods women spend out of the work or in part-time work, performing unpaid work as mothers or carers for other dependent relatives, or housework. At best, this represents a blatant, unjustified and mounting loss of income compared with male colleagues but, for the least advantaged women, it means a higher risk of poverty and greater propensity to fall ill due to the unrecognised, unremunerated forms of work. Member States are simply failing to apply the law. We want it to include sanctions, and to see the Commission treating this with the seriousness that is invested in other policy areas, such as anti-trust law, for example.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 There is still an unjustified disparity in pay treatment between men and women of around 15% within the European Union. I wonder how many reports, how many parliamentary debates it will take even before equal treatment is fully and fully implemented. Yet this is a principle which has been present in the Treaties since 1957 and which has resulted in several directives. I congratulate the rapporteur on her work and on her report, which highlights, if necessary, all the areas in which inequalities continue to persist. I certainly agree with the recommendations addressed to the Commission and I also agree with the call for a new directive that will deal with this issue in a broader way. I wonder whether we are faced with a regulatory deficit or whether it is not the will of the Member States to monitor the application and implementation of existing European legislation that is lacking.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report calls on the Member States and the Commission to raise public awareness of equal pay for men and women and the gap in pensions, as well as direct and indirect discrimination against women at work at European, national, regional and local level. The Commission is called upon to establish a European Year for combating the pay gap between men and women.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Anna Zàborskà's report on equal status and treatment of women in employment and employment. I agree with the rapporteur that it is regrettable that the law still fails to resolve the disparities between men and women. I also find the pension differences unacceptable, as well as the social differences correctly highlighted in this report. Although men and women have objective physical and psychological differences, they must be placed on an equal footing in the field of work and employment.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The issue is not so much that women are paid less for doing the same jobs. The issue is that women are less likely to be employed in the high-paying jobs. Comparing men and women job by job conceals the fact that men still dominate many of the highest-paying jobs. Why is this? Well, there are a variety of reasons including the fact that women are still the primary carers in Irish and European families. We are the ones who make the most sacrifices when it comes to raising babies and looking after elderly family members. A Commission report shows us that only 65.8% of women with young children in the EU are working, compared to 89.1% of men. That can change only with laws that are targeted at changing our childcare culture – such as the introduction of real and progressive paternity care.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report because it called for the reversal of the burden of proof between employer and employee, which would fundamentally change the UK legal system and end the principle of ‘innocent until proven guilty’. It also included calls for EU sanctions, EU audit regimes for companies and EU-imposed gender quotas for companies. UKIP believes that only the elected and accountable politicians in our own country should decide these things, not un-elected bureaucrats in Brussels. UKIP, of course, support gender equality and equal rights, and opposes any form of discrimination.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2006/54/EC consolidated a set of Community instruments on gender equality in employment and occupation. Although gender equality is inscribed in the Union's own DNA, there have been few advances.  This report, which I support and vote for, recognises that developments have been made but, as Parliament has consistently advocated, more effective action needs to be taken. Not only in combating the gender pay gap, the main object of the Directive, but also in the context of indirect discrimination: assessment at work, employment system or pension schemes.  Without regulatory overdevelopment or bureaucratic daydreams, all measures should be considered and cooperation and exchange of best practices between Member States stimulated. It is certain, however, that listed companies should be subject to tighter regulation than a micro-enterprise. For the most part, public authorities require an irreprehensible record.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important to admit that the non-binding strategies and measures put in place so far in favour of equality between men and women, even if guided by noble intentions, have been inefficient. The difficulties for women to emerge in the labour market are enormous, from unequal pay to having to bear all the family burdens, or having little prospect of making a career by excluding access to top positions. However, despite many important passages in this report, I cannot but express my opposition to the introduction of sanctions in the event of non-compliance with the principle of equal treatment, which would also exclude companies that do not comply with their responsibilities from public procurement of financial goods and services with European financial resources, and to reverse the burden of proof, or to introduce wage audits for listed companies. These sanctions would only increase the administrative burden on companies, especially SMEs. There are also some concepts that I believe cannot be accepted, so I reiterate the need to make a point about what are the priorities of the European political agenda.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Gender inequality in the field of employment hampers the potential of women to fully use their skills and abilities in contributing to society while seriously impacts living conditions of European families. No mother should be made to choose between earning an income or caring for her child, elderly, disabled or other vulnerable family member.  Parents have the exclusive discretion of deciding how to balance their family responsibilities with their employment and policies must aim at setting up different frameworks within which parents can make a free and informed decision as to what is best for their own family and circumstances. In this regard, the EU needs to offer evidence-based options for family focused growth and an integrated approach of equality in employment. In doing so policies must also seek to propose measures which while facilitating work-life balance do not seriously prejudice SMEs. This must be accompanied by an understanding that an employee who reaches a work-life balance is a better employee. I have voted in favour of quotas and similar measures as temporary provisions addressing the current situation and which are to be systematically reviewed.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of updating Directive 2006/54/EC in view of the problems that still exist with regard to inequalities between men and women, both in terms of representation and in terms of pay and positions occupied in the workplace.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it requests the European Commission to review the Directive on the application of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in matters of employment and occupation. Despite being based on the case-law of the European courts, that legislative act has failed to end the huge disparity in wages between men and women in general (16.4% on average), or between Member States; nor with discrimination in workplaces. It therefore calls for strong measures such as incorporating sanctions against undertakings that fail to comply with equality measures, an audit on this issue of large publicly traded undertakings, or the Council adopting a position to unblock the so-called Maternity Directive.  However, I believe that this report should have included some of our considerations; in particular, how austerity measures to tackle the financial and economic crisis, together with the increasing easing of employment contracts, have led to high levels of poverty among women in Europe (22% in the Spanish state).

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 If you are a woman you work as much as a man and you earn about 16% less than men. Equal treatment has been in the European legal system since 1957, but the data tell us that we are still a long way from its full implementation. Maybe we're not working hard enough on it. We are well aware that it is not a directive that break down stereotypes and prejudices, but it is our duty to strongly call on the Commission for a new directive and greater rigour of application by the Member States. On the other hand, if individual choices can make women's access to careers more or less justifiable and, for this reason, that aspect is less standard -unless quotas are introduced, but I find it unnecessary and harmful - the disparity in economic treatment is only an anti-historical legacy. There are no rational reasons for – almost 70 years on – the persistence of the gender pay gap. It is a gap that must be healed immediately.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the long years of work of my fellow Member, Congresswoman Záborská, which was reflected in the report on equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in the field of employment and work. The report on the application of Directive 2006/54/EC points out that Member States have done much to introduce the Directive into the national legal order, but rightly points out that, despite these efforts, mainly due to the inability to transpose, the pay gap between men and women remains present in society. More needs to be done by the Member States to eradicate this discrimination completely. Unfortunately, despite the efforts of the rapporteur and a number of Members of the People's Party, the report has unfortunately included a number of recommendations that violate the principle of subsidiarity. Examples include the introduction of sanctions for employers who discriminate in each Member State and mandatory annual gender equality business plans for companies. For these reasons, I abstained from voting on this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in matters of employment and occupation. I believe that this report offers a very interesting insight. Each and every Member State should be committed to ensure equal treatment at the place of work and should be strongly against discrimination on the basis of sex, racial or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, sexual orientation or age. The fight against undeclared and precarious work should be a strong one particularly since it impacts negatively both economic growth as well as social well-being in general. An issue of concern is the call to the Commission to take action by means of legislative measures to address the gender pensions gap at the EU and national level when Member States remain responsible for the design and operation of the social protection systems. Having said that the EU must provide valuable contributions to the activities of the Member States in tackling the gender gap in pensions.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the existence of Directive 2006/54/EC of 2006 on equality between women and men in the labour market, the pay gap still persists and is even growing. Equal pay for equal work is a fair principle that must also work on gender equality and that must be assessed by all employers, and for this we need better legislation.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report highlights gaps in the application of EU standards on equal pay for men and women. The report calls on the European Commission to formulate a new legislative proposal including provisions on equal treatment for pensions, effective monitoring systems and strengthening the role of social partners and access to legal support for victims of discrimination. We have tabled in the EPP Group a number of amendments to exclude controversial references that do not depend on the competence of the European Union, on the definition of gender, for example. Supporting the principle of equal opportunities and treatment between men and women in the labour market, however, I supported the report.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. – The gap between men and women in the workplace needs to be eliminated. I voted in favour of this directive because it ensures better implementation of equality principles. For example, the EP wants victims of gender discrimination to be better served and more attention to discrimination in the workplace. This should improve productivity and opportunities for both women and men, something I, as a liberal, can only approve of.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the application of Directive 2006/54/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 July 2006 on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment for men and women in employment and employment deals with one of the main injustices of our time in Europe. Even today we are witnessing these anomalies on our continent. First of all is the constant difference between the male and female employment rate (around ten percentage points for 2013). In fact, the gender pay gap also has very serious consequences for the living conditions of these women and their families. In addition, today we are witnessing a phenomenon of shifting wage bargaining from the collective to the individual level: this reduces the possibility of understanding the phenomenon in its complexity and damages those workers who have less room for negotiation, as they are in a less favourable position. For this reason, it is necessary to work through a remodulation of wage policies, in order to guarantee workers more bargaining power and at the same time ensure safe occupational integration for those most disadvantaged through emancipation policies.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. At a time when the fight to reduce wage gaps no longer seems to be having the desired effect, Parliament has asked the European Commission to revise this directive with a view to strengthening and making more effective the legislative framework to end gender-based wage discrimination. Indeed, the major problem that remains is that of unjustified wage inequality between men and women, with a gap of 16.2% in the European Union. So I voted for Mrs Zaborska's report.  Thus, by adopting this resolution, we highlight the importance of equal opportunities and treatment between men and women in employment and work.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the work of the rapporteur, Congresswoman Záborská, in the presentation of the ppe values in the report on equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in the field of employment and work. I consider it very important that the need for women's employment, which is aimed at long-term sustainability and has become a priority in creating financial stability in ageing societies, is very important in order to create a social climate where employment and childcare can be fully matched. Nevertheless, I regretted, despite the efforts of the rapporteur and a number of MEMBERS of the People's Party, that although social policy, for each country, is embedded in an existing institutional system and value system, the report included a number of recommendations that deeply violate the principle of subsidiarity and thus weaken the report rather than strengthen it, which I cannot support, such as the imposition of sanctions on employers who discriminate in each Member State. and mandatory gender equality annual business plans for companies.

name: Martina Dlabajová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Equal treatment of men and women is one of the fundamental principles of the EU law. We might not believe it but in 2015 the average gender pay gap in the EU is still above 16%, going as high as one-third of pay in some Member States.  As a result of the adoption of various instruments at national and EU level and of the consistent application by the courts of the principles of anti-discrimination laid down in Article 157 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and in Directive 2006/54/EC, we have come a long way forward on eliminating gender pay gap in salaries and pensions. However, what we need to fight more than ever are the stereotypes. If society is not ready to mature by overcoming traditional thinking, we will not be able to eliminate practices which belong to history.  Despite many positive elements outlined in this report, I took a decision to abstain on the final vote. Simply I do not believe that financial sanctions and administrative burden on companies or binding quotas can fight the stereotypes which are at the core of direct and indirect discrimination on pay.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report looks at the application of gender equality guidelines in the workplace. First, it wants to put in place coercive measures in the workplace, in order to force employers to ensure effective compliance with this equality. It also plans to adjust the applicable rules according to the personal situation of the citizens concerned. However, in addition to coercive measures, this report serves as a Trojan horse for many recommendations from ideological coteries. The issue of differentiation according to personal circumstances could lead, under the guise of good feelings, to an interference with privacy. While France was one of the first countries to implement the European recommendations on gender equality in the workplace, this report seeks, on the pretext that some European countries would not comply with these requirements, to promote communitarian demands. I therefore objected to this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not support this proposal quite simply because I believe that many of the ideas do not fall within the scope of this report and are issues of a completely different nature. To deal with them, I do not believe that the top-down approach is the ideal solution. There are still too many substantive issues to be resolved before we can even consider creating pan-European binding rules and guidelines. We also need to look at factors such as culture, ethnicity, history, etc., which are very important. That is why I cannot support the report in its current form.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Negative as a whole, because gender equality includes normal genders, i.e. men and women and not lesbians, bisexuals, transgender and other such species as well as ethnic minorities.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the work of the rapporteur, Congresswoman Záborská, in the presentation of the ppe values in the report on equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in the field of employment and work. I consider it very important that the need for women's employment, which is aimed at long-term sustainability and has become a priority in creating financial stability in ageing societies, is very important in order to create a social climate where employment and childcare can be fully matched. Nevertheless, I regretted, despite the efforts of the rapporteur and a number of MEMBERS of the People's Party, that although social policy, for each country, is embedded in an existing institutional system and value system, the report included a number of recommendations that deeply violate the principle of subsidiarity and thus weaken the report rather than strengthen it, which I cannot support, such as the imposition of sanctions on employers who discriminate in each Member State. and mandatory gender equality annual business plans for companies.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. This report is a great job in relation to the implementation of Directive 2006/54/EC, which consolidates and modernises the acquis communautaire in the field of equality by merging previous directives. The Directive addressed objectives such as equal pay for work of equal value and the reduction of the pay gap, but it has certainly not been exploited in the same way by all Member States.  A review is therefore needed, a new legislative initiative to replace the existing one, which addresses the remaining substantial problems, such as: the correct and uniform evaluation of work, the implementation of equal treatment provisions in relation to pension schemes, effective monitoring systems and the role of the social partners, as well as the access of victims of discrimination to legal assistance.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report because it called for the reversal of the burden of proof between employer and employee, which would fundamentally change the UK legal system and end the principle of ‘innocent until proven guilty’. It also included calls for EU sanctions, EU audit regimes for companies and EU-imposed gender quotas for companies. UKIP believes that only the elected and accountable politicians in our own country should decide these things, not un-elected bureaucrats in Brussels. UKIP, of course, support gender equality and equal rights, and opposes any form of discrimination.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. No one should have to be discriminated against in the EU on grounds of gender, colour or sexual orientation. This non-legislative report was an important marker for safeguarding the rules and principles that exist for anti-discrimination in europe, and I therefore voted in favour of it. However, I would like to point out that there were parts of the text that I did not vote in favour of, such as those relating to quotas and issues relating to parental insurance at European level.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. All women, regardless of age, education or social status, are potential victims of discrimination in the workplace, whether directly or indirectly. The impact of inequality on employment cannot be underestimated. In fact, equal pay between men and women is a matter of fairness and motivation. At the same time, it can also be understood as a family-related issue. In Europe, the well-being of many families depends on women's salaries. Most mothers participate in the labour market and many even bear the primary responsibility for supporting their families as a single or primary source of sustenance. However, over the last decade the gender pay gap, as an important indicator of gender inequality in the labour market, has almost stagnated from 17.5% in 2008 to 16.4% in 2012. I agree with the need to revise the Directive on this matter.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this deliberation because it makes appeals in favour of gender theory, which has nothing to do with the initial objectives of the report.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Equal treatment and the principle of non-discrimination are principles inscribed in primary EU legislation. However, by action – by virtue of their policies – and by default, we are far from seeing them in the EU. Over the past decade, the gender pay gap has almost stagnated from 17.5% in 2008 to 16.4% in 2012.  This own-initiative report is important. Among other aspects, labor policies that aim to end the principle and practice of collective bargaining deserve to be highlighted, favoring individual wage bargaining. The level of professional and sectoral segregation between men and women in different types of employment remains high, with some professional categories being mainly occupied by women, and these sectors and professions are less well paid or valued. Income disparities between men and women increase after retirement, with women's pensions on average 39% lower than men's; It should be more important to the role played by trade unions and employers and civil society organisations in promoting equal treatment and the concept of equal pay in employment. There are several positive recommendations of the report and its scope is satisfactory and we have voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 We meet repeatedly with the topic of gender equality from the point of view of employment, whether at European or domestic level. The shift towards equality needs to be faster. Today, despite occasional forceful promises and rhetoric from employers in this area, there is little that is happening. Continuous improvement of conditions for the employment of women, including their appropriate evaluation, is one of the important factors of the often mentioned sustainable economic growth and the overall development of our society at all. Change must also occur in our thinking and the related elimination of the stereotypes we experience. The proposed measures must also include an effort to bring employment policy more into line with family policy. After a week's work, we should be able to guarantee at least one day off.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 As always, the FEMM committee uses the pretext of the title of the report and uses women as a political tool in order to insert LGBTI instances and more.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Gender equality is an important factor in the social, cultural and economic development of countries. But the use of this fundamental value, individually, and without taking into account morals and morals, will lead to criminal acts and destructive practices. So my vote is against.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because the UK adequately prohibits gender discrimination. There is no need for further EU legislation in this matter. I fundamentally agree with equal pay for men and women but I believe that employment law should be made at Member State level and not at EU level. In addition, the call for an EU harmonised job classification system is absurd and unnecessary.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The fact that progress towards gender equality in pay has proven totally insufficient in many EU countries, even though EU measures have been transposed into national laws, leads to a very uneven situation. We must make absolutely sure that unequal pay practices are discouraged and we must promote wage transparency, as requested by trade unions and gender equality bodies. I support the request to introduce mandatory pay audits for companies listed on the stock exchanges, except SMEs, and to introduce sanctions to exclude companies which fail to meet their responsibilities with regard to gender equality from the public procurement of goods and services from the EU budget. And I welcome the reversal of the burden of proof – a fundamental concept introduced by the report that makes sure the employer would have to prove that any difference in treatment was not based on discrimination.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the work of the rapporteur, Congresswoman Záborská, in the presentation of the ppe values in the report on equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in the field of employment and work. I consider it very important that the need for women's employment, which is aimed at long-term sustainability and has become a priority in creating financial stability in ageing societies, is very important in order to create a social climate where employment and childcare can be fully matched.  Nevertheless, I regretted, despite the efforts of the rapporteur and a number of MEMBERS of the People's Party, that although social policy, for each country, is embedded in an existing institutional system and value system, the report included a number of recommendations that deeply violate the principle of subsidiarity and thus weaken the report rather than strengthen it, which I cannot support, such as the imposition of sanctions on employers who discriminate in each Member State. and mandatory gender equality annual business plans for companies.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report, given my complete conviction that equal treatment between women and men in matters of employment and occupation is a non-negotiable issue. From the EU we cannot and will not allow women to be discriminated against at work, directly or indirectly. Therefore, the pay gap between women and men for the same work must be persecuted and eradicated. Similarly, we must continue to work to create the necessary conditions for the work-family balance.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that equal treatment between women and men in employment is a fundamental principle which must be respected and promoted. Unfortunately, large differences still persist and a review is needed to improve and modernise the Equal Employment Directive.  It is unacceptable that there is still a gender pay gap of more than 16% in Europe today, so it is urgent to promote non-sexist systems for job assessment and classification, which ensure wage transparency and combat gender biases that make the pay gap systematized. It is essential that mandatory wage audits are proposed for companies listed on a stock exchange in the Member States (excluding SMEs).  It should also be mandatory for companies to develop and implement annual strategic plans on gender equality and also to facilitate the reconciliation of the working lives of women and men with family life, which remains very difficult. Finally, it is unacceptable that the proportion of women in senior management positions in enterprises is less than 18%.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. The Treaty on the Functioning of the EU mentions equality between men and women as one of its principles. The report on equal opportunities in employment and employment, on the other hand, shows that, unfortunately, direct and indirect discrimination between men and women is still prevailing in our society, especially in the professional field. A gender pay gap currently at around 16% and consequently a pension pension gap of around 39%, inadequate services and family care, no guarantees of return to work after pregnancy, discrimination and the risks of social and occupational segregation: these conditions are totally unacceptable and are in flagrant contravenon of the principles of freedom of the individual, social justice and social justice. , protection of human dignity enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. I therefore hope that, with the support of this report, Europe will take action for greater participation by women in the labour market, introduce measures for transparency of remuneration as soon as possible and do everything possible to prevent prejudices about women's free and democratic access to working life, without limits of ambition, role or remuneration.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully supported the EP resolution on the application of Directive 2006/54/EC of the EP and of the Council on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment for men and women in employment and employment, because since its transposition into the national law of the Member States it has demonstrated its inadequacy to reduce differences in pay between men and women. I also hope for a revision of the directive which will ensure effective equality between men and women in relation to wages and pensions. The recent employment and pay gap is due solely to the recent fall in employment rates in the EU. I therefore believe that the time has come to make full use of the work of caring for children, elderly and disabled family members, which are mainly entrusted to the care of women. Similarly, I would like to see the full protection of women's rights to maternity by means of measures to prevent unfair dismissal during pregnancy and to implement provisions to help these workers. In addition, it is essential to include in all national legislation the prohibition of discrimination based on gender orientation or gender identity, introducing explicit protection for transgender people. Finally, it is necessary to promote their participation in political and economic decision-making processes, according to a quota system.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today against the report by Mrs Zaborska on equal opportunities and equal treatment for men and women in labour and employment matters, as this text violates the principle of subsidiarity in some key areas, restricts the collective bargaining autonomy of our social partners and makes demands with issues such as absolute wage transparency that are incompatible with a free, social market economy in Europe.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The adoption of the motion for a resolution on gender equality and women's empowerment sends a clear signal to the European Commission that action on this issue needs to be accelerated.   Every year in the world, 14 million girls are forced to marry and 62 million do not take up education. Many countries still have discriminatory laws and practices that deny women fundamental rights, access to jobs or political and economic participation. This not only limits women's personal development, but also inhibits their countries from achieving economic and social adaptation to the norms of a democratic world. Women should be free from threats under any latitude.  The promotion of cultural change at institutional level and the emphasis on the EU's role on the international stage must be clearly visible in the text. Women's health and their right to decide on reproductive issues must also be respected, especially now, in areas of armed conflict. The real test of the effectiveness of our policies will be when women in developing countries start to feel the difference in their treatment by the local community. We must do everything we can to keep our promises and put them into practice as soon as possible.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Women in the EU are still paid, on average, 16% less than men and receive 39% less in pensions. There is still a lot to do to ensure that all EU citizens can enjoy sufficient economic independence to exercise control and make free choices in their lives. I welcome this report that calls on the Commission to propose concrete action to decrease the gender pay gap, improve labour market accessibility and career progression for women, and fundamentally increase equality in decision-making. However, I do not believe that imposing quotas in enterprises is an adequate answer in terms of preventing gender-based discrimination. I therefore did not support these suggestions.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. – The UK has, in terms of legislation, the Equality Act and the Sex Discrimination Act, both of which prohibit direct discrimination on grounds of sex and of gender reassignment. Excessive EU interference in this area is unnecessary and it suggests that Member States are unable adequately to protect people against discrimination. The UK Conservative delegation fully supports the principle of equal pay between men and women and we do not accept any form of discrimination in or outside of the workplace. We believe, however, that the specifics of employment law are nationally sensitive and therefore should be determined in individual Member States, and not at EU level. There are a number of elements of the Záborská report which we are unable to support: for example, Commission-imposed sanctions for companies who do not consider gender equality in their public procurement process; binding quotas for women in the political and economic sectors; EU harmonisation of employment terms; a further call for an EU maternity leave proposal; and a strengthened role for trade unions in establishing employment contracts. The UK delegation supported a significant number of paragraphs that reaffirm the principle of non-discrimination and equality, but we rejected this report as a whole.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because, despite the benefits of equality between men and women, studies show that EU legislation in this area is still not effectively implemented in the Member States. Gender discrimination and non-compliance with equal opportunities and treatment between women and men in employment are a scourge comprising a very significant cost to individuals, all European societies and their economies. In general terms, Member States have not taken the opportunity of Directive 2006/54/EC to review their national systems in depth or simplify and modernise their equal treatment legislation. This report calls on the Commission to draw up a new legislative proposal to replace the existing Directive and introduce binding measures on the issue of equal treatment and occupation. In doing so, we hope to be able to reduce the current 16% men-women pay gap and the 39% pension gap, which to date place women in a situation that poses an increased risk of poverty in the face of men.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against the report on the application of Directive 2006/54/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 July 2006 on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment between women and men in the field of employment.  There is no doubt that a gradual elimination of the gender pay and pension gap is necessary. However, I regret that the European Parliament has once again voted in favour of the report, which promotes demands such as gender quotas and LGBT issues. I believe that, as regards the harmonisation of the definition of terms of labour law, such as the gender pay gap or equal pay for equal work, the Commission's guidelines would be a better solution.  As a Member of the European Group of Conservatives and Reformists, I do not support the imposition of mandatory wage controls in listed companies or mandatory reporting of average salaries on the basis of sex in individual positions, as they will create additional administrative and financial burdens for companies.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the Socialist & Democrats Group, I voted in favour of this resolution as progress on closing gender gaps in employment and occupation has been slow. Today, women still account for 32% of part-time work, the gender pay gap is 16% and the pensions gap is 39%.We need to do more to narrow this and bring about true equality for all EU citizens. In the UK, on average, women earn just 81p an hour for every pound a man earns. Forty-five years after the Equal Pay Act, this is completely unacceptable. We need to turn gender equality in law into gender equality in practice. Based on the current rate of progress, the gender pay gap will not be closed until 2084. Along with my Labour colleagues, I have long supported rules to require companies to publish their gender pay gaps. However, transparency alone is not enough: this data must be used to make equal pay a reality across Europe.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. Strong gender inequalities persist in the labour market to this day. In the face of this situation, I have spoken out in favour of revising the 2006 directive on gender equality in the labour market. In order to finally move from words to action, concrete answers are needed, which is why, together with my progressive colleagues, I call on the Commission to act by incorporating, in a revised directive, mandatory wage audits for listed companies (with the exception of SMEs) and the introduction of sanctions at European level to exclude companies from European public procurement that do not assume their responsibility for equal pay. We also call on States to ensure that the burden of proof is reversed, ensuring that the onus is always on the employer to prove that the differences in treatment found are not the result of some form of discrimination. Finally, we call for free legal aid for victims of discrimination, a ban on discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation, gender identity or gender change, work-life balance and positive measures to increase women's participation in decision-making.

In order to empower girls and young women globally these targets need to be achieved.

Wage inequality, when based on gender discrimination and not justified by any objective element such as skills or diplomas, is unacceptable and must be vigorously addressed.  Despite national legislation and awareness campaigns, a 16% pay gap between men and women persists. We cannot remain insensitive to this situation and cannot accept discriminatory practices based on sex in some companies. That is why I call on our legislators to be strong and would like to reaffirm my commitment to equal treatment between men and women in employment and work.

Also, I am a firm believer that empowering women and girls through education is an essential element in promoting equal treatment and equal opportunities in employment.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the application of Directive 2006/54/EC of parliament and the Council on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in matters of employment and work, as I believe that equal opportunities and treatment of all are one of the key principles of European law. Also, economic independence is a prerequisite for a decent life for all citizens of the European Union. I am against any discrimination (based on ethnicity, religion, disability or otherwise) and so is the gender gap between men and women. Advances in this area are still insufficient and a disproportion in wages has been found throughout the Union. Therefore, I believe that further efforts are needed to increase the availability of the labour market and encourage career progression for women, and furthermore their representation in decision-making processes. I support this report because it is geared towards achieving real equality.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The desire to ensure equal pay for equal work between men and women is commendable. But the report hijacks the subject to develop communitarian demands, especially LGBT ones.  Moreover, the uneven application of this directive could add unnecessary constraints, such as the social policy of entrepreneurs. In addition, Mrs Zaborska, rapporteur, has dissociated herself from this text because of certain ambiguities and communitarian amendments. So I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Anna Zaborska's report on the application of the Equal Opportunity and Equal Treatment of Men and Women directive on employment and work. The report calls for a review of this directive, in order to relaunch the fight to reduce wage gaps and to address the problems identified so far, notably in terms of the effectiveness of control systems, the role of social partners or access to legal aid for people who are victims of discrimination. The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. While it has very good substantive initiatives and is moving in the right direction, it is very poorly constructed and will not, in its current form, facilitate effectively address inequalities between men and women in access to employment and work.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting against this report because it stands for the implementation of minority rights in the Member States. It is up to the Member States to decide which laws should be adopted in order to achieve gender equality and close the wage gap. He also calls for sanctions against companies that do not adhere to gender equality, wants LGBT equality to be addressed in the curriculum, and data on gender, LGBT and transgender discrimination is collected. I reject these proposals and therefore vote against them.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. – I abstained in the European Parliament's vote on the resolution on the directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in matters of employment and occupation. I believe that ensuring equal opportunities and rights for men and women in terms of employment and occupation is a very important task, but this resolution contains many points that do not relate to the directive and its objectives. For example, I voted against a paragraph in the resolution calling for a mandatory audit of wages and salaries for companies in the new EC directive. Nor did I support the proposal to prohibit companies from tendering for public procurement if they do not employ an appropriate number of women, as it is often the specificities of the company that determine the proportion of the sex involved, as is the case in construction companies, for example. The requirement for mandatory gender quotas not only interferes with national legislation, but directly undermines the principle of equality in our society when a person is not judged by his abilities, but by gender. In the light of the above paragraphs and others, I decided to abstain in this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Along with my Labour colleagues, I have long supported rules to require companies to publish their gender pay gaps. However, transparency along is not enough; this data must be used to make equal pay a reality across Europe.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The principle of equal pay for equal work is an integral part of EU law and one of the key cornerstones of anti-discrimination policies in member states. Nevertheless, in practice, the average gender pay gap in the European Union remains stable at 16.4%, and the so-called total pay gap, which takes into account the employment gap between the two sexes, is as high as 39%.  I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of Directive 2006/54/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 July 2006 on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in the field of employment and work, as it recommends practical solutions for reducing the pay gap, such as job classification and valuation systems based on clear and comparable criteria. At the same time, it points out that, in order to fully close the wage and pay gap and the associated pension gap, more needs to be done in the form of an effective policy of combining work and family responsibilities, which will ensure that women and men participate in the labour market on an equal footing.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for my colleague Anna Zaborska's report on the balance sheet and the application of EU directives on equal pay for men and women. In fact, the reduction of the unfair gender pay gap has been stagnating for several years. We need to clearly take stock, identify the reasons for this wage inequity, distinguish the causes of real and unacceptable discrimination, differences due to non-homogeneous career paths, and propose concrete and effective remedies and avenues, through, for example, appropriate sanctions for companies that do not respect the principle of "equal work, equal pay".

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in employment and work. While the text is at first glance well oriented (ensuring equal pay for equal work, avoiding undignified pensions...), it is undermined by various communitarian demands and proposals for measures incompatible with freedom of enterprise, a breeding ground for employment. One of these demands is parity on boards of directors. Paragraph 28 removes the freedom to choose employees. Moreover, France is one of the few countries that has applied the original directive. It should therefore not be exploited by other countries to add constraints that are neither useful nor within the purview of the European Union, such as the social policy of entrepreneurs.
