name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this report, which is all so incredible and bizarre that it could not be born anywhere but in the completely breakaway environment of the Brussels Eurocracy. For the purposes of this explanation, I select some of the most terrible points: paragraph 16 'calls on the Commission and the Member States, by establishing effective monitoring systems, to take supervisory and control measures to improve the collection of data on cases of harassment and discrimination', paragraph 17 'calls on the Commission to closely monitor the effectiveness of national complaint-handling authorities and their procedures in relation to the application of the Gender Directives on gender identity issues , its expression and changes in gender identity' and 'to support and encourage Member States in the integration of transgender and intersex people into training in promoting diversity,' paragraph 36 'calls on the Member States to ... required companies to draw up and implement annual business plans for gender equality," paragraph 41 "calls on the Member States to take the necessary measures to reverse the burden of proof in such a way as to ensure that it is always the employer who has to prove that the difference in treatment found does not lead to any discrimination" (the rule of law appears to be something unacceptable in Brussels) and paragraph 45 'emphasises: that binding quotas have proved to be one of the best ways to achieve this objective'.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report. There are a number of substantial, unresolved problems in the area of equal opportunities in the labour market. In 2008 and 2012, the European Parliament adopted important resolutions on the equal pay of women and men. I, too, stressed the importance of non-discriminatory treatment of women in terms of access to education, information and a balanced working life. Although many Member States have harmonised their national legislation with the relevant provisions of European Union law, this transposition is insufficient to ensure respect for fundamental rights. The principle of equal pay for the same work or for work of the same value, as set out in Article 141 of the Treaty and confirmed by the settled case-law of the Court of Justice, is still infringed. We need to ensure that we have a fair and uniform assessment of work, that the principle of equal treatment applies to pension schemes, that effective monitoring systems exist. In addition, access to legal aid for victims of discrimination of any kind is fundamental. If we want a Europe where equality of opportunity does not remain a mere slogan, we must generate the legislative framework that makes that possible.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. – Discrimination against women in matters of employment and occupation is undesirable and unacceptable in a democratic society. Its impact is negatively felt at the different stages of women's social and economic life, which impairs their overall quality of life. I support the drafting of an amendment to directive 2006/54/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 July 2006 on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in matters of employment and occupation, so that this regulation take account of past practices and findings in the field of unequal treatment and introduces justice and equality between women and men.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the implementation of Directive 2006/54/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 July 2006, on the application of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment for men and women in matters of work and employment for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/10/2015, and because we see that the wage differences against women continue to exist and that women are paid at least 16% lower wages than men. We have over-representation of women in part-time work, we have under-representation of women in full-time jobs and we also have pensions at least 39% on average lower in women than in men. In particular, now, in the countries affected by the Memorandums, it is women who have been most affected by austerity and fiscal adjustment measures. In Greece, the latest figures from 2015 show that women have an unemployment rate of 30.6%, while men have an unemployment rate of 23.5%. Measures must, as a matter of urgency, be taken to tackle and stop discrimination between the sexes.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report. This text, which was originally commendable, provides for equal pay for equal work, avoiding undignified pensions and the use of grids with recruitment criteria. Although interesting, this text is perverted and hijacked by the multiple pro-LGBTI amendments, and European measures which are neither useful nor within the purview of the EU.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Equal treatment of men and women in employment and occupation is a matter of freedom and justice. It is a non-negotiable part of the social contract. All women regardless of their age, education or social status are potential victims of discrimination in the workplace, directly or indirectly.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Equal treatment of men and women in employment and employment is certainly one of the European Union's priority objectives. Equal treatment is also a family issue because the well-being of many families depends on women's wages, since they have the main responsibility for maintaining their families as their only sources of income. Exploiting women's potential and skills are therefore essential factors in bridging the wage gap and achieving the objectives of the European Union's growth strategy. Narrowing the pay gap is in fact an EU priority given that women earn on average around 16.4 fewer than men in the EU economies, and this figure has remained almost unchanged in recent years.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Zaborska resolution because I am convinced that equal opportunities for men and women are a key point for European socio-economic development policies. Further progress is being made with this approved document, but further impetus is now needed, not only to combat the wage gap, but also for what is indirect discrimination. Strengthening the role of women and allowing equal treatment to close the contractual gap are also growth and freedom strategies for the European Union. I hope, therefore, that the Commission will finally intervene with a comprehensive and incisive directive on this issue, so that we can complete comprehensive legislation in favour of gender equality, which is one of the founding elements of European principles.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I reject this report on the grounds that national legislators are to be required to make a large number of LGBTI demands. In my opinion, the title of the report does not reflect its content.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as I am an advocate of promoting gender balance. Binding quotas are already a part of the Irish political landscape.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Despite anti-discrimination legislation, including the 2006 directive, the gender pay gap is still stagnating at around 16.5%. This report recalls the need to combat gender stereotypes, which the Christian Democrat rapporteur strongly opposes. Reason enough for her not to vote for her report as amended. The text recommends a number of access to justice measures and sanctions for companies that are reluctant to hire women. It also points to the imbalances between work and family life, discrimination in pension schemes but above all the precariousness of work: the increase in part-time work, "the abuse of atypical forms of contracts, especially contracts without hours, which allow to escape the obligations of employment and social protection".  I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The desire to ensure equal pay for equal work between men and women is commendable. But the report hijacks the subject to develop communitarian demands, especially LGBT ones.  Moreover, the uneven application of this directive could add unnecessary constraints, such as the social policy of entrepreneurs. In addition, Mrs Zaborska, rapporteur, has dissociated herself from this text because of certain ambiguities and communitarian amendments. So I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the implementation of Directive 2006/54/EC on the application of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in areas related to employment and occupation. The rapporteur's report distances itself from what would be her main purpose: the defence of equal treatment between men and women. For this reason, I have put my vote against it.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it proposes many measures that would address the stagnation in tackling the gender pay gap. The European Union should do more to narrow the gender pay gap and also address the regional discrepancies in the Union.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – This report calls on the European Commission to propose new actions to eliminate the still-existing inequalities between men and women in the labour market. Today, there is still an inexplicable gap between what men and women get in their wage bill at the beginning of the month. This difference in pay increases even after retirement age. In this way, women in the EU receive up to 39% less pension. This difference in pensions is due to shorter careers, fewer full-time jobs but also to more difficult access to the labour market and limited career opportunities.  Closing the pay gap is necessary to ensure the chances of women's individual development and their economic independence. At the same time, the application of the principle of equal pay for equal work will also improve the financial situation of many European families. Access to the labour market also needs to be improved. Application procedures and job evaluations are quite gender neutral so that not the nicest or the toughest, but the most suitable candidate gets the job.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome and consider it necessary to take very active steps for equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in matters of employment and occupation. I am aware that tensions between family and professional life contribute to a low birth rate in most Member States, which threatens the labour market, the healthcare system and the pension system. In doing so, surveys show that Europeans would like more offspring. However, provided that they are economically sufficient. However, according to the analyses, the gender pay gap is most visible precisely after a woman returns to the labour market after her first maternity leave. Moreover, they increase even further after retirement, when, according to available statistics, women in the EU receive on average 39% less pension than men.  I therefore join the recommendation to take into account the importance of women's unpaid work as carers and to adequately recognise the value of this unpaid work. At the same time, however, I must reject the fact that, on this meaningful issue, the ambiguous term 'gender' (gender) re-emerges in the text of the submitted report instead of the unambiguous concept of gender, in which experience has shown that it is clearly manipulated.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which calls for a revision of the recast directive, since its transposition into national law has proven insufficient to reduce differences in pay for men and women. It is essential to call for pressure on unequal pay practices and to promote wage transparency, as requested by trade unions and gender equality bodies. The report also calls on Member States to take steps to reverse the burden of proof, so the employer would have to prove that differences in treatment have not resulted in any discrimination.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Economic independence is a prerequisite for enabling European citizens, both women and men, to exercise control and make genuine choices in their lives. In this case it is clear that there is no subsidiarity issue, since we are talking about a directive – European Union legislation – on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment. According to my knowledge, not implementing the law should not be an option for Member States. Therefore I wonder why the Commission is not doing more to resolve the Member States’ partial incompliance and omissive attitude regarding the provisions of the directive.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality adopted a report on the application of Directive 2006/5/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 July 2006 on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in the field of employment and work, and, on that basis, a motion for the adoption of a resolution on this. The draft concludes that Directive 2006/54/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in the field of employment and work has reached its limits and has exhausted its possibilities and should therefore be further developed. Given that I consider the problem raised to be crucial, I voted in favour of the draft.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is essential that Member States take the opportunity to simplify and update their legislation on equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in areas related to employment and occupation. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is essential that Member States work together and articulately to promote greater equal opportunities in all employment-related matters. I voted against the introduction of quotas in listed companies and in politics because I believe that women should take up these positions because of their competence, work ability and prestige rather than being only by numerical categorisation in terms of boards of directors or political activity.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The Zaborska report on equal opportunities for men and women in employment and work aims to provide an update on the progress of the 2006/54/EC directive on this subject. While this text may seem well oriented because of the stated objective of ensuring equal pay for equal work and combating undignified pensions, it is undermined by communitarian demands of various kinds and puts forward proposals for measures that are too restrictive for the employer, thus risking jeopardising the freedom to undertake as it exists in France. Moreover, France is one of the few countries that has already applied the original directive; there is therefore no need to use the lack of zeal of some Member States to add unnecessary constraints and additional powers to the EU, particularly with regard to corporate social policy. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the UK, on average, women earn just 81p an hour for every pound a man earns. Forty-five years after the Equal Pay Act, this is completely unacceptable. We need to turn gender equality in law into gender equality in practice. Based on the current rate of progress, the gender pay gap will not be closed until 2084. Along with my Labour colleagues, I have long supported rules to require companies to publish their gender pay gaps. However, transparency along is not enough: this data must be used to make equal pay a reality across Europe.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which deals with the implementation of the Directive on the implementation of equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in employment and work. It calls on the European Commission to revise the European legislative framework to strengthen and make more effective the directive aimed at ending gender-based wage discrimination. In particular, I supported the provisions which call on Member States to make efforts to make services available to pregnant women or mothers that can help them not to have to choose between work and family life.

name: Elisabeth Morin-Chartier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Anna Zaborska's report. This report relates to the application of Directive 2006/54/EC, which consolidates and modernises the Union's acquis in this area by merging previous directives. The European Parliament has consistently called for stronger action to improve the implementation of equal pay provisions at European level and adopted resolutions to this effect in 2008 and 2012. In her report, Ms Zaborska points out that Member States have generally brought their laws into line with EU legislation. It draws attention, however, to the fact that, as things stand, transposition has proved insufficient to allow full application and implementation, since a large wage gap continues to exist. The aim is to address the important problems that remain, such as: adequate and uniform assessment of work, the application of equal treatment provisions for pension schemes, effective control systems, the role of social partners and access to legal aid for people who are victims of discrimination.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that reiterates the need for clear, harmonised definitions – to facilitate EU-level comparison – of terms such as gender pay gap, gender pension gap, remuneration, direct and indirect pay discrimination, and, especially, work treated as ‘equal’ and work of the same value. A clear and harmonised job classification system and greater wage transparency will improve access to justice.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Being part of the FEMM (Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality) committee in the past mandate, I supported this report because I believe that this problem still exists in many of our societies, including Romania, and the European Union must have a common vision in this context. Since the employment rate is generally lower among women than among men, and equal treatment between women and men is one of the fundamental principles of European Union law, we need common European legislation on equal opportunities for employment. As the document adopted today states, Member States must actively apply gender mainstreaming in the budget in order to promote and improve the situation of women in the labour market. It must also combat gender inequality by taking appropriate measures to bridge the gap, which is a direct consequence of gender gap. The potential of women, which is a low-exploited source of economic growth at European level, must not be forgotten.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on equal opportunities in employment and occupation, because I believe that this issue needs to be given increased attention. I did so despite the fact that not every part of the resulting report corresponded to my positions, but I still felt it necessary to support the report. In particular, respect for the principle of equal pay should be a priority, but it is also important to combat other barriers to equal treatment, such as discrimination within pension schemes. I believe that, on the whole, women's involvement in the management and management of companies and businesses needs to be increased, on the one hand, to ensure their equality and, on the other hand, to make full use of their skills and potential.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This report calls on the Member States to strengthen those mechanisms that implement equality between women and men more efficiently. Other points include equal opportunities and protection against direct or indirect discrimination. It also calls for the principle of equal pay for women and men. The Commission is also calling for sanctions to be introduced at EU level to exclude companies that violate the principle of equality from public procurement and funding from the EU budget. As I believe that small and medium-sized enterprises cannot meet this requirement for economic reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This initiative report proposes a reform of the European Parliament and Council's 2006/54/EC Directive on the implementation of the principles of equal opportunities and treatment of men and women in employment and work. By the observation that the wage gap remains unchanged if not deepened since the implementation of this directive, and by the ineffectiveness of the principles of equal pay enshrined in the texts, this reform is necessary in the sense of strengthening guarantees of full implementation. This includes harmonizing the definitions of the key terms of equal pay, or establishing financial penalties for companies that deviate from these principles. I'm voting for.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, calling on the Commission to address the failure by many Member States to tackle the gender pay gap, which stands at an average of 16.4% across the EU. In Ireland, women continue to earn on average 14% less than their male counterparts, a situation which is unacceptable in the 21st century. This is a positive and strong report that stresses the need to introduce binding measures in order to tackle the roots of this discrimination. It calls for pressure on unequal pay practices and for the promotion of wage transparency, as requested by trade unions and gender equality bodies. It also calls for the introduction of mandatory pay audits for companies listed on the stock exchanges, and for sanctions against those companies that fail to implement equal pay, including their exclusion from the public procurement of goods and services from the EU budget. The report calls on Member States to take steps to reverse the burden of proof, so the employer would have to prove that a difference in treatment had not been caused by discrimination. Additional elements include introducing quotas for women at management level in companies, and taking measures to improve work-family balance.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The European Union must consistently address the reduction of the gender pay gap. Women's lower wages not only affect their current economic security, but future incomes, such as pensions, also depend on it. In addition, it inhibits the development of society as a whole.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. Although the EU has made considerable progress on gender equality in recent decades, thanks in particular to the legislation adopted in this field and the transversality that gender equality has taken on in the various EU policies, inequalities between men and women, particularly in the world of work, are still present. Although women account for 60% of graduates in the EU, employment rates are usually lower among women than men and, in general, they are under-represented in management positions.  Women usually receive a wage of about 16% lower than men's, and this pay gap, which has remained almost unchanged over the past decade, is reflected in a lower level of pension received. The revision of Directive 2006/54/EC represents a crucial challenge for all EU Member States to generate a major driving force on equal pay and to offer women practical solutions that would help them better reconcile professional and family responsibilities. I therefore believe that the Commission must closely monitor the implementation of the country-specific recommendations and act promptly against Member States that do not comply with the provisions of the directive.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 While I recognise the importance of gender equality between men and women in employment and while taking into account the fact that the gender pay gap has changed minimally, I would vote against it because I do not fully agree with the way in which this issue has been dealt with.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I agree with the need to bridge the differences between the remuneration of men and women for equal work and to eliminate the disparities that are happening in this area, but I do not agree with all the ways that have been included in this resolution, which is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Even nine years after the adoption of Directive 2006/54/EC on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in employment and labour matters, the position of women in the labour market has not changed significantly. Women continue to be victims of direct and indirect discrimination, which is manifested in the form of lower employment rates, lower wages and pensions, and in the form of discrimination with regard to maternity and/or parental leave.   I applaud the purpose of the report, but what I oppose is its inconsistency. While the report is intended to achieve equality between women and men in terms of employment and work, as many as seven points speak to gender equality rather than gender equality.  In addition, the report refers to as many as four points the issue of official recognition of people who have changed genders - an issue that has nothing to do with the equality of women and men in the labour market. Precisely because of the inconsistency found in this report and considering that there is much room for improvement and progress in this regard, I abstained when voting.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Zaborska report on equal employment and work opportunities between men and women is intended to provide an update on the progress of the 2006/54/EC Directive on this subject. While this text may seem well oriented because of the stated objective of ensuring equal pay for equal work and combating undignified pensions, it is undermined by communitarian demands of various kinds and puts forward proposals for measures that are too restrictive for the employer, thus risking jeopardising the freedom to undertake as it exists in France. Moreover, France is one of the few countries that has already applied the original directive; there is therefore no need to use the lack of zeal of some Member States to add unnecessary constraints and additional powers to the EU, particularly with regard to corporate social policy. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Although much has been done in the area of equality between men and women, the issue of gender inequality in the labour market remains one of the fundamental problems facing women today. In this regard, I welcome this report and efforts to introduce stricter mechanisms for monitoring and sanctioning employers who are not ready to solve this problem, as well as the fact that the report illuminates problems that are still not sufficiently recognized such as the gender pension gap, discrimination and harassment of transgender people, etc. I welcome the more decisive introduction of measures such as gender-neutral job assessment and classification systems, the definition of clear criteria for assessing the value of work, the involvement of social partners and civil society in supervisory mechanisms, and greater efforts towards work-life balance.  While the gender pay gap in Croatia is much smaller than the EU average, we are still lagging behind in some areas. Gender equality is a constitutional category, and anti-discrimination measures extend through several laws, including the Labour Act. However, there are numerous exceptions in Croatian legislation that allow for the justification of direct and indirect discrimination, positive measures are often not binding on employers, and women in pregnancy and mothers, despite legal protection, remain subject to discrimination in employment and in the workplace.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased that Parliament has voted favourably on the report on equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in matters of employment and occupation. Gender equality is something which the EU strives to achieve – as do I – and this measure helps to address some of the gaps that are still prevalent in the workplace. The report stresses the importance of fighting indirect discrimination, especially with regard to pension schemes. It also calls on the Commission and Member States to raise awareness regarding the pay and pensions gaps between the genders. In addition, it recommends that Member States become role models within their own public institutions when it comes to equal pay for women. I am proud of the result of the vote on this report, and I believe that it will bring meaningful change and help with closing the gender gap.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report assesses the application of Directive 2006/54/EC modernizing Community provisions in the field of equal treatment for men and women in the labour market. The rapporteur, Mrs Roth-President of the Commission, has made a very important point in this report. Mr Zaborska points out that, although, in general terms, the Member States have brought national laws into line with the provisions of the European Union, the application of the directive has not proved sufficient in the light of definitive compensation for the wage gap between men and women. That is what Mr Syley has just said is a very important one. Zaborska calls on the European Commission to present a new draft legislation to replace what has been planned so far. In this report, however, there are some passages concerning company law – reference is made, for example, to a system of sanctions for companies in the event of non-compliance with the principle of equal treatment – and some references to the recognition of LGBT rights – such as, for example, the legal recognition of gender change – which I find to be non-acceptable. I have therefore chosen to vote against the motion for a resolution.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from this report, although I strongly support gender equality in all areas. However, the text of this report contains a number of measures that are ineffective and, moreover, can ultimately turn against the women themselves. As an example, I would like to give proposals for mandatory quotas for gender representation on boards. These measures really won't help women.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Equal employment opportunities for men and women are a political priority for me, and we must take all the necessary decisions to achieve this. These measures must be effective and appropriate to the intended purpose. Therefore, I do not want Europe to interfere in matters where it has no place. These postures defended by some of my colleagues do not respect the principle of subsidiarity. That is why I abstained on certain passages.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Equality between men and women is one of the fundamental principles on which the EU is founded. This resolution addresses the issue of gender equality in the context of employment and occupation. In this regard, it should be noted with concern that, despite the principle of equal pay, which has been enshrined in EU law since 1957, the pay gap in pensions and the employment rate between men and women still persists. In this sense, and it is certain that greater equality between men and women, in addition to being a question of fairness and justice, brings numerous benefits to the economy and society and is essential to promote growth, competitiveness and economic recovery, it is important that the EU and its Member States implement measures to ensure effective implementation of equal pay and equal treatment provisions. So i agree with the general ity of the recommendations which, in this regard, are formulated by the rapporteur, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which aims to strengthen EU legislation on equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in employment and work. The 2006/54/EC European Directive provides for this equality. However, its implementation in the Member States does not seem to be sufficient: the gender pay gap in the EU averages 16.4%; Employment rates are generally lower among women; pension gaps remain large.  The implementation of the 2006 directive must be strengthened and genuine equality of opportunity and treatment for men and women should be achieved by reducing the pay gap, increasing women's economic independence, improving women's access to the labour market, establishing equality in decision-making processes or removing discriminatory structures and practices.  For those who still doubt it, let us remember that this establishment will result in major positive effects that will benefit society as a whole.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The rapporteur considers that the current Directive 2006/54/EC needs to be updated. The report focuses on the gender pay gap, the work-life imbalance, discrimination in pension schemes, the concept of equal work, wage transparency and access to justice, among other relevant and important issues. I especially look at the issue of equal pay. 10 years after the introduction of an EU law aimed at ensuring equal pay for equal work between men and women, the latter still receive on average 16% less (aggravated by the economic crisis). One of the reasons for maintaining this discrepancy was the lack of sanctions for companies that, in a constant way, persist in unequal treatment between men and women. This is a situation that the trial of this report is trying to address by providing for sanctions for some companies (those listed on the EU stock exchanges) if they choose not to fulfil their responsibilities with regard to gender pay equality. It also suggests that Member States do the same with publicly funded companies. It was a courageous and decisive step towards justice.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that equal treatment between women and men in employment is a fundamental principle which must be respected and promoted. Unfortunately, large differences still persist and a review is needed to improve and modernise the Equal Employment Directive.  It is unacceptable that there is still a gender pay gap of more than 16% in Europe today, so it is urgent to promote non-sexist systems for job assessment and classification, which ensure wage transparency and combat gender biases that make the pay gap systematized. It is essential that mandatory wage audits are proposed for companies listed on a stock exchange in the Member States (excluding SMEs).  It should also be mandatory for companies to develop and implement annual strategic plans on gender equality and also to facilitate the reconciliation of the working lives of women and men with family life, which remains very difficult. Finally, it is unacceptable that the proportion of women in senior management positions in enterprises is less than 18%.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, I voted in favour of the report on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in employment and work. An important vote as this principle of equality is still far from being reality in Europe today. Despite the many legislative initiatives of the past 40 years, it is clear that the convergence of opportunities and equal treatment between men and women is slow and insufficient. Even today, women earn on average 16.4% less than men, their employment rate is much lower and they face more atypical forms of contract. The list of these unfair differences is still long and highlights the need to act more effectively. This report highlights the insufficient transposition of the 2006 directive, a problem that needs to be addressed. Through this report, the European Parliament is also making a series of proposals to the Commission for its new legislative proposal, which it will present in 2016. Finally, this report also addresses the discrimination that some people suffer because of their gender identity or gender change.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although I am in favour of equal opportunities and equal treatment for men and women in employment and employment, I consider the usual reference to 'recognition of gender change' in a report on equal treatment in employment and employment to be useless; Just as I do not approve of the request for a reversal of the burden of proof on the employer. The idea behind the resolution is excellent, but not the wording of the text.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because, despite the benefits of equality between men and women, studies show that EU legislation in this area is still not effectively implemented in the Member States. Gender discrimination and non-compliance with equal opportunities and treatment between women and men in employment are a scourge comprising a very significant cost to individuals, all European societies and their economies. In general terms, Member States have not taken the opportunity of Directive 2006/54/EC to review their national systems in depth or simplify and modernise their equal treatment legislation. This report calls on the Commission to draw up a new legislative proposal to replace the existing Directive and introduce binding measures on the issue of equal treatment and occupation. In doing so, we hope to be able to reduce the current 16% men-women pay gap and the 39% pension gap, which to date place women in a situation that poses an increased risk of poverty in the face of men.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – All women can fall victim to pay discrimination in the workplace. The fact that they receive a lower salary for doing comparable work compared to men has a significant impact, inter alia, on their social security in old age. It is unacceptable that women receive an average pension 39% lower than men. I therefore consider the introduction of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment in employment for men and women to be necessary and I therefore welcome the proposal for this report. Employers should pay attention not only to equal pay regardless of gender, but also to increasing the representation of women in senior positions.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it requests the European Commission to review the Directive on the application of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in matters of employment and occupation. Despite being based on the case-law of the European courts, that legislative act has failed to end the huge disparity in wages between men and women in general (16.4% on average), or between Member States; nor with discrimination in workplaces. It therefore calls for strong measures such as incorporating sanctions against undertakings that fail to comply with equality measures, an audit on this issue of large publicly traded undertakings, or the Council adopting a position to unblock the so-called Maternity Directive.  However, I believe that this report should have included some of our considerations; in particular, how austerity measures to tackle the financial and economic crisis, together with the increasing easing of employment contracts, have led to high levels of poverty among women in Europe (22% in the Spanish state).

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the World Economic Forum's Global Gender Differences Index, Portugal was in 2014 in 39th place.  Here are some figures: 31% of seats in the National Parliament are held by women, 21% of ministerial positions are held by women and there are only 12% of women on the boards of business administrations. A man Portuguese earns on average 30% more than a Portuguese woman.  For these reasons, I think it is very positive that this report explicitly states that Member States should legislate to ensure a balanced representation of women and men on boards.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a very important vote for the women, men and transgender persons in my constituency. I voted in favour of this report because I want to see equal pay for all genders. The amendments concerning transgender persons are particularly important to me, and I feel that the European Union can and should definitely be doing more in this area.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Unjustified gender pay gaps still exist and are unacceptable. Another key factor that disadvantages women in the labour market is their maternal role. Both, in turn, lead to differences in the amount of the old-age pension, and all this leads to the feminisation of poverty. The lack of an economic assessment of the benefits of women – mothers in the care of children and other dependants in informal home care and their investment in human capital – only contributes to this society-wide economic and social injustice and persistent inequalities. It is therefore necessary to take concrete measures and take the necessary steps to eliminate this injustice. The resolution does not take these facts into account sufficiently, while at the same time using misleading gender terminology. I therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. —Equal treatment of men and women in employment and occupation is a matter of justice and fairness.  All women, regardless of their age, education or social status are directly or indirectly potential victims of discrimination in the workplace. There are several main elements by which women are discriminated against: the pay gap, the work-family imbalance, access to justice and discrimination within the pension system. Equal treatment and the principle of non-discrimination has been an important part of eu primary legislation since the adoption of the Treaty of Rome in 1957. In plenary, I supported the proposal for a directive that would allow the implementation of penalties for those responsible and compensation for victims of discrimination. Sanctions and penalties will encourage avoidance of situations that can be discriminatory.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Equal treatment between men and women is one of the fundamental principles of EU law. The amended directive aims to bring EU legislation in this area more in line with the case-law of the Court of Justice of the EU and to simplify and modernise relevant equality legislation at national level to contribute to a better position for women on the labour market (by 2014 the proportion of women in the management positions of companies operating in the EU was below 18%). Some innovations have been introduced, such as the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities, the definition of the concept of indirect discrimination and protection against discrimination on grounds of gender change. Economic independence is a prerequisite for European citizens, both women and men, to have control over their lives and to make life decisions. I therefore agree that the correct application and enforcement of equal pay rules (Directive 2006/54/EC) is a key challenge for all Member States. As greater equality between men and women benefits society and the economy, and reducing the gender pay gap helps to reduce poverty and is of paramount importance for employment growth, competitiveness and economic recovery, and because the pay gap has a profound impact on the living conditions and life chances of many European families, I supported the report.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of non-legislative resolutions on equal treatment of men and women in employment because it is important and necessary to point out that wage differences not only persist but are even increasing, despite the existence of a 2006 EU directive on the subject. According to Eurostat 2013 data, the pay and pension gap between men and women averages 16.4% and 38.5% across the EU, with significant differences between countries. In view of the slowness of the Member States in implementing existing European legislation on equal pay, Parliament is calling on the Commission to propose new rules establishing more effective means of monitoring the application of the directive in the Member States. Among the proposals contained in the resolution, I would like to highlight in particular the possibility of imposing sanctions at European level in the event of non-compliance for employers who do not respect equal pay. Indeed, while some virtuous states have transposed the directive, in many other countries including, unfortunately, Italy, national legislation still has a lot of progress to make towards equal pay.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today against the report by Anna Zaborska on equal opportunities and equal treatment for men and women in matters of employment and employment, as it violates the principle of subsidiarity on a number of key points. It calls for absolute wage transparency and the associated threat of sanctions that do not make sense in terms of market economy or within the EU's sphere of competence.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I strongly support family policy and active women, but I do not share the view that equal opportunities need to be addressed with administrative quotas. Women can assert themselves without such regulation.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. The N-VA delegation abstained on this report. The N-VA stands for an inclusive society with equal rights and obligations for all, as well as an equal opportunities policy tailored to and with attention to all diverse target groups. Violations of this equality, both at work and in private, are not acceptable to us.  Because of the call for mandatory quotas for women, we had to abstain on this report. There are social and root causes of the glass ceiling and discrimination. Quotas are not a solution. The N-VA is also a party that pays close attention to the well-being of the family. At the same time, subsidiarity is also important for the N-VA. We have an eye for the different levels of policy and the demarcation of powers. From this point of view, the report in front of this report is problematic, as the report calls for a common position on the Maternity Directive.  The N-VA delegation also points to the very specific and rather complex Belgian context given the existence of the various systems such as time credits and thematic engagement (e.g. parental leave). These systems are integrated into a system of career account, which is a flexible and tailor-made form of career policy and ensures an effective and workable combination between work and care.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I would like to stress that I certainly support equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in terms of employment and work and equalization of their rights, but I voted with restraint in this report due to the excessive use of the ambivalent term gender, instead of the clear and legally defined concept of gender – sex. The use of vague terminology in this way makes the text unclear.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly supported this report. Based on the current rate of progress, the gender pay gap will not be closed until 2084. Along with my Labour colleagues, I have long supported rules to require companies to publish their gender pay gaps. However, transparency alone is not enough: this data must be used to make equal pay a reality across Europe.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in employment and professional work. Although the differences in employment rates and wage levels have decreased slightly in recent years, this is not due to the improvement in the situation of women, nor is it due to the better action of the Member States in this area. The report rightly notes that Member States often only transpose the Directive into their national law, but do not do enough at other levels, such as monitoring the implementation of the principle of equal pay and enforcing all available remedies for payment discrimination.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In today's vote on the amendments to the report on equal opportunities and equal treatment for men and women in the field of employment and occupation, I voted in such a way as to reaffirm my position expressed earlier in voting in similar cases, namely that the issue of subsidiarity should be strictly applied on certain bioethic or family policy issues and not confused with those issues which are the subject of other reports or opinions of the European Parliament.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Tough neoliberal policies hit all workers, but working women crush them. Over the past decade, the gender pay gap has remained almost stagnant, from 17.5% in 2008 to 16.4% in 2012. In the light of this stagnation, it was considered that the current directive has reached its limits and needs to be updated. It is good that the report recognises inequalities, calls for intensified efforts to combat undeclared work and precarious jobs, proposes concrete measures to ensure stronger rights for men and women and even proposes sanctions for large companies that do not comply with their gender equality obligations.  However, what is overlooked in the report is that gender parity cannot be conceived in the context of neoliberal policies promoted daily by the EU. However, despite the individual problematic references in the report (e.g. using the European Semester to combat inequalities and ensure equal treatment), the text contains many positive references that we cannot ignore.  That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Gender equality is an important factor in the social, cultural and economic development of countries. However, the use of this fundamental value individually and without taking into account morals and morals will lead to criminal acts and destructive practices.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the work of the rapporteur, Congresswoman Záborská, in the presentation of the ppe values in the report on equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in the field of employment and work. I consider it very important that the need for women's employment, which is aimed at long-term sustainability and has become a priority in creating financial stability in ageing societies, is very important in order to create a social climate where employment and childcare can be fully matched.  Nevertheless, I regretted, despite the efforts of the rapporteur and a number of MEMBERS of the People's Party, that although social policy, for each country, is embedded in an existing institutional system and value system, the report included a number of recommendations that deeply violate the principle of subsidiarity and thus weaken the report rather than strengthen it, which I cannot support, such as the imposition of sanctions on employers who discriminate in each Member State. and mandatory gender equality annual business plans for companies.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report, which rightly stressed that greater equality between men and women, reducing the pay gap between them, would increase the performance of the economy, contribute to reducing poverty and have a beneficial effect on society in general. The report looked in detail at the issue of equal opportunities between men and women in the field of employment, drawing attention to all the issues where almost all Member States need to develop.  I think it is important that the report noted that the economic crisis was the reason for the slight decrease in the gender employment and pay gap in recent years, as some Member States tend to report such changes in statistical indicators on their own merits. However, this prevents real results from being achieved in reducing the pay gap and increasing employment and competitiveness. At the same time, I would like to draw attention to the fact that access to lifelong learning, vocational training and mentoring networks should not be limited to women only. It is important for both sexes to have the opportunity to do so across Europe.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We, 5 Stars, welcome this report which aims to promote equal treatment and opportunities for men and women in companies and in the world of work in general. In fact, the reality of employment is worrying and Italy is a sad example of this: the gender disparity between workers reaches 20% in our country. Same situation for the gender pay gap still very, very high (16.4% in 2012). We need to do more and create fairer opportunities between women and men, creating the right conditions where women, and indirectly the whole family, can reconcile family and working life. So yes to better social and welfare policies. However, we voted against those amendments which wanted to introduce sanctions and bureaucratic practices, which are already unsustainable, for companies and employers.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Gender equality is a fundamental principle of natural law, requiring that a man and a woman be treated similarly, fairly and equitably. However, it is noted that this principle is still too often denied, even decried by the corporate world, where men occupy the places with higher responsibility. Once again the European Parliament is in favour of more effective equality because that is what it is all about. We will not stop fighting as long as women's rights are so abused

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This own-initiative report is concerned with the gender pay gap and discrimination in the workplace. It states that – in spite of EU efforts throughout the last 40 years, EU primary legislation and case law – the gender pay gap still exists, at an average of 16.4 % across the EU. The report therefore calls on the Commission to prepare a new legislative proposal that would necessitate observance of the principle of equal pay. While I wholly subscribe to the concept of equal treatment of men and women in employment and otherwise, I have difficulties with some of the specific measures proposed by this report. In particular, I do not fully identify with the recommendation of binding quotas, which the report considers as the best way to increase women’s involvement in political and economic decision making. I therefore abstained from voting on this report.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Another of the many reports on the initiative of the European Parliament's FEMM Committee, whose title promises a lot and the content compromises the title beyond recognition. I also hold the fact that the rapporteur, Zaborska, voted abstained on the finally amendmentd version of the text of the report in the Committee. As a woman with a long-standing police career who has encountered numerous prejudices during her professional career, I strongly support the principles of equal opportunities and equal treatment of women and men, and the principle of equal pay for the same work. It is an irrefutable and sad fact that the gender pay gap persists and averages 16.4% for the entire European Union area. But what I have never been able to, nor will I ever be able to agree with, is the hypocritical mixing of the right to equal opportunity with the unscrupulous promotion of gender ideology. Some groups in the European Parliament have unfortunately succeeded again in their intention to undermine constructive debate on another extremely important topic, including in the report their standard requirements such as binding female quotas, LGTB community rights, prohibition of discrimination against people who have changed gender, special privileges for under-stated sex, wage audits for companies listed on the exchanges of the Member States of the Union, the term 'gender' rather than 'gender' and many others.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the proposal for the application of Directive 2006/54/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 July 2006 on the implementation of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women in employment and work in the majority, as I really want the pay gap between men and women to be narrowed or not. Since the report falls short of my expectations on all points, as it involves the promotion of gender ideology, which, in my opinion, does not add value to the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in employment and professional work, I would abstain in the final vote.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation of European women on the labour market is characterized by systemic discrimination. This is reflected in lower income, lack of representation at the highest levels of the career ladder and concentration in the less prestigious and less profitable sectors of the economy. Particularly vulnerable are women of childbearing age. Available settings in the field of education, in fact, reproduce the gender imbalance in the labour market. The issue of gender equality in the EU received public and Member States’ recognition, although the measures taken so far have not led to a radical change in the status of women on the labour market and to achieving substantive (rather than formal) equality between men and women in employment, in political and social life.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because, despite the benefits of equality between men and women, studies show that EU legislation in this area is still not effectively implemented in the Member States. Gender discrimination and non-compliance with equal opportunities and treatment between women and men in employment are a scourge comprising a very significant cost to individuals, all European societies and their economies. In general terms, Member States have not taken the opportunity of Directive 2006/54/EC to review their national systems in depth or simplify and modernise their equal treatment legislation. This report calls on the Commission to draw up a new legislative proposal to replace the existing Directive and introduce binding measures on the issue of equal treatment and occupation. In doing so, we hope to be able to reduce the current 16% men-women pay gap and the 39% pension gap, which to date place women in a situation that poses an increased risk of poverty in the face of men.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Any measure that promotes equality between men i women is good and has my support. Unfortunately 26 Member States have outstanding issues in the transposition of the directive and the Commission is one year behind schedule in adopting the legislative initiative wing was committed to promote and facilitate the effective implementation of the principle of equal pay in practice. It is an urgent issue and I encourage the Commission to work on it. I encourage Member States in the sense that consistently apply and implement the recast Directive 2006/54/EC and to encourage the social partners (unions and employers) and NGOs to play a more active role in promoting equal treatment, also using action plans to address any wage inequality based on gender, with specific actions and track the results at enterprise, national and EU.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. While the text is clearly oriented (ensuring equal pay for equal work, avoiding undignified pensions, etc.), it is undermined by LGBT and ethnic minority communitarian demands and proposals for measures incompatible with freedom of enterprise, a breeding ground for employment.  Moreover, France is one of the few countries that has applied the original directive. It should therefore not be exploited by other countries to add constraints that are neither useful nor within the union's purview, such as the social policy of entrepreneurs.  I voted against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This is a very important legislation, and there are many important Community measures in the field of equal opportunities and equal treatment between men and women. We need to examine the results of the application every year. I have proposed that the report be adopted by my vote.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because, despite the benefits of equality between men and women, studies show that EU legislation in this area is still not effectively implemented in the Member States. Gender discrimination and non-compliance with equal opportunities and treatment between women and men in employment are a scourge comprising a very significant cost to individuals, all European societies and their economies. In general terms, Member States have not taken the opportunity of Directive 2006/54/EC to review their national systems in depth or simplify and modernise their equal treatment legislation. This report calls on the Commission to draw up a new legislative proposal to replace the existing Directive and introduce binding measures on the issue of equal treatment and occupation. In doing so, we hope to be able to reduce the current 16% men-women pay gap and the 39% pension gap, which to date place women in a situation that poses an increased risk of poverty in the face of men.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this non-legislative resolution, in which we urge the Commission to table new legislation providing for more effective means of supervising the implementation and enforcement of gender pay provisions in Member States. It is of the utmost importance to close the pay gap in employment between men and women. I am personally glad that Slovenia is, in this case, an example of good practice on the matter, and we need to ensure that such legislation is applied in all Member States. This is why I supported the proposed mandatory pay audits for large stock-exchange-listed companies and possible sanctions at EU level in cases of non-compliance.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that equal treatment between women and men in employment is a fundamental principle which must be respected and promoted. Unfortunately, large differences still persist and a review is needed to improve and modernise the Equal Employment Directive.  It is unacceptable that there is still a gender pay gap of more than 16% in Europe today, so it is urgent to promote non-sexist systems for job assessment and classification, which ensure wage transparency and combat gender biases that make the pay gap systematized. It is essential that mandatory wage audits are proposed for companies listed on a stock exchange in the Member States (excluding SMEs).  It should also be mandatory for companies to develop and implement annual strategic plans on gender equality and also to facilitate the reconciliation of the working lives of women and men with family life, which remains very difficult. Finally, it is unacceptable that the proportion of women in senior management positions in enterprises is less than 18%.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is indefensible that in our country, in this day and age, on average, women earn just 81p an hour for every pound a man earns. Forty-five years after the Equal Pay Act, this is completely unacceptable. We need to turn gender equality in law into gender equality in practice. Based on the current rate of progress, the gender pay gap will not be closed until 2084. Along with my Labour colleagues, I have long supported rules to require companies to publish their gender pay gaps. However, transparency alone is not enough: this data must be used to make equal pay a reality across Europe. That is why I voted in favour of the report and the amendments that back this requirement. It is time to stop hoping that things will change, and to take proactive steps to ensure that women achieve pay equality, not in some distant future but in the here and now.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report. In 2015, it should no longer be possible for men and women of all ages to receive unequal opportunities, reward or treatment because of their gender and even because of their orientation. The report shows that many things have happened for the better, but that we still have a long way to go before we can speak of equal treatment and equal opportunities in their working lives.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Inequality between women and men in the labour market remains a sad reality. This is despite an important legislative arsenal, the principle of equal pay being enshrined in the treaties since the beginning of European integration and in particular transcribed into European law by the 2006 Directive on Equal Opportunity and Equal Treatment. Revising this directive is therefore a necessity, in particular, to create truly binding tools capable of combating discrimination. The report proposes a series of measures on pay transparency and the fight against discrimination in pension schemes. I welcome the presence of provisions to combat gender stereotypes, of which the deconstruction of these stereotypes from an early age is a necessity, despite opposition from the right and the extreme right. Worse still, I have seen that the extreme right, especially the FN, has almost systematically rejected measures promoting gender equality, including in the name of rejecting any binding European mechanism. However, there is an urgent need to implement binding measures to combat such discrimination. That is why I voted for it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Equal treatment and the principle of non-discrimination are an important part of primary EU legislation. However, over the past decade, the gender pay gap has almost widened from 17.5% in 2008 to 16.4% in 2012. In this way, the current Directive 2006/54/EC (recast) has reached its limits and needs to be updated. It is intended, among many things, the introduction of mandatory audits of the salaries of listed companies in the Member States, with the exception of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and the possibility of imposing sanctions in the event of non-compliance, or the need for country-specific recommendations within the Framework of the European Semester to include targets to reduce the gender pay gap, discrimination and the risk of poverty of older women and to apply the principles of equal treatment. They're positive ideas. However, this issue cannot be disconnected from a broader framework which has to do with the fight against exploitation and the general setback of all workers and, with particular acuity, women.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I reject this report on the grounds that national legislators are to be required to make a large number of LGBTI demands. In my opinion, the title of the report does not reflect its content.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Traditional gender roles (husband/father, woman/mother) prevent self-realisation in the labour market, which is why the EU should use taxpayers' money from mothers and fathers to counteract the cementation of gender stereotypes. As if human self-realization were exclusively on the labour market. Anti-discrimination measures and the ideological management of values and norms are directed against human nature. It is striking that clear harmonised definitions of gender issues are only now being called for. If gender terminology is only now to be clearly defined and harmonised, then it means, conversely, that gender experts have been experimenting with the concept of gender since 1995 without any clear definitions. Their new major theme, by the way, is gender reassignment as the consummate denial of human nature, especially in the employment office. The EUROPEAN Parliament reminds Member States that their national legislation must include a clear ban on any discrimination based on sexual orientation, gender identity or gender reassignment, and that these privileges should be extended equally to all transgender persons. In the meantime, the European Social Fund will actively combat discrimination against transgender people. Quite honestly, I reject that. Member States must comply with the labour market rules that their national parliaments have given themselves. But this resolution is not necessary for that.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the UK, on average, women earn just 81p an hour for every pound a man earns. Forty-five years after the Equal Pay Act, this is completely unacceptable. We need to turn gender equality in law into gender equality in practice. Based on the current rate of progress, the gender pay gap will not be closed until 2084. Along with my Labour colleagues, I have long supported rules to require companies to publish their gender pay gaps. However, transparency alone is not enough: this data must be used to make equal pay a reality across Europe.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported this report, after all, the European Parliament has in the past taken a position on initiatives and the promotion of concrete resolutions. This initiative modernises the EU acquis on equality in the workplace by condensing the previous directives in order to strengthen their more efficient implementation.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained in this case. Not because I do not support equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in the field of employment. In my opinion, equality and non-discrimination is an important part of the values to which the European Union subscribes. I consider it very important, in particular, to bridge the gap between men's and women's pay and the subsequent pension gap, which takes only a minimal account of the time a woman has devoted to caring for a family, caring for members of the household or, in many cases, sacrifiable care for a disabled child. On the other hand, however, a number of topics were included in the report in the committee, which I do not support, namely the statements concerning binding employment quotas as the most effective means of achieving equality, as well as many, in my opinion, with little effective and, in particular, employers burdensome obligations such as gender plans, compulsory audits, as well as gender-split reports on remuneration. By evaluating all these topics, I have come to the report's decision not to give my vote, but out of respect for the positive provisions and the overall idea of the report not to give a negative vote, and I therefore abstained in the final vote.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Discrimination, as a social and economic phenomenon, is, of course, an evil that must not be tolerated. Knowingly excluding a group from access to the labour market on the basis of gender, political beliefs, religion or ethnicity is contrary to the rules of democracy. Equality, however, is not a concept that can be seen in abstract terms and in isolation from social reality. In every area of life, it cannot be required that there be a mathematically equal representation of men and women, so that the filling of each position is determined primarily by the mathematics and gender parity, not by the competence and experience of the candidate. It is also ludicrous and difficult to accept to support and encourage Member States to include transgender and intersex people in diversity training, as well as the need for gender-related issues in vocational training to be taken into account in this report.  Once again, we have an example of using the lofty idea of women's empowerment in the labour market, promoting extreme left-wing ideology and justifying social experimentation. The call to the European Commission to hold accountable Member States that have failed to provide clear protection against gender reassignment discrimination must also be regarded as outrageous. I am surprised that some of my Polish colleagues supported such a call.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report has very positive aspects, including the defence of the role played by trade unions in promoting equal treatment and the concept of equal pay in employment; the need for professional assessment and classification systems to be based, preferably, on collective bargaining; the assumption that MSs should guarantee maternity-related rights, including preventing the abusive dismissal of workers during pregnancy or when returning to work after maternity leave; the finding that data protection cannot be relied on as an excuse for the non-publication of annual information on wages in the workplace. The report also advocates the need to strengthen public labour inspection mechanisms and that Member States take necessary measures to ensure that the burden of proof is reversal, ensuring that it is always up to the employer to prove that the differences in treatment found are not the result of any discrimination factor. Move these positions from theory to practice, and we'd be on the right track.

name: Preşedinte. –
text: The period devoted to explanations of votes has ended.
